## Page 5

ABSTRACT The archaeological investigations undertaken at two of the prehistoric archaeological sites within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir (Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch) are discussed in this volume. These two sites have been included in a single volume because they both possess large features (ca. 16 m in diameter and more than 2 m deep) that are similar in form and content to the Wylie focus pits found along the East Fork of the Trinity River near Dallas. The features along the East Fork have been the subject of numerous speculations, but only limited investigations. A major goal of the Richland Creek Archaeological Project was to examine further the hypothesized functions of such features by careful investigation of the features at Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch. The field work was conducted between June 1982 and-~December 1984, by the Archaeology Research Program, Southern Methodist University. The reservoir, located in Navarro and Freestone Counties, is 100 km south of Dallas. It is under construction by the Tarrant County Water Control and Improvement District Number One, Fort Worth, Texas, and will inundate 44,750 acres along Richland and Chambers Creeks. The Bird Point Island site contained significant archaeological deposits relating to hab- itation, with four major periods of site use observed. First, sporadic use of the site occurred during the Late Archaic period (170 B.C. - A.D. 130). The large feature was excavated and used for roasting food and for human burial during this time. The next major use of the site occurred during the Richland Creek phase (A.D. 580 - 860). Primary evidence for this period occurs inside the large feature, which was used for cremation burials and for trash deposition. The following Round Prairie phase occupation (A.D. 1000-1200) consisted of a sedentary hamlet of three houses. Significant economic data were recovered from this occupation which indicated that the inhabitants existed solely on a diet of wild plants and animals, with primary reliance on hickory nuts, acorns, Psoralea tubers, and deer. The final occupation of the site occurred during the St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300 - 1650). Several periods of short-term site habitation took place during this time, and a shift to a more mobile settlement pattern characterized by seasonal use of the sites seems to have occurred. The economic pattern of the Round Prairie phase continued, except that some maize was introduced into the diet. The very small quantity of maize suggests that it was a minor supplement to the diet. No house patterns were identified at Adams Ranch; the most significant data were recovered from within the large feature. Radiocarbon dates indicate that the feature was first excavated around A.D. 200, during the Late Archaic period. Shell tempered sherds were discovered in the bottom layer of feature fill (dating between A.D. 200 and 700); however, none were found at Bird Point Island. This suggests that the pit at Adams Ranch was excavated at a later point in time, after the introduction of ceramics. The most intensive occupation of the site occurred during the early Round Prairie phase (A.D. 800 - A.D. 1000). Most of the features and artifacts recovered from the large depression date to this period. Grog/grit/bone tempered ceramics replaced shell tempered ware during this period, and arrow points were used along with dart points. The distribution of these artifacts across the site indicates that most other features at Adams Ranch also date to the early Round Prairie phase. Only limited occupation occurred after A.D. 1000 during the St. Elmo phase. Economic data indicate that a hunting/gathering lifestyle based on a diet of deer, acorns, nuts, and Psoralea tubers persisted throughout all periods of occupation, Unlike Bird Point Island, no evidence of maize was recovered at Adams Ranch. The final part of this volume discusses the Wylie focus concept. This construct was originally defined in 1952 to classify several sites with large, man-made depressions observed along the East Fork of the Trinity River. It was characterized by a trait list which included the presence of large pits, ceramics, and flexed burials without grave goods. The data obtained from the similar features at the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites have added Significant information on the function of such large depressions. The features are now believed to date to the Late Archaic period, when they functioned as roasting pits for interband feasting and as cemeteries, which may have also served as territorial markers. The new assignment of these large features to the Late Archaic period casts doubt on the usefulness of the Wylie focus as it was originally defined, and calls into question its validity as a meaningful archaeological construct.

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The successful completion of any complex project is dependent upon the dedication and assistance of many persons, In this respect, the Richland Creek Archavological Project (RCAP) is no different. In fact, the highly interdisciplinary and multi-seasonal nature of the Project has involved a myriad of field personnel, analyists, writers, consultants, and support staff. We owe a large debt of gratitude to all these individuals, and in this section we recognize their contributions. First, and foremost, we thank Mr. Woody Frossard of the Tarrant County Water Control and Improvement District Number One (hereafter referred to as the Water District). Mr. Frossard was the representative from the Water District who was assigned the responsibility of selecting an archaeological contractor and insuring that the work was completed in a manner consistent with the Water District's needs for completion of the Richland/ Chambers Dam and Reservoir. Mr. Frossard performed these duties admirably, providing direction, encouragement, and constructive criticism in all phases of the archaeological work. Without Mr. Frossard’s support, the Richland Creek Archaeolog- ical Project would not have achieved the success it has. Second, special thanks go to the members of the Memorandum of Agreement Committee, a project review council established by an agreement between the Water District, che U. S. Army Corps of Engineers (USCE), the Texas Historical Commission (THC), and the National Park Service (NPS). The members of this committee, aside from Mr. Frossard, consisted of one person from each of the agencies involved: Ms. Daphne Derven (USCE), Dr. LaVerne Herrington (THC), and Dr. Stephanie Rodeffer (NPS), who was later followed by Dr. Ann Johnson. The MOA Committee members provided valuable comments and support while attending field meetings during some of the coldest and hottest temperature extremes experienced in this part of the State. The ultimate success of this Project is due in large measure to their collective effort. We also wish to thank Mr. Robert Burton, archaeologist with the USCE, for his assistance in developing the Memorandum of Agreement that made the mitigation phase of the RCAP a reality. Mr. Burton was particularly instrumental in negotiating the mag- nitude of mitigation activities within the reservoir. A great deal of appreciation goes to the field and laboratory crews who worked during the four seasons of the RCAP. Despite the physical discomfort imposed by summer's heat and winter's chill, the field crews worked steadily and often put in long hours to make sure the job was completed properly. Likewise, laboratory workers put in long, tedious hours washing, identifying, and cataloging artifacts from both prehistoric and historic sites. Crew chiefs of prehistoric crews included: Jeffery Bohlin, Marilee Irvine, Thomas Guderjan, Daniel McGregor, Allan McIntyre, Donald Manchester, and William Martin. In addition Debra Desarmeaux and Esther Read served as assistant crew chiefs. Crew chiefs of historic crews included: David Jurney, Susan Lebo, Debbie Marcaurelle, and Abigayle Robbins. During Season I, Marilee Irvine served as lab director. Susan Lebo directed the lab during Season II through IV, with the assistance of Debbie Marcaurelle during Season HI, Dana Curtin during Seasons III and IV, and Melissa Green during Season IV. Many thanks are extended to these supervisory personne! who put in many hours of their own time to complete maps, forms, and computer processing so that the project could run smoothly. ## Page 23

INTRODUCTION TO VOLUME II by James E. Bruseth and William A. Martin The Richland Creek archaeological Project began in 1980 as a five-year, interdisciplinary program to investigate the cultural re- sources to be impacted by construction of the Richland/Chambers Dam and Reservoir (Figure I-1). The reservoir is located in Freestone and Navarro Counties, Texas. Construction of the dam and reservoir was started in 1982 and was completed in 1986, The archaeological work carried out in the reservoir consisted of three major phases. The first phase, begun in September 1980, involved the survey of the 44,750 acres to be inundated by the reservoir which resulted in the identification of 911 archaeological properties (Archaeology Research Program 1980, 1981). The second phase consisted of site testing and determining the eligibility of sites for nomination to the National Register of Historic Places (Raab et al. 1981). Testing procedures involved an interdisciplinary program of archaeological excavations, geolog- ical and geomorphological field work, architectural studies, informant interviews, and archival research. The results identified 106 archaeological sites and historic structures containing important information, which were considered eligible for nomination to the National Register (Archaeology Research Program 1981, 1982). The first and second phases were completed by August 1981. Data from the testing program were used to formulate a plan for the third phase: mitigation of the loss of significant archaeological properties in the reservoir. Any of the 106 significant archaeological properties identified during testing which were located below an elevation of 325 ft msl, under the dam, or inside of highway relocation corridors were recom- mended for intensive study. A program of archaeological mitigation was begun in June 1982, and carried out in four field seasons, each about three months in duration, with the last field season being finished in December 1984, The intensive data collection was undertaken for 80 properties, while it was possible to avoid 26 properties by changing the design of the dam and the locations of roads. The type of work conducted for each significant property during the third phase varied from intensive excavation at all prehistoric and many historic sites to architectural documentation, dendrochronology, geomorphology, informant interviews, and archival research. The remainder of this introduction is divided into two parts. The first is a review of the Richland Creek Technical Series. The present volume is part of this series, and this discussion directs the reader to other volumes where information on the Project can be found. The second part is a brief, but essential, environmental background. The discussion of human ecology in later chapters requires a basic familiarity with the Project's natural setting. THE RICHLAND CREEK TECHNICAL SERIES This present volume is the second in the Richland Creek Technical Series, a five volume set devoted to reporting the archaeological mitigation program conducted in the Richland/ Chambers Reservoir by Southern Methodist University. The series presents all major data, interpretations, and conclusions for the research conducted at historic and prehistoric sites. More details on the contents of each volume are presented below. Volume I provides background information on the Project. The first part of this volume summarizes management issues including agency review and monitoring, in-house quality control and task management, and construction and maintenance of a computerized data base management system. The second part of Volume I presents environmental information for the Richland Creek area and reviews the results of pollen, soil, and geological studies. The data are used to model environmental change during the Holocene for the Richland Creek area. The next two volumes in the Technical Series are devoted to reporting the results of investigations at 15 prehistoric sites. Specifically, Volume IH, the present volume, reports on excavations conducted at the Bird Point Island (41FT201) and the Adams Ranch (41NV177) sites. Both sites contained large, man- made depressions known as Wylie focus pits; because of these unique features, the sites are combined into a single volume. It should be noted, however, that during investigations at these two sites, substantial deposits unrelated to the large depressions were also found. In particular, village deposits with important information pertaining to local and regional patterns of human adaptation to the environment of North Central Texas were recovered from the Bird Point Island site. Consequently, a substantial part of Volume II is devoted to reporting data on these occupations as well. Volume III is composed of two parts. The first presents basic data on the excavations conducted at 13 prehistoric sites. The presentation for each site is relatively straightforward and serves primarily as a means of communicating information to other researchers. Brief interpretations on the temporal and functional uses of each site are made. In the second part of Volume III, syntheses of the overall prehistoric research are presented. These syntheses are included in chapters on effective site investigation strategies, chronology, human ecology, and lithic technology and raw materials utilization. The final chapter of Volume III compares the prehistoric archaeology of the Richland Creek area to other sites in North Central Texas. In addition, directions for future investigation in this part of Texas are presented. The last two volumes provide information on the results of archaeological and architectural studies of historic sites in the Richland Creek Archaeological Project area. Volume IV provides information on the research design, field methods, and major data collected from 64 historical properties.Thirty-seven historical properties received archaeological studies as a primary focus. Site descriptions for each property are given in Volume IV. Volume V, the final volume in the Richland Creek Technical Series, reviews the results of specialized historic artifact analyses and synthetic studies of historic sites. The Richland Creek historic artifact classification is presented, and specific chapters are devoted to reviewing major artifact classes for sociocultural information. The remainder of the volume reviews categories of data at various synthetic levels and provides insight into the rich traditional lifeways once practiced on the farmsteads in this region. Sets of microfiche complete the Richland Creek Technical Series and contain various types of data pertinent to each volume.These sets are located in the backs of the volumes. In addition to the data provided in the microfiche and the five volumes, other information, such as original field notes, artifacts, computerized data, and site maps are curated at the Institute for the Study of Earth and Man at Southern Methodist University, Dallas, Texas. ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING The environment surrounding the Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island sites consists of the broad floodplain of Richland Creek to the south, and terrace and upland areas to the north. The terraces and uplands have been dissected by numerous tributary streams of Richland Creek, creating an undulating topography with elevation differentials between 5 and 15 m. In the remainder of this section the environment within a3 to 5 km radius of the Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island sites is described in order to provide a background against which human ecological discussions in later chapters can be evaluated. BY: rts, The the | be natal ters ek the nd/ ies the ils ct. ies rol Fa nd cal ng 2S, on he se Introduction of the biotic resources of the entire reservoir is provided in Chapter 6, Volume I, The data for this reconstruction were compiled by David Jurney, principally from records at the General Land Office (GLO) of Texas, and are based on notes made by original land patent surveyors between 1835 and 1850. Included within these notes are directions, distances, and sizes of witness trees for all major tracts of land surrounding the sites. These data, although potentially biased in several ways (cf., Wood 1976; Warren 1976), have been useful tools for the reconstruction of pre-Euro- American settlement in many parts of the midwestern United States (King 1984; Jumey 1982). In addition to the GLO witness tree data, other more general botanical summaries of Texas, such as Kiichler (1964) and Gould (1969), as well as data on soils and topography, are employed to interpolate between the known GLO data points. - The results of this effort are shown in map form in Figure I-2. This map represents our best approximation of pre-Euro- American settlement vegetation and provides a valuable ecological baseline for understanding the potentially exploitable prehistoric biomass. Three biotic communitites are shown in Figure I-2: Post Oak Savannah, Bottomland Forest, and Tall Grass Prairie. All of the communitites occur with in a 3 km radius of either site and would have been easily exploitable within convenient walking distance (i.e., less than two hours) from both sites (cf., Vita-Finzi and Higgs 1970). Since the disturbances that have occurred to these zones following historic settlement are not relevant to this discussion, we have only reconstructed each zone as it would have appeared in a natural setting at approximately A.D. 1850. POST OAK SAVANNAH Although all three biotic communities are significantly rep- resented in the vicinity of the sites, the Post Oak Savannah has the largest representation. Dominant overstory vegetation of this area would have been post oak and blackjack oak (Gould 1969), which together would have accounted for 80 to 85% of all tree species, based on GLO data (see Chapter 6, Volume I). The third most frequent tree species would have been hickory, accounting for 11 to 15%. The distribution of hickory in the GLO data with respect to topography shows that it prefers slopes and was slightly more frequent in these areas. The remaining 4 to 6% of trees would have consisted of red oak, pin oak, ash, and locust which probably would have been encountered in small drainages and along creeks cutting into the Savannah environment. Although today the dominant understory vegetation consists of shrubs and vines (U.S. Army, Corps of Engineers [USA, COE] 1982), in a prehistoric state tall grasses would have been dominant (Gould 1969:11). Climax species would have been little bluestem, Indiangrass, purple top, silver bluestem, and Texas wintergrass. The occurrence of these species indicates that the density of trees was substantially less than is seen today, and the area would have been more open and a true savannah environment. Such a shift is also supported by the fact that modern prevention of fires has caused trees to increase in number during the past decade (Halls 1971:171). In fact, some botanists prefer to classify the Post Oak Savannah as a prairie association of the grassland (Gould 1969:11). Several elements of this community would have made it particularly important to prehistoric populations. Important faunal resources indigenous to this area would have included whitetail deer, red wolf, fox squirrel, raccoon, gray fox, eastern cottontail rabbit, opossum, and several species of rodents, snakes, and birds. The dominance of oak and hickory species, accounting for nearly 95% of all trees, would have offered great potential for acorn and hickory nut collection. Both species are known to have been important foods of Native American groups throughout the Eastern Woodlands during the historic contact period (Swanton 1946:364-367). In addition, the high frequency of nut producing trees would have created a favorable environment for deer, and hunting of this mammal would no doubt have been a major FEU IOR PA FOL Tall Grass Prairie Post Oak Savannah {J Bottomland Forest oe were kilometere Figure 1-2. Major biotic zones in close proximity to the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites. exploitation strategy. An important plant food available in this habitat, but not found commonly in the others (Correll and Johnston 1970:813-817), would have been the prairie turnip (Psoralea sp.). The remains of the tuber from this plant are common at many of the reservoir sites, and its common occurrence underscores its importance in the prehistoric diet. A similar heavy usage of this plant is documented from further to the north in the Great Plains by historic Native American groups (Wedel 1978). BOTTOMLAND FOREST The second major biotic community within close proximity of the sites was the Bottomland Forest. As with the Post Oak Savannah, the dominant overstory species of this zone would have been post oak. The second most frequent species in the Post Oak Savannah, blackjack oak, would have dropped in frequency within the Bottomiand Forest to fifth, again based on GLO records. The species that would have replaced it in occurrence are ash, hackberry, and elm. Less common species would have included hickory, red oak, locust, and bur oak. In the swamps and wetter parts of the floodplain, green ash, sugarberry, hackberry, and cedar elm would have been dominant, with willow and cottonwood also occurring. Understory vegetation probably would have consisted of shrubs (e.g., coral berry, hawthorn, elderberry, privet, and American beautyberry), vines (e.g., Smilax, Virginia creeper, poison ivy, and grape), grasses, and sedges. The difference in the vegetational compostion between the Bottomland Forest and the Post Oak Savannah is due in large part to a single factor. The bottomlands tend to collect runoff from rainfall that falls in surrounding uplands and thus provide a better-watered environment for plant growth. The Bottomland Forest would have offered several species of potentially high economic value to prehistoric people. The oak species would have comprised a third of all trees, and acorns would have been an importnat autumn food source. The dense

## Page 26

shrubby understory would also have permitted the exploitation of several types of wild berries, grapes, and fruits, Potentially important mammal species of this area would have been whitetail deer, fox squirrel, raccoon, gray fox, bobcat, swamp rabbit, eastern cottontail, opossum, several species of fish and amphibians from creeks and other water sources, and a variety of birds. The total faunal biomass would have been the greatest of any of the habitats, with more variety and a greater frequency of most species available. Two obvious exceptions to this would have been deer and bison, both of which would have been greater in frequency in the Post Oak Savannah and the Tall Grass Prairie, respectively. The high overall exploitable biomass would have made this zone a focus of many procurement activities throughout the prehistoric period. . TALL GRASS PRAIRIE Based on GLO records, the Tall Grass Prairie zone would have been located within 2 to 4 km of the Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island sites. These records also indicate that post oaks and blackjack oaks were present among the grasses, although these trees were widely spaced at 80 m or more apart. This occurrence of oak species in some parts of the prairies is common where soils are medium to light in texture (Gould 1969). The dominant climax species would have been little bluestem, followed by big bluestem, Indiangrass, switch grass, side oats grama, and hairy grama. Faunal species of importance to prehistoric man would have been bison, eastern cottontail rabbit, jackrabbit, rodents, and birds. Volume H, Part One Shafer, Dering, and Baxter (1975) have defined the Tall Grass Prairie as a marginally specialized ecosystem. Geertz (1964) defines a specialized ecosystem as one in which a low species diversity index exists, although each species is represented by a large number of individuals. The modifier “marginally” is used to indicate that the specialized nature of the prairie is buffered by the drainage habitats which support linear bands of the Bottomland Forest. If we accept this statement as a reasonable categorization, the above data would suggest that the Bottomlan Forest and Post Oak Savannah habitats can be categorized as less specialized, or generalized ecosystems. Based on presently available archae- ological data from North Central Texas (Murry 1982), it would appear that the subsistence economy of prehistoric people certainly was oriented away from the prairie and toward the bottomland habitats. For example, although the Tall Grass Prairie contains many species of grasses and forbs, there is little evidence of these having been exploited prehistorically (Skinner et al. 1978:151). Thus, from an economic standpoint, only a few animal species from the Tall Grass Prairie could have been of any great importance. A legitimate counter to this argument might be that the sheer quantity of bison, both in terms of individual size and herd numbers, would have offset the low species diversity of the prairie. However, the actual frequency of bison in this habitat is not clear, and in fact, archaeological evidence indicates that they have been infrequently exploited throughout much of the prehistoric period and may have been absent altogether at certain times (Lynott 1979; Dillehay 1974). In support of this latter view is the rarity of bison remains form prehistoric sites in the Richland/Chambers Dam and Reservoir area (see Chapter 9). a Be

## Page 29

THE BIRD POINT ISLAND SITE. by James E. Bruseth and William A. Martin * The Bird Point Island site (41FT201) has received more atten- tion in terms of excavation time, artifact analysis and other specialized analyses, and remote sensing detection of features than any other site in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. The reason for this greater effort is due in part to the work of Mr. Bill Young, avocational archaeologist from Corsicana, who initially discovered the site. Young collected artifacts from the site for more than a decade prior to Southern Methodist University’s work, and amassed a sufficient artifact collection to understand that the site was important with respect to the local archaeology. More ceramic artifacts, which are generally rare from the reservoir area, had come from this site than from any other along Richland Creek, In addition, the overall density of artifacts showed that substantial cultural occupation had taken place at the site at several different times during the prehistoric period. Aside from the artifacts, Young had identified important cul- tural features at the site. The most important of these was a large surface depression, approximately 10 m in diameter and 1 m deep, located on the western slope of the site. The shape and size of the pit were reminiscent of the Wylie focus pits located along the East Fork of the Trinity River, about 100 km to the north (Stephenson 1949a, 1952b). This similarity to the Wylie focus pits underscored the importance of this feature at the Bird Point Island site. Despite considerable attention by archaeologists since the late 1940s, the function of the pits along the East Fork is not clearly understood. The most thorough investigation of a Wylie focus pit was conducted by Lynott (1975) at the Sister Grove Creek site, but even this left several hypothesized pit functions in need of further testing. Unfor- tunately, construction of Lake Ray Hubbard and Lake Lavon has in- undated most of the remaining known Wylie focus pit sites, so further testing of Lynott’s hypothesis is not possible along the East Fork. Consequently, the occurrence of the pit at Bird Point Island was thought to offer another chance to advance our knowledge about these features. At a minimum we had an opportunity to test Lynott’s hypotheses, and with luck, we would finally understand why these pits were built and how they functioned within the prehistoric community that constructed them. Of course, a critical assumption in this reasoning is that the pit at Bird Point Island was culturally similar to the Wylie focus pits located further to the north. Although the surface depression of the pit and Young’s artifact collection both suggested this, there was no guarantee that this would be verified as excavation proceeded. Indeed, our work showed that the pits are culturally similar, both in terms of physical structure and content, and the work at the Bird Point Island site has shed light on the function of these pit features of North Central Texas. HISTORY OF INVESTIGATIONS AND RESEARCH ORIENTATION In this section we outline the history of the investigations at the Bird Point Island site since its initial discovery. This is also a convenient place to present the development and evolution of our research orientation at the site. As in any project, research goals and objectives change with time and this certainly has been the case at Bird Point Island. Moreover, understanding how our research orientation has evolved is crucial for understanding the shifts in field strategies. Based on land surveyor notes and records on file at the General Land Office in Austin, the Bird Point Island site was forested during much of its post-occupational history. The first change in site vegetation is evident in photographs taken during the 1940s. These show the site to be covered in brush and small trees, and suggest that shortly before the photographs were taken it had been cleared and farmed or used as a pasture. The few historic artifacts found during field investigations support this limited Euro-American use of the site. Discovery of the archaeological significance of the site oc- curred in the early 1970s when the area was cleared of all vegetation by a bulldozer. The site was subsequently planted

## Page 30

with grass and used as pasture. Mr. Bill Young was the first person to locate the site and made several surface collections. It was at this time that the site was given its name by Young based on the large number of arrow, or “‘bird,” points that he found at the site, and its resemblance to an island during annual spring floods. Also at this time, Young discovered the large surface depression. Shortly afterwards, Southern Methodist University personnel visited the site and recorded it as part of the Tennessee Colony Lake Project then being conducted along the Trinity River (Richner and Bagot 1978). At that time, the potential significance of the site was noted and further investigations were recommended. In the summer of 1980 the Richland Creek Archaeological Project began, the first phase of which was a survey with limited testing for significance of cultural resources within the Rich- land/Chambers Reservoir. During the survey, the Bird Point Island site was reexamined to provide updated information and to insure that data would be collected that were comparable to data from other sites located in the survey. In early 1981 the site was tested. This work involved the excavation of several backhoe trenches, two 1X1 m test units, and several shovel tests, with the purpose of: (1) determining whether or not the large surface depression was indeed a Wylie focus pit, (2) delineating both the vertical and horizontal extent of the cultural deposits, and (3) obtaining samples of artifacts from both within and around the pit. This work successfully demonstrated a similarity between the pit at Bird Point Island and the features along the East Fork and also showed that the site, as suggested by Young, contained extensive cultural deposits surrounding the pit. Based on this work, the site was scheduled for more in-depth investigation during mitigation. On the basis of the information obtained from testing, two hypotheses were developed to guide future excavation. The first stated that: “The Wylie focus pit . .. represents adevelopment from a local Archaic stage cultural base” (Raab and Moir 198 1:203). This hypothesis was based on radiocarbon dates from a similar pit at the Adams Ranch site which suggested a Late Archaic origin for the deeper layers. The second hypothesis was: ‘“The nature of the Wylie focus pit utilization changed through time’’ (Raab and Moir 1981:204). This was based on testing data indicating that burials were placed in the lower levels of the pit, and that trash was dumped in the upper levels at a later date. The implication of these two hypotheses is that the pit functioned initially as an Archaic cemetery and that during the Late Prehistoric period, the pit ceased to be a cemetery and instead was used as a trash dump. In 1982, Southern Methodist University began archaeological mitigation on the historic and prehistoric properties within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir. Since the testing information had corroborated initial impressions about the significance of the site, a multi-seasonal investigation plan was developed for mitigation. The first phase was to involve the excavation of one-fourth of the pit for the purpose of testing the two hypotheses outlined above. An additional one-quarter of the pit was to be excavated during the following field season, and a third season was scheduled for the purpose of investigating the surrounding deposits. Implicit in this plan was the assumption that the pit was the most important feature at the site and, as such, should receive the majority of any field effort. This assumption was supported by testing data from outside of the pit which, although showing that substantial deposits existed, indicated that these materials were not significantly better preserved than those represented at other sites within the reservoir. As can be seen in the remainder of this volume, this impression of the site was grossly inaccurate. In fact, the deposits around the pit were found to be better, in terms of both the variety of features present and the high degree of spatial integrity, than those at most other sites in the Volume II, Part One reservoir. Interestingly enough, this had been suggested by Young prior to beginning our investigations at the site. The goal of excavating a quarter of the pit was achieved during Season I which took place in the summer of 1982. At that time, a sample of artifacts adequate for initial feature interpretation was obtained, a profile of the pit was drawn, and bone and charcoal samples were recovered from which radiocarbon dates were calcu- lated. Most importantly, artifact frequencies could be related to dated stratigraphy, so we were able to test directly the hypotheses concerning pit function proposed by Raab and Moir (1981). The results demonstrated, as these hypotheses had proposed, that the pit was constructed during the Archaic period (AD. 1 to 600) and its function changed over time from a cemetery to a trash dump. However, our understanding of why the pit was excavated in the first place and how it functioned within the prehistoric cultural system that created it was still incomplete. Therefore, we modified the following season’s field plans to involve excavation outside of the pit and changed the emphasis of field work to investigate deposits relating to habitation. We hoped that learning what went on outside of the pit would teil us more about the pit itselfthan would continued excavation within it. Season II began in February 1983 and continued through May 1983. Evidence of at least two, and possibly three, periods of major occupation, and numerous periods of minor occupation, was un- covered at the site. So massive was the recovered data base and so extensive the potential remaining data that an entire additional field season was planned around the pit. This was carried out during Season III, from October 1983 through January 1984. At this same time additional limited work was conducted inside the pit to increase the length of the profile and to supplement the artifact sample. A final week of field work was conducted at the site during Season IV, in December 1984. The purpose of this final work was to cross- section several house post holes and finish up other work that could not be completed during previous field seasons. A particularly important discovery during the field investigations at Bird Point Island was that major periods of occupation appeared to have some degree of spatial separation. This implied that detailed intrasite studies could recover information on internal community patterning. A long-standing assertiqn by some researchers in Texas has been that detailed intrasite studies are needed at sites before we can make further improvements in our understanding of prehistoric cultural dynamics (D. Story, personal communication 1981). In the past, the mitigation phase at too many sites has consisted of small excavation units scattered across the site with the goal of recovering chronological data, often at the expense of understanding large-scale intrasite patterning. Large-scale excavations are required to expose enough site area to draw conclusions about spatial patterning. Since the Bird Point Island site contained extensive habitation deposits amenable to detailed intrasite analysis, we decided to conduct extensive excavations over the course of four seasons of field work. In conjunction with this emphasis on the recovery of large-scale intrasite data, a commitment was made to test a variety of techniques and sampling strategies to maximize the efficiency of data recovery. The large size of the site (4 ha) precluded the use of traditional block excavations for collecting the spatial data; at best, only a small portion of the site could be investigated in this manner. If we were to truly learn about intrasite community patterning, large-scale hori- zontal sampling was needed and a variety of techniques was used to collect this data. Consequently, the site was used as a test case for experimentation with different investigation strategies. As an added benefit to this procedure, the relative effectiveness of each approach was evaluated so that only the better techniques would be used at other sites in the reservoir. In other words, we hoped that the lessons learned at Bird Point Island could be translated into improved

SPATIAL DIVISIONS USED IN LATER CHAPTERS As outlined in Chapter 12 on site chronology, several different periods of occupation are recognized at Bird Point Island. A major focus of the artifact and feature analyses presented in this volume is on the placement of these materials into the temporal framework of Chapter 12. Ultimately these data are used to reconstruct major periods of site habitation and the cultural behavior that occurred during each period. Since most artifacts and features are not easily placed into the chronological periods, spatial analysis has been used to assist this operation. The rationale behind this procedure is that the different periods of site occupation have not occurred on exactly the same parts of the site and the spatial distinctiveness of certain components permits horizontal prove- nience to be used as a chronological tool. In the remainder of this chapter, we present the major spatial divisions used at the site. The division of the site is shown in Figure 1-1. The “North” refers to the area from the 40N line northward and corresponds to debris associated with occupation within and around three house patterns. A subset of this area is “Houses 1, 2, and 3.” All are part of a Late Prehistoric village that existed at the site. Most analyses, however, only examine House | and not the other houses. This is because block excavation uncovered artifacts from the northern 60% of this house pattern; the southern portion was uncovered by bulldozer scraping. In contrast, the other two houses were only discovered after extensive mechanical scraping, so intensive sampling for artifacts was not possible. The next two areas of the site refer to different parts of the same feature. This feature is the large midden, or organically stained zone, that occurs to the south of Feature 1. The limits and composition of this feature are discussed in Chapter 11. The midden has been divided along the 10N line to form two more or less equal halves. Other data, particularly radiocarbon dates and feature locations, suggest that the southern portion of the site may have been occupied later in time (see Chapter 4 and Chapter 12). Division of the midden into two halves along the east-west axis should provide a means to examine this chronological question further. The areas are referred to as “North Midden” and “South Midden.” In certain analyses, however, where data are limited or otherwise temporally inconclu- sive, the midden may not be divided into these two halves and instead is referred to as simply the ““Midden.” Another area of the site is the “South” area. This area corre- sponds to limited excavations that were conducted in the extreme southern portion of the site near the slough. This area was initially discovered during surface collection at the site (see Chapter 13), and later investigations found limited but nonetheless important cultural deposits in this region. ## Page 33

PEDOLOGY: IMPLICATIONS FOR ARCHAEOLOGICAL INTERPRETATION by Edward F. Janak, Jr. and William A. Martin The physical, chemical, and biological composition of the soil often varies considerably from one archaeological site to the next, and sometimes varies within the confines of a single site. Because dif- ferent soil properties effect changes in cultural materials after they have been deposited during the course of archaeological site forma- tion, an understanding of the specific soils present at any given site is critical to its interpretation. For instance, the shrink-swell capacity of a soil and the activities of burrowing animals living within it can re- sult in the displacement of artifacts, thereby complicating stratigra- phic interpretations. In addition, an understanding of soil genesis can determine whether the site surface has been aggrading, resulting in the burial of cultural horizons, or has been eroding, resulting in the mixing of archaeological deposits, or has been stable, with insignifi- cant effects on the deposits from aggradation or erosion. This chapter presents a discussion of the soil and landscape fea- tures present at Bird Point Island. A detailed soils map of the site is presented along with a description of each soil type based on the sys- tem of soil taxonomy utilized by the USDA Soil Conservation Ser- vice (United States Department of Agriculture, Soil Conservation Service [USDA, SCS] 1975). Following the soil descriptions, the relevance of the specific properties of these soils for understanding site archaeology is discussed. LANDFORM DESCRIPTION A geomorphological study conducted by Pheasant (1982) identi- fied three alluvial terraces of presumed Pleistocene origin and a floodplain of Holocene alluvium within the Richland Creek Reser- voir area. Pheasant examined soil profiles at Bird Point Island and identified traits characteristic of the eroded T-1 terraces found in the eastern end of the Project area. The texture of the Pleistocene allu- vium ranged from fine sand to sandy clay loam, and A, B, andC hori- zons were observed (Pheasant 1982:227). The landform has the convex slopes associated with the T-1 terraces (USGS topographic Il map, Roustabout Camp Quadrangle), but soils of the Wilcox forma- tion of the Tertiary system are also preserit. The entire landform is mapped as part of the Wilcox formation on the geological map (Uni- versity of Texas, Bureau of Economic Geology 1970) because the area of terrace sediments (less than 4 ha) is too small to be de- lineated on a map with a scale of 1:250,000. Soils of the Wilcox formation form a narrow strip along the peri- phery of the landform adjacent to the floodplain. Pleistocene terrace soils cover the Wilcox formation along the higher elevations of the knoll where the majority of the archaeological deposit is found. The Pleistocene terrace materials are devoid of gravel or any other lithic material. The Wilcox formation, on the other hand, con- tains a lithic member in the form of iron-enriched siltstone and sand- stone. At Bird Point Island, outcrops of ironstone are eroding out of the Wilcox formation in the slough at the south end of the site. When heated this resource was widely used for cooking and roasting, so the presence of these outcrops may have had a significant influence on the selection of the site for habitation by prehistoric populations. SOIL TAXONOMY A brief discussion of the taxonomic system used by the USDA Soil Conservation Service is presented here to familiarize the reader with nomenclature referred to in the following sections. The system classifies soils according to physical properties which can be quanti- tatively measured (Brady 1974:318). Soils are arranged in a hier- archy of classes which are based on the relationships observed among soils. Six levels of increasing specificity are used in the hier- archy: order, suborder, great group, subgroup, family, and series. Orders are based primarily on morphology, grouping soils with similar sequences of horizons and similar soil genesis into a single category. Suborders emphasize genetic homogeneity and utilize fac- tors such as climate, environment, and vegetation to differentiate soils. The presence or absence of diagnostic horizons are used to

## Page 34

12 assign soils to great groups. Subgroups define the central concept of great groups and gradations away from that central concept. Fam- ilies are grouped according to textures, mineral content, and tem- perature. Finally, soils with uniform characteristics and arrange- ment of horizons are assigned to the same series (Brady 1974:321). Soil profiles are described as a sequence of horizons, which are layers of soils approximately parallel to the soil surface that have been produced by soil forming processes and have different proper- ties from layers immediately above and beneath (USDA, scs 1975:14). Most soils are comprised of three general horizons, the A, B, and C horizons. The A horizon is the surface layer which is usually darkened by the accumulation of organic matter. For the purposes of this report, the A horizon also includes the eluvial (E) horizon which is the zone of maximum leaching from which clays and certain chemical compounds have been removed. The A horizon is also the zone of maximum biological activity in which the action of roots, rodents and microorganisms have resulted in soil mixing, often referred to as bioturbation (USDA, SCS 1975:14). The B horizon lies immediately beneath the A horizon and is called the illuvial horizon. It is the zone of maximum accumulation of materials such as iron aluminum oxides, and silicate clays. The C horizon lies beneath the B horizon and is the zone of unconsolidated sands, silts, and clays which have had the least exposure to climatic and biological agents. Intact horizontal bedding planes are often visible in the C horizon (USDA, SCS 1975:16). Specific diagnostic horizons which comprise parts of the BandC horizons are used to sort soils into different categories. Among the soils recognized at Bird Point Island, the argillic horizon and the calcic horizon are important for classification. An argillic horizon is an illuvial zone in which silicate clays have accumulated. A calcic horizon is a layer of accumulation of calcium and magnesium car- bonates which is usually below or within the argillic horizon. At Bird Point Island, the terms B horizon and argillic horizon may be used interchangeably because the argillic horizon is the only diagnostic zone within the B horizon. The calcic horizon occurs further down in the profile at variable depths within the C horizon. SOIL DESCRIPTION Examination of the natural soil profile was conducted using north- south and east-west line transects across the knoll on which the site is located. The line transect is a systematic sampling technique com- monly used by pedologists in which auger holes are dug at regular intervals so that observations can be made about soil composition. Readings were taken at 20 m intervals on the north-south transect along the 20E line and at 11 m intervals on the east-west transect along the 60N line. A series of random readings was taken along the perimeter of the knoll to supply additional data for the generation of the soils map (Figure 2-1). A soil cross section generated from data collected along the east-west transect is illustrated in Figure 2-2. Six different soil classifications at the subgroup level were recog- nized based on the observations made at the site. These include Aquic Paleustalfs and Udic Paleustalfs associated with the Wilcox formation, and Typic Haplustalfs, Udic Haplustalfs,Ultic Haplust- alfs, and a small area of Typic Ustochrepts associated with the Pleistocene terrace deposits. The two great groups, Paleustalfs and Haplustalfs, are both characterized as freely drained soils with high base saturation and are different primarily in genesis. Paleustalfs were formed prior to the Pleistocene, and Haplustalfs and Ustochrepts were formed during the late Pleistocene. The term Typic defines the central concept of the great group, whereas the sub- group terms Aquic, Udic, and Ultic refer to variations of soil proper- ties associated with different moisture regimes. Paleustalfs are characterized by a loamy epipedon, an argillic hor- izon, and a calcic horizon below or within the argillic horizon. Aquic Volume II, Part One MN a 10° 20 «30 meters + 140 N 100 E Ulfic Héplustatts \ A Us Figure 2-1. Distribution of soils across the terrace at Bird Point Island. Paleustalfs are subject to water saturation during part of the year and exhibit mottling with a chroma of 2 or less in the B horizon. Udic ‘Paleustalfs have a humid moisture regime and either lack a calcic horizon or have this horizon at a greater depth than Typic Paleustalfs (USDA, SCS 1975:45). . Haplustalfs have a sandy or loamy epipedon, an argillic horizon with a gradual or clear, but not abrupt, upper boundary, and a calcic horizon at variable depths. The subgroups, Typic, Udic, and Ultic, differ mainly in the degree of leaching of bases that has occurred. Typic Haplustalfs have a calcic horizon at a moderate depth and are moist for an appreciable part of the growing season. Udic Haplust- alfs exhibit an intermediate degree of leaching of carbonates and have a calcic horizon between 1.5 and 2 m below the surface. Ultic Haplustalfs have been completely leached of carbonates which re- sults in an acid reaction and a decreased base saturation in the B hor- izon (USDA, SCS 1975:141). It is interesting to note that nearly 80% of the cultural features and artifact concentrations recorded at the site lie within the boundaries of Udic and Ultic Haplustalfs. This may reflect a preference for topography rather than soils, since these soils occur on the highest and best drained portion of the knoll.

Typic Ustochrepts are characterized by a shallow calcic horizon and an organic carbon content that decreases regularly with depth (USDA, SCS 1975:255). The texture of the entire profile is clay loam. The Ustochrepts were formed on the portion of the terrace that was subjected to the greatest erosion. More recent terrace deposits were washed away, exposing the underlying sediments in which the Ustochrepts were formed. This erosion also removed some A hor- izon material from the adjacent Typic Haplustalfs, creating an A horizon only 10-15 cm thick. With the exception of the Ustochrepts and a small eroded portion of the Typic Haplustalfs, all of the soils formed in terrace sediments generally can be described as having a brownish, fine sandy loam A horizon, 20 to 40 cm thick, which is underlain by a yellowish brown to reddish brown argillic horizon. Maximum clay accumulation occurs in the upper 15 to 20 cm of the B horizon, and clay content gradually decreases downward into unaltered, stratified, sandy terrace materials at depths ranging from 1.2 to 1.5 m below surface. The Wilcox soils exhibit a thinner A horizon (10-20 cm) and an argillic horizon with a higher clay content than that found in the terrace soils. One other kind of soil development known as an anthropic epi- pedon must be described. The anthropic epipedon is a surface soil layer that has been extensively altered by human activity. This type of soil is often found on archaeological sites and is referred to as a midden in the archaeological literature. Characteristics of this soil are increased levels of organic matter and of elements such as calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus. The deposition of plant and animal remains as refuse increases the organic matter content of the A horizon and darkens the soil to a dark brown or black. The addition of bone and shell increases the calcium and phosphorus content of: the soil. ARCHAEOLOGICAL IMPLICATIONS INTERPRETATION OF STRATIGRAPHY The nature of soil genesis and the physical properties of the A and B horizons at Bird Point Island are of great importance for inter- preting the nature of cultural stratigraphy. The soils present on the knoll were formed during the late Pleistocene, long before the first human occupation took place. This, combined with the lack of soil aggradation, means that the ground surface observed today is essen- tially the same surface that has been in existence from Paleo-Indian times up to the present. Consequently, debris deposited during various occupations of the site have become mixed together in the sandy loam A horizon. Cultural stratigraphy in the traditional sense does not exist over most of the site. Instead, most vertical separation of artifacts, with the exception of features excavated into the soil, is due to bioturbation. : In nearly all of the units excavated on the site, some artifacts were found resting directly on the surface of the argillic horizon, with the argillic horizon itself being relatively devoid of artifacts. An analo- gous situation can be observed in many soils that have gravelly sur- face layers overlying argillic horizons; high concentrations of gravel are found resting on top of the argillic horizon, but virtually no gravel is contained in the drgillic horizon itself. Both phenomena can be explained by the previously described characteristics of the layers involved. The A horizon exhibits physical properties favorable to the movement of objects, whereas the relatively high clay content of the argillic horizon forms a barrier impeding the progress of roots and burrowing animals. Since most artifact displacement is a result of plant and animal disturbance, this horizon also impedes the down- ward movement of artifacts. In recent years, archaeologists have devoted much attention to the role of soil-mixing processes in the formation of the archaeological record, For example, Wood and Johnson (1978:317) discussed the effects upon archaeological sites of pedoturbation resulting from plant and animal activity, freezing and thawing, mass wasting (soil creep), swelling and shrinking of clays, growth and wasting of salts, erosion, and earthquakes. The concept of bioturbation also has been examined in recent archaeological literature from East Texas. Brown (1975) countered the conclusions reached by Hyatt et al. (1974) in their analysis of material from the Cox site at Cooper Lake with a new explanation derived from a pedological approach. Hyatt et al. (1974) assumed that artifacts found at greater depths had been covered with alluvium which had been subsequently reoccupied, resulting in the stratification of the artifacts. Because fewer artifacts were recovered from the lower levels than from the upper levels, they concluded that utilization of the site had increased through time. In contrast, Brown (1975) suggested that all cultural materials had been deposited at or near the present ground surface, and that artifacts had been displaced downward by natural factors. He tecognized a size-sorting effect in which artifact frequencies de- clined with depth while the mean weight of artifacts increased with depth. This same pattern was shown to exist at sites 41FT158 and 41NV160 within the Richland Creek Project area (McIntyre and Janak 1982), and it appears to occur at Bird Point Island as well. i ap

i4 The principal effect of bioturbation is the gradual vertical dis- placement of artifacts downward through the soil. At sites associated with Lake Limestone, Prewitt (1975:35) observed a gross separa- tion of Archaic and Late Prehistoric artifacts with some overlap of vertical proveniences in the sandy deposit. He proposed that this pattern represented the cumulative effects of natural disturbance processes, or bioturbation. Subsequent geomorphological analysis by Byrd (1979:27 3-300) demonstrated that alluviation was partially responsible for the vertical separation of artifacts at some sites on floodplain knolis, but that the mixing effects of bioturbation were still amajor influence on the vertical distribution of artifacts at most sites. At Lake Fork Reservoir, Bruseth and Perttula(1981:56) recognized that: Invariably, where the A horizon extends deeply, artifacts are also encountered deeply. In many cases artifacts are found directly on the clay B horizon. Given that this B horizon formed through leaching and was never an exposed surface, these artifacts must have migrated downward from the surface. In addition, they noted variability in artifact movement which was related to the amount of time available for any given artifact to move through the soil. Artifacts deposited during earlier occupations had migrated deeper than those deposited during later occupations, pre- sumably because they had been subjected to the processes of biotur- bation for longer periods of time. This distribution was called the “age effect” (Bruseth and Perttula 1981:57), and it is believed to occur on most sites that are deposited on nonaggrading surfaces. DETECTION OF CULTURAL FEATURES Three properties of the argillic horizon at Bird Point Island act together to provide an excellent environment for the detection of cul- tural features: (1) resistance to bioturbation, (2) close proximity to the ground surface, and (3) light color. In soils classification, the upper 50 cm of the argillic horizon is examined because it is the por- tion of the solum which is most likely to express properties pertinent at the family level, and itis relatively unaffected by cultivation or bio- turbation. This lack of disturbance also promotes the preservation of cultural features which have been dug into the B horizon. At Bird Point Island, where the A horizon is only 20-40 cm deep, most cul- tural features were dug into the B horizon. Since the colors of argillic horizons formed in Haplustalfs are lighter than the organically enriched A horizon soil that forms much of the feature fill, cultural features are visible as light to dark brown stains against the yellowish brown argillic horizon. The ability to detect cultural features depends upon the contrast between the feature fill and the surrounding soil. The darkness of the feature fill depends upon the quantity of organic matter present in the fill, and this in turn, varies according to the use of the feature. For example, hearths are usually darkened by charcoal remnants and also may be marked by oxidized clay as a result of burning. These features usually have distinct boundaries visible against the lighter colored B horizon. At the other end of the continuum are post holes. Post holes were not filled intentionally with organically enriched material as were hearths or pits filled with refuse. Rather, they gradually filled with A horizon sandy loam after the wooden posts decayed. Post holes which filled with organically enriched midden soil are quite distinct, whereas those dug in areas without midden development are often difficult to see. This pattern was observed among the post holes in House | at Bird Point Island. Several post holes were of the same chroma as the argillic horizon, and the distinc- tion was barely visible as a value difference of one on the Munsell scale. In fact, many of these post holes would have been overlooked Volume II, Part One if a segment of the south side of the house had not consisted of darker, distinct post holes resulting from a localized midden accumulation in the A horizon. INTERPRETATION OF FEATURE PROFILES Drainage characteristics of the A, B, and C horizons also must be considered in order to understand the profiles of cultural features. For example, the mottled appearance of the profiles of Features 35 and 36, believed to represent large roasting pits, differed greatly from those of other large pits observed on the site. Examination revealed that the other large pits had gone completely through the B horizon and penetrated the C horizon sands, whereas Features 35 and 36 were confined within the argillic horizon and exhibited characteris- tics of poor drainage such as grayish colors and iron segregation. Apparently, the clay content at the bottom of these two features was sufficient to hold water, particularly after the compaction that un- doubtedly occurred when the pits were intially excavated. This created a trap which collected downward moving water as well as water moving laterally along the top of the argillic horizon. As the two pits became saturated up to the original subsoil level, normal lateral movement was restored. The stratigraphic profiles reflect this fact, exhibiting normal A horizon material underlain by a grayish zone with low chroma mottling. Drainage and associated leaching also explain the complex pro- file observed in Feature 1. This tremendous prehistoric feature, measuring approximately 15X17X2 m, was excavated from the A horizon down into the C horizon. The removal of the B horizon promoted drainage through the pit fill, causing leaching of organic matter which resulted in a gradual decrease in darkness of soil color with depth. Leaching of iron resulted in reddish staining immediately above the pit bottom (McIntyre and Janak 1982). This lens of iron accumulation occurred when the downward capillary movement of water was impeded by the strongly contrasting pore size of the undis- turbed C horizon sediments at the bottom of the pit. The occurrence of this lens was used to help delineate the bottom of the pit, which was otherwise difficult to distinguish. CONCLUSION The implications of soil variability for archaeological research are considerable. First, since the surface of the site has been non- aggrading over much of its history of human habitation, artifacts would have been deposited on a surface similar in elevation to that observed today. These artifacts would have moved into the soil through natural disturbances, probably caused in large part by the burrowing of pocket gophers. Pedestrian traffic across the site could also have forced lost or discarded artifacts into a subsurface context. Under these circumstances, the value of excavating in vertical levels, as archaeologists have traditionally been taught to do, is called into question. Although there is some order apparent with respect to the vertical distribution of artifacts, this gross separation of Archaic from Late Prehistoric artifacts is due to the age effect noted by other researchers (cf., Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Prewitt 1975). The age effect results in the oldest artifacts occurring deeper than the most recent artifacts simply because the older artifacts have been dis- turbed and subjected to displacement for a longer period of time. This vertical movement of artifacts is not uniform; artifact displace- ment is related to artifact shape and size (McIntyre and Janak 1982 ). Thus, the vertical context of the material is mixed and difficult to interpret. On the other hand, the horizontal movement of artifacts by natural processes is probably less destructive to cultural patterning since the scale of movement is smail relative to the overall site size (Bruseth and Perttula 198 1:57). The implication of the soils data for the detection and excavation of cultural features is that feature preservation will be minimal within the A horizon. Most cultural features at Bird Point Island represent pits dug into the soil for a variety of functions and‘most of these were filled with the dark organically enriched sandy loam that comprises the A horizon. The close similarity between the color and texture of the feature fill and that of the A horizon, combined with the mixing effects of natural disturbances, prevents visual detection of the upper portions of features within the A horizon. Features are only visible where they have penetrated the B horizon, which is lighter in color than the A horizon and has a sandy clay texture. Although material found in the upper portion of features may be of importance for understanding feature function or chronology, the mixed nature of the A horizon at Bird Point Island precludes detailed analysis of this material. Therefore, sampling of features should concentrate on the lower portions of pits, hearths, and other features which are preserved within the B horizon. These features form discrete units for analysis, and stand in contrast to the mixed A horizon artifacts. The A horizon should be sampled in a manner that will facilitate an understanding of large scale spatial patterning that 15 can be compared with the discrete areas occupied by features visible in the B horizon. The implication of soils data for the presence of interpretable stratigraphy and the identification of chronological levels is that no interpretable cultural stratigraphy is present, except inside Feature | which was sequentially filled and reused a various points throughout prehistory. The possibility of observing different surfaces of origin for features, which is directly related to their relative chronological placement, is limited to the stratified context of Feature 1. All other features originated at the ground surface which is similar to the present day surface. _ Finally, the different soils present at the site have different poten- tials for the preservation of bone and mussel shell. These faunal remains.are affected by differential pH values of the soil and are less likely to be preserved in an acidic environment. As stated previously, the terms Typic, Udic, and Ultic are differentiated primarily by variation in the leaching of bases that has occurred. Ulltic soils display the strongest acid reaction and Typic soils display the weakest acid reaction. Consequently, a lack of bone or shell within the area of Ultic Haplustalfs may reflect poor potential for preserva- tion rather than a lack of faunal processing or trash disposal. The interactive effects of cultural behavior and differential preservation must be considered when final interpretations are made.

MANAGEMENT OF THE DATA RECOVERY PROGRAM by William A. Martin and James E. Bruseth The archaeological literature of the past decade is filled with articles stressing the benefits of problem oriented research both for aiding the organization of individual projects and for adding useful information to the regional archaeological data base (Canouts 1977; McGimsey and Davis 1977; Fitting 1977; Raab 1979). In this vein, work conducted during the Richland Creek Archaeological Project followed a problem oriented research design incorporating a multidisciplinary approach toward the study of prehistory through- out the course of the data recovery program (Raab et al. 1981). At Bird Point Island, the collection of data in several phases over a five year period provided the flexibility required to make adjust- ments to field and laboratory procedures as the need arose. Method- ology was scrutinized carefully and evaluated as work progressed. As new data came to light during the interim periods of analysis, new procedures were devised to address problems of particular interest presented by these data. The refinements in excavation and analyti- cal strategies implemented during successive seasons of field work created a more effective mitigation program than could have been attained using a single-phase approach. The data management approach of the Richland Creek Archae- ological Project incorporated the philosophy of Lipe (1977:33): Like other disciplines, archaeology is healthy only to the extent that it continues to evolve new and more satisfying approaches to explanation. Nowhere was the effect of this philosophy more pronounced than at Bird Point Island, the site which received the greatest concentra- tion of effort during the course of testing and four seasons of mitiga- tion. This chapter presents a discussion of the data collection procedures used during the testing and mitigation field work, the manner in which improvements were made based upon the results of ’ each season of field work, and the effects of these improvements on efficiency and quality of the research. The evolution of the data recovery methodology is outlined as it progressed over the course of five field seasons. Bird Point Island 17 was extensively investigated because it is a large complex site with great potential to enhance the understanding of North Central Texas prehistory, but it also served as a testing ground for a wide variety of field techniques that have not commonly been used in this part of the State. Although some techniques did not reveal significant data, others provided a comprehension of prehistoric cultural behavior that previously could only be achieved with large scale block excava- tions and years of data analysis. Funds are seldom available for such large scale studies, so consequently, little is known of community level patterning at sites in Central and East Texas. The advances in methodology developed by experimentation at Bird Point Island can only be understood by examining them on a season by season basis. Although detailed discussions of the most successful techniques are presented in subsequent chapters, the logic behind decisions to use or abandon specific techniques can be under- stood only by examining progress at the site from one season to the next, as presented in this chapter, In fact, the entire reason for out- lining the methodology in a single chapter is to explain the factors responsible for selection of each specific technique used, not merely to list the techniques without any discussion of their importance. The following sections discuss the methods used during testing and then during mitigation Season I through Season IV. THE TESTING PROGRAM The excavation methods utilized during the testing phase at sites in the Project area were carefully matched to levels of information return. Traditional hand excavation was used on sites where intact cultural deposits were known to exist, such as creek bank sites with buried hearths. On sites where very little was known about the nature of the deposit, a more cost-effective approach was to explore the sites rapidly by means of backhoe trenches. When deposits warranting careful investigation were found, the backhoe was abandoned in favor of hand excavation (Raab et al. 1981). At Bird Point Island, a

One of the major goals of the testing program at Bird Point Island was to determine whether the large depression along the western slope of the terrace was the result of erosion or of cultural activity. Although similar depressions, representing large pits that had been excavated and refilled prehistorically, had been found near Dallas, no such pits had been observed south of the East Fork of the Trinity River. A backhoe trench (Unit 25) was dug to bisect the depression rapidly, exposing a profile for stratigraphic examination. The results of this excavation clearly demonstrated that the depression was a man-made pit of prehistoric origin which measured roughly 15 m across and more than 2 m deep (Figure 3-1). The pit, designated Feature 1, contained five human burials within the small portion excavated by the backhoe, as well as pre- historic artifacts similar to those found in the pits near Dallas. The burials, which included one cremation and fragmentary remains of other individuals, were distributed from 75 cm below ground surface to the bottom of the pit. The stratigraphic profile consisted of a layer of mixed yellow and brown sediments overlain by a homogeneous dark brown midden layer that extended beyond the edges of the pit. This suggested that the pit had been excavated and partially refilled prior to the accumulation of the dark brown midden (McGregor et al. 1982:36—38). Another goal of testing was to examine the horizontal and vertical extent of the cultural deposit across the terrace. Toward this end, 21 shovel test units (Units 1-20, and 26), measuring 40X40 cm were excavated at roughly 20 to 30 m intervals across the terrace, and two 1X1 m units (Units 21 and 22) were excavated in areas where shovel test units indicated deep deposits (Figure 3-1). All soil was dry- screened through 1/4 in (6 mm) mesh, except for standardized 81 samples removed from the [<1 m units and water screened through 1/16 in (1.4 mm) mesh. Two additional backhoe trenches (Units 23 and 24) were also dug to search for cultural deposits. Results of the shovel testing indicated that the highest density of cultural material occurred in a broad area south of the large pit, although some material was found across the entire terrace. The test units south of the pit also exhibited dark soil color, a characteristic of midden development, and higher densities of arrow points and ceramics. This suggested that an intensive Late Prehistoric occupa- tion occurred primarily on the portion of the terrace south of the pit. On the other hand, a relative lack of dark soil color, arrow points, and ceramics, coupled with a higher density of dart points, was observed on the northern half of the terrace. This suggested that a less inten- sive Archaic occupation occurred on the northern portion of the terrace. The vertical extent of the deposits in Units 21 and 22 was considerable. Unit 21 was excavated to a depth of 160 cm within the midden south of Feature 1. Unit 22 was excavated within the undisturbed area of a pit exposed by one of the backhoe trenches (Unit 24). This pit, subsequently labeled Feature 124, measured 4m long and was relatively shallow in the trench profile, but Unit 22 encountered cultural material and human bone to a depth of 190 cm. Although Unit 22 was tested with a post hole digger down to 250 cm, few additional artifacts were found below 190 cm. The final goal of the testing program was to assess the nature of the landform on which the site was located as part of a geomorphological study of the Richland Creek valley. Four additional backhoe trenches (Units 27-30) were excavated to expose the natural stratigraphy and allow soil samples to be collected. These trenches were also examined for evidence of cultural activity, but little was found. The only backhoe trenches that encountered substantial archaeological deposits were Units 24 and 25. Very little damage was done to the cultural deposits as a result of backhoe use. Only about 8% of Feature 1 and 10% of Feature 124 were affected by the Velame II, Part One backhoe, leaving the majority of these features intact for subsequent hand excavation. THE MITIGATION PROGRAM SITE RESEARCH GOALS As previously stated, a multiphased approach consisting of testing and four excavation seasons was used at Bird Point Island, with the focus of investigation changing from season to season as new lines of research manifested themselves. The first mitigation season concen- trated exclusively on excavation of Feature 1, the large pit. This season consisted of 302 person-days and was conducted during 10 weeks in the summer of 1982. Since most of the Wylie focus pits found near Dallas are covered by the waters of reservoirs, the discov- ery of a similar pit at Bird Point Island provided a rare opportunity to study the chronology, cultural affiliation, and function of these poorly understood features. Therefore, Feature 1 was the obvious object of initial research in an attempt to unravel the mysteries of these enigmatic features. Using data from excavations of other pits, along with information obtained during testing, hypotheses regarding chronology and pit function were proposed (Raab and Moir 1981). Lynott (1975:70) had proposed a Late Prehistoric origin for the pits, based on four radiocarbon dates ranging between ap. 950240 and 1590+90 recovered from the pit at Lake Lavon. Indeed, all of the previously reported pits contained artifacts associated with the Late Prehistoric period. However, the stratigraphy of the pit at the Upper Rockwall site suggested that its earliest use may have occurred during the Archaic period (Ross 1966:18). The evidence from Unit 25, the backhoe trench inside Feature 1 at Bird Point Island, also pointed toward an Archaic origin. As a result, it was hypothesized that the pit had been dug during the Archaic period and that a subsequent Late Prehistoric occupation was responsible for the midden overlying the pit (Raab and Moir 1982:204). Since few artifacts were observed in the lower portion of the pit, whereas a concentration of artifacts and faunal remains was present in the upper 1 m, it was also hypothe- sized that the nature of pit utilization changed through time (Raab and Moir 1982:204). The results showed some low- magnitude magnetic anomalies over and around the pit. These data were compared with the findings of the excavations inside the pit, but little meaningful correlation was apparent. The magnetic data were set aside until a more extensive magnetometer survey could be undertaken at the site to provide a broader comparative base for interpretation. , Before beginning new excavations, backhoe trench Unit 25 was reopened to provide a profile which would, hopefully, permit excava- tion of the pit using cultural levels by following the strata observed in the backhoe trench. Unfortunately, the moisture content of the sandy C horizon created: unstable conditions which resulted in wall slumping. The trench was backfilled quickly to prevent additional damage to this important feature, and excavation proceeded by arbitrary levels within 2X2 m units.
