Most features were recorded within the upper | m of pit fill and consisted of pits containing deer bone, antler, stone tools, nut shell, prairie turnip, and in one instance, maize fragments. The few features found in the lower levels of the pit included an animal burial, acharcoal concentration, and a small circular pit. Most ofthe human remains were found in the lower levels of the pit, including a tightly flexed male skeleton and several fragments of another individual. However, an extended buriaf was also found in the upper portion of the pit (Martin 1983:61-73). A series of radiocarbon dates demonstrated a clear stratigraphic sequence within Feature 1. The bottom layer of the pit dated from the Archaic period, roughly between 170B.c. and ap. 130.A single date from the middle levels of the pit suggested that a later occupation occurred around ap. 580 to a.p. 860. Finally, dates from the upper midden layer ranged between A.D. 1300 and ap. 1650. The fact that the bottom zone contained human and animal burials, but little occupational debris, indicated that the pit was intended as a cemetery during the Archaic period. The presence of occupational debris in pits dug during the late occupation suggested that the pit utilization had changed over time from ritual use to domestic use (trash discard). ‘ METHODOLOGICAL EVALUATION Although sufficient data were recovered to address the hypoth- eses posited prior to the field work, the amount of work accomplished for the time and money spent was deemed unacceptable. An increase in efficiency was necessary to allow adequate investigation of the remainder of the site during subsequent field seasons. The reasons for the relatively slow progress made during Season I were exam- ined, and a revised strategy was developed for use during Season Two. One reason for the impeded progress was the fact that excavators proceeded with extreme caution, being well aware that Feature | represented one of only twosuch pits known to exist intact. Previous researchers had generated a myriad of hypotheses about the function of these pits, including use as large pit houses, ritual feasting areas, sacred dance arenas, defensive breast works, and water storage Velume II, Part One tanks (Stephenson 1949a; Losrain and Hoffrichter 1968; Lynott 1975:11). Consequently, excavators were cautioned to proceed carefully so that data necessary to test these proposed functions could be observed. As the excavations proceeded, however, it became clear that data supporting most of these interpretations did not occur inside the feature. In addition, the hot summer climate of North Central Texas was a major factor responsible for decreased efficiency. The physical dis- comfort resulting from daily temperatures in excess of 100°F cer- tainly had a detrimental effect on the energy level of the crew, but more than that, the heat and lack of rain made the soil almost un- workable. The uppermost levels of all units were so hard that they had to be broken up with picks. Features discovered in the lower, moister levels quickly dried out under these conditions, making it difficult to map and photograph them. Perhaps the factor most re- sponsible for impeded progress was the difficulty involved with screening the soil once it was excavated, Dirt clods from the surface levels had to be broken apart by pounding them with wooden stakes. The first two problems were easily remedied for Season II mitiga- tion. The first problem, over-cautiousness, was less of a factor during Season II because all work was concentrated outside the pit. The second problem, the summer heat, was avoided by planning a spring field season. The third problem, screening efficiency, was more diffi- cult to solve. Although the soil was moister and easier to screen in the spring because of increased rainfall, dry screening still required a great deal of time and labor. Instead, water screening was selected as the preferable artifact recovery method. However, no water source was available other than the slough which remained dry during half of the year. Prior to the start of Season II, some Project funds were expended for the construction of a pond in the floodplain west of the site. Pumps were purchased, and a work area for water screening and artifact processing was constructed along the western slope of the terrace. The work area was bounded on the north and south by two heavy-duty frames which utilized interchangeable screens. A drying area, artifact collection hopper, and supervisor’s desk were located in the center of the work area. Once screens were inserted in the frames and were filled with soil, water pressure was used to wash the matrix through the mesh (Figure 3-2a). Upon completion, the screens were removed and were set in a drying area, while replace- ment screens were inserted in the frames. When the artifacts were dry, delicate materials were removed by hand, and the screens were emptied into the hopper which funneled artifacts into plastic bags (Figure 3-2b). Finally, a supervisor labeled the bags, recorded them in the log, and placed them in boxes for transport to the laboratory. The cost of constructing this factory-like system was anticipated to _ pay for itself many times over in terms of reduced labor costs; in fact, an increase of more than 100% in data recovery per person-hour expended was realized during Season II. SEASON I FIELD STRATEGY The second season of field work at Bird Point Island was zonducted during the spring of 1983. At this time, the research emphasis shifted from investigating Feature 1, a single feature at the site, to understanding the configuration of the site as a whole, The research centered on two problems: the identification of temporally discrete areas, and the detection of intrasite functional variability. Study of the first problem sought to relate the archaeological deposits found across the terrace to the occupations recognized in the strata of Feature 1. The second problem involved the delineation - of activity areas within the temporally discrete areas. Efficient examination of a site the size of Bird Point Island, which measures approximately 100X200 m, requires a rapid overview of

A four stage data-recovery strategy was used during the Season II field work in which an overview obtained during the first stage was used for planning the second, third, and fourth excavation stages. The first stage utilized remote sensing and surface collection techniques to provide maps of potential cultural features and artifact concentrations. During the second stage, inten- sive excavation was conducted in areas believed to contain features or activity areas. The third stage used systematic hand excavation to ’ sample areas of both high and low artifact density. During the fourth stage, larger excavation areas were opened to expose features visible in the B horizon. Originally, block excavations were planned for the final stage, but the quantity and size of the features necessitated a limited amount of surface scraping using heavy equipment to expose portions of them. A total of 435 person-days was expended during Season II mitigation. GEOPHYSICAL REMOTE SENSING Two remote sensing devices were used to survey portions of the terrace prior to excavation: a proton precession magnetometer and a sensor capable of measuring minute changes in electromagnetic conductivity (EM-38). A total of 13 20X20 m blocks (5,200 m2) was surveyed magnetically during Season II, including a resurvey of two blocks surveyed during Season I. The total coverage for both seasons was 16 blocks (6,400 m2). Three 20X20 m blocks and one partial block measuring 10X20 m, covering 1400 m2, were surveyed with the EM-38 prior to excavation. At the end of the field season, additional survey was conducted over a 4X6 m partial block, a 10X20 m block, and a 20X30 m block which partially overlapped a block surveyed at the beginning of the season. Total coverage with the EM-38 was 2024 m?, These surveys identified locations of potential cultural features, thereby providing target areas for initial excavation. The magnetom- eter survey encompassed an area broad enough to include peripheral areas where little activity was thought to have occurred. The objec- tive of this broad coverage was to isolate areas of concentrated activity in an attempt to define site limits. The conductivity survey was confined to a more limited area due to the fact that its use was experimental and its effectiveness was unknown. At least 32 magnetic anomalies and several conductivity anoma- lies were recognized. In areas where both techniques were used, substantial overlap was observed among magnetic anomalies with 21 b Figure 3-2. Water screen work area: (a) water screens in operation, (b) funneling artifacts into a bag with a hopper. high magnetic responses and conductivity anomalies with low conductivity responses. These overlapping anomalies were used as starting points for the excavation stage. A detailed discussion of the remote sensing surveys and results is presented in Chapter 10. AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY Aerial photographs were taken by Lauden Aerial Productions at both high and low altitudes. A 35 mm camera mounted to a small air- craft was used to shoot Kodak panchromatic black and white film for the high altitude photos and Kodak infrared black and white film for the low altitude photos. Sufficient overlap between frames was allowed to permit the production of stereo pairs. The grid used to conduct the magnetic and conductivity surveys was marked to make it visible in the photographs, allowing comparisons to be made. The site was plowed with a disc plow prior to the flights to remove un- eveness in ground temperature caused by vegetation which could adversely affect the photographs. This procedure caused minimal damage to the archaeological content of the site, since it had been plowed several times by the previous landowner. Unfortunately, the results of the aerial photography were less useful than had been hoped. The small film format was inadequate for producing good quality enlargements, and optical distortion prevented direct mea- surement of ground distances from the photographs. Aside from these difficulties, the photographs were useful for delineating areas where brush had been cleared and burned in recent years. Also, the general outline of the midden on the south half of the site was visible, as was a small patch of darker soil on the north part of the site which was later determined to be of cultural origin (see Chapter 11). CONTROLLED SURFACE COLLECTION The next procedure was the systematic collection of surface artifacts to delineate activity areas. This technique has been used at several other sites with success (Binford et al. 1970; Bruseth and Perttula 1981), and it was used to obtain a picture of the horizontal distributions of artifacts to plan further excavations. The site was gridded into 55 m units and all artifacts from each unit were col- lected. The artifact frequencies were then entered into a micro- computer and transferred to the mainframe computer on the SMU campus. A computer program (SYMAP) was used to generalize the data into a spatial map of contoured artifact densities.

## Page 44

22 The SYMAP program, a synographic computer mapping pro- gram which uses a complex algorithm to construct contours of similar artifact frequencies, allows the user to select the number of contours and the interval magnitude for each contour. The interval magnitude of the contours was selected to delineate three major density classes observed on many sites in East Texas: high density clusters, low density clusters, and low level scatters (Bruseth and Pertulia 1981:56). Low level scatters represent materials such as lithic debris or broken tools that were unintentionally entered into archaeological context by means of casual discard during the course of occupation. Low level scatters usually encompass the entire site area, and within these scatters, low and high density clusters are found where specific activities occurred. Low density clusters are usually comprised of objects that were curated and repaired by the prehistoric inhabitants, such as projectile points, knives, etc. High density clusters are comprised of artifact classes with short use life and high discard frequency, such as lithic debris in a stone tool manufacturing area, or fire cracked rock in a cooking area. Unfortunately, most artifact classes were too low for useful maps to be generated. Lithic debris, the most common single artifact class, did show an interpretable distribution, so this map was used to plan subsequent excavation strategies at the site. Further details on this technique and its results are discussed in Chapter 13. MUNSELL COLOR READINGS As soon as the controlled surface collection was completed, the same 5 m grid points were sampled for soil color in an effort to de- lineate midden boundaries. Soil samples were collected at a depth of 20 cm, just beneath the plow zone. The soil was stored in plastic bags to preserve moisture and was taken to the laboratory so that Munsell color readings could be taken under standardized lighting conditions by the same individual. The Munsell colors were digitized to rank them from brightest to darkest. These digitized values were used to generate a SYMAP of soil color which exhibited a large cluster of dark soil within the midden, closely paralleling the lithic debris clus- ter. The results of this study are discussed in detail in Chapter 11. INITIAL EXCAVATION The second stage of Season II field work was designed to interpret cultural patterning outside of Feature 1. In a sense, the initial exca- vation can be viewed as an anomaly-testing program because magnetic and conductivity anomalies were the primary targets of investigation. However, artifact clusters visible on the lithic debris SYMAP and low density areas were also examined. The goal of the initial excavations was to expose as many features as possible, as quickly as possible, so that decisions concerning subsequent stages of excavation could be made. Trenches composed of contiguous 1X1 m squares were exca- vated across the center of anomalies, artifact clusters, and low density areas which were dug as controls. The trenches varied in length between 2 and 12 m depending on the size of the anomaly or artifact concentration. A particular effort was made to extend each trench beyond the limits of the anomaly or artifact cluster so that artifact frequencies from inside the feature could be compared with those from adjacent areas. In all, 162 1X1 m units were excavated, including 93 units across anomalies, 24 units across artifact concen- trations, 39 units in control areas, and 6 units within large features (Figure 3-3). The excavation strategy enabled the excavators to locate the boundaries of cultural features. Excavation of each trench began with the units at both ends and proceeded to the center. Units were dug in 10 cm intervals down to the interface between the A and B Volume II, Part One horizons, exposing the yellowish brown, sandy clay B horizon. Once the depth to the B horizon was established at each end of the trench, excavation continued across the trench at this depth. Using this procedure, excavators were able to detect several large features by the distinct color and texture changes, from yellowish brown sandy clay to dark brown sandy loam, where the edges of these features penetrated the B horizon. Some trenches were excavated on selected portions of the site where anomalies and artifact concentrations appeared to be absent to insure that important features were not overlooked simply because they did not register on remote sensing or surface collection maps. These trenches acted as controls, providing data useful for com- parison with data from the excavations through the anomalies and artifact concentrations. Control Trench 1 was dug to examine an area of high soil conductivity, the opposite of the conditions found over cultural features. Control Trench 2 was dug to search for possi- ble structures indicated by low intensity conductivity anomalies that appeared on a filtered version of the map. Control Trenches 3, 4, and 5 were dug within the midden where artifact density was lowest and no anomalies were observed. Control Trench 6 was excavated in a low density area at the north end of the site. No cultural features were found in Control Trenches 1, 2, or 6, but portions of features were encountered in Control Trenches 3, 4, and 5. The vertical distribution of artifacts in these trenches and others across the site reflect the fact that all artifacts were originally depos- ited on the present ground surface and then worked into the soil by means of bioturbation and plowing, or prehistoric excavation of pits (see Chapter 2). This belief is supported by the preponderance of artifacts in levels 1 and 2 in all units not disturbed by cultural fea-- tures. The relative increase of artifacts at lower levels inside the features represents a mixture of artifacts related to the use of the features with those artifacts already present in the A horizon at the time the features were dug. The increase of fire cracked rock in the lower levels at the interface of the A and B horizons reflects the advanced degree of bioturbation that has occurred within the A horizon. Even though the pedological analysis indicated that the site sur- face was stable and that artifacts were mixed by means of natural and cultural disturbance, the initial excavations employed a traditional approach using 10 cm arbitrary levels. This conservative approach was adopted to collect the data needed to confirm or reject the bio- turbation hypothesis. The lack of interpretable cultural stratigraphy was confirmed by examining the vertical distribution of artifacts, so the use of 10 cm levels was abandoned for subsequent excavations, except in large features where vertical control was required to address specific research problems. SYSTEMATIC EXCAVATION Even though a substantial quantity of earth was processed during the initial stage of excavation, the overall percentage of the site that was actually sampled was rather small. A program of systematic excavation was undertaken to provide more uniform coverage of the site so that intrasite functional variability could be more confidently assessed. The methodology used to mitigate historic properties had proven useful for this kind of analysis, isolating structures, fence lines, and yards on SYMAPs generated from excavation data (Moir 1983:33). Therefore, this methodology was adapted for use at Bird Point Island. Units measuring 50X50 cm were excavated at 5 m intervals from 20N to 120N and 20E to 60E. Six 20X20 m blocks in the midden were excavated in 10 cm levels down to the B horizon. Excavation proceeded in levels because the data from the initial excavations had not been analyzed when systematic excavation began. However, when SYMAPs were generated for each level, it became apparent

MECHANIZED EXCAVATION Prior to the initiation of excavation, it was assumed that many anomalies recorded by remote sensing instruments had resulted from natural conditions. However, as the initial excavation stage pro- gressed, nearly all of the anomalies were found to have resulted from cultural features. The additional time expended to test all of the anomalies drastically reduced the amount of time planned for exposing broad areas by means of block excavation. Therefore, an alternative strategy was implemented which utilized heavy equip- ment to carefully strip the A horizon from limited portions of the site. Nine east-west transects were carefully scraped with a bulldozer on selected areas of the site to uncover portions of the features found during the initial stage of excavation and to search for evidence of structures. The scraping operation was monitored by the supervising archaeologist who accompanied the machinery as it traversed the site. The operator varied blade depth in response to signals from the archaeologist to avoid undue damage to features. Several passes were made along each transect with soil removed in 5 to 10 cm increments until the interface of the A and B horizons was visible. The bulldozer trenches were 4 m wide (the width of the blade) and varied from 75 m to 90 m in length (Figure 3-4). The locations of the trenches were chosen to provide uniform coverage of the site, sampling the north part of the site, the midden, and the concentration adjacent to the slough. Remote sensing and excavation data were used to place trenches with precision so that portions of large features could be exposed, leaving the remaining portions undisturbed for future investigation. Once these trenches were opened, they were scraped by hand to provide aclean surface in which features could be observed. Crew members used hoes with sharpened blades to scrape the surface of the B horizon, exposing organic stains where pits had penetrated the B horizon. Supervisory personnel followed the crew to map features as they were found. Trenches 2 through 7 were completely scraped and mapped, but Trenches 1, 8, and 9 were only partially investigated due to time constraints. The magnetometer proved to be one of the most useful techniques, identifying concentrations of fire cracked rock as magnetic highs. SEASON III FIELD STRATEGY The third season of field work was conducted during the fall of 1983 and winter of 1984. The research objectives of Season I and II were also pursued during Season III. This separation allowed SYMAPs to be run for each level individually, providing a map of the least disturbed zone inlevel 2. . FEATURE INVESTIGATION More than 400 organic stains, most of which are believed to represent cultural features, were mapped once the B horizon had been scraped. The size of these features varied from 0.02 m? for post holes to 160 m2 for Feature 1. Also, additional circular house patterns, Houses 2 and 3, were uncovered. Obviously, only a fraction of these features could be excavated, so a sample was select- ed from the different categories of features observed. The shape, size, and color of feature fill were used to sort features into the rough categories from which the sample was selected. Six categories were recognized: (1) post holes; (2) smail, circular pits with black fill hypothesized to be smudge pits; (3) circular to oval pits 1 m or less in diameter, with very dark brown fill, thought to be storage pits; (4) large, irregularly shaped pits on the north end of the site, believed to represent roasting pits; (5) large pits within the midden similar to those on the north part of the site, but containing more bone, shell and ceramics; and (6) small, circular pits filled with charcoal and fire cracked rock, interpreted as hearths. An attempt was made to obtain a representative sample from each class of fea- tures. A total of 55 features was sampled during Season II, although seven were later found to contain cremated human remains and were assigned burial numbers in place of feature numbers. METHOLOGICAL EVALUATION For the most part, the field procedures used during Season II were well suited for the collection of data necessary to address the research questions. Of particular effectiveness for the study of spa- tial patterning and chronological assessment of features was the exposure of broad areas by means of mechanized excavation. Cer- tain interpretations could not have been made if features had not been exposed and mapped over the majority of the site area. For example, after scraping it became clear that numerous circu- - lar and oval pits were intrusive into large irregular pits in the midden south of Feature 1, demonstrating that they post-dated the large pits. Similarly, spatial relationships between houses and the large pits thought to represent roasting pits on the north part of the site sug- gested that these features occurred within yard areas around the houses and therefore dated from the ap. 1000-1200 occupation. The pronounced lack of intrusions into the large pits, dating from A.D. 1000-1200, at the north end of the site suggest that the ap. 1300- 1650 occupation was responsible for the numerous intrusive pits south of Feature 1, and that the majority of activity during this last occupation was concentrated on the south half of the site. Radio- carbon dates and distributions of temporally diagnostic artifacts offer additional support for these interpretations (see Chapter 12), but this information never would have come to light ifexcavation had been limited to small blocks and the broad pattern had not been observed. The data provided by 50X50 cm units were extremely useful for defining artifact clusters indicative of specialized activities. How- ever, evaluation of the fine sampling interval used during Season III suggested that fewer units could be excavated to obtain similar re- sults, It now appears that a spacing of 4 m is adequate for most sites. These areas were not thoroughly investigated during Season ITI due to time constraints. The South area adjacent to the slough was scraped, mapped, and. features were sampled to obtain chronological and functional data. At the north end of the site, post holes were cross-sectioned and pro- filed to obtain information on post hole shape, depth, and diameter. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS Bird Point Island has received more attention than any other site within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir and-perhaps has received more than any other site in North Central Texas. A substantial por- tion of the site has been excavated during the course of a testing program and four seasons of mitigation including 21 40X40 cm shovel tests, 2087 5050 cm units, 178 1X1 m units, 12 1X1.5m units, 17 2X2 m units, and 16 backhoe trenches (Tables 3-1 and 3- 2). A systematic sample of approximately 9% of the entire site area was obtained, and major excavations were conducted within the numerous large pits found at the site, with a total of 340 m* exca- vated by hand. In addition, nearly 1,800 m3 of topsoil were removed by machinery to provide an unobstructed view of all features present at the site, once the systematic sample of the A horizon was com- - pleted. This procedure permitted an unbiased assessment of the spatial relationship present among features. Aside from the vast quantity of soil excavated at the site, Bird Point Island also received the most attention with respect to the use of remote sensing techniques. Magnetometer survey was conducted over 6,400 m? at the site as well as over 800 m? off the site in a control area. Electromagnetic conductivity was investigated at vari- ous levels of intensity over a 1,400 m? area. ## Page 53

, DESCRIPTION AND ANALYSIS | OF CULTURAL FEATURES by William A. Martin and James E. Bruseth The term "cultural feature" as used in this discussion includes a broad range of contexts such as hearths, roasting pits, burials, post holes, caches of tools or food, artifact clusters, and other discrete loci where specific activities occurred. Schiffer and Reid (1975:275) call features "behaviorally significant proveniences" because they represent specific locations that were intentionally dug, used, and sometimes intentionally filled by the inhabitants of the site. Thus, features represent specific episodes of cultural behavior. In order to understand the relationships among features, their function must be determined by analysis of form and content (Binford et al. 1970). Depositional processes responsible for the inclusion of material in feature fill must also be considered (Schiffer and Rathje 1973). For example, an artifact recovered from a feature may have been included intentionally in the feature fill because it was directly related to use of the feature, or it may have been included unintentionally through loss or other incidental cultural behavior (primary deposition). On the other hand, the artifact may have been present in the soil before the feature was dug and included accidentally when the feature was backfilled (secondary deposition). Natural forms of secondary deposition also account for the presence of some artifacts in features. For instance, movement of artifacts by erosion or chuming of the soil by means of bioturbation can cause artifacts unrelated to feature function to enter into the feature fill. The purpose of this chapter is to describe the cultural features recorded at Bird Point Island (Figures 4-1 through 4-4), present the methods used to analyze feature form and content, and discuss the probable functions that the features fulfilled. Also, the natural and cultural factors which may have influenced the content of the features are discussed. More specifically, the chapter is divided into four sections which move from descriptive data in section one to statistical analysis of feature content in section two, followed by classification of features in section three, and analysis of house- patterns in section four. Feature 1, the so-called Wylie focus pit, is complex enough to warrant treatment in a separate chapter (see Chapter 6). Descriptive information, including the dimensions, magnetic responses,.and contents of the features, is presented in a 31 tabular format in the first section. Tables 4-1 through 4-3 are presented in place of traditional narrative descriptions of each feature to facilitate comparison of data. The artifact, floral, and faunal data are presented in a volume-corrected form in Tables 4- 4 and 4-5 as artifacts per 100 1 of fill. This permits direct comparison of large features from which huge samples were obtained with small features which contained far less material. Since all values are listed as artifacts per unit volume rather than as actual frequencies, comparison of the values is unaffected by variations in the volume of feature fill excavated. The raw data for each feature sampled are presented in Appendix C. The manner in which the tables were compiled is also discussed in the first section, especially with respect to missing data. For the most part, the analytical scheme and system of classification utilized over four seasons of mitigation changed very little. However, some changes in the system became necessary as our knowledge of the site increased and the data categories were . refined, The effects of these changes on comparability of the data are discussed. The second part of the chapter is devoted to the analysis of the data presented in Tables 4-4 and 4-5. The analytical methodology used to organize features into discrete groups having similar qualities is presented along with the results of this analysis. Correlations among data classes are discussed along with the results of Q-mode factor analysis. The third section describes the functional classes of features recognized at the site: hearths, roasting pits, storage pits, dog burials, post holes, and human cremations and burials. Features are assigned to these categories on the basis of the statistical analysis presented in section two along with data on size, shape, and spatial relationships. The final section concerns the analysis of data from Houses 1, 2 and 3. Architectural characteristics are discussed using wall post and interior post data in a manner similar to that used for the analysis of the houses found at the De Shazo site (Good 1982). The features recorded within the houses are also discussed. Finally, the architectural style of the houses at Bird Point Island is compared and contrasted with house styles from other regions. nD Dy

FEATURE DESCRIPTIONS NUMERICAL DESIGNATION OF FEATURES The numerical designations of features presented in Tables 4-1 through 4-3 divide features into three categories: features, burials, and post holes. In general, cultural soil disturbances were assigned feature numbers unless specific criteria were observed which clearly distinguished these disturbances as human burials (including cremations), or post holes. This system was developed to avoid confusion resulting from multiple numerical designations for burials and post holes, such as "Feature 10, Burial 2", or "Feature 22 Post Hole 3.” Instead, a single designation was assigned to each cultural disturbance. For example, instead of assigning a feature number to a grave pit and a burial number to the skeleton within the grave, both the pit and the skeleton are referred to by a single burial number. Burial numbers were assigned to all features containing human remains, including isolated fragments of individuals and fragmentary cremated remains. Cremations are defined as pits which contain burned human bone. Each pit containing cremated remains was assigned a single burial number, except for one pit

In the tables used in this report, burials and cremations are indicated by the letter "B" followed by a numeral, such as B1. Post hole numbers were assigned to small circular to oval pits, ranging in area between 100 cm2 and 1000 cm2, which exhibited steeply sloping straight to tapering profiles indicative of cylindrical or conical shapes. The term post mold, which is often used interchangeably with the term post hole, is more properly defined as the remains of an actual post found within a post hole (Good 1982:53). No post molds were observed at Bird Point Island, but more than 100 post holes were identified. Post holes are listed in the tables by the letter "P" followed by a numeral, such as P7. One problem with this system of numerical! designation is that some features had to be redesignated as post holes or burials once further excavation and analysis was conducted. Several gaps are- visible in the consecutive listing of feature numbers in Tables 4-1 through 4-3 because some pits assigned feature numbers in the field were later redesignated as post holes or burials. For instance, many pits containing cremated human remains were not recognized as cremations until the osteological analysis was Pios . ~& = eT 35 completed. The feature numbers originally assigned to these pits were changed to burial numbers, and these feature numbers were removed from the list. Another reason for the gap in feature numbers is that some natural disturbances were originally assigned feature numbers, and these numbers were eliminated from the tables when excavation revealed that they were actually caused by roots or rodents. However, the largest single factor accounting for missing feature numbers in the tables is the fact that more than 500 features, burials, and post holes were mapped and recorded at the site, but only a sample of 177 was excavated due to time constraints. Table 4-3 presents the anomaly number, the magnetic response, and direction of polarity associated with the cultural features. Only the 27 features which produced measurable magnetic responses are included in the table. This number represents approximately 22% of all features excavated at Bird Point Island and approximately 6% of all organic stains identified at the site that are believed to represent cultural features. The anomaly number represents the number assigned by the magnetic specialist to each location exhibiting magnetic enhancement prior to the initiation of excavation. Some features do not have anomaly numbers because, prior to excavation, their high magnetic responses were thought to be the result of historic iron trash. The magnetic response is presented in gammas and measures the intensity of the magnetic field associated with each feature. The magnetic polarity indicates the orientation of the magnetic field around the feature. For most cultural features, a pronounced magnetic low is aligned due north of the magnetic high, but in some cases the magnetic low is shifted to the east, and in other cases several weak magnetic lows are oriented in several directions around the feature, causing mixed polarity. The implications of magnetic response and polarity for interpreting the use of features is discussed in Chapter 10. Volume-corrected data are presented for 83 features in Tables 4-4 and 4-5. Table 4-4 includes data from the 62 features which had the most complete sets of data, and Table 4-5 lists the same information for nine cremation burials and 12 post holes. Twenty data classes are presented in these tables which include magnetic data, artifact content, and macrobotanical content. Magnetic response is listed in gammas. Total large lithics (greater than 6.4 mm), total small lithics:(2 mm - 6.4 mm), total fire cracked rock, bifaces, unifaces, cores, dart points, arrow points, and ceramics are listed as volume-corrected counts calculated from the raw frequencies. Baked clay, bone, burned bone, shell, wood, hickory, pecan, acorn, Psoralea, and maize are presented as volume- corrected weights calculated from the original weights in grams. These 20 classes were selected for use in factor analysis because. they provide functional and temporal information useful for classification. Magnetic response is tied directly to thermal alteration of iron oxides in Wilcox sandstone and is useful for identifying features with heat related functions (see Chapter 10). Likewise, fire cracked rock and baked clay are indicators of features subjected to heat, such as hearths. Two size classes of lithic debris were included following the lithic reduction trajectory model proposed by Raab.et al. (1979) to account for differences in lithic reduction technology among features. The tool categories were not divided into more specific types because the resulting frequencies would have been too low to be meaningful. These general tool categories still have functional implications that are useful for feature classification. For the same reason, projectile points were separated only into dart points and arrow points, categories which have functional and chronological relevance, rather than into a myriad of specific types. Ceramics also have functional implications, such as use for cooking or storage, as well as chronological meaning. Bone and shell indicate the degree of faunal utilization represented in features. Poor preservation and small sample size per feature precluded division of these categories into specific taxa. Bumed bone was included in the analysis to help identify features which may have been cremations containing unidentifiable fragments of human remains. This was accomplished by comparing the overall contents of known cremations with those of suspected cremations. Finally, floral remains were included to help identify features with food preparation or storage functions. Volume standardizations were calculated as follows. DATA COMPARABILITY Data comparability hinges on the consistent collection of data and the use of identical sorting criteria in the lab during each season of excavation. However, it is usually impossible to foresee all classes of data relevant to the research goals prior to field work, so modifications often must be made. For the most part, the data collected for features from all four field seasons are directly comparable, but some minor differences resulting from problems with the recognition of certain data classes, and from economic and time constraints on the analysis, were encountered. All data from Seasons II, III, and IV are directly comparable, and most classes of data from Season I are directly comparable with those from the later seasons. The principal difference lies in the category of fire cracked rock. This artifact category was not included in the Season I artifact tabulations because it was not identified as culturally modified until the end of the season. Otherwise, data classes were similar to those used during subsequent field seasons.

7,70 15.20 FLOTATION SORTING METHOD All material recovered by means of flotation was sorted into light fractions and heavy fractions. The heavy fraction was further sorted in two steps. First, all material was sifted through 6.4 mm mesh and material remaining in the mesh was sorted into all data classes presented in Appendix C. This provided results that were directly comparable with data obtained from dry screening and water screening through 6.4 mm mesh elsewhere on the site. Next, the material that passed through the 6.4 mm mesh was passed through a 2 mm sieve and lithic debris, bone, shell, and macrobotanical remains were removed and quantified. All extremely smal! materials that passed through the 2 mm sieve remained unsorted and unquantified, with the exception of micro flakes which were removed for detailed lithic analysis. The unsorted material was sent to a specialist along with the sorted macrobotanical specimens so that a rapid spot check could be made to make sure important seeds were not overlooked, The 1/8 inch- (3.2 mm) mesh size from the light fraction was sorted in the same manner. Smaller screen sizes from the light fraction were not sorted for artifacts, but were sent to a specialist for analysis of macrobotanical remains. MISSING DATA The missing data in Table 4-4 are data recovered by means of flotation only. All macrobotanical remains are absent from Features 42, 54, and 120 because flotation samples were not recovered from these features. Small lithic debris is missing from Features 94, 95, 97, 98, 99, 101, and 102 because, although flotation samples were obtained, time constraints prevented sorting for anything other than macrobotanical content. All missing data were coded so that missing categories were ignored by the computer rather than read as zeroes. Thus, the statistical analysis was not greatly affected. The fire cracked rock frequencies for Features 33 through 36 were corrected for the purposes of statistical analysis to avoid using figures that were drastically underrepresented. During Season II, only fragments of fire cracked rock larger than 2.5 cm were quantified. During Season III, it was learned that small fragments provided more useful information than large fragments, so both sizes were recorded. Unfortunately, Features 33 through 36 were excavated during Season II, so only large fragments were recorded. Their counts are not comparable with the total fire cracked rock frequencies recorded for the rest of the features. To compensate for this discrepancy, an estimate of small fire cracked rock was obtained by examining the ratios of large to small fire cracked rock from features with good data. Although the ratios varied considerably, many were in the range of 1:2 to 1:5, Feature 38 appeared most similar to Features 33 through 36 in size, shape of plan view, and artifact content, so its ratio of 1:2.5 was selected as a correction factor. The estimates for small fire cracked rock for Features 33-36 were obtained by multiplying the large category frequencies by 2.5 and the new totals were increased accordingly and used as values for the statistical analysis. The actual counts for large fire cracked rock are listed in Appendix C. This correction procedure has a methodological weakness, namely that it insures that slightly higher correlations will occur between Features 33 through 36 and Feature 38. However, the overall similarity of these features in other respects suggests that this estimate is reasonable. Since the correlations are based on 20 variables, the alteration of one variable should not affect the results to any great extent. It seemed wiser to use the estimated values than to compare values which were clearly underrepresented. One assumption underlying the analysis of feature data is that features with similar contents, shapes, and sizes were used for similar purposes by the prehistoric inhabitants of the site. This assumption is tempered by the complicating factor of secondary deposition, where some of the contents found in a feature are unrelated to the original use of that feature. This concept affects feature content only; variables such as size and shape of the feature are completely unaffected by this process and they are unlikely to change after the initial use of the feature unless it is subjected to episodes of reuse. Therefore, feature size and shape act as good controls for comparison with features grouped together on the basis of content. The following section presents the goals of factor analysis, the manner in which the analysis was conducted, and the results of the analysis, Then, the sizes and shapes of features associated with the factors generated by this analysis are compared using the Chi- square statistic to examine the significance of relationships among feature content, size, and shape. Following the discussion of statistical analysis, general functional classes of features are described using information derived from field observations in conjunction with factor analysis results. FACTOR ANALYSIS BACKGROUND Factor analysis, specifically principal components analysis, was the technique selected for assessing the relationships among features based on the 20 variables described previously. For several years now factor analysis and related quantitative techniques such as cluster analysis, have been used increasingly by archaeologists to simplify complex relationships among their data. In a recent example, Ciolek-Torrello (1985) used cluster analysis to examine room content at Grasshopper Pueblo which allowed him to identify six classes of rooms used for different functions. Similarly, Hill (1968) used factor analysis to sort 14 pottery types into seven clusters of covarying types in his analysis of room variability at Broken K Pueblo. This type of analysis has been applied to the study of cultural features in recent years. For example, feature types at Cannon Reservoir were defined by Q- mode factor analysis of feature shape and size (O'Brien and Warren 1982). It can also be used to describe regularities in the data, allowing inferences to be made about the nature of the data. Thus, factor patterns are useful for classification when treated as purely descriptive categories (Rummel 1967:455), The original purpose for selecting factor analysis was to sort the cultural features into discrete functional types. It was hoped that each factor generated by the analysis would represent a discrete functional class of feature. However, this was an unrealistic goal because the relationships among features are too complex to permit this specific level of classification. Secondary deposition processes complicated the analysis, and the unquantified information from field observations mentioned previously proved. to be more important for functional assessment than was originally believed. It is important to stress that factor analysis provided much useful information related to feature function, temporal placement, and degree of secondary deposition among features. This information provided insights into the nature of feature function and the kinds of relationships that exist among features that could not be observed on an intuitive level. The information derived from the analysis is discussed in detail here, and is later used to aid in the definition of functional classes. PRINCIPLES OF FACTOR ANALYSIS Rummel! (1967, 1970) describes five kinds of factor analysis: common factor analysis, principal components analysis, image analysis, canonical analysis, and alpha factor analysis. Common factor analysis only examines the common (shared) variation among variables whereas principal components analysis looks at all variation among variables, not just the variation they have in common. Image analysis is similar to common factor analysis, but has different mathematical properties. Canonical analysis defines common factors for a sample of cases that are best estimates of those for the population. This enables tests of significance to be used. Alpha factor analysis defines common factors for a sample of variables that are best estimates of those in a universe of content (Rummel! 1967:455-457). For the purposes of this study, principal components analysis was selected because it considers all variation among variables, not just the variation that is shared by the variables. By considering all of the variability, a better picture of feature classes can be obtained. The principal components analysis is also easier to use than common factor analysis, since estimates of communality do not have to be made. The basic steps in principal components analysis are: (1) the preparation of a correlation matrix, (2) the extraction of initial factors, and (3) rotation to terminal factors. Factors are defined as separate patterns of relationships between the variables. According to Rummel (1967:463): "The number of factors generated by principal components analysis is the number of ee ee me ee ie ee let ee ok

Variables are assigned loadings for each factor, which can be interpreted like correlation coefficients denoting those variables that are most highly related to the pattern.. Eigenvalues are the sum of the columns of squared loadings for each factor; they measure the amount of variation accounted for by the factor. The initial, or unrotated factor pattern lists the most general patterns of relationship, whereas the rotated factor pattern lists the distinct clusters of relationships (Rummel 1967:466). It is the rotated factor pattern that is the object of interpretation because it provides factors that are much more closely related than are the initial factors. Rotation simplifies reality by shifting away from general factors involving all variables to groups of factors involving different sets of variables. It identifies each variable with one factor, or a small portion of factors, and minimizes the number of variables loading highly on any given factor (Rummel 1967:475). . Correlation coefficients are statistical measures of association used to examine the strength of relationships among variables. Several types of correlation coefficients are in common use and the selection of the proper statistical measure hinges on the nature of the data being compared. Most of the information quantified for feature content is counting level, or ordinal level, data. Kendall's Tau and Spearman's Rho are tests designed to produce correlation coefficients for ordinal level data. Kendall's Tau was selected for use in generating matrices of correlation coefficients because it is more suitable than Spearman's Rho for data sets with large numbers of ties among paired values (Blalock 1972:419). A great number of ties among the paired values was observed in the data set, especially among low frequency categories such as bifaces and unifaces where zeroes were common in the matrix. This fact made Kendall's Tau the logical measure of association for use with the Bird Point Island data. Two correlation matrices were generated: first the data classes were correlated with each other, then the features themselves were correlated with each other. Weak to moderate correlations were obtained in the first matrix, with the highest correlation coefficient being .58 between dart points and bifaces. The data classes appeared to be relatively uncorrelated and the moderate correlations were inadequate for providing an interpretation of feature function. On the other hand, numerous strong correlations were generated in the second matrix, with the highest correlations being .95 between cremation Burials 23 and 28, and .97 between Features 37 and 67. This matrix appeared to have the greatest potential for simplifying relationships among features, so it was used as the correlation matrix for Q-mode principal components analysis. Once initial factors were generated, rotation to final factors was conducted using both orthogonal (varimax) rotation and oblique rotation. In orthogonal rotation, the factors are rotated at right angles to each other like the spokes of a wheel, whereas in oblique rotation, each factor is rotated individually to fit each distinct cluster. Controversy exists as to which method of rotation is the best approach, so both were examined in this study. However, the results were not drastically different between the two methods, so only the factors generated by varimax rotation are discussed here. . RESULTS Twelve factors were isolated, with Factors 1-6 accounting for 89% of the variability among features. Factors 1-4 are the most important, accounting for 82% of the variability. Each factor from Factor 5 on accounts for a small percentage of the variability, and Factors 7-12 account for only 1.2% to 2.3% per ' factor. Therefore, only Factors 1-6 are considered for the classification of cultural features. In this section, varimax rotation factors are interpreted by examining factor loadings for features with known functions, such as cremations and post holes, and comparing them with the loadings for features with unknown functions. Features with loadings of .4 to .9 are listed for Factors 43 1-6 in Table 4-6. To understand which variables are responsible for the factors selected by the principal components analysis, the mean values for each of the 20 variables recorded for features associated with the six factors were calculated. The mean values for each variable are presented in Table 4-7 along with the standard deviations for features which loaded on the factors at the level of .4 or above. The mean values for features loading at .6 or above were also calculated, under the assumption that a feature loading at .4 or .5 may load at an equal or higher level on another factor. However, with few exceptions, the values obtained from these calculations were not drastically different from those presented in Table 4-7. The mean values for each variable are plotted graphically by factor in Figure 4-5 to illustrate important differences observed among the factors. The spatial distribution of features associated with Factors 1 through 6 is presented in. Figures 4-6 and 4-7. Prior to discussing the factors, the features with known functions must be defined. These features meet specific criteria that are traditionally associated with cremations, post holes, hearths, and storage pits. As stated previously, cremations are defined simply as pits which contain burned human bone. They are often difficult to identify because bone fragments that are clearly identifiable as human must be preserved before a burial number is assigned. As a result, some features containing burned bone too fragmentary to be identified may also be cremations, but they were not assigned burial numbers. Post holes, as defined earlier, are relatively small, circular to oval pits, ranging in area between 100 cm2 and 1000 cm2, which have steeply sloping straight or tapering profiles and thus are cylindrical or conical in shape. The principal attribute of hearths is evidence of intense burning marked by the presence of burned clay, charcoal, and in some cases by fire cracked rock. Storage pits are known primarily from their locations: inside houses in the central living area around the hearth. Their principal contents are charred plant foods. Factor 1 Factor 1 accounts for 58.7% of the variability among the features and includes 52 features with loadings of .4 or higher. The mean artifact densities for features included in Factor 1 exhibit the highest levels of bummed bone and charcoal found among any of the factors (Tabie 4-7, Figure 4-5). This trend is most pronounced for features with the highest loadings (.6 - .9). All other artifact classes are present in very low densities and many are lower for Factor 1 than for any other factor. Of the features with known functions, cremations and post holes have the highest loadings. Some features (Features 18, 20, and 91) suspected of being cremations because of their similarity to cremations in size, shape, and location on the site, also loaded highly on Factor 1. This lends support to the idea that they may be cremations in which human bone was too fragmentary to be identified. Features with moderate loadings (.4 - .5) include cremations and post holes but also include hearths (Features 104 and 105) and storage pits (Features 37, 63, 64, and 67) as well as features of unknown function. The different kinds of features included in Factor 1 appear to- be unrelated at first glance, but similarities become visible when the basic nature of their uses is considered. All of these features are essentially holes dug to include a limited set of cultural items and therefore, they all exhibit low densities for most artifact classes. The high density of burned bone and charcoal is easy to explain in that cremation pits were intentionally dug to store bumed human remains which probably were mixed with charcoal from the funeral pyre, and hearths are primarily comprised of charcoal. Post holes and storage pits contained less charcoal and little burned bone, but are similar to cremations and hearths in their lack of artifacts for most classes. In all of these features the primary function does not involve the inclusion or use of artifacts, so artifacts would not have been intentionally included within the pit fill. This means that most of the artifacts that are present within the feature fill probably were introduced by processes of

Examination of the mean artifact densities show that Factor 4 features are only high in smal! lithic debris, acorn, and hickory. Factor 4 is the lowest of all factors for almost all other artifact classes and is second lowest for fire cracked rock (Table 4-7). Features with the highest loadings are Features 37 and 67 which are both pits inside House 1 containing charred plant material but lacking baked clay and fire cracked rock. These features correlate with one another at a level of .97. and are-believed to represent storage pits because of their content and location within the house. Post holes 32, 35, 102 and 104 all correlate highly with Features 37 and 67, probably reflecting their shared locations within houses and the results of secondary deposition of household items, In general, Factor 4 is similar to Factor 1 in that the low frequencies of most artifact classes are probably the result of secondary deposition. Whereas Factor 1 includes cremations, hearths, and post holes, Factor 4 contains storage pits and post holes, mainly features with low fire cracked rock and baked clay content, associated with the village occupation (Figure 4-7b). It is also similar to Factor 3 in that several features related to the house occupation are included. Factor 5 Factor 5 accounts for 4.0% of the variability and contains three features, Features 78, 86, and 87, all with loadings of .9. All of these features are dog burials found within Feature 1. The selection of these as a separate factor is due to the manner in which they were excavated. Unlike pits dug into the B horizon, which is a culturally sterile layer, those dug into the fill of Feature 1 include material present in the fill that is unrelated to their use. Thus, when dog burials were found, the bones were removed and no fill from around them was saved for flotation because the data recovered by flotation would have been unrelated to the dog burials themselves. The computer factored out these features because they had the highest bone densities of all features and because data were missing from all other data classes, This resulted in perfect correlation coefficients of 1 for all three features. It is clear that dog burials form a discrete class of features at the site, but the principal components analysis has artificially created Factor 5 due to the excavation strategy. Factor 6 Factor 6 accounts for only 2.9% of the variability among features and contains only four features. These four features have the highest densities of maize, ceramics, arrow points, large lithic debris, cores, shell, charcoal, and hickory found on the site, and the second highest densities of fire cracked rock, bifaces, and unifaces (Table 4-7). The factor loadings appear to be most affected by ceramic variability. Feature 89, with the highest loading of .8, also has the highest density of sherds found at the site. The types of ceramics found in these features are quite different from those related to the house occupation. Feature 101 contained Late Caddoan ceramics (see Chapter 8) and Feature 89 contained large, thick, plain sherds with large chunks of bone temper which are different from all other plain ware found at the site. Features 97 and 102 were very similar in that both contained trash lenses from 3 to 5 cm thick in the bottom portion of fill. The similarities detected by the principal components analysis appear to be related to intentional trash deposition in the fill episodes of these pits rather than to their original functions. Features 97 and 102 also loaded highly on Factor 2 which was comprised primarily of large irregular pits used for roasting. Although Factor 6 may not be useful for defining original function, it appears to have isolated a group of features within the South Midden area belonging to the A.D. 1300-1650 occupation which were ultimately used for refuse disposal (Figure 4-7c). Volume II, Part One In summary, Factors 1-6 aided in directing our thoughts concerning the elements and processes important for classifying features. Although Factor 2 was the only factor (other than Factor 5 dog burials) to isolate a specific functional class of feature, the other factors isolated groups of features related to house occupation and others related to the final occupation. Perhaps the most important observation is the fact that a majority of features (Factor 1) has been grouped more on the basis of secondary deposition of artifacts than on primary deposition. The features affected by this process might not have been recognized and may have been classified on the basis of artifacts unrelated to their function, if the principal components analysis had not been run. In effect, the factor analysis has grouped features into discrete entities, “types” based on content which is not always related directly to original feature function. The analysis provides information useful for examining feature function, but does not always produce specific functional types. COMPARISON OF FACTORS WITH FEATURE SIZE AND SHAPE Just as similarity in the content of feature fill is assumed to reflect similar uses of features, regularities in sizes and.shapes of features are also assumed to reflect similarity of feature function. Since size and shape are not affected by anything like the complicating effects of secondary deposition, they provide good, independent sources of feature information useful for classification. Size and shape are unlikely to change after the initial use of the feature unless the feature is subjected to episodes of redigging or extraordinary levels of bioturbation. In this section, the Chi-square statistic is used to determine whether or not there are significant relationships between the clusters of features isolated by principal components analysis and feature sizes and shapes. The information on size, shape, and feature content is used to assign features to specific functional classes in the subsequent section. The size of each feature was calculated as its area in plan view, Three size categories were selected which correspond to small (0.01 - 0.30 m2), medium (0.31 - 1.00 m2), and large (1.10 - 100.00 m2) features. Of features with known functions, past holes and small pits fall within the small category, most hearths, storage pits, and cremations fall in the medium category, and Factor 2 pits form the large category. Shape was determined by examining the outline of each feature in plan view. Two basic shapes were used: symmetrical and asymmetrical. Symmetrical features include circular and oval pits, whereas asymmetrical features include all amorphous pits. The number of features falling within each size category is listed for Factors 1-6 in Table 4-8, and the number of features failing into the two shape categories is listed for each factor in Table 4-9. A brief examination of these tables reveals that pronounced associations do exist between size, shape, and the factors selected on the basis of feature content. In Factor 1, 62% of the features are within the small category, and 81% are symmetrical. On the other hand, 75% of Factor 2 features are large, and 70% are asymmetrical. Factor 3 features are mostly medium sized (75%) and are evenly divided among the two shapes. Factor 4 features are mostly small (75%) and are primarily symmetrical (79%). All Factor 5 features are small and symmetrical, and all Factor 6 features are large but are evenly divided among the two shapes. Chi-square values show that these relationships are statistically significant. Only Factors 1-4 were used for the Chi-square test because zeroes in the matrix for Factors 5 and 6 would have invalidated the test. A Chi-square value of 56.91 with a significance level of 00001 was obtained for size, and a value of 18.60 significant to .0004 was obtained for shape. The results of the comparison have important implications for assigning features to functional classes. Comparison of size and shape with Factor I indicates that small to medium features which

FEATURE CLASSIFICATIONS FUNCTIONAL AND TEMPORAL DESIGNATIONS The discrete functional classes recognized at the site are described here using information on size, shape, feature content, the behavioral and functional implications presented by Factors 1- 6, and spatial relationships among features. Spatial relationships are discussed in detail in Chapter 13, so it will suffice to say simply that the concept of the household cluster, an area composed of features within and around a structure (Winter 1976), was used to help classify hearths and storage pits around Houses 1 through 3. Some features are listed under more than one functional category because they exhibit characteristics associated with each category, and a definite classification cannot be made. These features are designated with the letter "f" to indicate that their functional assignment is uncertain. Other features assigned to single functional categories are also marked by the letter "f" to indicate that their assignment to that category is tentative. Such features exhibit some traits associated with the categories to which they are assigned, but their functional assignments should be regarded as best estimates. Features assigned to the Unknown category yielded too little data to formulate estimates of feature function. The temporal classification of features was hindered by the fact that many features did not contain material suitable for radiocarbon dating, nor artifacts diagnostic of specific time periods. The features from clearly dated contexts include those found within Feature 1 (see Chapter 6), those which contained 49 datable charcoal, and those which contained ceramics bearing decorative elements diagnostic of specific time periods. All other features were assigned to components on the basis of spatial relationships to similar features from clearly dated contexts. For example, features found inside Houses 1 - 3 are clearly related to the hamlet occupation in the North area dated at A. D. 1000 - 1200 from charcoal in hearths, roasting pits, and a possible cremation (Feature 20). The close proximity of many cremations to one another, and their central location between Houses 2 and 3, suggests that they represent a cemetery area related to the hamlet occupation. Likewise, the distribution of the large irregular pits around Houses 1 - 3 suggests that they were work areas associated with the hamlet (see Chapter 13). The North area was characterized by a distinct lack of superpositioning of features, which strongly suggests. that most features were the result of a single occupation, Even though a few features found in the North area dated from a later period, the majority of features appeared to be associated with the hamlet occupation and were assigned to the A.D. 1000 - 1200 component. Likewise, many features in the Midden area are assigned to the A. D. 1300 - 1650 component, since radiocarbon dates and ceramic types from this occupation are common in these areas. Features for which temporal placement is uncertain are marked by the letter "t" in Table 4-10. Although some bias is undoubtedly introduced into these temporal estimates, owing to the facet that some features from earlier and later contexts are probably scattered across the site, these estimates are considered to be reasonable approximations of reality. Discussions of burials, flora and fauna in subsequent chapters use these same temporal classifications. The following subsections present general descriptions of each functional class, and Table 4-10 lists the features assigned to each class by chronological period. This section is intended as a summary of feature classes, so the discussion is kept to a minimum. However, the roasting pit discussion is extended owing to the unusual nature of these features and the problems involved with interpretation. ROASTING PITS Roasting pits were the only functional class of feature isolated by principal components analysis (Factor 2). Most are characterized as very large irregular pits, although a few pits are smaller and oval in shape. The size of these features ranged from 3.7 m2 for Feature 97 to 107 m2 for Feature 42, with most features falling within a range of 20 - 50 m2. These features vary in depth from 100 cm to 225 cm below surface; however, the majority range between 120 and 150 cm. In profile, the pits are roughly basin-shaped, but most are characterized by bottoms with irregular undulating surfaces. In several, two colors of pit fill are usually present, an upper darker zone and a lower lighter zone, probably due to effects of leaching. Aside from size and shape, feature content was a primary criterion for classification. These large asymmetrical pits form an uncommon class of features. Such pits are not reported in the Caddoan area 100 km to the east and there is virtually no information available about them in the archaeological literature of North Central Texas, although similar pits have been reported within regions dominated by Post Oak Savannah (Story, personal communication 1985). The function of these features was not immediately apparent, so a careful program of excavation and analysis was conducted to investigate hypotheses related to the two kinds of processing suggested by the contents: heat treatment of chert, and roasting of plant foods. FUNCTION: HEAT TREATING VERSUS ROASTING If heat treatment of lithic raw material was the primary function of the Factor 2 features, then one would expect to find heat treated cores and lithic debris in and around the features. Although an increase in cores was found within these pits, no pattern of increase in thermally altered flakes was observed (Appendix C), The ratio of total flakes to heat treated flakes varies widely among features, with the highest concentrations of heat treated flakes occurring in features other than the large pits. Similarly, no relationship between large pits and heat treated lithic debris is apparent on the SYMAPs (see Chapter 13). This stands in striking contrast to SYMAPs of small fire cracked rock which clearly delineate these features. If, on the other hand, roasting of plant foods was the primary function of the Factor 2 features, then one would expect to find charred macrobotanical remains in the feature fill. Examination of Table 4-4 reveals that all of the large pits listed as roasting pits in Table 4-10 contain respectable quantities of hickory, pecan, and Psoralea. Roasting is an ethnohistorically documented method of preservation for nuts (Swanton 1946) and for the prairie turnip (Psoralea sp.) (Wedel 1978:165), so charred remnants of these species within the features support the roasting hypothesis. Another line of evidence that supports the roasting hypothesis and casts doubt on the heat treatment hypothesis is the great number of these features found at the site. ## Page 73

One on wo rer ee Cultural Features recovered from the site. Certainly, there would be no need to dig so many pits for the processing of lithic raw material when a few pits would suffice. On the other hand, the processing of seasonally available plant foods requiring prompt attention (see Chapter 9) could well require the use of several pits simultaneously, since foods would be available for only brief periods of time and would have to be processed rapidly to retard spoilage or infestation by insects. Ethnohistoric accounts mention roasting of acorns (Swanton 1946) and prairie turnip (Wedel 1978) as common practices. Roasting pits are recorded in the ethnohistoric record for the roasting of sotol bulbs by Lipan Apaches further west in Texas. The soto! bulbs were placed in pits filled with heated rocks after the coals and ashes had been removed, then the pits were covered with dirt. After a few days, the roasted bulbs were dug out for immediate use or storage (Dennis and Dennis 1925). The large pits at Bird Point Island may have been used in the same manner to roast nuts and prairie turnips. Although there are relatively high frequencies of baked clay inside these features, there is little evidence for in situ burning as is found in hearths. The Wilcox sandstone, which comprises most of the fire cracked rock, was probably heated outside of the pits and then placed inside with the plants. The increased baked clay frequencies probably resulted when the heated rock contacted the sandy clay B horizon soil. An explanation for the irregular outline of these features was hypothesized, based on the sotol roasting account. Every time a pit was used for roasting, two episodes of digging were required: one to prepare the pit for the placement of food and heated rocks, and one to uncover the roasted foods. If the same pits were used over and over again, the numerous episodes of redigging would gradually change the shape of the pit since the area excavated each time would never quite match the areas excavated during previous episodes of use. This would cause the pits to grow larger in a variety of directions, producing the asymmetrical patterns observed today. This hypothesis was supported by magnetic data which indicated multiple episodes of reuse (see Chapter 10). FEATURE 38 EXCAVATION Feature 38 was selected as a test case to examine the nature of pit use and hypothesized episodes of reuse. Excavation and analytical strategies were selected to test hypotheses regarding redigging and reuse. It was hypothesized that artifact distributions, both horizontally and vertically, would indicate an erratic pattern reflecting a great degree of disturbance. Fire cracked rock and stone tools would have been redeposited from their original positions along thé pit bottom to points further up in the profile once redigging occurred. Some portions of the pit may have been reused while others remained intact, thereby creating a randomly mixed artifact distribution. To test this hypothesis, finer control of artifact provenience was required than could be obtained in 1 x 1 m units, so unit size was reduced to 50 x 100 cm. Units 423-434 were dug through the center of the pit in 10 cm levels (Figure 4-8). A total of 99 levels was excavated in Feature 38 and all fill was water screened through 6.4 mm mesh. For the purpose of the artifact distribution analysis, only lithic debris and fire cracked rock were present in sufficient quantities to exhibit interpretable trends. The west profile of Feature 38 is shown in Figure 4-9. The distribution of lithic debris is plotted by level along the west profile of Feature 38 in Figure 4-10 and the distribution of fire cracked rock is plotted in Figure 4-11, Lithic debris and fire cracked rock frequencies were grouped into six classes to facilitate comparison. For lithic debris, class 1 contained 0-4 flakes, class 2 contained 5-9 flakes, class 3 contained 10-14 flakes, class 4 contained 15-19 flakes, class 5 contained 20- 24 flakes, and class 6 contained 25-29 flakes per level. For fire cracked rock class 1 contained 1-49 fragments, class 2 contained 50-99 fragments, class 3 contained 100-149 fragments, class 4 contained 150-199 fragments, class 5 contained 200-249 51 meters Figure 4-8. Location of Units 423 through 434 in Feature 38. fragments, and class 6 contained 250-299 fragments per level. High frequency classes 4, 5, and 6 are shaded in Figures 4-10 and 4-11 to provide a clearer view of the variation of artifact distribution. The pattern of artifact distribution visible in Feature 38 shows high density clusters scattered erratically throughout the profile. This pattern is markedly different from that for features that were filled with trash at the time of abandonment. Such features exhibit a dramatic increase in artifact frequencies in the lower levels. It is also markedly different from the pattern observed in the natural soil profile or in features that were merely filled with A horizon soil when abandoned, where there is a gradual decrease in artifact frequency paralleling an increase in depth. Figure 4-10 shows the highest density of lithic debris in the pit (class 6) in level 5 of Unit 429, whereas level 6 has a density of only class 3. Likewise in Unit 431, frequencies drop uniformly from class 5 to class 3 in the upper levels, but then surge up to class 5 in level 4. The frequencies jump back and forth from class 2 to class 4 and back to class 2 in the lower levels. Fire cracked rock frequencies reflect the same trend, with high density clusters occurring at a variety of depths in different units. The pattern of distribution looks as if an episode of redigging occurred in the vicinity of Unit 431, removing some fire cracked rock originally present in the lower levels of Unit 431 and redepositing it in the upper levels of Units 430 and 432. Although this particular interpretation is speculative, it is clear that some disturbance from redigging created the irregular distribution of artifacts found in Feature 38. It is assumed that this pattern is typical of roasting pits in general. Figure 4-12 illustrates profiles of some of the other roasting pits excavated at the site.

Storage pits fell in the small and medium size classes, ranging from .17 to .62 m? in area. They were relatively shallow, ranging in depth from 42 to 56 cm below surface.
