Factors 3 and 4 selected many features with high macrobotanical content situated inside houses. This reflects their function for storing food, as well as the secondary deposition of household items in abandoned storage pits. All of the storage pits recognized had frequencies of macrobotanical remains that indicated foodstuffs had been removed prior to abandonment. The only pit with a definite storage function that contained the original stored items was Feature 5, a cache of tested cobbles found in Feature 1. This feature is described in Chapter 6. DOG BURIALS Content was the sole criterion for assigning features to this class. Dog burials are defined as complete or partially articulated dog skeletons. It is not always possible to determine whether dog remains represent discarded food or intentional interments. For this analysis, disarticulated skeletons are interpreted as refuse from meals, whereas articulated skeletons are classified as dog burials. Several dog burials were found inside Feature 1 (see Chapter 6), but dog burials were also present in two features in the Midden. Figure 4-14 illustrates two dog burials. POST HOLES Size, shape, and spatial patterning were the principal criteria used to assign features to this class. Post holes ranged in size from 100 cm? to 1000 cm? and were circular to oval in plan view. In profile they were parallel sided or tapering and ranged from 45 to 80 cm below surface. Post holes forming house patterns were easily recognized by their regular spacing in circular patterns. Content was the least important criterion for designation of features as post holes. The original contents, wooden posts, had decomposed, so the post hole fill was the result of secondary deposition of household debris. Post holes are illustrated in the last section of this chapter concerning the architecture of Houses 1 through 3. CREMATIONS Content, shape, size, and spatial distribution were all important criteria for identifying cremation burials. Obviously, the principal criterion was the presence of burned human bone. However, most cremations fall within a narrow size and shape range as well. Cremation pits were primarily .30 to .50 m2 in area and were

ARCHITECTURAL STUDIES: HOUSES 1, 2, AND 3 A small hamlet marked by the presence of three structures was uncovered along the crest of the terrace during Seasons II and III at locations predicted by SYMAPs of artifact distributions. In this section, the remains of Houses 1, 2, and 3 are described and . analyzed to explain their method of construction, the arrangement of interior living space, the estimated population of the hamlet, the estimated extent of house occupation, and relationships between these houses and those from the Caddoan and Plains areas. HOUSE DESCRIPTIONS In general, all three houses were very similar to each other in shape and content. All houses were circular, ranging in diameter from a maximum of 7 m for House 1 to a minimum of 5.5 m for House 3. All houses contained large interior support posts arranged in a rectangular or trapezoidal configuration, as well as smaller randomly distributed interior posts. Houses 1 and 3 had central hearths, but House 2 did not have any visible remains ofa hearth. It is possible that a hearth was present in the A horizon which was scraped away by heavy equipment. The lack of storage pits recorded inside Houses 2 and 3, as opposed to the numerous pits within the A horizon inside House 1, is undoubtedly due to the fact that the A horizon was stripped away over Houses 2 and 3, whereas 60% of the A horizon over House 1 was excavated by hand. Some house patterns were more complete that others; for example, all post holes in House 2 were found and mapped, whereas only about 70% of the post holes for House 3 were found. Despite these problems, enough data were gathered to form an understanding of the architecture.

ARCHITECTURAL ANALYSIS The method used to compare regularities among the structures is based on that used by Good (1982) to analyze nine structures at the De Shazo site, a protohistoric Allen phase Caddoan village in Nacogdoches County. Good quantified the distances between wall posts and the distances from the center post to the wall posts, then used the mean distances for both to form a ratio useful for comparison among structures. She discovered that the ratios of mean distance between exterior post holes to mean distance between exterior and center post holes was remarkably similar for all structures, regardless of the differences in size observed among the structures or the variation observed among spacing of exterior posts. The ratios only varied from 1:3.1 to 1:3.8 for all nine structures (Good 1982:65). This indicated that regularity in post hole spacing was based not on standard units of measurement between post holes, but on the radius of the house. The distance between wall posts was slightly greater than 1/3 of the radius, regardless of the size of the house (Good 1982:64). The De Shazo style analysis was selected for use in the architectural studies of Houses 1, 2, and 3 because it quantifies house dimensions, providing results that can be directly compared with De Shazo data to examine possible relationships between Bird Point Island houses and Caddoan houses. Certain modifications in the methodology were required for use with Houses 1, 2, and 3 because they contained support posts arranged in a rectangular pattern rather than a single center post. The results of the post hole analysis indicate a great deal about the nature of construction of houses at Bird Point Island. Trees of roughly uniform diameters were selected for use as posts, with the larger diameter trees used for interior support posts. The interior posts were spaced in a rectangular, or slightly trapezoidal fashion, at a distance from the center of the house equal to 2/3 of the radius. Undoubtedly, cross beams were attached at the top of the posts to form a central support structure for the roof. The smaller wail posts were set in a circular pattern around this support structure, but less attention was paid to exact spacing of these posts. A lattice work of saplings was probably woven among the wall posts to provide a framework for the thatch (the relative lack of baked clay Volume I, Part One around the houses suggests that they were not covered with daub). Finally, a pitched roof was attached from the wall posts sloping upward to the taller support structure (Figure 4-22). It is not possible to reach firm conclusions about the location of the entryway into these houses because so many gaps are present in the post hole patterns. No extended entry ways are present, as are sometimes observed among Caddoan or Plains house styles (Wedel 1979). The relatively continuous post hole pattern observed for House 2, with only one gap, suggests that the entrance may have faced the southwest, where the gap is observed. However, the gap may represent an area where a few post holes were scraped away from a continuous pattern of posts. If short posts were set along the entry way to form a low wall, perhaps 20-30 cm high, then there would be no gap in the post hole pattern and it would be impossible to identify the entrance. This type of entry way has been documented historically in photographs (see Figure 14-2), POPULATION ESTIMATES Archaeologists have long been interested in obtaining estimates of aboriginal populations by developing formulas from modern ethnographic studies and from ethnohistoric accounts. Most studies relate house floor area to the maximum number of people that would fit in this area based on knowledge of the varying needs for personal space among different cultures. Naroll (1962) studied 18 tribes from the Northwest Coast and the Iroquois to conclude that population could be estimated as being equal to one-tenth of the covered floor space. Cook and Heizer (1968) studied California tribes and noted that a minimum area for a family of six was 11.1 m2 (1.8 m2 per person). Wedel (1979) examined the populations of Plains Indian houses by looking at ethnohistoric accounts of Pawnee village populations. He concluded that a figure of 5 m2 per person was a reasonable estimate. Perhaps the best estimates for the houses at Bird Point Island can be derived by looking at ethnohistoric data from tribes that were in the area historically. Ethnographic accounts for the Wichita and the Waco were provided by Captain Randolph Marcy in 1852. The Wichita village was comprised of 42 lodges about 25 ft (7.6 m) in diameter, each containing two families totaling about 10 people (Marcy 1937:125). Wedel (1979) notes that Wichita lodge size remained virtually unchanged since first reported by Ofjate in 1601, so there appears to be great stability in house construction over time. The Waco village contained 20 lodges and about 200 people, again with 10 people per lodge. Lodge size was estimated at 20 to 25 ft (6.1-7.6 m) in diameter, approximately the same size at the Wichita lodges (Kendall 1844). Wedel (1979:96) points out that these population estimates do not differ greatly from the estimates he calculated for Plains groups which had larger lodges. The minimum area per person for the Wichita and Waco appears to have been 4.6 m* per person, whereas Wedel’s estimate is 5 m2 per person. COMPARISON OF ARCHITECTURE WITH CADDOAN AND PLAINS STYLES The house styles of Caddoan and Caddoan-speaking Plains groups are compared with the houses at Bird Point Island in an attempt to discern cultural relationships. While house patterns from a broad geographical area were considered, this is by no means an exhaustive study. The cultural groups selected for this analysis are dll Caddoan-speaking groups and are assumed to be related culturally. Hughes (1968:302) has traced these groups back to a proto-Caddoan group occupying the Mississippi valley around 4000 B.C. and has outlined their spread toward the Plains over time. Thus, it seems likely that cultural relationships existed among these groups and the inhabitants of Bird Point Island. Early Caddoan house patterns from the George C. Davis site were examined (Newell and Krieger 1949) as well as late Caddoan houses from the De Shazo site (Good 1982). Fort Coffee and McCurtain focus houses from Eastern Oklahoma were compared (Wallace 1962) and Plains Indian house styles of the Pawnee were also examined (Wedel 1979). Ideally, houses from other Wylie focus sites located near Dallas should be considered for this comparison. However, examination of the literature shows that few houses have been found: the presence of houses has only been inferred on the basis of baked clay concentrations at sites such as Farmersville on Pilot Grove Creek (Stephenson 1949a:30) and at the Hogge Bridge and Branch sites along the East Fork of the Trinity River (Stephenson 1949a:38-40). A house floor was uncovered in the floodplain at a depth of 36 inches (1 m) at the Campbell Hole site, but only a small cross-sectional area was dug, revealing a hearth but no post holes. The house excavated by the Dallas Archeological Society at the Butler Hole site is documented by a map and descriptions (Figure 4-23). This house was elliptical, measuring 13 feet 7 inches (4.1 m) east-west by 10 feet (3 m ) north-south and contained 51 post holes. Shell tempered, wattle impressed daub was found around the wall of the structure, and there were no interior posts or clear evidence of a hearth (Housewright et al. 1947:9) Thus, it is clear that this house also bears little relation to the houses at Bird Point Island. The Caddoan houses in East Texas are generally circular or subrectangular in shape, and only the circular houses were examined for this comparison. All Caddoan house patterns were comprised of uniformly spaced exterior wail posts and a single central interior post within the hearth at the focus of the circle (Newell and Krieger 1949; Good 1982) (Figure 4-24), Other random interior posts were also observed, probably representing supports for sleeping berths. Ethnohistoric accounts describe men working from the center post, as if it were a ladder or scaffold, to tie the tops of wall posts together, forming the the beehive-shaped house characteristic of Caddo tribes. Once the wall posts were bent and secured at the top to form a sturdy structure, the center post was cut down and a hearth was dug in its location (Swanton 1942). The principal difference between the Caddoan houses and Houses 1, 2, and 3 is that Caddoan houses did not-require interior posts for support. The fact that Houses 1, 2, and 3 all contained interior support posts indicates that the style of architecture was substantially different, with a roof resting on supports rather than wall posts being bent to form the roof. The differences in wall post spacing between the De Shazo houses and Houses 1, 2, and 3 discussed earlier provides additional evidence that the Bird Point Island houses are probably not of East Texas Caddoan origin. One structure out of the 51 clearly identifiable structures at the George C. Davis site bears a resemblance to the structures at Bird Point Island (Figure 4-25). This structure, designated as Feature 125, was located in Unit 10 midway between Mounds B and C. It was a circular structure 7.4 m in diameter comprised of 88 wall posts and four large interior posts arranged in a rectangular pattern around a central hearth (Story 1972:85-87). These interior posts are believed to represent roof supports (Story 1972:86) and suggest an architectural style similar to that observed at Bird Point Island. Despite the general similarities in construction technique, several important differences are also apparent. For instance, Feature 125 has more than twice the number of wall posts than the 40 posts estimated for House 1, even though these structures are approximately the same size. Although the placement of interior posts is very similar, Lower Loup houses are by no means identical to Houses 1, 2, and 3, For example, Lower Loup houses are characterized by extended entrances facing east and an altar containing a bison skull directly opposite the entrance against the west wall. There is also quite a time difference between the two, with Lower Loup houses dating between A.D. 1550 and A.D. 1750 and Houses 1, 2, and 3 dating between A.D. 1000 and 1200. The houses of the Central Plains tradition (ca. A.D. 1000 - 1400), which preceded the Lower Loup phase, were rectangular but also had four interior support posts (Wedel 1979:87). Although this discussion is not a comprehensive treatment of architectural styles, it does point out some major differences and similarities that suggest cultural connections between the inhabitants of Bird Point Island and other groups. Our initial inclination was to seek relationships among Caddoan groups to the east because the pottery types recognized at the site include several Caddoan designs. However, analysis of the architecture provides little link with Caddoan architecture. The only common factor among the Caddoan houses examined and the houses at Bird Point Island is their circular outline. All other characteristics related to the presence or absence of interior posts indicate that Caddoan houses were constructed quite differently from Houses 1, 2, and 3. On the other hand, houses associated with the Plains tribes display similarities with Houses 1, 2, and 3 in regard to interior post arrangement. Although none of the Plains houses examined matched Houses 1, 2, and 3 exactly, more similarities were observed with Plains groups than with Caddoan groups. It may be possible that the occupants of the houses at Bird Point Island were related to the Wichita or Waco, whose lodges were described previously, but no definite cultural connection can be demonstrated at this time. The historic period house shown in Figure 14-2 may be close to the house style found at Bird Point Island. . SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS Including all burials, post holes, features, and organic stains believed to be features, over 500 cultural features were mapped and recorded, and 177 were excavated over the course of four field seasons. The 83 features (including post holes and cremations) containing the most complete data sets were analyzed using factor analysis with varimax rotation as an aid to classification. Twelve factors were isolated by principal components analysis, of which six accounted for most of the variability observed. Factors 1-6 selected features having contents related both to the original use of the features, the degree of secondary deposition obscuring the original function, and the temporal distribution of features. A significant relationship was Velume II, Part One 0 5 — Ges Bs meters N Figure 4-27. Plan view of a Lower Loup house (after Wedel 1979). observed between features loading highly on Factors 1-6 and feature size and shape. All of this information was used in conjunction with spatial information to classify features as hearths, roasting pits, storage pits, dog burials, post holes, cremations, or burials. A detailed analysis of Feature 38 was presented to test hypotheses regarding the possible uses of roasting pits. The results of this analysis indicate that the large irregular pits were used for- roastinig on several occasions over time. , Analysis of Houses 1, 2, and 3 was conducted using a methodology borrowed from Good (1982). The typical house pattern at Bird Point Island is circular, between 5.5 and 7.0 m in diameter, with four interior posts arranged in a rectangular pattern spaced about 2/3 the length of the radius away from the center. A central hearth is present surrounded by storage pits within the Limits of the interior posts and little activity is apparent along the walls. Assuming contemporaneity of structures, the population of the site at the time of house occupation was probably about 20 people, based on Wedel’s (1979) method. Comparison of Houses 1, 2, and 3 with houses of Caddoan and Plains groups shows that methods of construction are more similar to Plains styles than to Caddoan styles of East Texas.

## Page 87

BURIAL DESCRIPTIONS AND OSTEOLOGICAL ANALYSIS by Gary Rutenberg, Maynard B. Cliff, and William A. Martin Osteological analysis provides crucial data for ecologically ori- ented archaeological research. Direct evidence of human/environ- ment interaction is manifested in the skeletal remains of the popula- tion. The degree of adaptation to a specific environment can be assessed by examination of skeletal and dental pathologies, trace elements which reflect dietary intake, and the demographic recon- struction of the skeletal sample. In addition, comparison of anthro- pometric indices among the sexes permits observations to be made about status, the sexual division of labor and population dimorphism in general. This chapter provides a comprehensive analysis of the small and often fragmentary sample of human skeletal remains recovered from Bird Point Island. Although 27 individuals were recovered, 10 were cremated beyond recognition of age or gender and several noncre- mated individuals were represented only by fragments, precluding detailed analysis. As a result, only 11 individuals could be used to provide good anthropometric and pathological data. Despite problems inherent in the small sample size, an attempt is made to address several problems of archaeological interest. First, temporal changes in the principal locations of burials across the site are examined and social implications of these changes are discussed. Next, trends in burial orientation are presented along with a discus- sion of variability in orientation due to seasonality. The level of adaptive fitness of the Bird Point Island population is studied using demographic parameters, such as risk of death among age cohorts, pathological indicators of stress, and the prevalence of skeletal and dental pathologies. Changes in the dietary intake of the population _ over time are addressed using trace element analysis and the pres- ence of dental pathologies such as caries and calculus. Finally, the skeletal population is compared and contrasted with burial data from 65 similar prehistoric burials associated with the Wylie focus of Dallas and Collin Counties. METHODOLOGY Burials were removed from the field with minimal processing (gentle cleaning with a soft brush and water) to prepare skeletons for photographs. The skeletal material was thoroughly cleaned at the laboratory at SMU prior to examination. Friable skeletal remains were stabilized with a solution of duco cement and acetone. When- ever possible, skeletal elements were reconstructed. Anthropometric measurements were taken whenever possible and estimated when necessary. All bones were examined macro- scopically for signs of pathology. In addition, a stereomicroscope was used to search for lesions. Various elements presenting patho- logical anomalies were radiographed and selected long bones were radiographed to determine the presence or absence of Harris Lines. BURIAL DESCRIPTIONS During the testing and subsequent four seasons of intensive exca- vation at Bird Point Island a total of 27 burials was recovered from various portions of the site (Figure 5-1). These burials span all four defined occupation periods for the site and include both primary burials and secondary cremation burials (Table 5-1). Basic data on age, sex, and body orientation for the Bird Point Island burials are © presented in Table 5-2, while Table 5-3 describes each burial indi- vidually in regard to condition, skeletal elements present, and gener- al observations. FEATURE 1 Feature | was initially used as a mortuary during the first inten- sive occupation ofthe site (170 B.c.-A.D. 130). Prior to ap. 1000, the majority of the burials at Bird Point Island were placed in Feature 1, while after ap. 1000 the majority of the burials were interred outside of Feature 1. ie ht of 1e d Osteology bone fragments recovered from cremation contexts are maximally only several centimeters in diameter, and range in color from charred brownish black to dark blue to white (heavily calcined). These char- acteristics indicate that the cremation process took place at a rela- tively high temperature, between 800° and 900° C, for a period of not less than several hours (Geujall 1969). The bones of the cremations are angularly cracked and fractured, indicating that that the body was burned while the soft tissue still covered the skeleton. It has been suggested that cremation was used in the case ofdeaths which occurred away from the site, with the remains subsequently being returned and buried on the site (Prewitt 1974a; Binford 1971). However, this is not the only possible explanation forthe occurrence of cremations. Evidence exists that the cremations at Bird Point Istand were secondary rather than primary interments. For example, Burial 2 was recovered from a shallow bone lens, approximately 75 cm in diameter within Feature 1. The condition of the surrounding soil showed no evidence of in situ baking, suggesting that cremation occurred elsewhere with subsequent burial in Feature 1. A burned projectile point also was found in association with the Burial 2 cre- mation. It may have been the cause of death, a grave offering, or an incidental inclusion. Other cremations at Bird Point Island, while less complete, show similar characteristics of color, bone size, and fracture. patterns. In each of these cases, no evidence indicating in situ cremation was found. It is possible that one or more crematory areas existed on the site where bodies were burned prior to interment. Such features would be expected to show evidence of recurrent firing at a relatively high temperature and might contain isolated human bone fragments from several individuals. Cremation pits dug into the clayey, B horizon would exhibit fire hardened oxidized edges resulting from intensive burning of the sandy clay. No features with these characteristics were identified at Bird Point Island, but this does not mean that they were not present. If crematory areas involved above ground funeral pyres resting atop the A horizon, then we would expect little evi- dence to remain. Experiments conducted during Season II concen- trated on the effects of intensive burning on both A and B horizon soils. Pits weré dug so that one was completely confined to the A horizon and one was well within the B horizon. Intense fires were allowed to burn for several hours and the soil was examined for changes in color and texture after cooling. The clay enriched B hori- zon became fire hardened and exhibited a reddish oxidized color. On the other hand, the A horizon tumed a dark black and was only slight- ly hardened. By the time the site was revisited during Season III, the A horizon hearth had been completely obliterated whereas the B horizon hearth was still visible. It is unlikely, then, that any crematory area confined to the A horizon would have been preserved at the site. The evidence presented here demonstrates that no cremations occurred in pits dug into the B horizon because no pits exhibiting fire hardened oxidized surfaces were found. Thus two possibilities are left for consideration: either individuals were cremated on the ground surface at the site and no archaeological evidence remains, or the individuals were cremated somewhere away from the site. Due tothe sedentary nature of occupation between ap. L000 and 1200, the former possibility seems more likely. BURIAL ORIENTATION The primary burials previously recovered from Wylie focus sites were characteristically found with an east-west head orientation. This east-west orientation is less clear for the Bird Point Island burials. Figure 5-2 summarizes the orientation data from Bird Point Island along with data from burials found at Wylie focus sites 69 One point per individual sworeeraavees Bled Point [siaad Sample -—_——— Wylie focus (East Fork) Samgie Combined Sample Figure 5-2. Burial orientation of the Bird Point Island sample, the Wylie focus sample, and both samples combined. (Lynott 1975) and graphically illustrates an overall trend toward an east-west axis of orientation. Although deviations do occur, with some individuals oriented in all of the cardinal directions, most burials cluster along the east and south axes. Turner’s (1978) work on burial orientation from the Tuck Carpenter site, a Titus focus site in Northeast Texas, demonstrates a rigid pattern in which all burials are oriented east to west. However these burials were extended rather than flexed, unlike the majority from Bird Point Island. Other Caddoan sites reviewed by Turner demonstrate variability of orien- tation; although many, especially those of the Frankston, McCur- tain, Sanders, and Allen foci, are characterized by a similar strong affinity towards an east to west orientation. An examination of slight variations in orientation away from the east to west alignment suggested to Turner that upwards of 80% of the burials (hence deaths) occurred between September 21 (autum- nal equinox) and March 21 (spring equinox) (Turmer 1978:49-55). Furthermore, he suggested a bimodal distribution of deaths during this period with peaks in October and February. Doubtless, seasonal skewing of deaths occurred, exacerbated by harsh weather and food scarcity, but the degree to which seasonality of death is concentrated within only a few months may not be as great as he suggests. BIRD POINT ISLAND DEMOGRAPHICS The structure of a prehistoric population in regard to its composi- tion by age and sex can yield valuable insights into the nature of its lifestyle and its adaptation to the environment with which it interacts. Observations of the sex ratio and age at death can provide informa- tion regarding life expectancy, general health and morbidity, and overall population structure. These data can, in turn, allow other inferences to be made about status, division of labor, migration, and population growth. Age and sex determinations were made macroscopically and through the use of metric comparisons with other known skeletal samples from the North Central Texas area (Navey 1975; Westbury 1978). Sex determination was made using cranial and pelvic mor- phology (Krogman 1962; Bass 1971; Ascadi and Nemereski 1970) and postcranial anthropometrics (Steele and McKerm 1969; Olivier 1969). Age determination in subadults was made by examination of epiphyseal closure (Krogman 1962; Bass 1971) and dental devel- opment (Shour and Massler 1941; Ubelaker 1978). Adult age deter- mination was estimated from the degree of dental attrition (Broth- well 1965), cranial suture closure (Krogman 1962) and skeletal degeneration (Ubelaker 1978).

Life tables are constructed using specified age (and often, sex) categories (cohorts) to represent the risk of death to various segments of the population. The burials from Bird Point Island were classified into the following age cohorts: 0-1, 1-5, 5-15, 15-20, 20-25, 25-35, 35—45, and greater than 45 years (Table 5-4). The 0-1 cohort (neonatal) is a period of high mortality risk. The following two cohorts (1-5 and 5-15) were established to represent periods of decreasing juvenile and adolescent mortality. The post- adolescent cohorts (15-20 and 20-25) were established to represent a high risk period of mortality for females giving birth and males who would be more active in high risk activities. The subsequent adult age cohorts were subdivided into 10-year intervals. As was true in earlier studies of the burial sample from the Rich- land Creek area, there was an underrepresentation of individuals in the 0-1 year age cohort of the life table (Rutenberg 1982). The lack of an appreciable number of infants in the sample may be due to the generally poor preservation of their skeletal remains. Mobley (1980) pointed out that infants, and taking the idea one step further, fetal deaths, may be considerably underrepresented in burial populations from archaeological sites. This may be due largely to the incomplete ossification of bone at the time of death, and the subsequent poor preservation of the existing boney remains. Ethnographic evidence from various pre- or proto-agricultural societies suggests that the probability of infant mortality may be as high as 20 to 40% of all births (Weiss 1973). There is no evidence within the pit for preferen- tial burial (by gender, age or status) and hence, no reason to believe that infants were buried elsewhere. Assuming that the pit was recog- nized and utilized as a cemetery during the first period (170 B.c.-a.D. 130), the substantial disturbance found within Feature 1 at Bird Point Island may, in part, be a reflection of unpreserved infant buri- als. Mobley’s response to this problem was to correct the early age cohorts by inputting a proportionate number of individuals, usually 20-25% of the total adult sample, and recalculating the appropriate life table results. Table 5-4 uses a number equal to 25% of the total adult sample, a value which is consistent if not conservative with known prehistoric populations, to standardize the 0-1 year cohort. The previous life tables computed for the Richland Creek popula- tions also used this estimate (Rutenberg 1982, 1983). No significant difference in the sex ratio at death was found for the Bird Point Island sample as a whole. However, it should be remem- bered that the sample at hand is small and subject to statistical bi- ases. No appreciable change in the aggregate life table statistics were noted when compared with the results of previous studies (Rutenberg 1982, 1983). Unfortunately, the small size of the Bird Point Island sample does not allow us to fine tune subtle differences by time period. The life table construction for the total sample of burials from Bird Point Island tended to follow Weiss’s (1973) 20:60 model, in which life expectancy at age 15 (e15) is 20 additional years and only 60% of the original cohort born are still alive. The survivorship curve for the total Bird Point Island sample (Figure 5-3) shows a strong resem- blance, even to the point of partially overlying it, to the curve calcu- lated for the sample of burials from Wylie focus sites along the East Fork of the Trinity River (Navey 1975). It is difficult to say how valid the Bird Point Island mortality pat- tern actually is. However, this pattern and those from Wylie focus sites tend to show the lowest mortality when they are compared to other prehistoric cultures (Figure 5-3). In this connection, it must be remembered that 0 age cohort values (d) have been adjusted to re- flect approximately 25% of all deaths occurring in this age cohort. Furthermore, it should be recalled that a large number of cremated remains, upwards of 40% of the total sample, was recovered from this site. PALEOPATHOLOGY The health status of a population is a reflection of its adaptation to its immediate environment. Stresses such as overcrowding and food scarcity may manifest themselves as disease processes. The result of ’ such stresses is reflected through skeletal trauma, infection, endo- crine or metabolic disease processes, tumerous growth, or congenital malformation. The conditions can be subdivided further into acute or Volume II, Part One chronic disease, with chronic disease more likely to affect the skele- ton. Occupational stresses can lead to degenerative osteoarthritis, trauma, or infection, while changing subsistence strategies and/or division of labor may lead to gender or age differences in the occur- rence of such diseases. The skeletal remains from Bird Point Island were examined ma- croscopically for lesions and microscopically with the aid of a stereoscopic scope (7-40X magnification). Radiography was used to examine pathological lesions and for selected long bones to deter- mine the presence or absence of Harris Lines. Harris Lines are radiographically dense areas of trabeculla, usually found towards the articular ends of long bones and formed at right angles to the tubular diaphysis, or shaft, ofthe long bone. A tabulation of several general disease categories by age cohort at death can be found in Table 5-8. These categories are: (1) arthritis, generalized degenerative boney changes inclusive of articular sur- faces and vertebral bodies; (2) osteitis or periostitis, generalized boney changes of the endosteum, cortical bone, or combinations of the two (the etiology of osteitis is often nonspecific; the cause of the inflammation may be due to a systemic chronic disease, or to an acute cause, affecting only a small portion of the skeletal system); and (3) trauma, specific boney changes due to violence, force, or accident which result in a localized boney lesion. These categories demonstrate some interesting patterns. As can be seen from Table 5- 8, periostitis and trauma occur most frequently in the 26 to 35 year cohort. This may be associated with greater risks of injury from oc- cupational stresses (Ortner and Putchar 1981; Steinbock 1976). The two instances of osteoarthritis are not severe and are not re- stricted to a single age cohort. Instead, they are evenly divided be- tween the two cohorts from 26 to 45 years. This arthritis may be due largely to normal wear and tear of the connective tissue. Unfortunately, when these data are broken down by period of site occupation, no gross temporal trends can be discerned. During the 1703.c. to A.D. 130 period, two skeletons showed traces of periostitis (B9/11 and B15) and two showed evidence of arthritis (B3 and B15). During a.p. 1000-1200, periostitis was observed on the remains of Burial 13; while Burial 16 revealed evidence of the same condition during the period between a.p. 1300-1650. The higher frequency of both conditions during 170 8.c. to A.D. 130 is probably simply the re- flection of a larger sample of preserved, primary burials from this occupation rather than any actual reflection of a poorer standard of health. Dating between 170 B.c. and av. 130, Burial 15 showed pro- nounced periostitis of unknown origin on the femora, tibiae, and fibu- lae. This condition was characterized by a dense proliferation of longitudinally woven bone over the original cortical surface. Slight to moderate vertebral osteoarthritis was also observed in this skeleton. Dating to this same period, Burial 18 had slight to moderate verte- bral osteoarthritis. Burial 9/11, also dating to the first occupation, demonstrates slight to moderate periostitis on both tibiae and both fibulae, but the right tibia presented the most severe cortical change (Figure 5-4). Several elongated islands of dense compact bone overlay the original cortical bone midshaft on the right tibia, representing a possible ossi- fied subperiosteal hemorrhage (cf., Saul 1972). This condition occurs when blood flowing between the bone surface and the peri- osteum, due to trauma or vitamin deficiencies, becomes infiltrated with osteocytes and subsequently calcifies. The left fibula presents a thickened area with moderate periostitis at the midshaft. The margin of the anterior crest corresponding to the origin of m. extensor digi- torum longus abruptly changes, travelling obliquely laterally through the region of periosteal bone thickening, then downward to an area of normal cortical bone. Radiographic analysis indicates that the me- dullary cavity follows this same curvature and then resumes its normal path downward, providing a strong indication of an old, healed greenstick fracture (Figure 5-5). Cranial anomalies, suchas a flattening at lambda, suggest possible antemortem cranial deforma- tion (Bass 1971; Brothwell 1972). Premature fusion of the left coronal suture has occurred, but no concomitant cranial asymmetry was found. Burial 16, which appears to date between a.p. 1300 and ap. 1650, has slight nonlocalized periostitis of unknown origin on the tibiae and femorae while Burial 8 possesses a well defined instance of traumatic osteoarthritis upon the left scapula. This is characteriz- ed by granular pitting and anterior enlargement of the glenoid cavity, possibly due to chronic dislocation (Figure 5-6). The head of the left humerus was too poorly preserved to determine if concomitant func- tional changes had occurred on this bone. The cause of this patholo- gy may be due to partial dislocation or recurrent subluxation of the humerus. The result would be chronic irritation of the cartilage stim- ulating a hypertrophic bone response (Ortner and Putchar 1981; Steinbock 1976). An alternative explanation is joint irritation due to a rupture of the supraspinatus tendon or the musculotendenous cuff. A rupture of this kind is a relatively common occurrence and may be caused when an arm is used to cushion a fall (Raney and Brashear 1971). DENTAL PATHOLOGY Dental pathologies are not uncommon in the sample from Bird Point Island (Table 5-9). Pathologies which were found included: (1) dental calculus or tartar, a mineral deposit which forms in varying degrees along the gingival line, (2) dental caries, cavities in the enamel, (3) abscesses, localized lesions of the bone surrounding the tooth, usually due to infection, (4) enamel hypoplasia, horizontal striations of the tooth enamel which form during enamel histogene- sis, and (5) hypercementosis, abnormal deposits of cementum upon the root portion of the tooth, often related to unusual stresses upon that tooth. All individuals exhibited slight amounts of calculus, hy- percementosis, and enamel hypoplasia. Most adults had consider- able enamel attrition or tooth loss. Dental pathology is strongly related to changes in diet. Increasing dependence on grains, usually as a result of agriculture, may lead to general increases in the incidence of caries and dental calculus. Diets rich in meats, on the other hand, may act as natural cleansers, remov- ing the minerals and residues which may form calculus or lead to dental caries (cf., Cohen and Armelagos 1984). In this connection, the dental data from Bird Point Island are somewhat equivocal. Hypoplasia and hypercementosis are present only during 170 B.c. to AD. 130; while abscesses occur only in this and the next (a.p. 580- 860) period. Only caries and calculus are frequent enough to even hint at significant patterns through time, and they seem to contradict each other. TRACE ELEMENT ANALYSIS An increasingly common analytical technique to identify dietary influences on prehistoric populations is trace element analysis. Shifts in proportional frequencies of trace elements in the bone can be directly related to changing dietary patterns or food preferences. Five trace elements were examined as indicators of diet in the Bird Point Island population: iron (Fe), calcium (Ca), zine (Zn), manga- nese (Mn), and strontium (Sr) (Angel 1984; Roosevelt 1984). Trace element analysis was carried out using a nondestructive X- tay fluorescence technique: Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX). Samples taken for this study were irradiated at 20,000 KEV for 100 seconds. The result is a characteristic curve, which has various dual spikes representing the presence of specific trace elements. The first and taller spike (Kal) represents the loosely held electrons of the given element, while the second spike (Kf 1) represents the inner core of electrons for the given element (Gill King 1985, personal communication). Counts for this study were taken from the first of these two peaks, from which a normalized count value was estimated by obtaining the ratio of the specific element count against the maxi- mum y-value for the curve. This resulted in values which represented amaximum of 10,000 counts and which could be more readily com- pared between individuals. As can be seen from Table 5-10, with a few exceptions to be dis- cussed later, iron levels appear to show a steady increase through time. Strontium shows no clear trend, although when mean levels are computed for each period, there is a slight increase around A.D. 1000 in comparison with the levels from earlier periods. Manganese shows a definite increase after A.D. 1000 as well, while zinc does not show an increase until after a.p. 1300. Manganese has been found to be correlated with an increased dietary dependence upon grains, in- cluding Zea mays. On the other hand, zinc is related to increased meat in the diet. Variations in zinc levels may also be an indicator of growth, revealed by increases in zinc, or wound healing, indicated by depletions of zinc. Variability in the proportions of these trace ele- ments may also be exacerbated by diets rich in nuts. Nuts contain large amounts of zinc, manganese, copper, and strontium. In addi- tion, zinc and manganese are both subject to leaching from the bone matrix in acidic soils. In some of the female burials, notably Burial 13 and Burial 15, calcium levels seem to be depressed, while iron levels are almost twice the norm of the other burials. Elsewhere in the Richland Creek area, similar values are found for a female from 41FT161B (Burial 2) and one male from 41NV179 (Burial 2). One possible explana- tion for the differences specific to the female sample may be that these represent pregnant or lactating women (Burial 2 at 41NV179 is the only male with these aberrant values). CONCLUSIONS SUMMARY OF RESULTS The analysis of burial data from the Bird Point Island site has sig- nificantly contributed to our understanding of the prehistory of this important archaeological site, despite the relatively small sample of burials. Some of the most critical results occur in relation to the tem- poral patterning of cultural and dietary practices revealed by the burial data, The changes in burial location and interment procedures that occurred around a.p. 1000 may mark changes in social organ- ization. One of the more valuable results of the work at Bird Point Island is the identification of Feature 1 as an early mortuary feature (see Chapter 6). Based on dating of the burials, Feature 1 was apparently almost the sole cemetery location for the Bird Point Island communi- ty prior to A.D. 1000. After a.p. 1000, radical changes occurred in burial location and treatment. The preferred burial area ceased to be Feature 1, and cremation became the preferred method of interment. The majority of the burials during the a.p. 1000-1200 period were located in the North portion of the site in close proximity to several posthole structures which have been interpreted as houses (see Chapter 4). Burial of deceased family members close to or within their former dwelling is a common pattern exhibited by sedentary groups over much of North America, and indeed over much of the world. There is enough variation in burial treatment, especially in regard to the continued placement of noncremated burials in the former cemetery area, Feature 1, to suggest that differences in status characteristic of social ranking may have been reflected in mortuary patterns. However, the data remain equivocal due to the inability to age and sex the cremations. The results of the osteological analyses combine to suggest a sig- nificant difference between health, physical status, and diet of the earlier inhabitants of Bird Point Island (170 B.c. to AD. 130 and pos- sibly A.D. 580-860) in comparison with the occupants of the site during the later periods (post-a.p. 1000). The anthropometric data indicate a decrease in both male and female stature when the sample from the 170 B.c. to A.D. 130 period is compared with that from after A.D. 1300. In the area of skeletal pathology, no temporal trends can be discerned for the Bird Point Island sample. In regard to dental pathology, the frequency of dental calculus is higher after ap. 1300 in comparison with the 170 B.c. to A.D. 130 occupation, while the frequency of caries may remain the same or actually decrease. Both of these characteristics are related to the frequency of meat versus grain in the diet; both are expected to rise in frequency with increased dependence on grain in the diet. As presented in Chapter 9, the only corn present at the site dates after ap. 1300. The data from the trace element analysis is more complete and several strong temporal trends can be noted. The level of iron shows asteady increase through time, manganese increases after a.p. 1000, while zinc increases after a.p. 1300. Calcium levels remain relative- ly constant, while strontium may show a slight increase after a.p. 1000 on an average basis. Manganese is related to the amount of grain, such as maize, in the diet, while zinc levels often increase with ahigher proportion of meat in the diet. Both of these elements, as well as strontium, can be gained from a diet rich in nuts. All of this data taken together suggests dietary and health differ- ences during the a.p. 1300 to 1650 period possibly related to a par- tial reliance on maize agriculture. The dental data, while admittedly somewhat equivocal, still tend to support the presence of maize agriculture at this time, although overall dental health did not decline as would otherwise be expected. Unfortunately, none of these data gives us any indication of whether or not agriculture was present at Bird Point Island earlier than a.p. 1300. The trace element analysis, however, seems to suggest that some nutritional changes had occurred as early as a.D. 1000. However, despite extensive flotation of feature fills, no agricultural evidence has been encountered for this period (see Chapter 4). The jump in manganese levels at around A.D. 1000 would seem to suggest the introduction of grain agriculture at that time, but a contemporary, although minor, increase in average levels of strontium may indicate that an increased reliance on nuts is actually the cause of both changes. Finally, by a.p. 1300, the trace element data strongly suggest a high proportion of meat in the diet, as shown by high levels of zinc, and a continuing reliance on nuts and grains, probably.due in part to agriculture judging from the anthro- pometric and paleopathological data mentioned above. One anom- aly is the unaccountably low level of manganese for Burial 16. The fact that this individual was apparently a female raises the possibility of gender related status differences being manifest in dietary practices. Unfortunately, the small sample of late burials prevents this from being much more than a suggestion at this point. ## Page 99

Ine he us Osteology excavated burials from the surrounding region. Her discussion indicated that a majority of the burials demonstrated both physical and pathological characteristics common to agricultural popula- tions. In other words, she found considerable periostitis of all forms, including osteitis and sub-periosteal hemorrhaging, and probable evidence of dental calculus (the original may have been inad- vertantly removed during the cleaning process). A critical difference between her sample and the present one is the absolute control of both horizontal and vertical provenience, with resultant firm dating controls, for the burials found within Feature | at Bird Point Island. She indicates that many burials in her sample may be more recent individuals who would have more likely been reliant upon agri- culture. Conversely, a large number of the complete burials from Bird Point Island were found in the lower, and earlier, levels of the pit. Rose (1984) notes that the impact of ariculture, specifically of maize agriculture in the Lower Mississippi area, may have actually decreased the general well-being of given populations. This obser- vation has been reiterated by numerous workers examining skeletal remains from other maize producing areas (cf., Cohen and Armel- agos 1984). A dependence upon agriculture in any region is an ecological paradox. On one end of the spectrum, domesticated culti- gens are a fairly dependable and productive food resource during optimal climatic periods. However, these cultigens may require greater population numbers to efficiently produce adequate food stores. This leads to increasing population size and population pres- sure. Furthermore, increases in population may increase the poten- tial reservoir for infectious disease with a net result of increased population morbidity. This has been continually demonstrated by increases in the incidence of pathological skeletal change: periostitis, osteitis, trauma, infection and periodontal disease. Finally, occupa- tional stresses related to agriculture may increase the incidence of arthritic change. Four factors have been shown to influence local subsistence in a given area. These are: (1) biomass, (2) climate, (3) geographical con- straints, and (4) general distribution of resources. Because these may vary from region to region, interregional changes may occur at dif- ferent rates, if at all. Rose (1984) has noted five general ecological trends which occurred in the Lower Mississippi Valley: (1) Late Archaic semisedentism; (2) knowledge of agricultural technology, 77 evidenced by native cultigens, which preceded maize agriculture; (3) general increases in population density with time: (4) food storage prior to widespread maize agriculture; (5) the widespread imple- mentation of maize agriculture within a narrow time period in the Lower Mississippi Valley. These changes, however, did not necessarily occur in all areas, and the degree to which these changes did occur in any single area was limited by the ecological constraints mentioned above. As an example, Rose notes that as late as a.p. 1200-1400, the skeletal evidence indicates that maize was not widely accepted in the Lower Mississippi Valley. The situation with regard to agriculture in the Late Prehistoric period of North Central Texas may be demonstrative of this. Navey (1975), and Huff and Biggs (1963) noted that skeletal remains from the Late Prehistoric Wylie focus were affected by large degrees of | periostitis and periodontal disease. However, the individuals from Bird Point Island have less severe and fewer skeletal pathologies. Two possibilities exist to explain these differences. The first follows Rose’s suggestion to the effect that the adoption of maize agriculture was not equally embraced by all groups in North Central Texas, pos- sibly due to local ecological insufficiencies. This model finds support in the Richland Creek area from the abundant meat resources, the ready availability of native plant sources, specifically nuts and Psoralea, and the low population density of the region. Finally, al- though maize has been recovered from Bird Point Island, it has not >een found in large quantities. Another possibility to account for the differences found between the present sample and other skeletal samples from the area may be. that they are derived from distinctly different time periods. In this regard, it must be kept in mind that excavations in other sites desig- nated as Wylie focus have been less exhaustive than the present work. Furthermore, the provenience of many of the previously re- covered burials has been poorly documented. In this connection, it should be noted that burials from the uppermost parts of the Feature 1 pit at Bird Point Island, as well as those from outside of Feature I which are generally more recent, tend to have somewhat higher inci- - dences of periostitis and have distinctly higher percentages of dental disease, including calculus. Thus, the burials from other sites, collec- tively referred to as Wylie focus sites, may be largely contempora- neous with the more recent burials at Bird Point Island.

FEATURE 1: THE LARGE DEPRESSION by William A. Martin and James E. Bruseth Feature 1 is the largest and most complex cultural feature at Bird Point Island, measuring approximately 17 m north-south by 13 m east-west and 2.2 m deep at the center. It was visible as a shallow depression on the ground surface along the western slope of the terrace, similar to the depressions reported at 12 sites along the East Fork of the Trinity River. The sites along the East Fork were attributed to the Wyiie focus by Stephenson (1949a). He characterized the Wylie focus as having large circular pits, pottery related to the Henrietta, Sanders, and Frankston foci, and flexed burials in poorly defined burial pits which lacked grave goods (Stephenson 1949b:305). As a result, large pits such as Feature 1 have been referred to in the literature as "Wylie focus pits" (Suhm et al. 1954; Lynott 1975; Raab 1982). This terminology is avoided here because it carries with it several cultural implications beyond the presence of a pit. Part III of this volume discusses the usefulness of the Wylie focus as a culture-historical construct, whereas this chapter simply describes the excavations inside the pit and presents the results of the analysis. The importance of Feature 1 for understanding site chronology cannot be overemphasized. Feature 1 was the only portion of the site where interpretable cultural stratigraphy was visible, The zones of Feature 1 pit fill were radiocarbon dated, thereby providing chronological information about artifacts and features within the pit which was critical for interpreting similar materials found elsewhere on the site. Since previous work within the "Wylie focus pits” along the East Fork had been quite limited, primarily confined to backhoe excavation (Ross 1966; Lynott 1975), the excavation at Bird Point Island provided a unique opportunity to study these enigmatic pits. The purpose of this chapter is to describe all pertinent data recovered from Feature 1, including stratigraphy, cultural features, burials, cremations, and artifact distributions. The ultimate goal is to provide an interpretation of pit utilization and the ways in which utilization changed over time. 79 SAMPLING AND EXCAVATION STRATEGIES During the testing program at Bird Point Island, the depression was tested rapidly by bisecting it with a backhoe trench to determine whether it was a natural erosional area or a cultural feature (McGregor et al. 1982). The profile of the backhoe trench and the presence of burials demonstrated that the depression was of cultural origin rather than the result of erosion, and it was labeled Feature 1. During mitigation Season I, excavations were conducted in the southwest quarter of the pit (Figure 6-1). The Season I excavation strategy was designed to excavate to the bottom of the pit in as many units as possible so that profiles extending from the center of the pit out to the rim could be examined and artifact frequency comparisons could be made among the strata observed. Only by reaching the bottom could the aboriginal construction of the pit and subsequent fill episodes be understood. An attempt was also made to open up a broad area, to expose a wide range of features and artifact concentrations that might yield insights into the function of the pit. Excavation preceeded in arbitrary levels rather than stratigraphic layers because the stratigraphy was extremely difficult to follow, and it was impossible to isolate discrete layers of cultural deposition. The stratigraphy was due to both cultural deposition and the natural effects of pedogenic processes such as leaching and bioturbation. Arbitrary levels provided the best means of maintaining control over vertical provenience and allowed the volume excavated to be calculated easily. The uppermost levels of Units 88 through 92 were dug in increments of 10 cm, but levels below 30 cm were excavated in 20 cm increments to increase the progress of the excavation and insure that the bottom of the pit would be reached by the end of Season I. This strategy succeeded, exposing the bottom of Feature 1 in these units during the final week of field work.

Soil samples were analyzed for the following chemical parameters: pH, total phosphorus (P), total calcium carbonate (CaCo), and total iron (Fe); in addition, levels of organic matter (O.M.) and organic carbon (O.C.) were assessed. Thirty-four of the samples were analyzed for soil particle size. Samples were extracted at 10 cm intervals from four vertical soil columns located in Units 88, 89, and 92 (McIntyre and Janak 1982:342). Osteological, faunal, and macrobotanical analyses were conducted on materials recovered from the pit, and tentative conclusions were derived about pit function. During the Archaic period, Feature 1 was thought to have been used solely as a cemetery, whereas it appeared to have been used for trash discard during the final occupation. Additional excavation was conducted during Season III to obtain a larger sample of features which might illustrate the range of activities that were conducted within the pit. Previous excavations indicated that male burials were predominant, so it was suggested that Feature 1 may have served originally as a special cemetery for high-status males. A larger sample of burials was required to test this hypothesis and to provide osteological evidence related to genetic or subsistence changes over time. A larger sample of radiocarbon dates from within Feature 1 was also required to refine chronological interpretation. The additional excavation conducted during Season III also provided a more complete sample of artifacts than that recovered during Season I because material was recovered by means of water screening rather than dry screening. Also, Season III excavations provided the only reliable data on the distribution of fire cracked rock, since the Wilcox sandstone comprising the majority of this class was not collected during Season I. Once the importance of this artifact category was recognized for the interpretation of other large irregular features (see Chapter 4), a comparable sample was required to adequately interpret the function of Feature 1. Units 401-404, were placed in a direct line with Units 88-92 to provide a complete profile through the center of the pit (see Figure 6-1). This permitted a view of the stratigraphic profile across the entire length of the feature, providing a better view of the entire fill sequence. PEDOLOGICAL INTERPRETATION OF PIT STRATIGRAPHY Mr. Edward Janak, Jr., Regional Soil Scientist for the USDA Soil Conservation Service, examined the profile of Feature 1 and helped isolate three major soil zones. The uppermost layer was designated as Zone 1, the middle layer was labeled Zone 2, and the bottom layer was designated as Zone 3. The undisturbed C horizon beneath the culturally disturbed layers was designated as Zone 4 (see Figure 6-2). It must be noted here that the specific locations where the boundaries between Zones 1-3 were drawn are not considered to be the exact points where zones are separated. The mixed nature of the fill and the diffuse boundaries caused by leaching make it impossible to define precise boundaries. The term zone is used here rather than stratum because there is no true stratigraphy in the traditional sense of gradual accumulation of distinct soil layers like those found on floodplain sites. The divisions of Zones 1-3 illustrated in Figure 6-2 provide a best estimate of zone differentiation based on color and texture variation. Radiocarbon dates and artifact distributions discussed later in this chapter are used to examine the accuracy of the zone boundaries. The east profile formed by Units 88-92 and Units 401-404 is illustrated in the upper half of Figure 6-2. The profile of Backhoe Trench Unit 25 is illustrated in the lower half. Since these three distinct zones were not recognized during testing (only Zone 1 was clearly mapped), the lower portion of the bottom profile is labeled as Zone 2 and 3 in Figure 6-2. In addition, it was impossible to differentiate Zones 1 and 2 in Units 402 through 404 in the upper Volume IH, Part One profile, so this portion is labeled as Zone 1 and 2. Zone 1 is comprised of fine sandy loam and is the most striking aspect of this profile, being characterized by a dark midden layer within the upper 40-80 cm of the pit. This dark soil (10YR3/1) is virtually nonexistent in undisturbed settings with similar parent material, relief, vegetation, and climate, and is directly relatable to human occupation and the addition of tremendous amounts of organic matter resulting from human behavior. The plow zone is slightly lighter in color than the underlying part of Zone 1. This is most likely due to recent plowing. Disturbance by tillage tends to accelerate the oxidation of organic matter, resulting in a lighter soil color. The plow zone (0-21 cm) is a dark grayish brown (10YR3/3) with a mean pH of 6.1, The remainder of Zone 1 (21- 80 cm) is a very dark gray (10YR3/1) with a mean pH of 5.8. However, the midden color fades to a very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) in Units 403 and 404 at the north end of the pit, suggesting that most refuse was discarded toward the center and south end of the pit (McIntyre and Janak 1982:352). Zone 2 is comprised primarily of very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) and dark grayish brown (10YR3/3) fine sandy loam sediments with lighter colored disturbances ranging from 10YR4/3 to 10YR5/4. Zone 2 is separated from Zone 1 by a gradual, smooth boundary and is separated from Zone 3 by a gradual, diffuse boundary. Zone 2 varies in depth from about 40 cm to almost 160 cm in places and has a mean pH of 5.8. It is a very uneven layer with its thickness ranging from only 10 cm in Unit 91 to a maximum of 90 cm in Unit 88. Zone 2 differs from Zone 3 in its darker soil color and higher concentration of iron, both of which apparently leached out of Zone 1. In fact, Zones 2 and 3 may represent a single fill episode in which soil color and changes in chemical composition have affected only the upper portion of the fill, creating the impression of two separate layers. Due to the lighter color of the Zone 1 midden in Units 403 and 404, it is impossible to distinguish Zone 1 from Zone 2 in these units. Zone 3 is highly variable with respect to depth; the upper boundary of Zone 3 is only 70 cm below surface in Unit 91, whereas it is 135 cm below surface in unit 89. Zone 3 is characterized by a jumbled mixture of soil colors, including: brown (10YR4/3), yellow (10YR7/6), yellowish brown (10YR5/4), and even yellowish red (SYR5/8). In addition to variation in color, Zone 3 is very heterogeneous with respect to texture and has characteristics which suggest that it was part of the Bt (argillic) horizon of the original undisturbed soil profile. Structural development, which is not present in the other layers, is readily apparent in Zone 3. The structural units are coated by thin patchy clay films, a property which is diagnostic of argillic horizons. The sandy clay loam texture and the yellowish brown color with yellowish red mottles are typical of those observed in the argillic horizons of the soils surrounding the pit area. The boundary between Zone 3 and the undisturbed C horizon subsoil is irregular, but quite abrupt. The original bedded terrace sands are clearly visible in this undisturbed soil layer and are characterized by a wider variety of colors than found in the feature fill including miscellaneous shades of yellow-brown, white and reddish brown (McIntyre and Janak 1982:352). The bottom of the pit is easily distinguished by the contact of the randomly mixed fill with the uniformly stratified material below the pit. In addition, a fairly continuous zone of reddish staining occurs directly above and roughly parallel to the undisturbed terrace sediments. This is most likely due to deposition of iron by water percolating downward through the backfill material. The difference in pore size of the stratified sediments interrupted the free movement of the water, causing it to perch above the contact, allowing iron that had been leached from the materials above to accumulate in the perched water zone (McIntyre and Janak 1982:354), The irregular undulating bottom of the pit probably reflects extensive rodent burrowing activity. Numerous rodent burrows were observed within Zone 3, where darker soil from the upper zones filtered down to fill in the burrows. It is likely that older burrows are completely obliterated by recent ones and that the: level of disturbance in the feature is greater than the profile smawweroenresnesaaren reakrgan et el ee

In addition, rodent gnawing marks were observed on most burials, further indicating the degree of disturbance caused by this form of bioturbation. Extremely high pocket gopher activity has been documented in sandy soils along the Brazos River (Buechner 1942) and it is probable that similar levels of activity occurred within the sandy loam fill of Feature 1 and the sandy C horizon sediments below the feature. The soils data obtained by visual observation and laboratory analysis support the second hypothesis. The appearance of the backfill material in Feature 1 suggests that little, if any, selectivity was used in choosing the materials. Intermingled fragments of genetic horizons from the original soil profile are evident throughout the backfill, and occur randomly with no observable pattern. This suggests that the materials that were excavated were stockpiled, then backfilled unselectively. Backfilling most likely occurred as a single event rather than as a succession of events with any appreciable time between them, since there is no observable evidence of silt laminations or organic matter accumulation in the bottom layer of feature fill. These phenomena would probably be observable had significant time elapsed between a succession of backfilling events or had the pit been left open for any appreciable length of time. Organic enrichment of feature fill is limited to the upper 80 cm of feature fill (Zone 1) which formed gradually as a result of colluvial deposition of surrounding A horizon soil. Laboratory analysis of chemical composition and soil particle size provides additional information concerning the processes responsible for the creation of Zones 1 through 3. The natural soil profile resulting from pedogenic processes has the following chemical characteristics. Reaction (pH) is neutral to slightly acid at the surface and gradually decreases with depth. Iron and phosphorus are fairly mobile in a slightly acid medium and tend to accumulate in horizons with high cation exchange capacity, such as horizons with high clay or organic matter content. Calcium carbonate is highly soluble and leaches downward to accumulate at depths below 2 m. Organic matter is concentrated along the surface and gradually decreases with depth. Soil particle size varies within the sequence of A, Bt, and C horizons. Surface (A) horizons are fine sandy loam ranging from 25 to 37 cm in thickness, underlain by an argillic (Bt) horizon that is sandy clay loam in texture (McIntyre and Janak 1982:341). Disturbance and rearrangement of the profile by excavation, stockpiling soil, and backfilling disrupts the natural chemical and soil particle properties of the soil. As a result, chemical properties and soil particles sizes should be randomly distributed throughout the profile if prehistoric excavation and backfilling occurred. Examination of Figures 6-3, 6-4, and 6-5 shows that the distribution of chemicals is noticeably erratic from one level to the next and varies dramatically among Units 88, 89, and 92. It must be concluded, then, that random rearrangement of the soil layers has taken place as a result of prehistoric excavation and backfilling (McIntyre and Janak 1982:356). sor Depth tem Zone Number ou $.0 S.1 5.2 53 54 5.5 5.6 5.755 SF 60 Bt 62 63 64 65 66 67 68 ED Ld a so 106 10 200 286 300 350 ppm Fe o 19900 20000 30080 40040 ppm Om. o of v4 ae ae 2.0 12 a 165 Figure 6-3. DESCRIPTIONS OF FEATURES AND BURIALS Even though the features inside Feature 1 were included in the analysis presented in Chapter 4, and raw data from these features are presented in Appendix C, feature descriptions are included here to illustrate the nature of pit utilization and change in use over time. Even though Zones 1 through 3 do not represent clearly separated zones of occupation, their artifact content and radiocarbon dates suggest that there is a degree of cultural relevance to these zones. Therefore, features and burials are described on a zone by zone basis from top to bottom, rather than in numerical order. Table 6-2 presents features and burials broken down by zone and Figure 6-6 illustrates their location within the pit. ZONE 1 Eleven features and one burial were uncovered in Zone 1. Features 2 and 3 were concentrations of refuse discarded within the very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) fill of Feature 1. Feature 2 consisted of two articulated deer vertebrae found at a depth of 20-40 cm in Unit 91. Feature 3 was a concentration of bone (95.3 g), baked clay (11 g), mussel shell (1 g), a few fragments of fire cracked rock, and charcoal spread over a 100 x 60 cm area of Unit 88, also at a depth of 20-40 cm. No discernible pits were associated with these concentrations. : Feature 4 was an oval concentration of charcoal (10YR3/2) found between 30 and 50 cm below surface in Unit 92. A date of AD. 1370 + 50 was obtained for this deposit. At the same depth, in Unit 89, a unique storage feature was found. This was Feature 5, a concentration of cores and tested cobbles (i.c., cobbles from which portions of cortex had been removed) found within a 30 x 30 cm Volume II, Part One area between 43 and 55 cm below surface (Figure 6-7). A total of 38 tested cobbles was recovered along with decortication flakes and a few secondary flakes. This feature appears to be a cache of raw materia! for stone tool production, probably placed in a pit intrusive into the very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) midden. However, no pit was observed due to the darkness of the midden soil. Feature 12 was a large, irregular pit which may actually represent several overlapping pits (Figure 6-8). This feature originated in Zone 1, but penetrated Zone 2. The feature was first observed as an amorphous, very dark brown stain (10YR2/2) at a depth of 70 cm in Unit 98. The end of the pit apparently extended east into Unit 91, but was not observed until it became apparent in the west profile of Unit 91. It extended 170 cm east-west and 70 em north-south and 134 cm below surface. A concentration of deer bone (70.7 g) and antler was found in the upper 30 cm of the fill and a few artifacts were recovered below this down to the bottom of the feature. A dart point, arrow point, and 173 flakes were recovered. Also, this was one of only three features found on the site that contained maize cupules. Feature 16 was visible in the west profile of Unit 90 and in plan views of Unit 97, but was not excavated due to time constraints. It was a very dark gray (10YR2/2) and contained an oval patch of black (10YR2/1). It looked very similar in profile to Feature 12, extending down within Zone 2. The presence of these pits indicates that numerous disturbances occurred within Zone 1 due to episodes of digging. Several features were dug into the rim of Feature 1. The term rim is used here to denote the undisturbed B horizon encountered at the edge of the pit, instead of an earthen berm, or surrounding ridge, that has sometimes been described for other Wylie focus pits (Stephenson 1949b), No such earthen embankments were observed at Bird Point Island. It is difficult to associate some of the pits found in the rim with a specific zone because such pits could have been dug either at the time of the original excavation of Feature 1, or during a subsequent episode of use. Features such as 61 and 61B clearly relate to Zone 1 because the bottoms of these features are confined within the Zone 1 midden and do not penetfate the subsoil. Features 17, 72, and 73 are primarily dug into the B horizon. The location of Features 72 and 73 adjacent to Features 61 and 61B suggests that they are probably contemporaneous with 61 and 61B. Feature 17 contained dark fill identical to the Zone 1 fill, so it is also believed to date to the Late Prehistoric period. It must be noted that most of the features associated with Zone | represent pits that postdate the accumulation of midden forming Zone 1. These pits were dug into Zone 1, and backfilled with Zone 1 midden soil, making it difficult to observe them until they penetrated the lighter colored soil of Zone 2 or the pit rim. RADIOCARBON DATES Fourteen radiocarbon dates (uncorrected) were obtained from the various zones within Feature 1. From Zone 1, seven specimens were analyzed, three of which provided modern dates and four of which provided dates ranging from A.D. 1280 + 110 to A.D. 1510 + 60 (Figure 6-9). The modern dates from Units 88 and 91 were obtained immediately below the plow zone, so it is probable that surface charcoal was chumed into the soil either by plowing or by bioturbation. A modern date for Feature 12 probably reflects recent charcoal working down into the soil by natural means. The maximum date range, ca. A.D. 1170 to A.D. 1570, appears to suggest that much of the midden accumulation of Zone 1 occurred during the final site occupation dating to the Late Prehistoric period. However, the two terminal dates obtained were from the charred log associated with Burial 8, which was intrusive into Zone 1 (Figure 6-9), so the majority of midden accumulation must have occurred prior to A.D. 1422 + 56. The distinction between Zones 1 and 2 appears to be substantiated by the occurrence of two specimens in Zone 2 dating at A.D. 720 + 140 and A.D. 700 + 100, for a maximum range of A.D. 580 to A.D. 860 at a depth of 95 cm to 120 cm. Due to a lack of charcoal in Zone 3, the only dates obtained for this zone were four bone dates from Burial 9/11. The collagen from rib fragments was dated to A.D. 140 + 110. Both collagen and apatite were dated for long bones by the SMU Radiocarbon Laboratory. These dates varied considerably, ranging from 107 B.C. to A.D. 521 (see Figure 6-9). However, the latest date was considered the least reliable by the director of the SMU Radiocarbon Laboratory and has been discounted (see Chapter 12). Thus, the accepted date range for Zone 3 is 170 B.C. to A.D. 130. In Zone 3 only dart points were found. The arrow point types recognized within Zone 1 include Alba, Scallorn, Friley, Hayes, Steiner, Catahoula-like, and Perdiz. The first four types were made until at least A.D. 1200 in East Texas, but generally predate the A.D. 1300-1650 period associated with Zone 1 of Feature 1. However, the Catahoula-like and Perdiz points could easily fall within the A.D. 1300-1650 period. It is possible that all of the projectile point types found at the site persisted longer in the Project area vicinity than they did in East Texas, but there is only a partial agreement between projectile point types and radiocarbon dates if the East Texas chronology is used (McGregor et al. 1982:142). The only classifiable arrow point types in Zone 2 are Alba (two specimens) and Scallorn (two specimens). These types are thought to be diagnostic of the early Late Prehistoric period. All dart points from Zone 2 are classified as Gary, with the exception of one Yarbrough point in Unit 403. Zone 3 contained six Gary points and no arrow points. The ceramics from Feature 1 are confined almost entirely to Zone 1 and include varieties associated with the Early and Late Caddoan periods in East Texas. The two specific types identified are Canton Incised, associated with the Sanders focus, and Maydelle Incised, associated with the later Frankston focus. Untyped ceramics bear decorative motifs common to Caddoan pottery, including incised and punctate designs as well as engraved and excised triangle designs typical of the Late Prehistoric period (see Chapter 8). The chronology for the ceramic types corresponds with the radiocarbon dates from Zone 1. Five charcoal samples provided dates clustering within the A.D, 1300- 1650 occupation period, which agree with the temporal placement of the Late Caddoan styles, but only one date from the A.D. 1000- 1200 period was obtained. It seems that little charcoal was deposited with the many ceramics associated with the Early Caddo styles which were discarded into the pit during the A.D. 1000- 1200 occupation, whereas substantial quantities of charcoal were left in the pit between A.D. 1300 and 1650. FEATURE FUNCTION: CHANGES THROUGH TIME In this section, the concentrations of artifacts, faunal, and floral remains throughout the Feature 1 fill are examined, and the different kinds of features and burials are considered in order to address probable feature function. Previous workers have ° proposed that Wylie focus pits were defensive breastworks similar to the pits dug by the historic Waco (Stephenson 1949b), subterranean structures (Ross 1966), or ceremonial areas for council meetings or ritual feasting (Lynott 1975). The data from Feature 1 at Bird Point Island were examined to search for answers to the problems of original pit use and changes in utilization over time. MORTUARY AND CEREMONIAL USE The most obvious function of Feature 1 is its role as a cemetery. Within the percentage of the feature excavated by hand and backhoe (38%), 13 burials, including three cremations, were recorded. Examination of Figure 6-6 reveals that most of the interments occurred near the center of the pit. Since about half of the center was dug, it is reasonable to estimate that about 50% of the total burials were recovered rather than only 38%. If this is the
