None of these burials were cremated and those individuals represented by more than fragmentary remains were buried in semiflexed or tightly flexed positions. As was the case for Wylie focus pits near Dallas, no grave goods other than a few mussel shells were included with these individuals, so no indicators of status differentiation were present. As previously noted, the predominance of males recovered during Season I led to the hypothesis that the pit served as a special cemetery for high-status males. However, Season III burials included males, females and infants, a population typical of a normal cemetery, so this hypothesis was abandoned (see Chapter 5). Very few features were recognized within Zone 3, other than a dog burial (Feature 11) and amorphous. patches of dark soil containing refuse which may represent soil dumped into the pit as part of the fill episode (Features 14 and 88) or which may be the product of rodent denning. The few features which are clearly of cultural origin that are not related to mortuary activity (Features 8, 10, and 15) are related to economic activity. Features 8 and 10 may have been hearths, and Feature 15, which contained charred Psoralea tubers, was clearly associated with food preparation. These are discussed further in the next section. All cremations found within Feature 1, (Burials 2, 19, and 20), occurred in Zone 2 around 100 cm below surface. Fragmentary long bones and ribs of two noncremated individuals were also found in Zone 2, but they may represent bones redeposited from Zone 3 burials as a result of redigging. It seems that either mortuary practices changed substantially by the A.D. 580-860 period from inhumation to cremation, or that both practices were conducted simultaneously during the later period. The presence of cremations and inhumations together around Houses 1, 2, and 3 indicates that the latter possibility is more likely. Along with human interments, dog interments were also encountered in Zone 2, demonstrating that its principal function was similar to that of Zone 3. As stated previously, the distinction between Zones 2 and 3 is based on soil color and iron content, probably due to leaching, and is not necessarily the result of cultural activity. It is not surprising that Zones 2 and 3 share many traits, since they probably represent a single episode of pit fill. It is only the upper part of Zone 2, where cremations and most features are found, that chronological differences between Zones 2 and 3 become apparent. Zone 1 differs dramatically from Zones 2 and 3 in that it contains the highest concentrations of artifacts in the pit and exhibits a relative lack of burials. All of the fill excavated in Units 95-99 and 102-103 was confined to Zone 1, which means that more than twice as much of Zone 1 was sampled than of Zones 2 and 3. Yet, in all this area, only Burial 8 was uncovered. This highly unorthodox burial was clearly intrusive into Zone 1, and had nothing to do with the primary activities conducted in Zone 1. The primary use of Feature 1 seems to have shifted away from the mortuary role to increased use for economic activities during the occupations that created the Zone 1 midden. NONMORTUARY USES Nonmortuary uses of Feature 1 can be clarified by examining trends in the vertical and horizontal distribution of artifacts as well as the faunal and floral material found within it. The comparison of materials by zone is supplemented with a similar comparison by level to identify finer gradations in artifact distribution. Volume- corrected figures are used in place of raw counts to compensate for the variations in volume caused by the presence of Backhoe Trench Unit 25, the presence of features, and the irregular shape of the rim and bottom of Feature 1. This overall pattern suggests that features are more or less uniformly scattered throughout Feature 1 until the distribution is viewed on a zone by zone basis. Beginning at the bottom, in Zone 3, six human burials and a dog burial are present in the center (58% of Zone 3 features), whereas five features were situated within 2.5 m of the pit edge (42%). The features recognized near the pit edge include Features 8, 14, and 88 which may be nothing more than dark patches of fill containing refuse. The only pits with definite economic uses are Feature 4, a hearth, and Feature 15, a pit containing charred plant remains. It appears that interment was confined to the center of the pit. Although economic use for food preparation may have been concentrated near the pit edge during the initial period of utilization, the presence of fire cracked rock and faunal elements throughout the Zone 3 fill suggests that it was used for food preparation prior to the interment of the humans and dogs. The center of Zone 2 contains three cremated individuals, a human long bone, two dog burials, and three pits (82% of all Zone 2 features), with one pit and a fragmentary burial along the pit edge (18%). The function of Feature 62 may possibly be related to a ceremonial offering of mussel shell, seeds, and antler; Feature 63 may merely represent a load of trash dumped in during the fill episode, and the functions of the other pits are not known. The presence of Burial 5, (a single long bone) along the edge of the pit appears to be the result of redeposition from elsewhere in the pit. It seems that mortuary activity within Zone 2 was also confined mainly to the center of the pit. Moving up into Zone i, the opposite trend is found. Burial 8, Feature 5 (a cache of cores) and an episode of trash disposal were observed in the center of Feature 1 (25% of Zone 1 features), whereas seven irregular pits, perhaps used for roasting, and two possible hearths are present along the pit edge (75%). It is clear that the mortuary function, which was of major importance during the early occupations of the site, was essentially abandoned in favor of an economic function during the later site occupations. Activity appears to have been concentrated near the edge of the pit, but it is possible that other pits were dug closer to the center, which were impossible to detect within the dark midden soil of Zone 1. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS Feature 1 is the only feature at Bird Point Island to exhibit interpretable stratigraphy. The complex stratigraphy within this pit has been simplified into three zones. Zone 1 is the dark brown midden layer forming the upper layer of pit fill; Zone 2 is a lighter brown layer with its color caused by leaching from Zone 1; Zone 3 is the bottom layer of mixed soil, exhibiting a patchwork quality of light brown, dark brown, and yellow-brown soils, resulting from 93 ' the mixture of A and B horizon soils in the fill and centuries of burrowing rodent activity. Examination of the pit filling sequence was directed toward understanding the original function of the pit and changes in its utilization over time. Data from soils analysis, artifact analysis, and floral, faunal, and osteological studies were used to examine this problem. Soils data indicated that heterogeneous fill was deposited in the pit shortly after its initial excavation. Chemical analysis identified erratic distributions of chemical properties, and particle size analysis indicated a mixture of A, B, and C horizon soils within the fill. No accumulation of organic matter suggesting the presence of old surfaces was found in the bottom layer of the pit. Darker, organically enriched soil was observed only in the upper 1 - 1.5 m of pit fill. This pattern suggests that the pit was partially filled during an intentional fill episode, probably to around the top of Zone 2, and then was gradually filled to its present level as a result of colluvial deposition of A horizon soil upslope from the depression. Radiocarbon dates obtained from Burial 9/11 found at the bottom of the pit indicate that the pit was originally excavated sometime between 170 B.C. and A.D. 130. Several skeletons were uncovered near the center in the bottom of the feature, none of which had visible grave pits or grave goods. The observed age and sex ratio is normal for a cemetery used by a tribal or band-level society; there is no indication that inclusion inside Feature 1 was restricted to a special class or status. Very low artifact densities were found in the bottom layer of pit fill (Zone 3), and only two definite features related to economic use were found. However, the presence of fire cracked rock and faunal remains suggests that economic activity related to food preparation was also conducted in the pit during its initial period of use. Even though the artifact densities are low, the importance of this economic function may have been equal to that of the mortuary function. Low densities would be expected if short term occupations occurred and the pit was partially refilled, as the evidence indicates. The possibility that ritual feasting accompanied mortuary ritual is discussed more fully in Chaper 21. Two cremation pits containing the remains of at least three individuals were found in Zone 2 nearly 1 m below ground surface. The pit containing Burials 19 and 20 also contained charcoal which provided a date of A.D. 720 + 140, Dog burials were also found in this layer, and most features were confined to the center of the pit. A shift in pit utilization occurred sometime after A.D. 860, when the mortuary function of the pit diminished and economic use increased. Numerous episodes of pit excavation were visible as intrusive features originating in Zone 1 and penetrating Zone 2. Concentrations of fire cracked rock and baked clay occur between 80 cm and 140 cm below surface, and the macrobotanical content of the features in Zone 1 is very similar to that found in roasting pits. It appears that several roasting pits were dug into Zone 1. Since the bottom layers of these intrusive pits contain few ceramics or arrow points, the period of principal roasting activity is believed to have occurred after A.D. 860, perhaps between A.D. 1000 and A.D. 1200 during the occupation of Houses 1, 2, and 3. . The last two major occupations at the site were a village occupation between A.D. 1000 and A.D. 1200, and series of brief occupations from A.D. 1300-1650. Evidence of both periods of occupation is confined primarily to the upper 50 - 80 cm of pit fill. The house occupation immediately north of Feature 1 resulted in the discard of Early Caddoan style sherds and arrow points in the pit. The A.D. 1300-1650 occupations are documented by radiocarbon dates and the presence of Late Caddoan ceramics within the upper layer of the midden. For the most part, the pit functioned as a trash disposal area during these final occupations. However, Burial 8 was also interred during the last period of occupation. In some of the Wylie focus pits reported along the East Fork near Dallas, researchers suggested the presence of structures within the pits on the basis of baked clay concentrations (Ross 1966:6; Lorrain and Hoffrichter 1968:11). The rationale for rapid excavation with a backhoe at the Sister Grove Creek site, aside from financial constraints, was that features and structural

54 remains would be found once the fill was removed (Lynott 1975:17). Although it seemed unlikely that the prehistoric inhabitants of Bird Point Island would have constructed a giant pithouse, the possibility of structures within the pit was carefully examined. A search was conducted for post holes both inside and around the edge of the pit. The upper 30 cm of the east half of Feature | was scraped with heavy equipment to expose the edge of the pit and any post holes or other features that were present. Although dozens of features were recorded, no post hole-sized features were found. No examples of post holes were found inside the pit either, although several rodent runs were cross-sectioned in the search forthem. The distribution of artifacts within the pit in no way resembles house occupation debris. The accumulation of fire cracked rock and baked clay forms the only layer of occupation debris and that layer is more similar to material found in a roasting pit than in a Volume II, Part One structure. No evidence of a floor is present at the bottom of Feature 1; rather, the bottom is irregular and has the lowest density of artifacts observed within the pit. In short, there is no evidence of a structure associated with any zone of Feature 1. In conclusion, Feature 1 at Bird Point Island was in use prior to the period defined for the Wylie focus, perhaps as early as 170 B.C., but certainly by around A.D. 130. No evidence of structures or occupational debris was found. Instead, human and dog skeletons and human cremations were encountered in the middle and bottom zones of the pit, and a highly disturbed midden deposit was present in the upper layer. The pit was used both as a cemetery and as a roasting or cooking area from at least A.D. 130 to A.D. 860. Its function then shifted away from the mortuary role to use solely for economic activities. Finally, the depression was used for trash discard resulting in the. accumulation of organic matter, bone, and artifacts in the midden of Zone 1.

of st 10 0 sg le sit se of Tr, LITHIC ARTIFACTS by Daniel E. McGregor ‘This chapter presents an analysis of the lithic artifacts recovered from the excavations at Bird Point Island. Its purpose is to describe these materials and to examine their intrasite distribution. Since artifact description is a traditional and relatively- straightforward task, the site assemblage has been divided into a series of morphological categories, and these categories provide the framework for the artifact descriptions. To examine the intrasite distribution of these artifacts, the total site assemblage is divided into a series of subsets following the spatial areas defined in Chapter 1. The subsets are compared to one another, and similarities and differences in their contents are identified and discussed. This is followed by a brief description of a technological analysis of lithic artifacts that includes a subset of the materials from Bird Point Island. That analysis is reported in Chapter 17 of Volume III. ARTIFACT DESCRIPTIONS LITHIC TOOL CATEGORIES In the following subsections we define the lithic tool categories that have been employed to classify artifacts from the site. In a later section of this chapter we examine the functional relationships of these classes and make interpretations about prehistoric cultural behavior as seen in the lithic artifacts. PROJECTILE POINTS Projectile points are defined as symmetrical, pointed bifaces with the proximal end modified (by notching, stemming or thinning) to facilitate hafting. This category also includes basal portions of points, but only when the hafting element is present. Possible projectile point tips, and medial and basal fragments that do not possess a definable hafting element are included within the biface fragment category. 95 The projectile points are divided into arrow point and dart -point subcategories, and are assigned to a recognized type whenever possible. The untyped specimens are subdivided according to stem morphology except when they are too fragmentary for this determination. Arrow Points Alba (83 specimens; Figure 7-la-d).These specimens are characterized by their rectangular stems with straight to slightly convex bases. Their triangular blades have either prominent, right-angled shoulders or slightly downward pointing barbs. Bassett (4 specimens). These specimens have small triangular blades with short barbed shoulders. The short contracting stems have pointed bases. Catahoula-like (4 specimens). These specimens have relatively broad blades with slightly concave edges. The shoulders are pronounced, with squared ends. All have short expanding stems with concave bases. Cliffton (2 specimens). Both specimens have short contracting stems and have a somewhat unfinished appearance. They were fashioned from small flakes by retouching that was primarily unifacial. Cuney (10 specimens). These specimens are characterized by their short expanding stems with deeply concave bases and triangular blades with barbed shoulders. Fresno (1 specimen; Figure 7-1e). This unstemmed specimen has a triangular outline and slightly concave base. The distal tip is missing. Hayes (31 specimens; Figure 7-1f). These specimens are distinguished by their slightly concave edges, triangular blades and bulbous stems with rounded bases.

This type was originally defined by Duffield (1963:17-18) and later expanded upon by Prewitt (1974b:58-62). They are characterized by their relatively long, straight to slightly contracting stems. The stem edges on nine specimens exhibit light grinding. The bases of most specimens are convex, but are formed by cortex on four specimens. Thirteen of the specimens have relatively long and narrow blades, whereas the blades on five specimens are much broader. Elam (1 specimen). This short, crudely fashioned specimen has a roughly rectangular stem and slightly convex base. The blade shoulders are weakly developed. Ellis (8 specimens; Figure 7-2d). These specimens have short triangular blades with prominent shoulders. The stems are sharply expanding with straight or slightly convex bases.

Outline morphology is highly variable, including triangular, subtriangular, leaf shaped, and oval specimens. Aborted Bifaces Aborted bifaces are bifacially worked artifacts that appear to have been rejected at some stage in the biface production process. These have been divided into early and late stage subcategories, depending upon the amount of bifacial reduction accomplished prior to discard. Arrow point preforms are aborted bifaces which are differentiated primarily on the basis of their small size. Fragments which may represent aborted bifaces, but are not sufficiently complete for confident classification, are included in the indeterminate biface fragment category. Early Stage (134 specimens; Figure 7-4d). These specimens tend to be thick and somewhat irregular in outline, with sinuous edges formed by the removal of large flakes. Most specimens retain at least one area of nodular cortex. Some specimens retain cortex on both faces and appear to represent aborted attempts at bifacial reduction of relatively flat cobbles. Others appear to have been reduced from large, thick, primary flakes. Although some of these specimens may have been used as cutting or chopping tools, their unfinished appearance has led to their classification as rejects from an early stage in the biface production process. Late Stage (87 specimens; Figure 7-4e). The edges of these specimens are less sinuous than those in the Early Stage subcategory, but they lack fine secondary retouch. Some specimens retain minor amounts of cortex or have an area of step fracturing on one face. Outlines are variable and include oval, leaf shaped, subtriangular, and subrectangular. Again, some of these specimens could have been used as cutting tools. Arrow Point Preforms (32 specimens). These specimens are all made on smail flakes and are generally subtriangular in outline. Their edges have been shaped by varying amounts of bifacial and unifacial retouch, and they lack evidence of basal modification for hafting. The proximal ends of some specimens retain portions of the original striking platform of the flake. Biface Fragments Possible Projectile Point Tip Fragments (192 specimens). These are pointed distal fragments of bifacially worked artifacts whose size and configurations suggest that they are the broken tips of projectile points. One hundred and four are of arrow point size, and 88 are of dart point size. Possible Projectile Point Base Fragments (114 specimens). These specimens appear to be the proximal ends of stemmed projectile points. Twenty-nine are of arrow point size, and 85 are of dart point size.

UNIFACES Steeply Chipped Unifaces Artifacts included in this category possess the following characteristics: (1) a zone of regular retouching rather than a more random pattern of flake scars; (2) two or more rows of overlapping (stepped) flake scars along the working edge; and (3) a working edge angle of greater than 60 degrees. Gossett Gouge (4 specimens). These specimens were made from rather flat quartzite nodules, and all have straight, steeply chipped bits at one end. The flat ventral surfaces of all specimens retain their nodular cortex, and all but one specimen retain cortex on their upper surfaces as well. This artifact category was originally defined by Story (1965:208-210). End Scraper (25 specimens; Figure 7-5a). These specimens are relatively thick flakes with steep, stepped retouch along either the distal or proximal end. Some specimens also exhibit retouch along one or both lateral edges. Side Scraper (40 specimens; Figure 7-5b). These specimens are all relatively thick flakes or broken flakes that exhibit steeply chipped retouch along one or both lateral edges. Scraper with Graver Spur (6 specimens). These specimens are all side scrapers with one or more pointed tips (graver spurs) along the steeply chipped edge. Spokeshave (12 specimens). Each of these specimens possesses at least one concave edge that was formed by steeply retouching the lateral edge of a relatively thick flake. Scraper on Tabular Piece of Silicified Wood (94 specimens; Figure 7-5c). These specimens are identical to Johnson's (1962:189) Mineola end scrapers. They are thin slabs of silicified wood on which unifacial flaking of one end has produced a steep bit. Some of the specimens also exhibit unifacial retouch along one or both lateral edges. Marginally Modified Uniface Artifacts included in this category are characterized by: (1) a relatively acute angled working edge formed by a single, nonstepped row of flake scars; and (2) relatively small, retouch flake scars (all are less than 2 mm in width; most are less than | mm). Graver (72 specimens; Figure 7-5d). These specimens are small, thin flakes on which regularly patterned edge retouch has produced one or more pointed tips. Some of these are composite tools that also possess concave, straight, or convex marginally modified edges. Denticulate (8 specimens). These are small flakes on which one lateral edge has been unifacially retouched to form a series of three or more regularly spaced, pointed tips. Split or Tested Nodule (151 specimens). These are pebbles or cobbles of knappable lithic material with one or very few flakes removed. They may represent discards from an early, material selection stage of the core reduction process or, in some cases, materials that were cached in anticipation of future need. Freehand Percussion Core. These are relatively large pieces of lithic material from which a series of flakes has been detached. The recovered specimens indicate that a variety of reduction strategies was used. They have been subdivided on the basis of the nature and positioning of their striking platforms. Bifacial Platform (20 specimens). Flakes were removed bifacially from one or more edges, but with no apparent attempt to thin the parent nodule. Cortex Platform. The platform is actually the cortex covered surface of the nodule. These specimens are further subdivided according to the number and position of the platforms. Single Platform (19 specimens). These specimens have a single cortex platform at one end, Double Platform (9 specimens). These specimens each have two cortex platforms which are located at opposite ends. Double Platform-90 degree (2 specimens). These specimens each have two cortex platforms located at an approximate right angle to one another. Multifaceted (192 specimens). Flakes have been removed from a number of directions without consistent platform development. - Prepared Platform (17 specimens). Platform preparation on these specimens was essentially limited to splitting the nodule. This newly created, flat surface was then used as the striking platform for further flake removal. In some cases, a few additional flakes were removed from the platform surface itself, apparently for purposes of rejuvenation. Small, Bidirectional Core (11 specimens). These are small chert pebbles with a series of flakes removed from opposite ends. They are similar to specimens which have been termed “bipolar cores" and characterized as resulting from reduction by a hammer-and-anvil technique (Mallouf 1976:157; Shafer 1973). Core Fragment (222 specimens). These specimens are portions of cores that are too fragmentary for further classification. Ground, Pecked, and Battered Stone Hammerstone (136 specimens). These are large, thick slabs (generally sandstone) which have been ground smooth on one or more surfaces. The artifacts tabulated for the North area do not include those recovered from the block excavation of House 1. The House 1 assemblage is tabulated separately. In addition, four subareas (A through D) were defined within the North area (Figure 7-7). These subareas correspond to the locations of higher density clusters of lithic debris. Because these clusters were reasonably discrete and showed spatial relationships with house patterns, it was thought that they might represent the locations of separate activity areas of lithic tool manufacture and use. The artifact counts for these subareas are also presented in Table 7-1. The provenience units represented by the columns in Table 7-1 provide a series of lithic artifact assemblages that can be compared to one another. The following discussion of these data is essentially an attempt to identify similarities and differences between these assemblages. As discussed in Chapters 12 through 14, the spatial divisions of the site have chronological integrity, and it should be possible, therefore, to elucidate changes in lithic tool use through time by examining these divisions. The projectile points are of particular interest because they are thought to be the most temporally sensitive of the lithic artifact categories. The best temporal contexts are provided by the stratigraphic zones within Feature: 1, the large pit at the site (see Chapter 6). Zone 3, the earliest zone, contained only dart points (Table 7-3). The ratio of arrow points to dart points increases through time from about 1:4 in Zone 2 to about 5:1 in Zone 1. The recovery of dart points from Zone 1, even in relatively minor proportions, is somewhat surprising. Radiocarbon dates from this zone are all later than A.D. 1200, a time when it is generally thought that dart points had been replaced entirely by arrow points. Although some mixing of materials between zones may have occurred through both cultural and natural processes, other evidence indicates the contemporaneous use of both dart and arrow points during the Late Prehistoric period. The range and frequency of projectile point types from excavations outside of Feature 1 show several important chronological characteristics. The proportions of dart points relative to arrow points are noticeably higher in the North area, and arrow points generally increase in relative frequency from north to south (Table 7-1). The highest relative proportions of dart points recovered from the A horizon excavations are among the areas encompassing the three house patterns (House 1, and subareas A and C). Although some of these dart points are probably attributable to Archaic period occupations, their distribution suggests that many of them are indeed associated with the A.D. 1000-1200 period village occupation. The higher proportions of arrow points from the Midden areas (both north and south parts) and the South area suggest that the assemblages from these areas contain a greater representation of materials associated with the A.D. 1300-1650 period of site occupation. Table 7-4 presents a typological classification of the dart points from the five horizontal subdivisions of the site. Those from A horizon and feature excavations are tabulated separately. It is noted that dart point types assignable to the Early and Middle Archaic, such as Angostura, Bulverde, Marshall, Pedernales, and Yarbrough, are relatively rare and indicate that Archaic occupation was sporadic and ephemeral. The most common dart point type is Gary (regular variety), a type with poor chronological specificity which appears to have been used into the Late Prehistoric period. Within both the North and Midden areas, Gary points account for a similar percentage of all dart points. In each area the small variety of Gary is the second most frequent dart point style. In the South area samples are small, but Gary also accounts for the majority of all dart points. Although arrow points are present in all parts of the site (Table 7-5), the ratio of arrow points to dart points shows that arrow points increase in relative frequency from north to south. Within the arrow point assemblages, a pattern of increasing relative frequency of Perdiz points from the northern to the southern Volume II, Part One 120N 40N -20N 60E PIECES OF LITHIC DEBRIS [] 0-20 21 - 28 29 - 48 Figure 7-7. Locations of lithic analysis subareas within the North area. portion of the site is evident also. Based on the published temporal placement of Perdiz points (Suhm and Jelks 1962; Prewitt 1981), this suggests that a later occupation which produced arrow points is better represented in the southern part of the site, whereas an earlier arrow-point-producing occupation was located primarily in the North and Midden areas. Dart points may have been used during both of these occupations, but appear to have been more common during the first. Evidence for the concurrent use of dart and arrow points is implied by their association in the block excavations over House 1. Because the SYMAPs showed higher densities of artifacts in this location, it is assumed that most of these artifacts resulted from the occupation of House 1. Consequently, the relative frequencies of arrow to dart points may be a reasonable indicator of the ratio in use during the occupation of House 1. A total of 23 arrow points and 27 dart points was recovered from the A horizon excavations, for an arrow to dart point ratio of .85:1. This is virtually identical to the ratio from A horizon excavations in the remainder of the North area of the site (.84:1). Perhaps the most anomalous aspect of the projectile point distribution is the consistent association of dart points with features. The relative proportions of dart points from feature excavations are consistently higher than the proportions from the A horizon excavations (Tables 7-4 and 7-5). This is the case regardless of the type of feature and regardless of the feature's horizontal location. The implication of this pattern is that dart points were being used more frequently in whatever activities were associated with these features. Only two of the 24 features containing projectile points had more arrow points that dart points. These are Feature 89 ( 2 arrow, | dart) and Feature 101 (4 arrow, 1 dart). Both features are located in the South Midden area and are thought to date to the A.D. 1300 to 1650 component. The most consistent occurrence of dart points was within the large features that have been interpreted as roasting pits (Features 34, 35, 36, 38 and 45), All 57 of the projectile points recovered from the fill of these features were dart points. The House 1 assemblage contains the highest percentages of both finished and aborted bifaces, as well as the lowest percentage of marginally modified unifaces. As mentioned above, the percentage of steeply chipped unifaces is also relatively high in this assemblage. Chapter 13 includes a discussion of the spatial distributions of various artifact classes within the House 1 block excavation area. Referring to Figure 13-15 in that chapter, it can be seen that bifaces exhibit three high-density clusters. Two of these clusters are inside the house, just outside the central hearth. The third cluster is outside the house, approximately 2 m to the north. This biface density map (see Figure 13-15) includes artifacts in the finished biface, aborted biface, and indeterminate biface fragment categories. The clusters within the house are composed primarily of aborted bifaces and, to a lesser extent, biface fragments. The outside cluster is composed of finished bifaces and biface fragments. The two interior clusters correspond to the locations of the two highest density clusters of lithic debris (see Figure 13-14). The spatial association of the aborted bifaces with the lithic debris suggests that both are related to biface production activities that occurred within House 1. In Table 7-9, the chipped stone artifact assemblage from the House 1 block excavation is divided into two subsets: artifacts recovered from excavation units located strictly within the house 105 versus those from outside. It can be seen that the percentage of aborted bifaces is about twice as high inside the house as compared to outside. Projectile points also occur with greater relative frequency inside the house. On the other hand, the percentage of marginally modified unifaces from inside the house is considerably lower than from outside. In general, these same differences are also found when the assemblage from inside the house is compared to those from each of the four subareas (A through D in Table 7-6). Houses 2 and 3 were located within subareas A and C, respectively, but very few of the systematically placed 50 x 50 cm units and none of the 1 x 1 m units actually sampled the interiors of these structures. Because of this, almost all of the artifacts in the subarea assemblages were recovered from outside of the house structures. Therefore, any consistent differences between the subarea assemblages and the assemblage from inside House 1 could be indicative of basic differences in the activities conducted outside versus inside of houses. The percentage of aborted bifaces within House 1 is higher than that of all subareas except B. However, the total chipped stone . artifact sample from subarea B (68 specimens) is small, and may not be representative. Although biface production, as indicated by the presence of aborted bifaces, appears to have taken place in all areas of the site, it is represented to a relatively greater degree inside House 1. The percentage of projectile points is also highest inside House 1. This does not necessarily indicate that projectile points were used more often inside houses than outside. Because projectile point production required a considerable investment of labor, they were probably curated more often than many other categories of lithic artifact. The higher percentage of projectile points within the house may reflect the fact that they were kept there in anticipation of future use. All of the subarea assemblages contain marginally modified unifaces in about twice the percentage as that of the assemblage from inside House 1. Many of these flake tools were probably retouched through use or with only a minor investment of labor. In this sense they represent expediently produced tools with relatively short use lives, and were probably not curated to any significant degree. In this case, the greater relative frequencies of these tools in the assemblages from outside the house structure most likely indicate their having been used more frequently in that context. SUMMARY UF ARTIFACT SPATIAL PATTERNING The recovered artifacts and radiocarbon dates suggest that Bird Point Island was a site of substantial prehistoric activity over a span of at least 1800 years (ca. 170 B.C, to A.D. 1650). The Archaic period dart point styles (e.g., Angostura, Bulverde, Palmillas, Pedernales, Wells, Yarbrough) indicate at least intermittent occupation for several thousand years before this. There are certain problems in defining and interpreting artifact patterning at an intensively occupied, multicomponent site like Bird Point Island, Patterns in the material remains of each component can become masked if the locations of earlier and later occupations tend to overlap spatially. Some of the differences recognized in the intrasite distribution of projectile point styles are very likely due to temporal changes in the locations favored for occupation. Although no particular area of the site appears to contain the remains of a single, unmixed component, differences in the ratios of arrow points to dart points indicate that the primary spatial focus of occupation changed over time. Along with the point style variation, other differences in assemblage composition have been demonstrated for certain proveniences within the site. It is not clear whether these differences in the relative proportions of artifact types are due to temporal or functional factors, but some tentative interpretations are offered as part of the following discussion.

TECHNOLOGICAL ANALYSIS The present analysis of the lithic artifacts from Bird Point Island views these materials only in terms of their morphology. These same artifacts can also provide information about the lithic reduction technologies employed in their production. In Volume IJ, Chapter 17, a sample of the chipped stone artifacts and lithic debris from several sites at Richland/Chambers Reservoir is analyzed from a technological perspective. The assemblage from the House 1 block excavation at Bird Point Island is included in | that analysis. The objective of the technological analysis is to define assemblage-specific reduction strategies and to compare these between sites of different time periods. This is accomplished with a detailed attribute analysis of both the unmodified lithic debris and the secondarily modified chipped stone artifacts. The methods and results of the technological analysis are presented in Chapter 17 of Volume III.

t4 ic rt G re of , al CERAMIC ARTIFACTS by James E. Bruseth with a contribution by Marilee Irvine From the excavations conducted at Bird Point Island over five field seasons, more than a quarter of a million artifacts have been uncovered. Despite this large sample, ceramics account for less than 2% of the total. This rarity is not uncommon for the reservoir, or for much of Central and North Central Texas for that matter, but it is in marked contrast to Caddoan sites to the east where ceramics can account for more than 90% of the overall artifact assemblage (Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Anderson et al. 1974). A total of 4967 sherds was found at the site, but only 4305 of these are discussed in this chapter. This reduction in number is due to the fact that 662 sherds lacked specific provenience, since they were collected from bulidozed or otherwise disturbed contexts. In addition, 11 sherds that are parts of pipes are described in a separate section of this chapter. The approach that we have chosen to use in analyzing the sherds from the site centers on the examination of several attributes in order to accomplish three basic objectives. The first and primary objective is to satisfactorily describe the ceramic sample from the site as a means of communication to others, Although the sherd sample is small, it is nonetheless important, since the large scale excavations conducted at the site place the ceramics into a well- documented cultural framework for North Central Texas archaeology. The second objective is to develop a refined framework of site chronology that can be used to date features and other contexts at the site which otherwise lack temporally diagnostic artifacts or radiocarbon samples. The additive nature of ceramic decoration (Deetz 1969) lends itself to detailed temporal tefinement, and this potential is investigated in this chapter. The final objective of the ceramic analysis is to determine if the sherds are from locally manufactured vessels or are the result of long- distance exchange. Based on the low frequency of sherds at sites in the area, it was initially hypothesized that trade was the principal means of acquisition of ceramic vessels. Several approaches are potentially available to deal with the stated objectives, depending on the theoretical orientation of research that is adopted. The type-variety system of classification, such as is used in the Lower Mississippi Valley, has been successfully employed to develop a refined ceramic chronology for Caddoan archaeology along the Great Bend of the Red River (Schambach and Miller 1984), and certainly has merit over simple “type-only" systems (e.g., Suhm and Jelks 1962). It has been suggested, however, that the type-variety system is only sufficient when attribute coassociations are used to define types (Brown 1971:1-5). While this approach would result in types that have some cultural validity, it necessitates that adequate samples of sherds are available and that these sherds are of sufficient size to accurately define decorative motifs. Unfortunately, the Bird Point Island sherds are small in size, with most measuring less than 5 cm in maximum diameter, making such an approach impractical. Another analytical approach for ceramic analysis is to utilize a classificatory system which divides ceramics initially by decoration or paste characteristics into groups, and then examines the variability among other attributes within each group (Irvine 1980; Hall 1981). Although this approach allows classification of sherds which are small in size, it suffers from an inherent assumption that the hierarchy of classificatory divisions have cultural significance. Without some type of coassociational analysis, however, this assumption is unverified. Nevertheless, it might be argued that the approach still provides a convenient framework for subdividing ceramic variability into smaller and more manageable subsets for description and information dissemination. However, if the classification fails to provide cultural insight, it is on the level of providing cultural lists and not offering explanations of cultural behavior (Brown 1971:1). Consequently, an attribute analysis approach is used in this chapter and is seen as the optimum type of ceramic analysis for the Bird Point Island sherd collection. Attributes have been selected to study archaeological questions of refined site chronology and exchange with other groups. At the same time, however, many attributes are included solely as a means of fulfilling the responsibility of describing the sherd assemblage in order to 109

A part of this descriptive responsibility is to compare the ceramics from Bird Point Island to existing type descriptions in an effort to show similarities to ceramics from other regions and to indicate possible directions and degrees of cultural affinity. ATTRIBUTES USED FOR ANALYSIS The attributes used in the Richland Creek Archaeological Project ceramic analysis fall into three groups: vessel form, ceramic manufacturing, and exterior decoration. Each is discussed below. VARIABLES RELATED TO VESSEL FORM The first group of attributes for ceramic analysis includes four variables that describe various characteristics of vessel form. These variables are (1) location of the sherd on the complete vessel, (2) lip form, (3) rim orientation, and (4) sherd thickness. Each is described in detail below, and should provide a means of describing the sherd assemblage and of examining possible chronological relationships that these variables might have. All of them have been found to have chronological variability at other ceramic sites (Brown 1971; Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Hargrave 1982). Sherd location was divided into three attributes: whether a sherd was part of the rim, part of the body, or part of the base. Mention should be made that the base category cannot be consistently observed and therefore is not a reliable indicator of the presence of this vessel part. That is, bases from flat-bottomed vessels are often easy to recognize, whereas bases from round- bottomed vessels are more difficult. This difficulty is increased when the curvature of the base of round-bottomed vessels is similar to that of the walls. Moreover, the small size of the sherds from the Bird Point sample further increases the difficulty of recognizing bases. A major goal of this variable was to obtain information on the types of vessel forms represented in the sherd assemblage. Since vessel form could be directly observed on only a very smail number of sherds because of the small size of individual ceramics, it was hoped that this procedure might provide insight on the range of vessel forms used over time. Specifically, the relative frequencies of body to rim sherds provide an indicator of the overall range of vessel forms, albeit at a much grosser level than direct form observation (cf., Schambach 1970:294-298). For instance, a large number of body sherds relative to rim sherds would indicate a predominance of restricted orifice vessels, deep- bodied vessels, or a combination of the two. Conversely, a high incidence of rim sherds relative to body sherds would imply unrestricted orifice vessels, shallow body vessels, or some combination. The former might indicate more storage forms, such as jars and bottles, while the latter might indicate food preparation and eating utensils. Rim orientation was selected to further examine the forms of vessels, and specifically, to help determine if more or less restricted orifice vessels exist in a given sample. The attributes observed under this variable were straight (i.e., vertical), everted (i.e., inclining outward), and inverted (i.e., inclining inward). An additional variable used to describe vessel form was lip form, or examination of the cross section of the terminal margin of the vessel orifice (Brown 1971:120). Five categories were defined (see Table 8-3). The reason for inclusion of this variable is based on the tendency of established ceramic types to show a greater incidence of flattened or rounded lips during the Early Caddo period and a greater incidence of rolled lips in the Late Caddo period of East Texas (Suhm et al. 1954). Since most of the decorated ceramics from Bird Point Island show similarity to Caddoan types, it was anticipated that temporal change in this attribute might also be found at Bird Point Island. Volume II, Part One The final variable used was sherd thickness. This refers to the average thickness in millimeters of each sherd. This variable was included primarily as a means of increasing the level of description of the ceramic assemblage from Bird Point Island. VARIABLES RELATED TO CERAMIC MANUFACTURING Included within this group are several observations which pertain to the manufacturing environment of the ceramics. These variables are sherd temper, color, and petrographic constituents. Sherd tempers were selected to cover the observed range of nonplastic additives to the clay. However, in some instances it is not clear if certain tempers were originally part of the clay or clearly an additive, such as was occasionally the case with sand. Some of the clays in the vicinity are actually sandy clays and this material could have unintentionally been selected. At the same time, however, some sherds contained considerable quantities of sand and are quite clearly intentionally tempered wares; we refer to this temper as sandy paste. Tempers were megascopically identified unless there was a question, in which case microscopic examination was made. The predominant tempering agents were grog, sand (grit), bone, and shell. In some sherds no temper was visible, and these were identified as such. Sherd colors were identified according to a Munsell color chart to provide a consistent means of identification. All readings were taken under fluorescent light. The exterior, interior, and core colors were identified on a 10% sample of all ceramics from the site. A sampling procedure was employed since. the primary purpose of the technique was to communicate the range of sherd colors to other workers. However, there are some manufacturing interpretations that can be drawn from this variable. Shepard (1971:105) notes that there are two determinants of sherd color: clay source variability and firing environment. Generally lighter colors such as creams, yellows, oranges, and reds can be inferred to represent oxidized firing environments, whereas darker colors such as browns, grays, and black can be due to either reduced firing environments or clay sources (Shepard 1971:105). Thus, some indication of change or stability in clay sources and in firing environments over time can be obtained from this variable. A secondary objective of using sherd color was to help determine if the ceramics from the site were manufactured locally or were trade wares. It was reasoned that if all ceramics had been manufactured locally, similar firing techniques would likely have been employed and have resulted in a similar range of colors. On the other hand, if ceramics were being traded, then color variations representing different clay sources should be apparent when compared over time. This analysis assumes that vessels did not consistently originate from the same source over time, a situation that seems unlikely. The final variable of this grouping involved the identification of the minerological constituents through thin-sectioning and petrographic analysis of a sample of sherds to observe clay composition and to quantitatively approach the problem of ceramic exchange. A trial study of ceramic thin-sectioning and petrographic analysis was conducted during the survey and testing phase of the Project with encouraging results (Irvine 1982a), and further examination was considered necessary to resolve the question of ceramic exchange. Although this issue has not been completely put to rest, reasonable conclusions based on this analysis can now be made. VARIABLES OF DECORATION The final grouping of ceramic variables that have been used to analyze the Bird Point Island ceramic collection consists of those which pertain to vessel decoration. The first is decoration method, and refers to the manner in which ceramic designs were executed on the exterior of the vessel. The specific attributes observed were

The ceramic analysis changed over time, becoming more refined, and earlier materials were reanalyzed to provide comparability with later changes. To maintain comparability from season to season, laboratory personnel were instructed by a person familiar with the procedure and coding system from the previous laboratory session. All attributes were entered onto computer coding forms for transfer to magnetic disk and final computer analysis. The presentation of the results is made with respect to the five spatial divisions of the site. These spatial areas, defined in Chapter 1 and displayed in Figure 1-1, are: North, House 1, North Midden, South Midden, and South. As outlined in Chapter 12, several periods of occupation are represented at the site and at least two of these produced ceramic artifacts. Chapter 13 presents data on the spatial distributions of each occupation and demonstrates that considerable spatial integrity of different temporal components exists at the site. Consequently, the ceramic data are analyzed according to spatial clusterings of ceramic artifacts in order to facilitate one of the goals of the overall analysis, namely refined ceramic chronology. In addition to the spatial divisions of the site, vertical division of the ceramic data is also employed. The above mentioned areas of the site only include ceramics from excavations into the A horizon. As outlined in Chapter 2, the A horizon is a sandy loam topsoil that has received extensive disturbance from various types of natural and cultural agents. In fact, most artifacts were originally dropped on a stable surface and have been worked into the soil by this activity (see Chapter 2). Subsurface features, in contrast, are less disturbed. They have been dug from the surface into the B horizon, and, where they have penetrated this zone, remain in relatively good condition. These contexts are "time capsules” of cultural behavior at the site and, consequently, have received separate consideration in this chapter. One last comment conceming the ceramic results is called for: the number of sherds used for analysis changes from variable to variable. This is because all attributes could not be observed on all sherds. For instance, even though a rim sherd could be identified as such, its lip form may not have been reliably discriminated if the sherd was very small and only a part of the lip was present. NON-FEATURE RESULTS VARIABLES OF VESSEL FORM Table 8-1 presents the results of analysis of the first variable in this grouping: sherd location on the complete vessel. The results are shown by the five spatial divisions of the site and by the variable categories of body, rim, and base. A base category has been included in the table, although as outlined earlier this observation cannot be consistently nor reliably made. Therefore, the frequencies of bases given in Table 8-1 should be viewed as minimal representations. ill Table 8-1 SHERD LOCATION BY SITE AREA North South North House 1 Midden Midden South (%) (%) (%) %) (%) Body 90.5 96.3 93.4 93.5 94.2 Rim 8.2 3.4 5.8 6.1 5.0 Base 1.3 3 6 7 38 Sample Size 539 324 986 1,764 483 All provenienced sherds from the site, excluding those from Feature 1, are included in the table. The results show that body sherds are clearly the most dominant type, as would be expected for any ceramic assemblage. This category ranges between 90% and 96% of all sherds. As argued earlier in this chapter, the relative frequency of body to rim sherds (with bases and body sherds collapsed) gives a rough indication of the vessel forms represented in the ceramic assemblage. The assumption behind this ratio is that vessels with restricted orifices and/or deep bodies will break into a large number of body sherds relative to rim sherds. Such vessel types are inferred to reflect storage forms. In contrast, large orifice vessels and/or shallow bodied forms will break into a lower frequency of body sherds relative to rim sherds. These forms are thought to reflect more short term activities such as food preparation or food consumption. It must be pointed out that one vessel form group is not expected to be found to the exclusion of the other; some degree of mixture will no doubt be observed. What is of importance is the relative mix of restricted orifice to unrestricted orifice vessels and how this varies from one occupation of the site to another. The results of this analysis, as presented in Table 8-1, support limited changes in the uses of vessel forms between areas at the site. The highest frequency of body sherds to rims occurs within House 1. We interpret the higher incidence of body sherds from this area to suggest that ceramic vessels were more often used for storage activities. In contrast, the frequency of body to rim sherds from the North area, outside of House 1, shows a much lower ratio, suggesting that storage was relatively less important and that other ceramic-related activities, such as the use of vessels as containers for short term uses, were dominant. Although data from inside two other houses are included within the North area, the relative contribution of the limited excavations within these structures is greatly outweighed by the excavation outside of the structures. In fact, for the purposes of our analysis, the North area may be viewed as indicating the types of activities undertaken outside of the houses, while House 1 can be used to reflect the range of activities inside the houses. The other three areas of the site, North Midden, South Midden, and South, have similar ratios of body to rim sherds. Whether this indicates that similar types of activities were conducted on all three areas or whether the assemblages are the mixtures of different occupations, cannot be determined at this time. Table 8-2 presents data on the orientation of rim sherds from the site. Again, only those sherds on which this observation could be reliably made are included. The purpose behind looking at the orientation of vessel rims is to add a further indicator of the range of vessel forms represented in the ceramic assemblages. This variable is particularly important since, as outlined above, direct observation of vessel form was not possible because of the small sherd sizes. Unfortunately, the rim orientation data are also biased by too few sherds large enough to examine for orientation. However, some statements about the ceramic assemblage overall can be made. The next variable examined to add information about ceramic manufacture is color. This variable can contribute data on the firing environment, specifically whether vessels were fired in an oxidizing or a reducing environment (Shepard 1971:105). As noted earlier, lighter colors, particularly creams, yellows, oranges, and reds, are reflective of oxidizing environments and darker colors of reducing environments. Although clay sources influence final sherd colors, lighter colors generally. indicate oxidizing environments. It was also hoped that ceramic color might be used to examine the problem of local versus non-local ceramic manufacture. This assumes that if vessels were obtained outside the Richland Creek area they would have had differing clay sources. On the other hand, similarity in colors would support local manufacture, since the same local clay sources probably would have been exploited over time. Table 8-6 displays the range of exterior sherd colors observed in the samples. Only the exterior colors are presented since these reflect the greatest variability and are thought to have the best chance of reflecting different clay sources. Interior colors tend to be darker, reflecting less complete oxidation of the clays, and are most frequently shades of brown and gray. Core colors have an even narrower range of colors and vary from shades of gray to black. The darkness of these colors represents incomplete oxidation of carbonaceous deposits. Exterior colors, in contrast, show lighter values and chromas and have probably been more completely oxidized. The data from exterior sherd colors are listed in Table 8-6 and exhibit considerable variability. Overall a similar range of colors is seen among all areas, although a few differences are noted. For instance, the North has more sherds in the SYR hue and House 1 has more sherds of a unique reddish color (10R4/6). The former may reflect sample bias, but the higher incidence of red sherds from the House 1 almost certainly relates to a single red slipped vessel that was broken inside the house. Although the pieces of this vessel could not be fitted together, the overall rarity of slipped sherds at the site and their similarity in paste argue for these sherds belonging to a single vessel. The remaining major difference in color among the areas is the high number of sherds from the South in the light yellowish brown category of the 10YR hue. None of the other areas has comparable frequencies in this color, and this suggests that the ceramics from this area may be coming from a different clay 113 source. Petrographic Analysis of Ceramics (by Marilee Irvine) The problem of local versus nonlocal manufacture of ceramics had been initially investigated prior to Season I mitigation when a petrographic analysis of thin sections of sherds recovered during testing was accomplished. The purpose of this analysis was to identify mineral inclusions in the paste in order to provide information to help in determining if the pottery was produced using local clay sources. This feasibility study was performed on eight sherds which had been selected as representative plainwares within the sample. The results were encouraging (Irvine 1982b), so it was decided to continue the analysis. Sixteen sherds from Bird Point Island were thin-sectioned for analysis. The analysis was performed using a Nikon microscope, type 115 with a UXF camera system. The sherds used in the analysis were impregnated with blue epoxy before they were cut for thin sections. This enabled the petrographer to discriminate actual void spaces (which would appear blue) from spaces where minerals had been removed during polishing (these spaces are clear). All of the thin sections were cut on the cross sections of the sherds to allow examination of the paste mixture. The significance of the combination of minerals within the clay matrix and the makeup of the sand can only be understood if there is some background information provided about the local geology and the minerals identified. The minerals that were identified in thin section are commonly associated with an igneous parent material. The presence of this material may be a result of its chemical and physical weathering. A source for this material is the sandstone bedrock (the Wilcox formation) that underlies a portion of the Project area, and outcrops at the southeast end of the reservoir. This bedrock material is highly eroded and has changed the soil to a very sandy loam. . A second source is the Pleistocene gravels known as the Uvalde gravels, which occur in the Project area and are found from eastern Texas (Bruseth and Perttula 1981) southwest into northern Mexico (Byrd 1971). These gravels were deposited in the Project area as a result of erosion and stream flow from the Llano Estacado area of the Texas Panhandle and northern New Mexico. The gravels are typically composed of waterwor pea gravel to boulder sized quartz, quartzite, chert, limestone, silicified wood, a few Cretaceous fossils, and granite. The granite is probably derived from the Llano Uplift region to the northwest (Menzer and. Slaughter 1971; Byrd 1971). There are nine minerals identified from the sample, but not every sherd contains all nine. Only one is common to all of the samples, quartz, while the others vary in their amounts. The other minerals include: quartzite clasts (which are basically recrystalized quartz), plagioclase and microcline (these are feldspars) and other types of mica, opaques (such as Fe-Ti oxides), calcite, zircon, and tourmaline (zircon and tourmaline are the only two heavy minerals present). All of these minerals are generally associated with a granitic parent material. The shape of the grains and their degree of sorting are important to determine distance from source localities. The more angular and poorly sorted the grains are the closer they are to their source, while the more rounded and well-sorted the grains are the further they are from their source. Related to this sorting effect is the breakdown and loss of certain minerals over distances. For example, the feldspars (plagioclase and microcline) break down much faster than quartz, which is probably the reason for their low percentages. The fact that the feldspars that are present appear to be fresh (angular, poorly sorted) may indicate that they have not traveled far from their source locality, or they have been

So the problem becomes one of determining if the pottery was made somewhere else and brought into the area, or if it was manufactured locally from the nearby clays. A thin section of a sherd from a black-on-white stirrup spout vessel from the Southwest (recovered from Dallas County, Texas) has been analyzed under a petrographic microscope (McIntyre and McGregor 1982). In contrast to the matrix of the Richland samples, which are mainly quartz, this matrix and others from New Mexico (Shepard 1971) contain mostly basalt. Basalt is very common to the west of Richland and would be expected as a component of the clays from this area. - Thin sections of sherds from sites in eastern Oklahoma (Spiro, Brackett, and Paris Mounds) were also very different from the Richland samples (Ren Thompson, personal communication 1981). The samples analyzed had such small grain sizes that few of the matrix constituents could be identified. All of the sherds were similar. in that the matrix was made up of very fine-grained material. In contrast, the Richland samples had grain sizes identified as being sand size. The question of provenience may never be fully answered, but this analysis has provided some answers to questions about the nature of the sherds. In every instance the temper identified by the archaeologist was confirmed by the petrographer. In several instances the petrographer-identified bone in the matrix that was not originally observed, but in each case the bone occurred in the matrix of small grog pieces within the paste and was not observable except with a microscope. The question of the addition of sand (grit) to the matrix appears to be supported by the fresh, angular nature of the feldspar in comparison to the other grains observed in the paste. This seems to suggest that sand was being mechanically added in addition to what was present naturally in the clay. It would appear that the pottery from Bird Point Island was manufactured locally due to the similarity of the samples. Otherwise it would have to have come from a single area outside of the Project to account for its homogeneity, a situation that seems unlikely for the 800 years or so of ceramic occupation represented at the site. More than likely the prehistoric inhabitants were using the clays available to them on or near the site where they were residing to manufacture their pottery. VARIABLES OF DECORATION This variable grouping was devised to provide a means of refining the existing ceramic chronology for the site. Although decoration has been one of the principal tools of the archaeologist to devise cultural chronologies, these chronologies are often quite generalized in order to be relevant over large areas (cf., Suhm et al. 1954). Analysis of the Bird Point ceramics, in comparison, should provide a refinement to existing regional chronologies so as to provide a site-specific temporal framework. The first variable is decoration method and refers to the manner in which decorations were executed on the sherd. More specifically, this denotes whether the decorations were made by incised lines, punctations, or some other technique. The results of this analysis are shown in Table 8-8. Although some differences are noted among the areas of the site, overall there is a general level of uniformity. Plain ceramics account for 65% to 80% of all sherds, with incising the most common method of decoration in most areas. Punctations are next most common, followed by brushing. The exception to the overall uniformity is in the frequencies from the North area. Here there are more decorated sherds than from other areas. This is particularly puzzling in comparison to House 1, which is part of the same occupation as the entire North area. If the argument presented earlier is correct, that more storage related activities with ceramics were undertaken within House I, then this attribute difference may indicate that undecorated vessels were more often used for storage. However, this interpretation is somewhat tautological and should be viewed simply as speculation at this point. The second variable used to look at ceramic decoration is the configuration of design elements seen on the sherds. Based on the range of elements observed, 13 different categories were defined (Tables 8-9 and 8-10); many of the element configurations are illustrated in Figures 8-1 and 8-2. The small samples of sherds with identifiable element configurations minimize the interpretability of the data. Overall, however, simple random punctations are the most frequent element category, ranging from 26% to 56% of all sherds with decorations. The next most frequent categories of elements involve those with various combinations of incised lines at different angles relative to the vessel orifice. The incised elements are similar to established ceramic types, such as Maydelle Incised, Canton Incised, and Davis Incised. However, more definitive affinity to these types cannot be given because of the small sizes of many of the sherds. Comparison of element categories among the areas of the site show overall similarity. Perhaps the most meaningful difference is the occurrence of the "engraved triangle configuration.” Only one sherd from this category was found from the North and none from the other areas with the exception of the South Midden, where six were uncovered. This element is similar to elements found on some Late Caddoan ceramic types of East Texas, particularly Poynor Engraved. Although the sample size is small, the occurrence of this element in the South Midden supports a tentative conclusion that later occupations at the site occurred here and corroborates the results of other attribute analyses presented earlier.

RESULTS FROM FEATURES A few comments are in order on how the ceramic data from features are presented. First, only brief descriptions of the function and temporal assignment of each feature are made; more detailed discussions can be found in Chapters 4 and 6. The emphasis here is in the presentation of ceramic data, with only the minimum necessary amount of information given to acquaint the reader with each feature. Second, the sherd data are described in the text of this chapter as opposed to being put into a table. Although tabular presentation would eliminate the need to read through several paragraphs of text to understand the contents of a particular feature, the size and complexity of the table would cause even greater problems in data communication. Third, only sherds found in 1/4 inch screening are included. Although sherds were also found from flotation, these tended to be too small for the analysis presented here. These sherds, however, are tabulated and presented in Chapter 4. And finally, not all variables presented for the "Non-feature Results" section are included within the discussion for features. In most cases only a small sample of ceramics was found, and a detailed breakdown by several of the variable categories is of dubious value given the low frequencies. FEATURE 1 Feature 1 is the large pit that was proposed to be a Wylie focus pit. Chapter 6 of this volume discusses this large pit and concludes that its purpose was multifunctional, changing over time as the site was reoccupied. The initial utilization of the pit occurred between 170 B.C. and A.D. 130. At this time the pit was excavated, used for roasting and mortuary activity and partially filled; this layer of the pit is termed Zone 3. The next episode of cultural activity inside the pit was around A.D. 700. This layer of the feature is defined as Zone 2 and includes cremation burials. In addition, there is evidence of small pits having been excavated and used as roasting pits in this zone. This activity dates between A.D. 580 and A.D. 860. The final layer of the pit, defined as Zone 1, represents the 117 accumulation of trash associated with two periods of occupation dating between A.D. 1000 and A.D. 1650. Despite two seasons of excavation into Feature 1 and the removal of more than 85 m3 by hand excavation, only 209 sherds were recovered. Table 8-11 shows the distribution of sherds according to depth within the feature and by the position of the sherd on the complete vessel. The first variable examined for ceramics from inside the pit is sherd location, The ratios of body to rim sherds, compensating for small sample sizes, remain fairly constant from zone to zone and level to level. Perhaps more informative than the ratios of sherds are the vertical distributions of all sherds within Feature 1. The vast majority are located in Zone I, or to a depth of about 40 cm. Only four sherds were found in Zone 3, corroborating the pre- ceramic radiocarbon dating of this layer. The presence of sherds in Zone 3 may be the result of rodent disturbance, which was prevalent in this part of Feature 1. Table 8-12 presents data on sherd temper by zone and level within Feature 1. A tendency exists for more grog-tempered ceramics to be located in Zone 2 of the pit than in Zone 1. Grog with bone and grit (mostly sand) temper becomes more common in the upper zone. The chronological implications of this are confusing, since they imply that pure grog temper was more common during the earlier ceramic occupations at the site (ca. A.D. 700) and that bone and grit additions to the grog were later (ca. A.D. 1000-1650). This late occurrence of grit tempering is the opposite of that observed by other workers who note that sand temper tends to occur early in Texas (cf., Story 1981). However, this trend shows up in both the Season I and Season III excavations and indicates that it is not a statistical fluke, but is instead a reflection of cultural behavior. The distributions of decoration methods within Feature 1 are shown in Table 8-13. The data show a difference between Zones 1 and 2 in the frequency of decorated ceramics. More plainwares were represented in Zone 2 than in Zone 1. A higher incidence of decorated sherds in Zone 1 is due largely to the occurrence of engraved wares, which are absent in Zone 2, and to a much higher frequency of incised wares. Other decoration types, which represent combinations of the major categories, also account fora high percentage of the decorated sherds. Table 8-14 examines the vertical distributions of specific ceramic element configurations within Feature 1. Since only those sherds which were large enough to determine element configurations are shown, the sample sizes become sufficiently small to limit the interpretive value of the data. Although we are able to form a picture of the types of decoration in use, we cannot make conclusions about how these changed over time. In general the assemblage from the pit is dominated by incised and punctation elements, a situation similar to that observed from the remainder of the site. All of these elements are common to established ceramic types, such as Canton Incised and Maydelle Incised (Suhm and Jelks 1962). The dominance of the "Engraved Triangle” element in Zone 1 affirms its apparent late occurrence at the site. This element configuration seems to be a good temporal indicator . at the site. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS At the beginning of this chapter, three objectives were stated to serve as a guiding framework for the ceramic analysis: (1) description of the assemblage, (2) development of a refined chronology, and (3) determination of the location of vessel manufacture (i.e., manufactured locally or imported). In this section we summarize the data that bear on each objective. The first objective, description of the ceramic assemblage, was undertaken as a means of communicating data to other researchers. Through the tables and text descriptions, this goal has been accomplished. Hopefully, other readers will be able to extract the data they need to assess our conclusions or, if they wish, to examine other problems not discussed in this chapter. The second objective of providing a refined site chronology has not been entirely met. Unfortunately the data show greater uniformity among areas of the site, and hence among different occupations, than is desirable for optimum chronology building. Relevant chronological attributes are shown in Table 8-17. This similarity in attributes over time is seen in several variables. For example, sherd temper, although exhibiting some differences, shows that grog inclusions are the dominant type in most areas. Only within Feature 1 were possible temporally significant differences found. Here, Zone 1, which is radiocarbon dated between A.D. 1000 and 1650, was found to have a greater incidence of sand tempered sherds relative to Zone 2, dating to

This category is nearly identical to the design on type Weches Fingernail Impressed, and shows cultural similarity to the Early Caddoan period of East Texas. More details on ceramic chronology for the overall reservoir can be found in Chapter 15 of Volume III. An additional variable that showed temporal change is rim orientation. Of the three orientation classes identified, only the South Midden and South area had the inverted category. This may relate to a higher incidence of carinated bowl forms in these areas, a vessel form that occurs more frequently in the Late Caddo period of East Texas (Suhm and Jetks 1962). The occurrence of this rim orientation in the South Midden and South area is consistent with the temporal implications of the decoration element data. Another variable showing some temporal relationship is the occurrence of exterior rolled lips in the South Midden and South area, Although the sample sizes are small on which this interpretation is based, a tendency does exist for rolled rims to occur more frequently in the southern portions of the site, once again corroborating the results of other variables that suggest latest occupation in this area. In summary, the objective of a refined ceramic chronology for the site has, at best, only been partially successful. In the southern parts of the site (South Midden and South) ceramics are found Volume U, Part One which have some characteristics similar to the Late Caddoan types of East Texas. Otherwise the sherds from the site are quite consistent in attribute variability and show greatest affinity to the Early Caddo of East Texas. Concerning the objective of where these ceramics were manufactured, the data suggest that they were made locally. The petrographic analysis on thin-sectioned samples of sherds showed that all specimens had constituents and grain sizes that were most likely from local clay deposits. The analysis of exterior sherd colors also showed uniformity in colors among the areas of the site, with the exception of the South area. The uniformity is interpreted to indicate local manufacture of most ceramics. The aberrant colors from the South, however, may be due to vessels from this area having been made somewhere else. Perhaps the later occupation that seems to have occurred in the South Midden and South areas represents a temporary occupation by a non- indigenous group. Considering the close proximity of the reservoir to the East Texas Caddo, it is possible that the site was visited by groups of Caddo during the A.D. 1300 to 1650 time period and that these groups were at the site for a sufficient time to leave several broken pots. Unfortunately the petrographic analysis did not include sherds from this part of the site, so this hypothesis must remain untested. Chapter 14 discusses the occupation of this part of the site in greater detail, using other data sources to address the question of local versus non-indigenous group occupation.
