weweuee Eee AU eee SUBSISTENCE PATTERNS by William A. Martin and James E. Bruseth with contributions by Gayle J. Fritz, Phillip Murry, and Richard Fullington In this chapter, the macrobotanical and faunal remains recovered from excavations at Bird Point Island are discussed within the context of human ecology. The ultimate goal of this approach is to examine changes in resource utilization over time in order to better understand the diet of the prehistoric populations occupying the site during the past two millennia. In the first section, human ecological theory is briefly discussed. In the second section, the macrobotanical data analyzed by Gayle Fritz of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill are presented. In the third section, faunal data are presented by Phillip Murry of Tarleton State University, along with a description of molluscs identified by Richard Fullington of the Dallas Museum of Natural History. In the final section, the implications of these data sets are discussed with respect to human nutritional requirements and resource scheduling. At the outset, it must be noted that preservation of subsistence remains, particularly faunal remains, is rather poor. Acid soils, natural soil disturbance processes, and scavenging of discarded remains by wild animals have all had a negative effect on preservation. As a result, the sample is undoubtedly affected by preservational biases. Yet despite this problem, extensive sampling for floral and faunal materials has remained a major goal of the excavation strategy. The strategy applied to the study of subsistence remains at Bird Point Island was to sample as wide a variety of contexts as possible and to identify floral and faunal remains to the most specific taxon possible. Even though poor preservation limits the interpretive potential of the data, it appears that minimal data from a wide variety of contexts can provide a representative picture of subsistence patterns. This certainly provides a better overall understanding of subsistence patterns than does the sampling of only a limited number of features with good preservation, which may reflect idiosyncratic behavior or which may not represent the overall pattern of resource acquisition and utilization. ECOLOGICAL BACKGROUND HUMAN ECOLOGY AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL REMAINS In anthropology, two major theoretical approaches have been used to study the relationship between culture and environment. Cognitive anthropologists have examined living cultures to identify the social norms and values that affect subsistence behavior (Bamburger 1971; Levi-Strauss 1969), whereas materialists have attempted to identify the ecological variables that influence human subsistence behavior (Harris 1979; Rappaport 1968). The materialist approach toward the study of cultural ecology has been adopted by archaeologists because they can measure biophysical variables and relate them to site distributions and site contents, whereas they cannot measure variables associated with the value systems of extinct cultures (Hilliard 1980:3). The principal concept of ecological theory is energy and its flow throughout the ecosystem. The ecosystem is a system in which energy flows among the plants, animals and microorganisms which interact to form the food chain (Erlich and Erlich 1970:157). The biological concept of adaptation to a particular environment is applied to organisms which are altered as a result of natural selection in a manner such that they become better suited to their environment and increase their ability to reproduce in that environment. Cultural ecology, often referred to as human ecology, considers the biological concepts of energy flow and energy capture among organisms which interact with a human population. It also considers the nonbiological factors unique to human populations, i.e., social and cultural factors that influence the adaptive strategy of the human population (Raab 1976). 127

128 The ecological reconstruction of prehistoric diets from archaeological materials entails the céllection, quantification, and identification of the various food remains found on sites to establish their relative importance in the dietary intake of the population (Gilbert 1985:344). Understanding the season of resource availability, its abundance, distribution, and ease of collection is also necessary to make statements about subsistence related decision-making processes (Lee 1979:68). The resources that were available to the population and the socioeconomic means used to exploit resources must also be considered (Raab et al. 1982:99). This entails the collection of paleoenvironmental data from several disciplines in addition to the collection of archaeological data. At Richland Creek, the analysis of pollen from cores obtained in nearby bogs, and the geomorphological analysis of the terraces and floodplain provide information suitable for reconstructing changes in the environment over time (see Chapter 5, Volume I). Thus, changes in the resources available to human populations can be inferred at various points in time for comparison with materials recovered from archae- ological contexts. RESOURCE AVAILABILITY AND ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE The three environmental zones discussed in detail in the Introduction to this volume are within close proximity to Bird Point Island, so a variety of resources could have been exploited by the prehistoric inhabitants with a minimum investment of time and effort. These zones, the Post Oak Savannah, Bottomland Forest, and Tall Grass Prairie, contained several plant and animal species important in the diet of the inhabitants of Bird Point Island. Although detailed information is available in Chapter 1, a brief description of these environmental zones and their relative resource potentials is presented here. The highly diversified Post Oak Savannah is advantageous for nut procurement, since several nut producing species are present which can be relied upon to produce a crop year after year. When one species has a bad year, others can make up the deficit (Hilliard 1980:21). Since acorns are an important wildlife food for many species, and animal reproduction rates are directly tied to good and bad years of acorn production (Crawford et al. 1969:206), the Post Oak Savannah is also an ideal hunting territory. Whitetail deer (Odocoileus virginianus) and wild turkey (Meleagris gallopavo) rely heavily on acorns (Ellis and Lewis 1967; Lay 1969). Deer concentrate their daily activity in the presence of a concentrated food supply and disperse when food becomes scarce (Byford 1969:77). This relationship between acorn production and animal behavior has important implications for the seasonal scheduling of resource exploitation. Raab (1976) believes that the aggregation of deer around nut resources would have increased hunter/prey contact during the fall, as human and animal populations competed for nut resources. Also, it is in the fall that the rutting season occurs and deer behavior changes dramatically as mating commences. Ethnographic accounts show that historic Indian groups took advantage of this season to hunt deer (Swanton 1946). Competition from mammals and insects would have forced human populations to collect and process acorns and other nuts early in the fall (Hilliard 1980:26). If the acorns were not collected shortly after they dropped, deer and squirrel competition would have made collection less effective. Moreover, if they were not roasted or processed in some form, massive infestation of weevil (Curculia sp.) larvae could have devastated the supply (Hilliard 1980:28). Ethnographic sources indicate that nut resources were extremely important to the native populations of the Southeastern United States (Swanton 1946; Hudson 1976; Heizer 1977). Hickory nuts and walnuts were usually processed to obtain vegetable oil for use as seasoning and thickening for soups (Hilliard 1980:26). The nuts were cracked by pounding with stones, and the meats and shells were boiled. The oil was skimmed off the top and stored in Volume H, Part One ceramic vessels or skin bags (Hariot 1590:18). Acorns were also processed to retrieve oil and were roasted (Swanton 1946:366). Analysis has shown that some prehistoric populations intentionally collected the most nutritious acorn species. For instance, Hilliard (1980:36) demonstrated that acoms of the red oak group were chosen over those of the white oak group by the prehistoric inhabitants of the Arkansas Ozarks, even though those of the white oak group were more. abundant. This strategy reflects the fact that acoms of the red oak group have a much higher fat content, and hence, a higher caloric value than those of the white oak group. In addition to nuts and deer, another important resource that would have been plentiful in the Post Oak Savannah is the prairie turnip (Psoralea sp.). Psoralea esculenta is a historically documented staple among numerous groups of Plains Indians (Wedel 1978; Reid 1977; Kaye and Moodie 1978). In the dry, grassland climate of the Plains where agriculture was marginal, this fleshy tuber was heavily relied upon by several groups (Kaye and Moodie 1978:329). From its name, one might expect to find the prairie turnip within the Tall Grass Prairie environmental zone; instead it would have been concentrated on the sandy soils of the Post Oak Savannah and terraces of Richland Creek (Correll and Johnston 1970:813-817). Although the tubers are present year round, they must be collected in the early spring before the above ground parts wither and are blown away (Wedel 1978:162). Once the plant tops are gone it is virtually impossible to locate the tubers; consequently, the scheduling of Psoralea exploitation within the Richland Creek vicinity must have occurred during a critical period in early to mid-May. Ethnographic accounts document the importance of Psoralea in the diets of Plains Indian groups. It accounted for most of the carbohydrate intake among several groups and was an important subsistence item because of its abundance and long term storage capacity. Lewis and Clark (1904-1905) noted that when dried, the tubers could last up to several years. Wedel (1978:166) notes that the tubers were eaten raw, boiled whole, sliced, or mashed with meat, berries, and other items. Other accounts note that the tubers were roasted, which may account for the high incidence of charred Psoralea inside roasting pits at Bird Point Island. Within the Bottomland Forest zone, aquatic resources were present in creeks and sloughs that would have provided good sources of protein. Gar and other fish would have been available in quantity after spawning in early spring and could be taken through fall before they moved to deeper water (Butler and Perttula 1981:122). Fish and turtle were probably abundant and could be collected with a minimum amount of effort during late spring and summer once they were confined to sloughs and pools after spring floodwaters receded (Gibson 1973:331). Aquatic resources are known to have supplied a reliable source of protein to Mississippian populations adapted to meander belt regions during the summer when deer were dispersed and more difficult to hunt (Smith 1975:481). Mussels from the stream beds also provided sources of protein that have been easily obtainable during periods of low flow in the summer and fall. The fruits and berries available within the Bottomland Forest zone would have been sought as sources of carbohydrates and vitamin C (Bruseth and Perttula 1981:125). They ripen in the late summer and fall and were probably dried and stored for winter use, a common practice among both Plains and eastern tribes (Wedel 1978; Hudson 1976). Small herbaceous annuals growing along the disturbed habitats of the floodplain would have yielded abundant quantities of seeds during middle to late summer. These seeds would have provided additional sources of carbohydrates and in the case of marsh elder, a vegetable oil high in fats as well as carbohydrates (Yarnell 1978). Thus, both plant and animal resources available within the Bottomland Forest zone would have been exploited primarily during the summer and fall. The resources of the Tall Grass Prairie were probably among the least important to the prehistoric groups occupying the Richland Creek valley since few edible species were available. The plant community was dominated by grasses, so few species would

PRESENTATION OF SUBSISTENCE DATA The following sections present data tabulations and discussions of macrobotanical remains by Gayle Fritz, faunal remains by Phillip Murry, and molluscan remains by Richard Fullington. Sampling techniques and factors of preservation are outlined here, showing their implications for underrepresentation of some species which could affect interpretation. First, macrobotanical remains were recovered by means of flotation from cultural features only. Faunal remains were recovered from the flotation samples too, but they were also analyzed from 1 x 1 mand 2x 2m units which were screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh. This discrepancy in sampling is due to the fact that charred plant remains are too small to be recovered in 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh, whereas numerous faunal elements are large and easily collectable in mesh of this size. The faunal remains recovered by flotation include small bones of fish and birds which would pass through the larger mesh. As a result, the total faunal assemblage from the site is more heavily represented by large mammal remains. In general, faunal preservation is relatively poor, particularly in the North portion of the site where the higher acidity of the Ultic Haplustalfs has deteriorated bone specimens (see Chapter 2). Within the midden where more alkaline Typic Haplustalfs and Typic Ustochrepts are present, bone preservation is better. In addition, concentrations of mussel shells in some of the features within the midden apparently neutralized the detrimental effects of acidity and resulted in relatively good bone preservation in a few instances. Charred macrobotanical remains are relatively well preserved in all features. However, Munson et al. (1971) point out that different plants have different potentials for being deposited, preserved, and identified in archaeological contexts, and the proportions of plants recovered from features do not necessarily reflect the actual proportions used. They define three classes of plants arranged in descending order of depositional, preservational, and identifiable potential. The plant remains most likely to be recovered are dense inedible parts such as nutshell and fruit pits. Next are the dense edible parts such as seeds, nut meats, and maize kernels. Finally, plants least likely to be encountered are nondense plant parts with high water content such as greens, tubers, and fruit pulp. Differences in nut shel! thickness, weight, and durability must also be considered. For instance, thick-shelled species such as hickory and walnut have much higher preservation potential than do thin-shelled species such as acorn (Munson et al. 1971:427). ANALYSIS OF CARBONIZED MACROBOTANICAL REMAINS (by Gayle J. Fritz) Carbonized plant remains recovered by flotation during all seasons of excavation at Bird Point Island have been analyzed at the Macrobotanical Laboratory, Research Laboratories of Anthropology, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Field work at Bird Point Island has resulted in the recovery and examination of archaeobotanical remains from 87 features at the site. Approximately 3,744 | of soil were processed to yield these items. Analysis was conducted by the author with advice from Dr. Richard A. Yarnell. 129 METHODS The contents of each sample were passed through a series of 10 graduated, standard geological sieves with mesh sizes ranging from 6.4 to 0.2 mm in order to facilitate sorting. The size groups were examined under a low power (7x to 30x) binocular micro- scope, and fragments larger than 2.0 mm were sorted and weighed according to category. The combined weights of heavy and light fractions are recorded in Table 9-1. The smaller size groups were examined for seeds and types of materials not present in the larger fractions. They were not completely sorted since many fragments smalier than 2.0 mm cannot be identified with enough certainty to justify the time expenditure necessary for such separation. The kinds of seeds identified are presented in Table 9-2, A standard laboratory procedure developed by Yarnell (1974:113-114) involves using the weights of the sorted categories larger than 2.0 mm in order to calculate the weight of each type of carbonized material larger than 0.7 mm. This method was not applied to the Richland Creek samples due to the large number of rootlet fragments. The weight of the combined carbonized remains smaller than 2.0 mm or larger than 0.7 mm was not determined since they could not be efficiently sorted from the uncarbonized matter in the time available. The ratio of carbonized to uncarbonized remains appeared to vary considerably from feature to feature and from size group to size group, making highly questionable the assumption that types of materials were represented in the 0.7 to 2.0 mm fractions in the same proportions as they occurred in the larger sized part of the sample. Parts of the samples smaller than 0.7 mm contain a disproportionately high percentage of fine soil particles, so they are excluded from the calculations in this as well as other analyses, although they were always scanned for seeds. RESULTS Wood Wood was the most abundant component of the flotation samples both by weight and frequency of occurrence. All features sampled contained some quantity of wood charcoal for a total weight of 135.43 g. Features 30 and 125 consisted of little other than charcoal, and Features 18, 20, 21, and 36 were especially dominated by wood. Nutshell Nutshell ranked second to wood charcoal in frequency of occurrence. Hickory nut shell (Carya sp.) was most common, occurring in all features except Features 30, 122, 125 and Post Hole 102, Pecan shell (Carya illinoensis) occurred in 72% of the samples, being absent from only 19 features, 5 burials, and 10 post holes. Acom shell (Quercus sp.) was present in 61% of the samples, being in all but 21 features, 7 burials, and 6 post holes. The total weights for nutshell were 50.47 g for hickory, 3.2 g for pecan, and 1.64 g for acom. Black walnut (Juglans nigra) was also present in Feature 12 with a weight of 0.06 g. The over representation of hickory shell is a common phenomenon in archaeobotanical samiples due to the greater probability that hickory shell will have been charred and preserved in large enough fragments to reach the analyst. Most if not all of the thick-shelled hickory nut remains from Bird Point Island are presumed to belong to the species Carya texana based on modern species distributions (Correll and Johnston 1970). Likewise, underrepresentation of acorns is common. Yarnell (1974:119) estimated that weights of acorn shell in flotation samples need to be multiplied by 20 in order to compensate for differential preservation relative to thick-walled hickory nuts.

INTERPRETATION Time Depth Excavations at Bird Point Island have revealed prehistoric occupation during four time periods: ca. 170 B.C. - A.D. 130, ca. A.D. 580 - 860, ca. A.D. 1000 - 1200, and ca. A.D. 1300 - 1650 (see Chapter 12). Table 9-3 (percentage of plant foods by weight) has been prepared in an effort to recognize changing patterns of plant utilization through time. However, as noted previously in Chapter 4, the temporal placement of several features is uncertain, so broad pattems of change in plant use must be regarded as best estimates. Some categories of plant remains are included in this tabulation in spite of their dubious qualification as foods. The rhizome fragments, for example, could not be narrowed down to any particular taxon and were, therefore, possibly not remnants of subsistence items at all. Grass stems were not recognized in these features, however, and underground piant parts were obviously being utilized. The rhizome fragments are therefore included with the plant food types. The bud or fruit category was likewise of questionable significance for subsistence, since the few tiny items classified as either buds or fruits could well have been incidental inclusions in the features. Some of the seed types also may not have been ingested, poison ivy, for example. ~ Unfortunately, macrobotanical specimens from the earlier two periods were recovered in only five and three features, respectively, that can be assigned with confidence to those periods. The combined weight of plant foods present in the flotation samples from these eight features is less than one gram, so the proportions of different types of plant foods may not be representative. The absence of pecan shell from the three A.D. 580 - 860 features could be a function of the small sample size. The differences between proportions of the other nut types (hickory and acorn) and Psoralea tuber are not felt to indicate any changing patterns between the two periods. ve Subsistence Remains up in these features is an increase in use of seeds and fruits through time, with sumpweed, vetch, knotweed, and sumac showing up in the samples dating to A.D. 580 - 860, and continuing to be present later. The A.D. 1000-1200 time period is represented in the macrobotanical sample by at least 15 and perhaps as many as 20 features and burials and 14 interior post holes from Houses 1, 2, and 3. The three circular house patterns indicate that a small hamlet occupied the site at this time. One of the features assignable to this period, Feature 38, is a large, irregular pit classified as a roasting pit. Five other features called roasting pits (Features 33, 34, 35, 36, and 45) may date to ca. A.D. 1000-1200 as well. Table 9-3 shows that, when averaged across the features, hickory nutshell accounts for approximately 75% of the plant food weight, followed by Psoralea tuber at approximately 10%, pecan shell at 4%, and acorn shell at 2.1%. Rhizomes and small fruits also are occasionally present. Seeds were recovered from 60% of the nonposthole features, with a total of 133 identifiable seeds. Only two seeds came from postholes. More than 65% of the seeds from features assignable to this period were concentrated in two features: Burial 28, a probable cremation; and Feature 113, a possible storage pit inside House 3. The 51 Vicia-type seeds (see Fritz 1983 and 1984 for descriptions) from Burial 28 are difficult to interpret given the lack of any comparable concentration of wild pea or vetch seeds in other features. In smaller numbers, however, the Vicia-type seeds were recovered from nine features (including post holes) assignable to the A.D. 1000-1200 time period, with a total count of 69. The use of this plant type for food is therefore a good possibility. The deliberate inclusion of vetch pods with this cremation (Burial 28) as a burial offering could have resulted in the concentration as found. Feature 113, with 29 sumpweed seeds, two Vicia-type seeds, one unidentified legume (Fabaceae), and one other unidentified seed, is seen as especially good evidence for intentional processing of sumpweed for subsistence use. [va was present in five other features of this period (n=46), making it the most abundant and most frequently encountered seed taxon after the vetch type. Use of fruits such as sumac and grape is indicated by four Rhus and one Vitis seed. The two Polygonum seeds from Feature 58 are weak evidence for exploitation of knotweeds and smartweeds for food. Nineteen features at Bird Point Island are assignable to A.D. 1300-1650. This most recent period does not appear to differ markedly from its earlier counterpart in terms of proportions of the major plant food types (Table 9-2). Hickory nutshell averages close to 75%, Psoralea tuber is just over 11%, pecan shell accounts for an average of 7.2%, and acorn shell averages 4.8%. Feature 12 yielded the only walnut shell recovered from the site, but its weight accounted for only 1.4% of the plant food remains. Rhizome and fruit continue to be minor categories as before. Two notable contrasts, however, are the presence of maize and a possible drop in the exploitation of seeds. The recovery of a few maize cupules from three features of the period raises more questions than it answers. Do four cupules from four seasons of intensive excavation constitute evidence for local maize husbandry, when contact with Caddoan farmers less than 100 km to the east was probable? Why was maize recovered from this later, nonsedentary component rather than from the A.D. 1000-1200 hamlet? These questions cannot be answered by considering macrobotanical evidence alone. Even in conjunction with bioanthropological data, it might be difficult or impossible to determine whether a small amount of maize was being produced locally or was being acquired through exchange. It seems clear, however, that all components at Bird Point Island were essentially nonagricultural. Some maize was present after A.D. 1300, but the main pattern of plant use remained one dominated by nuts and roots. The smaller number of seeds from the 19 features dating to A.D. 1300-1650 (34 as compared to 135) may reflect a decline in exploitation of the two most abundant taxa represented earlier: sumpweed and vetch. Each of these seed types, however, was recovered from five of the features dating to the most recent 135 occupation, so some use of them continued. Sumac and grape are more abundant in the most recent features, but still present only in small numbers. The other taxa (Oxalis, Polygonum, Chenopodium, Galium, and Desmanthus) were present in numbers too small to be considered significant. Seasonality Nuts must be gathered in the fall, but could be processed and stored for use throughout the year. Other fall-ripening plants found in the flotation samples at the site are sumpweed, sumac, grape, knotweed, and chenopod. Psoralea tubers are reported to have been gathered in the spring or early summer, because the stems and leaves break loose and blow away after spring flowering, leaving no indication of the location of the roots (Gilmore 1977; Wedel 1978; Reid 1977; Kaye and Moodie 1978). Although the tubers were stored in large quantities for winter use across the Plains, ethnographic sources cited by the above authors indicate that prairie tummips were peeled immediately after harvesting. Since the carbonized fragments recognizable archaeologically seem to be parts of the hard outer cortex, a spring or early summer occupation at Bird Point Island is inferred. Another good indicator of spring occupation is the presence of vetch seeds (Correll and Johnston 1970). Maize would mean spring and summer or summer and fall occupation, if produced locally. ' Dietary Considerations The proportions of plant food types in the features as shown in Table 9-2 are useful for making comparisons across time and space, but do not necessarily reflect the relative dietary importance of the items listed. Difficulties in reconstructing the botanical element of prehistoric human diets are widely recognized; the basic problems stem from considerable differences in the likelihood of various plants becoming carbonized, deposited, preserved intact, recovered, and recognized during analysis (Yarnell 1982). Thick hickory nut shell is probably vastly overrepresented, especially as compared to fragile acorn shell. So far, there is no good system of adjusting for this disparity. At Bird Point Island, it seems that nuts were extremely important. It is best at this point to refrain from speculations concerning which nut type may have been dominant. Acorn and pecan are both common enough to be viewed as very important. The possibility that acorns contributed more heavily to the diet than hickory nuts should not be discounted. Hickory nuts and acorns provide very different proportions of basic nutritional elements. Hickory nut meats are more than 70% fat (dry weight composition), 13-16% protein, and 8-10% carbohydrates. They provide more than 700 calories per 100 g of nut meat (Talalay et al. 1984). Acorns, on the other hand, are high in carbohydrates, although the red and white oak groups vary with respect to percentages of fat and carbohydrate content. The red oak acorns have more than 20% fat and 60-70% carbohydrates, while white oak acorns are characterized by only 4-8% fat but more than 80% carbohydrate content (Petruso and Wickens 1984), Protein content in acorns ranges from 6% to 8.5%. The number of calories per 100 g of acorn meat varies from 221 to 328, with red oaks being significantly higher than the white oak group. The nutritional value of Psoralea esculenta is discussed by Wedel (1978) and by Kaye and Moodie (1978). The main species represented archaeologically at Bird Point Island may be P. latestipulata Shinners, formerly included in the taxon P. esculenta Pursh, Shinners (1958:209) notes that this species "has been misidentified as P. esculenta Pursh, which occurs from Oklahoma northward.” Other species of Psoralea have swollen taproots, but do not offer the ovoid tubers that form on P. esculenta and P. latestipulata roots. Nutritional data for P. esculenta are provided SS

The primary plant foods, then, would have contributed fats (especially the hickories, the red oak acorns, and Iva seeds), carbohydrates (especially the acorns and tubers), and essential vitamins and minerals. Meat is assumed to have been the primary source of protein, but the nuts and sumpweed seeds could have supplied protein during times when meat was scarce. Sumac fruits would have been another good source of vitamin C, and grapes were probably enjoyed for sugar content. It is quite likely that other plants were utilized when in season without entering the archaeological record. All of the major plants recovered are known to have been gathered as foods or drinks by native North Americans, although medicinal usage also may have been practiced. The use and importance of vetch or wild pea seeds remains problematic. Gilmore (1977) lists a type of wild sweetpea, Lathyrus ornatus, which was eaten by the Ponca. "Children sometimes gathered the pods, which they roasted and ate in sport. The plant was not considered of any importance, although noted and named (Gilmore 1977:46).” Edible early-season legumes such as Lathyrus and Vicia on the southern prairies must have been welcome additions to the diet, even if they never played a major role. ANALYSIS OF FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) The presence of three major habitats in close proximity to Bird Point Island is reflected in the archaeological faunal assemblage by the presence of numerous species with varied habitat preferences. Some degree of preservational bias undoubtedly affects the faunal assemblage such that the sample, although representative of the total archaeological assemblage present at the site today, probably does not represent the assemblage in the same proportion that the animals were exploited (Smith and Wetterstrom 1978:99-100). There is a definite bias toward the preservation of large bones from large mammals. Dense elements resistant to destruction and not favored for tool use are more likely to be recovered. Despite the problems with representation of total numbers of individuals, several conclusions are possible on the basis of the wide range of seasonally exploitable species present. This section presents a description of the faunal composition of the site with regard to changing patterns of utilization over time. Each species recognized is discussed and conclusions are presented concerning seasonality and the general nature of the faunal assemblage. Volume II, Part One METHODOLOGY Vertebrate specimens were recovered from Bird Point Island through excavation and sieving with a minor amount of specimens recovered by means of flotation techniques. Recovered material was transported to the Archaeology Research Program laboratory in Corsicana, Texas, for cleaning and cataloging and then transferred to the Department of Physical Sciences at Tarleton State University for further analysis. Upon receipt of the faunal material a general survey of the assemblage was conducted to determine faunal components and trends. Bones were further cleaned with dental picks and brushes for analysis and measurement. Although many faunal analyses utilize numbers of bone specimens within the site in determining cultural patterns, such modes of analyses have certain drawbacks. For example, usually no distinction is made between large and small unidentifiable bone fragments and these are counted individually. Therefore, a site which contains numerous tiny bone fragments due to cultural or preservational factors would seemingly contain much more bone than is actually preserved within the site. A more accurate method for determining bone concentration is through measurement of bone volume or weight. Both measurements were attempted in this study. Numerous bone fragments were measured within the site to determine bone volume. However, the irregularity of bone fragments, the curvature of large bones, and the number of measurements necessary for analysis make this an impractical and somewhat imprecise method when large numbers.of specimens are involved. Therefore, it was determined that a more accurate and efficient method for determining bone concentration was through the weighing of all bone within each level. Also, so that midden and butchering areas could be better differentiated, the bone was separated into burned and unburned portions for measurement. After the initial survey and weighing of the bummed and unburned portions of the assemblage, each identifiable element was compared with species within the vertebrate osteology collection at Tarleton State University. Elk and mule deer specimens were borrowed from the private collection of Mr. Robert Scott for comparison with some of the larger cervid specimens. Counts of identifiable elements are presented in Tables 9-4 through 9-6. Bone weights are presented in Appendix C. After identification of the faunal elements was completed, the microfilm library of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Fort Worth was consulted in order to establish a regional interpretation of faunal distribution and utilization within the North Central Texas area. Despite the poor bone preservation mentioned previously, considerable material was collected from the extensive excavations. Although preservational bias exists which may cause large mammal bone to be somewhat overrepresented, the results of the study provide important insights into the prehistoric. patterns of animal exploitation. ; Bone was recovered from a variety of contexts including 1 x 1 m and 50 x 50 cm units excavated in the A horizon (Table 9-4), material found within feature exposed at the interface of the A and B horizons (Table 9-5), and the 2 x 2 m excavation units within Feature 1 (Table 9-6). Although several units excavated within the A horizon were placed across the upper portions of features, and therefore may be related to feature content, they are discussed by area of the site rather than with the features, because the A horizon is the zone most subject to secondary deposition and bioturbation. Only elements recovered from clear feature contexts are included in Table 9-5. The material from Feature 1 is presented on a zone by zone basis in Table 9-6 to help assess changes in the use of the pit over time as well as changes in the species exploited over time. The overall site fauna is dominated by whitetail deer (Odocoileus virginianus) although other mammalian species were recovered from Feature 1 including bison (Bison bison), domestic dog (Canis familiaris), black-tailed jackrabbit (Lepus californicus), cottontail and swamp rabbit (Sylvilagus floridanuslaquaticus), and opossum (Didelphis marsupialis). Also, a variety of rodent species was recovered including packrat (Neotoma floridana), cotton rat (Sigmodon hispidus), vole (Pitymys/Microtus sp.), pocket gopher (Geomys sp.), and white- footed mouse (Peromyscus sp.). Fish species recovered within Feature 1 were gar (Lepisosteous sp.), sunfish (Lepomis), and other unidentifiable teleosts. Both softshell turtle (Trionyx sp.) and testudinid turtles were recovered, as well as frog and iguanid lizard bones. A considerable variety of colubid snakes was recovered including racer (Coluber constrictor), pine snake (Pituophis melanoleucus), water snake (Natrix sp.), and possibly com snake (Elaphe sp.). Viperid species recovered included both cottonmouth water moccasin (Agkistrodon piscivorous) and western diamondback rattlesnake (Crotalus atrox). Also, a number 137 of bird remains were found including what are probably bones of wild turkey (Meleagris gallopavo), Bison (Bison bison Linnaeus) Bison remains were found at a level below Features 78 and 86, in Unit 401 of Feature 1, which are dated at A.D. 580-860. Since the remains are below the dated level it is assumed that they are older than A.D. 860. Bison remains from Feature 45 may date between A.D. 1000-1200. Burned bison material was present within Feature 102, which has been tentatively dated at A.D. 1300- 1650. A number of other bison elements of uncertain chronology were also found. Within the South Midden several bison remains were found, including material from Control Trench 4 at the southeast end of the midden, Within the artifact concentration near the slough in the South area of the site, bison remains were also found. According to Schmidly (1983), bison once ranged over much of Central Texas. Late records of bison within the Central Texas area include accounts of numerous animals within the northern part of Brazos County in 1822 and in the northern and western sections of McLennan County. Both counties are within 120 km of the study area. These populations soon became extinct with the appearance of Euro-American settlement within the area. Bison have been identified from numerous archaeological sites within North Central Texas (Lynott 1979; Murry 1982). However, their numbers are not nearly as numerous as whitetail deer within any of these sites. Lynott (1979) proposed that bison populations in North Central Texas were relatively smal! until the Late Prehistoric period (post- A.D. 1200). The reason for this apparent increase in the bison population after A.D. 1200 was supposedly related to the hypothesized expansion of the short grass prairies during times of drought. Bison elements are relatively poorly represented in all features within the site, although some elements were found within three chronological periods; A.D. 580-860, A.D. 1000-1200 and A.D. 1300-1650. It is apparent that either not many bison were killed within the period from A.D. 1-1650 or that bison were killed elsewhere and only the meat was transported back to the site. It is also possible that the Bottomland Forest and Post Oak Savannah environments surrounding the site did not satisfy the habitat requirements of bison. More data from nearby prairie sites is needed for comparison to fully test this hypothesis. However, it is clear that, compared with other food species, especially whitetail deer, bison was only of minor importance in the prehistoric diet throughout all time periods. There is a slight tendency, though, for more bison to occur in parts of the site assigned to the A.D. 1300 - 1650 period. This is seen in Tables 9-4 and 9-5 where excavations in the South Midden and South areas produced more bison. Whitetail Deer (Odocoileus virginianus Zimmerman) Deer bone dominated the faunal assemblage at Bird Point Island. The Post Oak Savannah and Bottomland Forest habitats are most favorable for deer because of the presence of plant browse species which account for approximately 50% of the deer's diet. The presence of such plant species will provide for large populations of deer. In 1981, for example, the Post Oak Savannah of Texas supported a population of over 279,000 deer, considerably higher than surrounding zones. Considering that the number of deer in East Texas has declined sharply due to recent agricultural practices, it is apparent that this habitat supported tremendous deer populations during the prehistoric period (Davis 1974; Schmidly 1983). Very large amounts of deer were apparently consumed by the prehistoric population of Bird Point Island. Examination of Table 9-4 shows that deer bone was found in the majority of units excavated in the A horizon. The vast majority of bone was found - in the North Midden and South Midden areas. This pattern probably reflects the higher rate of discard of refuse in the midden, coupled with the better bone preservation potential of the soils in these areas of the site as compared with the soils in the North area. Table 9-5 illustrates the ubiquitous nature of deer bone throughout the features. Only seven features (25%), out of the 28 containing faunal elements, lacked deer bone. The large variety of deer elements which has been recovered indicates that entire deer were transported to the site for butchering and processing. There is a sparcity of identifiable long bone elements at the site, except for metapodial fragments whose extremities tend to be preserved and which are easily recognized. The long bones were apparently broken for the extraction of marrow. Bone marrow, besides being a favorite food of prehistoric peoples, also provides a major source of vitamin C in hunting cultures (Speth 1983). The most common types of deer elements present are those which are resistant to destruction and which are little utilized for food or tool-making, such as teeth, calcanea, and astragali. Domestic Dog (Canis familiaris Linnaeus) A dog burial (Feature 11) in Zone 3 of Feature 1 is believed to date between 170 B.C. and A.D. 130. Dog remains found in Feature 86, also in Feature 1, probably date between A.D. 580 and 860. Other remains found within Zone 1 of Feature 1, date to later periods. A dog burial containing numerous elements was found within Feature 98, tentatively dated at A.D. 1300-1650. Burned. elements of dog were also found within Feature 87. Tentative identifications of domestic dog in Feature 95 and in Feature 116 were also made. One 1 x 1 m unit excavated in the South Midden contained dog elements, but all other canine remains were found within the context of features. Volume H, Part One The above chronology indicates that dog burials are present within three chronological periods; 170 B.C. - A.D. 130, A.D. 580 - 860, and A.D. 1300 - 1650. Considering the close proximity of the remains in Feature 88, dated at 170 B.C. to A.D. 130, to those within other parts of Feature 1 dated at A.D. 580-860, the former date range is somewhat suspect. However, it.is certainly evident that dog burials were more common after A.D. 580. It is curious that no dog burials are clearly associated with the A.D. 1000-1200 occupation, since this period produced much of the fauna found outside of Feature 1. Measurements of long bones, vertebrae, and maxillae of the dogs were compared to those of an adult coyote. The dog elements, parts of several individual adults, were approximately 80% of the size of the coyote. This indicates that their approximate total length was 1 m, if we assume that the animals were proportioned . similarly to the coyote. The presence of burned remains of domestic dog within Feature 97, and possibly Feature 95, may indicate some utilization as food or may possibly represent cremations. Raccoon (Procyon lotor Linnaeus) The only positively identified raccoon elements were recovered in Zone 1 of Feature 1, dating between A.D. 1000 and 1650, and from two 1 x 1 m units, one dug in the North area and one in the South Midden (Table 9-4). Possible raccoon elements were recovered from other 1 x 1 m units in the North Midden and South Midden, and a possible element was recovered within the context of Feature 102 (Table 9-5). The dates associated with these areas of the site range from A.D. 1000-1650. Today raccoons are commonly hunted for their fur, and this was likely the case during much of the prehistoric period. Although raccoons are found in many habitats, they prefer hardwood forests and are very abundant along the larger streams (Schmidly 1983). Therefore, these animals would be abundant components of the faund and certainly would be available for utilization. They have been widely utilized as food during historic times (Lowery 1974), and the fact that they are very fat may be one reason for their popularity as food items. As mentioned by Speth (1983), both modern and ancient hunters often sought fat- bearing species because they preferred their taste. Fat also supplies a concentrated source of energy in the diet. Black-Tailed Jackrabbit (Lepus californicus Gray) The only bones in Feature 1 which may represent jackrabbit were found in Zone 2, dating between A.D. 580 and 860 (Table 9- 6). Other features containing jackrabbit remains are Features 45, 97, and 102, which indicate utilization between A.D. 1000 and 1650 (Table 9-5). Jackrabbit remains were equally divided between the North area and the South Midden, which also suggests utilization between A.D, 1000-1650 (Table 9-4). Thus, jackrabbit is represented for every period except the 170 B.C. to A.D. 130 occupation. Bumed bones indicate that jackrabbits were a’ food source of the prehistoric inhabitants of Bird Point Island. Jackrabbits are characteristic of prairie communities and are often found within environments on the black clay soil. Jackrabbits become especially abundant where herbage has been thinned and actually benefit from grazing by cattle (Schmidly 1983). In fact, jackrabbits will remain only where there is open grassland. Eastern Cottontail and Swamp Rabbit (Sylvilagus floridanus Allen and S. aquaticus Bachman) These two species of Syivilagus are considered together because of their taxonomic similarities. Although the swamp rabbit tends to be larger than the cottontail, there is considerable overlap in size and similarity of morphology during the life

Burned rabbit remains were found in Feature 1, in Zones 2 and 3 of Unit 401, ranging in age from 170 B.C. to A.D. 860. From the A.D. 1000-1200 period, Feature 45 contained considerable rabbit elements. Only one unit containing bones of Sylvilagus was found in the North area, whereas several units in the North Midden and South Midden area yielded Sylvilagus remains. It appears that these species were utilized to some degree during all periods of occupation but may have been utilized to a greater extent during the later occupations associated with the midden accumulation. The best habitat for cottontails is within brushy or grassy areas with good ground cover. They prefer grassy areas much more than woodlands. With increased grazing, cottontails tend to decrease in numbers, while jackrabbits tend to increase in population. Swamp rabbits tend to inhabit hardwood bottomland swamps. The species is seldom found far from water, and within the Tall Grass Prairie, Sylvilagus aquaticus is restricted to the floodplains of rivers-(i.e., the Bottomland Forest habitat). The lack of these rabbit elements with the assemblages dating from 170 B.C. to A.D. 130, and from A.D. 1300-1650, may prove to be significant for determining climatic conditions at these times. The data, albeit tenuous, suggest drier conditions during those periods. Rodents Several rodent species were encountered: beaver (Castor canadensis), pocket gopher (Geomys sp.), pocket mouse (Perognathus sp.), vole (Microtus/Pitymus sp.), white-footed mouse (Peromyscus sp.), cotton rat (Sigmodon hispidus), and wood rat (Neotoma floridana), The temporal distribution of rodents is difficult to assess, because their burrowing habits tend to cause disturbance to cultural stratigraphy, leaving recent remains within older zones of cultural deposition. Pocket gopher appears to span all periods of occupation from 170 B.C. to A.D. 1650, while cotton rat is present from A.D. 580-1200. Other rodent species cannot be assigned to temporal periods with any confidence. No rodent remains were found in the North or South areas, but a few units in the North Midden and South Midden did yield rodent bone. Rodent species common to the Bottomland Forest include some Peromyscus species (P. leucopus and P. gossypinus) and Pitymys (Microtus) pinetorum. A number of species evolved in interior grassland habitats and are most common with the Tall Grass Prairie of Texas. Those include Geomys bursarius, Perognathus hispidus, Peromyscus maniculatus, and Microtus ochrogastor. Pocket gophers, such as Geomys breviceps, prefer areas with sandy soil and will avoid areas with poor drainage or clayey soils. The hispid cotton rat, Sigmodon hispidus, prefers areas with very dense ground vegetation and with good surface drainage. Areas with dense stands of broomsedge and varieties of bluestem are preferred by these species. The beaver, Castor canadensis, has a very broad geographic range. However, they are essentially aquatic and are generally found in smaller bodies of water such as narrow creeks or tributaries which lead into larger rivers or ponds. Amphibians Frog specimens were recovered near the bottom of Zone 2 and within Zone 3 in Feature 1. No other amphibian remains were recognized from the rest of the excavations, so this class of fauna appears to have been either a very minor element of the diet or a natural inclusion unrelated to the diet. Reptiles Reptile species from Bird Point Island include: softshell turtle (Trionyx sp.), red-eared turtle (Chrysemys pseudemys scripta), 139 various testudinid turtle elements, racer (Coluber constrictor), water snake (Natrix sp.), cottonmouth (Agkistrodon piscivorous), rattlesnake (Crotalus sp.), pine snake (Pituophis sp.), corm snaxe (Elaphe sp.), and various unidentifiable lizard species. The temporal distribution of reptiles shows only snake species in the 170 B.C. to A.D. 130 portion of Feature 1. In Zone 2, dating to A.D. 580 - 860, softshell turtle and snakes are present. The A.D. 1000-1200 period is represented by all species of turtle and racer. Turtle species comprise the entire reptilian assemblage in features dating between A.D. 1300 and 1650. The abundance of testudinid turtle elements after A.D. 860 increased dramatically. Both burned and unburned turtle sheil was present in many levels within the site, indicating extensive utilization of these animals. Softshell turtles, as well as many testudinids, are abundant within the period from A.D. 1000-1200. However, this may be somewhat misleading since most features within the site have been referred to this age. The distribution of reptiles by site area shows a predominance of remains in the South Midden. The reptilian species found at Bird Point Island tend to be either aquatic or aquatic/woodland species. The species which are predominantly aquatic are turtle, water snake, and cottonmouth. Racers are found in many different habitats, although they often occur within trees near water (Webb 1970). The copperhead is usually found in rocky or wooded country but also occurs in relatively wet environments such as floodplain areas and swamp edges (Behler and King 1979; Raun 1965). The presence of the above species indicates exploitation of the aquatic habitats within close proximity to the site. Fish A number of fish taxa was found at Bird Point Island. Most are represented by small fragmentary vertebrae which are virtually impossible to identify. However, positive identification of catfish ([ctaluras sp.), gar (Lepisosteous sp.), and sunfish (Lepomis sp.) has been achieved. Catfish was identified in Feature 45 and gar was identified in Feature 124, both of which date from the A.D. 1000- 1200 period. Sunfish was recovered from Zone 1 of Feature 1 and dates between A.D. 1000 and 1650. Fish species appear to have been minor components in the faunal assemblage at the site, despite the fact that they would have provided readily accessible sources of protein in the summer when they were concentrated in sloughs and pools. The lack of fish remains in the A horizon excavation units can be attributed in part to the data recovery methodology used. Soil from these units, as well as from 1 x 1 m and 2 X 2 m units inside features, was screened through 6.4 mm mesh which was large enough to allow many fish bones to pass through. Most feature fill, on the other hand, was floated, thereby avoiding the problem of underrepresentation due to mesh size. Yet, despite this, there was still a very low quantity of fish remains recovered. This lack of small fish bones and scales may be the result of the poor faunal preservation potential of the site which favors preservation of large mammal bones. In addition, small bones would have presented less of a disposal problem than large bones to the prehistoric inhabitants of the site, so bison and deer may have been intentionally placed in feature fill whereas fish bones may have been scattered about the surface of the site and subjected to rapid deterioration. Thus, although fish were a minor component of the faunal assemblage, no firm conclusions can be reached concerning their level of importance in the prehistoric diet. INTERPRETATION Although the archaeological faunal assemblage is dominated by deer, diverse vertebrate species were recovered which are very similar to the modern fauna found in the Richland Creek area. However, the presence of numerous jackrabbit bones and bison

Today, the maximum eastern range of the jackrabbit includes only the western portions of Navarro County (Davis 1974), so the high incidence of jackrabbit at the site suggests that a period of aridity occurred which extended their range further to the east. Likewise,the presence of bison at Bird Point Island and at other archaeological sites further east in Texas suggests that the extent of the prairie habitat was greater at one time. The presence of aquatic species (fish, turtle, water snake, etc.) and species which prefer moderate rainfall (vole) along with bison.and jackrabbit in Zone 3 of Feature 1 suggests that localized aquatic habitats remained available for exploitation during the hypothesized period of prairie expansion. The relative abundance of fauna in Zone 3 of Feature 1 is partially due to the better potential for bone preservation. The human burials recovered from Zone 3 were in a better state of preservation than was Burial 8 in Zone 1, and were in much better shape that other burials found at the site. Yet, it is unlikely that preservation alone is responsible for the lack of aquatic species in the upper zones of the pit. Calculation of Minimum Number of Individuals Many faunal analyses place emphasis on the calculation of the minimum number of individuals in archaeological sites. Usually, the minimum number of individuals is given for each excavation unit, and faunal utilization patterns are hypothesized based on this data. Unfortunately, the remains of a single faunal member are not generally confined to one unit. If we consider the minimum number of individuals at Bird Point Island using the traditional approach, we would arrive at a much higher number of individuals than were actually present, since most deer were scattered over more than one unit. Therefore, a survey of the minimum number of individuals was conducted only for features, since these have a greater possibility of reflecting a limited activity usage, and thus have less chance of being mixed. Feature 1 was excluded since it encompassed a very large area, spanned a long period, and contained many units. The survey indicated that each feature contained only one identifiable individual per taxon, and suggests that all vertebrates, including deer, were processed and cooked individually. There was no concentration of a large number of individuals in any given feature, although several species were often processed together. Seasonality A good indication of seasonality is available based on the remains of whitetail deer. In Units 91, 95, 97, and 98 several fully developed antlers were found which were fused to the frontal . bones. All of these units are within Feature 1 and all specimens represent different individuals probably killed in different years. All specimens were recovered from Zone 1, except those from Unit 91 which were found at the interface of Zones 1 and 2 and may belong to the earlier period. The specimens could range from A.D. 860-1650. According to Schmidly (1983), whitetail deer in East Texas shed their antlers between late December and mid- February. Therefore, these deer must have been killed in fall, or early winter, when the antlers became mature. The hypothesis that many deer were killed in the fall or early winter is further substantiated by determination of age by means of dental characteristics. Based on the eruption and degree of wear of the lower third molar, deer found in Units 97 and 98 and in association with Burial 8 were determined to be approximately one year and seven months old at death. Considering that deer in Texas are born in May and early June (Schmidly 1983), this would place the time at which they were killed in the period from November to January. Therefore, several indicators suggest that major utilization of deer took place during late fall or early winter. There are no specific recommended daily allowances for fats and carbohydrates, but it is estimated that a well balanced diet will derive 50-60% of its caloric intake from carbohydrates and 20% from fats (Wilson et al. 1959:29-30). Protein intake of 10-12% of total calories is recommended. For adults the recommended quantity is one gram of protein per kilogram of body weight, but 0.6 g/kg of body weight has been found to be a minimal quantity to maintain nitrogen equilibrium in adults (Wilson et al. 1959:53). Table 9-10 presents nutritional data for the principal food species recovered at Bird Point Island. Only the most important contributors to the diet are included, so fruits, seeds, and animal species not well represented in the assemblage are omitted. Corn data from modem specimens is included for comparison, even though maize was never a major staple. It is clear from the breakdown in Table 9-10 that the major sources of protein came from animal species. Although the percentage of protein is similar among all species, deer were the most common species selected. This pattern is related to the fact that there is more edible meat per individual with deer (Smith 1975:137). Animals with high reproductive rates and/or high quantities of meat were selected for exploitation among Mississippian populations, and seasonal peaks in availability appear to have influenced the selection process to the greatest degree (Smith 1975:138). Hickory nuts and acorns of the red oak group provided the greatest quantities of fat in the diet, although this was no doubt supplemented by the occasional use of fat-bearing animal species such as bison and raccoon. Finally, the major sources of carbohydrate were acorns of the white oak group and prairie turnips (Psoralea sp.). Maize provided additional carbohydrates during the final occupation, but was never a major dietary item. SEASONAL AVAILABILITY OF NUTRIENTS The abundance of resources within the Post Oak Savannah (nuts, deer, and prairie turnip) and within the Bottomland Forest (nuts, deer, seeds, fruit, and aquatic fauna) provided the bulk of the dietary intake for the hunters and gatherers at Bird Point Island. Resources were available in both zones during spring, summer, and fall although spring and fall were the principal harvest periods for major species such as Psoralea (spring), nuts (fall) and deer (fall/winter). Deer were probably hunted to some extent on a year-round basis, but they would have been easier to approach and would have had higher quantities of edible meat in the fall. The faunal analysis conducted by Murry demonstrates that Id] the few seasonality indicators identified from the faunal assemblage support late fall/early winter as the principal period of deer exploitation. Examining the nutritional data from the standpoint of seasonal availability of protein, fat, and carbohydrates, it is clear that a relatively balanced diet could have been maintained throughout most of the year for a sedentary population at Bird Point Island. Although several important nut species were harvested in the fall, they could have been stored and used throughout winter and spring to provide fats and carbohydrates. Likewise, dried or roasted prairie turnips have excellent storage potential and could have provided the most important source of carbohydrates year-round if sufficient quantities were collected and processed. Although reliable estimates for the density of Psoralea in the Post Oak Savannah prior to modern grazing practices are not available, the ubiquity of Psoralea peels across the site indicates that it must have occurred in great abundance, especially considering the poor potential for preservation of tubers. Thus, it appears that sufficient quantities of prairie tumip were available and within exploitable range of the site. Fruits and seeds, although supplements to the major components of the diet, also have food storage potential and could have provided carbohydrates and vitamins in the winter. In fact, the species with the least potential for long term preservation are the faunal species, the principal sources of protein. Meat and fish would have been primarily consumed during the seasons of peak availability, although some storage by means of smoking or drying was probably practiced. Thus, fall and winter would have been a season cf high protein intake, and perhaps lowered carbohydrate intake depending upon the supply of acorns and prairie turnips. Protein intake during late spring and summer probably focused on the ease of collection of aquatic species during this period. Fish, turtle, and mussels would have been collected at that time, as well as small mammals which were present in all three habitats surrounding the site. . CONCLUSIONS Four important conclusions related to subsistence can be made from the analysis of floral and faunal remains from Bird Point Island. First, and perhaps most importantly, this is the first reported occurrence of Psoralea from an archaeological context. Although numerous ethnographic accounts have demonstrated its crucial role as a source of carbohydrates among Plains Indians, it was thought that Psoralea would not be detectable in archaeological deposits because of the poor potential for preservation of tubers (Wedel 1979). Now that charred rinds have been found at Bird Point Island, as well as at other sites in the Richland Creek drainage (see Volume IID), it is possible to understand the importance of this plant during prehistory. Future _ floral analysis in North Central Texas should be conducted with an awareness that this plant is detectable and was a primary resource. Second, the distribution of bison and jackrabbit through time may have important implications for understanding the paleo- environment. Bison remains were recovered in Zone 3 of Feature 1 and at the interface of Zones 2 and 3, so the utilization of bison in this feature ranges from at least 170 B.C. to A.D. 130. Bison are also frequent in the South Midden and South areas which date between A.D. 1300-1650. Jackrabbit was found also in features falling within the A.D. 1300-1650 period as well as in the North area which is predominately the product of the A.D. 1000-1200 occupation. These data suggest that prairie was relatively close to the site during later periods of occupation, but that exploitation of prairie resources was low. Slight increases in the frequencies of bison remains in the South Midden and South areas (ca. A.D. 1300-1650) suggest either that larger prairie areas existed close to the site during these periods, resulting in increased utilization of bison and jackrabbit, or that existing tall grass species were replaced by medium grass species preferred by bison. Both hypotheses suggest that drier conditions existed during these periods.

GEOPHYSICAL REMOTE SENSING by Robert J. Huggins, James E. Bruseth, and William A. Martin Geophysical remote sensing devices were used at Bird Point Island to locate cultural features prior to field work so that excavation could be directed toward potentially more productive areas of the site. Two techniques, magnetic survey and electromagnetic conductivity survey, were tested to assess their effectiveness for finding cultural features. The specific instruments used included Geometrics proton precession magnetometers and a Geonics Limited EM-38, All work was conducted by Spectrum Geophysics, Inc., of Fort Worth, Texas with the assistance of the Archaeology Research Program staff. This chapter presents a discussion of the principles of operation for each instrument, the methodology used, and results of the surveys. In the final section, the methodology and results of magnetometer experiments designed to test hypotheses pertaining to feature function are discussed. MAGNETIC SURVEY Magnetic survey to locate in situ cultural features was used in Britain and Europe as early as the 1950s, with much of the current knowledge of the field contributed by a few individuals (Le Brogne 1955; Belshé 1957; Aitken 1958; Linington 1964; Graham and Scollar 1976). Use of this technique has only recently been introduced into New World archaeology (Ralph 1964; Beven 1975). During the past decade magnetic survey has been used successfully to locate subsurface archaeological features at several sites across the United States (Tite 1972; Weymouth 1976; Weymouth and Nickel 1977; Weymouth and Huggins 1983). Its success elsewhere prompted the selection of this technique for use on sites within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. Since the magnetic properties of each site environment vary widely and can drastically affect the shape, magnitude and geometry of the measured anomaly, some form of preliminary testing and assessment is a prerequisite to the accepted use of magnetic surveying in any given region. Therefore, a feasibility study was conducted during mitigation Season I to test the effectiveness of this technique, during which five 20 x 20 m blocks : were surveyed at Bird Point Island and four blocks were surveyed at Adams Ranch. PRINCIPLES OF OPERATION The proton precession magnetometer measures total magnetic intensity by means of a signal generated by the precession of spinning protons in a proton rich hydrocarbon fluid. The spinning protons are temporarily aligned by the application of an electric current from a coil in the sensor. When the current is removed, the spin of the protons causes them to precess in the direction of the ambient magnetic field. The precession frequency is measured by digital counters as the absolute value of the total magnetic field to within 0.1 gamma. The gyromagnetic ratio of the proton is a well known atomic constant which allows the magnetic field intensity to be calculated from the precession frequency (Breiner 1973:3). FORMATION OF MAGNETIC ANOMALIES The location of buried archaeological features using magnetic methods depends on the measurement and recognition of anomalies in the earth's magnetic field caused by changes in the concentration, orientation, and type of iron oxides in the soil. In culturally sterile alluvial, or wind blown sediments, iron oxides are commonly found in the form of weakly magnetic hematite and are distributed in such a way as to produce a distinctive, often uniform magnetic field at the surface. In the presence of cultural activity, various forms of energy are brought to bear on the soil which can create localized changes in the magnetic properties of the oxides. These changes produce measurable variations or “anomalies” in the magnetic field over the area of interest. Three principal forms of energy act to create magnetic anomalies. 144 forms such as magnetite and maghemite. Even if the burned material is redeposited in a midden or is transported by wind or water, the magnetic enhancement is still measurable. Another form of energy that was commonly applied on archaeological sites is the excavation of pits which disturbs the original sediments. The topsoil is usually more magnetic than the sediment underlying it, so removal or redistribution of the A horizon is often reflected in the magnetic record. Unburned structures, borrow areas, or other depressions often produce anomalies in this manner. Finally, chemical energy can cause magnetic enhancement through the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter which alters the iron oxide content of the soil by a reduction-oxidation process. This phenomenon is common in regions where wet-dry seasonal climatic patterns have existed in the past. The shape, magnitude, and symmetry of magnetic anomalies provide information about the size and depth of buried features. Magnetic anomalies can assume a variety of shapes and magnitudes but are usually composites of two basic categories, the "monopole" and the "dipole." The monopole anomaly consists of a group of measurements which has a magnitude greater or less than the surrounding equally spaced values in the immediate vicinity. This type of anomaly is typical of more deeply buried or diffuse features. The dipole anomaly consists of two groups of measurements, one group higher than surrounding values and the other group, lower, but closely associated with the first group. Complicating factors often act to hinder the detection of cultural features. Noise-producing agents affect the ease with which magnetic anomalies can be detected and recognized as culturally significant. "Noise" as used in this discussion is defined as extraneous contributions to the earth's magnetic field which tend to obscure archaeologically interesting anomalies. Intrusive geology with any appreciable iron content produces strong magnetic fields which mask the typically weak archaeological fields. Soil disturbance caused by vandals or heavy equipment can also cause difficulties. Magnetic fields from recent iron trash such as cans or bits of farm machinery will often obliterate anomalies. These confusing effects can usually be minimized by appropriate computer image enhancement (filtering), but in some instances the archaeological magnetic record is not detectable above the surrounding noise. It should be noted that the phenomena that are being measured in a magnetic survey are not visible to the human eye. It is only because these phenomena usually have visible physical correlates that it is possible to associate magnetic anomalies with archaeological features. It is conceivable that some features detectable with magnetics are difficult or impossible to discern with the naked eye. In these cases it is necessary to utilize other types of analysis, perhaps of a chemical nature, to determine whether these ephemeral features are indeed culturally significant. For a more extensive discussion of the principles of magnetic surveying, refer to Aitken (1974), Breiner (1973), or Weymouth (1976). SURVEY PROCEDURES Prior to the magnetic survey, a visual inspection was made of the area around Bird Point Island to search for noncultural sources of magnetism which could adversely affect the results. A road cut through the terrace showed that the terrace soil appeared to lack intrusive features such as lenses, gravels, or other inhomogeneities that might produce magnetic anomalies. However, the iron stained Wilcox sandstone exposed along the southern end of the site was widely dispersed across the terrace because it had been gathered and used in hearths and roasting pits by the prehistoric inhabitants. Initially, it was thought that this iron rich stone would be strongly magnetic and might contribute adversely to the measurement of weaker magnetic fields from in situ cultural features. However, Volume I, Part One crude susceptibility measurements made using a method outlined by Breiner (1973) showed the rock to be weakly magnetic. Subsequent survey confirmed these initial susceptibility measurements, showing uncorrelated soil noise in the absence of cultural material to be less than 3 gammas. Measurement of the magnetic field over the site was accomplished using two Geometrics proton precession magnetometers in the difference mode capable of an accuracy of 1 part in 200,000. One magnetometer remained stationary on the site to monitor the time fluctuations in the earth's magnetic field (diurnal drift) while the other instrument measured the field over the area of interest at a sample interval of one meter. This interval was chosen because it represents a reasonable compromise between resolution and speed of surveying. It is feasible to cover up to 2,500 m2 per day under ideal conditions, but 1,200 m2 was the average during the Bird Point Island survey. A total of 6,400 m2 was surveyed during Seasons I and II. Figure 10-1 shows the area surveyed during both seasons, with the magnetometer survey area indicated by the bold outline. The objective of this broad coverage was to isolate clusters of cultural activity occurring within areas of sparse activity so that excavations could be directed toward potentially more productive areas. Three people were used for the survey, one person to remove ferrous objects with the aid of a metal detector, and two people to carry the sensor and instrument pack (Figure 10-2). All magnetic materials which could affect the readings were removed from the clothing of the person carrying the sensor. The instrument pack was carried by another person to ensure sensor isolation. The stationary sensor was continuously monitored by a computer. Although care was taken to ensure accurate positioning of the sensor during the survey, it is reasonable to assume a spatial error of 5 cm for any given reading due to terrain irregularities. In addition, the height of the sensor varied over the course of a survey although efforts were taken to account for small scale topographic changes. The magnetometers are factory calibrated to produce combined errors of 0.35 gammas, but once positional errors are taken into account, the repeatability of one reading might be more conservatively estimated at 1 gamma. RESULTS The area examined at Bird Point Island during Season I encompassed all of Feature 1 and the immediately surrounding area. The magnetic anomalies recognized were diffuse, suggesting widespread activity areas rather than discrete features. However, the excessive background noise resulting from pieces of metal obscured some of the readings, making it difficult to assess the effectiveness of the technique at the site. Better results were obtained from the survey conducted at Adams Ranch where excavation revealed a small oval pit beneath a magnetic anomaly. Additional survey was scheduled for Season II which required resurvey of the blocks affected by background noise and the survey of 13 other blocks. Prior to Season II, the site was systematically scanned with a metal detector to remove ferrous debris that would adversely affect the survey results. Data collected during the survey were first computer corrected for diurnal drift and then run through error checking routines. Preliminary contour maps were generated to detect the magnetic fields caused by archaeological features. Convolution filtering was then performed on some of the data to reduce contributions from the geology or recent iron trash. Convolution filtering, similar to removing general trends from data by polynomial regression, replaces each data value by a weighted sum of the surrounding data allowing more control over the size of the remaining residuals. As a result, anomalies from specific features remain while anomalies which are smaller and/or larger are diminished or removed. After preliminary processing, color density contour maps were produced on a computer graphics screen with the magnitude of the readings keyed to a color scale. The computer allowed interactive

ELECTROMAGNETIC CONDUCTIVITY SURVEY Electromagnetic conductivity survey is a technique that measures soil conductivity, which is the inverse of galvanic resistivity. Although galvanic resistivity surveys have been used successfully to locate cultural features in recent years (Carr 1977), there has been little attempt to use conductivity survey for this purpose. However, the EM-38 conductivity sensor provides better resolution and more easily interpretable results than the equipment used to conduct resistivity surveys (McNeil 1980:5). It is also much easier to use in the field since it is a lightweight, hand held instrument that requires no additional probes and wires. Therefore, a feasibility study was conducted on 1,300 m2 at Bird Point Island to assess the potential of the EM-38 to detect cultural features. PRINCIPLES OF OPERATION The ability of electromagnetic conductivity survey, as well as of galvanic resistivity survey, to detect discrete subsurface features is dependent on differences in moisture content between features and the surrounding soil matrix. Whereas a galvanic resistivity survey measures changes in resistance between probes when an electrical current is passed through the soil between the probes, the EM-38 electromagnetic conductivity sensor operates on the principal of electromagnetic induction. The EM-38 is equipped with a transmitter coil at one end, a receiver coil at the other end, and a power source and meter in the middle. When the transmitter coil is energized with alternating current at an audio frequency, very small currents are induced in the soil. These currents generate a secondary magnetic field which is sensed, together with the primary field, by the receiver coil. The meter measures the ratio of the secondary field to the primary field, which is linearly proportional to soil conductivity. This provides a direct reading of soil conductivity in millimhos per meter (McNeil 1980:5). FORMATION OF CONDUCTIVITY ANOMALIES The creation of electromagnetic conductivity anomalies is directly related to fluctuations in soil moisture. Water, the most highly conductive substance in most soils, percolates through the soil matrix at differential rates due to variations in permeability. As a result, poorly drained areas display high conductivity readings since they retain soil moisture, whereas well-drained areas yield low conductivity readings due to their low moisture content. As is the case with magnetic anomalies, the effects of cultural activity upon the soil can alter soil moisture content to create conductivity anomalies. Excavation of pits into the B horizon is the principal form of cultural activity affecting soil moisture content. The sandy loam A horizon at Bird Point Island is a porous, well- drained soil ranging in depth from 20-40 cm, whereas the clay enriched B horizon is relatively impermeable. Under natural
