SURVEY PROCEDURES The EM-38, a portable sensor developed by Geonics Limited, was used to measure electromagnetic conductivity over 1,400 m? at Bird Point Island during Season II. Two people were used for the conductivity survey, one to move the sensor and the other to write down the meter readings (Figure 10-4).Three 20 x 20 m blocks (Grid 1) were surveyed immediately east and south of Feature 1 at a sample interval of 1 m. One 10 x 20 m block (Grid 2) was surveyed at the north end of the site because magnetometer data indicated that a large anomaly was present in that area. RESULTS Data were entered into the computer to produce contour maps reflecting changes in soil conductivity. Large scale, dominant trends were indicated, with an area of very low conductivity present over Feature. 1 and an area of very high conductivity southeast of the feature. To remove larger scale trends, the data were convolution filtered to reveal anomalies caused by discrete features. These anomalies are illustrated in Figure 10-5. Interestingly, substantial overlap was observed between high intensity magnetic anomalies and low intensity conductivity anomalies. The ability of the EM-38 to record soil conductivity is related to the vertical sensitivity of the instrument as well as to the moisture content of the soil. The vertical sensitivity curve of the EM-38 is bell shaped, with maximum sensitivity at a depth of 40 cm and lowest sensitivity above and below this depth, particularly near the surface and below 2 m (Figure 10-6). This implies that water perched in the soil at the 40 cm depth will contribute a much stronger reading than water perched at any other depth. At Bird Point Island, the EM-38 successfully distinguished pits dug through the B horizon because moisture in these pits had moved below the zone of maximum sensitivity. ASSESSMENT OF REMOTE SENSING TECHNIQUES Both the magnetometer and the EM-38 were able to detect cultural features at Bird Point Island, but each instrument responded to different phenomena. Figure 10-7 illustrates the responses of both instruments along with the depth to clay for points sampled at 2 m intervals along the 15E line. Soils and magnetic data were collected between 36N and -20N, but conductivity data was only collected as far south as ON, so the graph of conductivity response ends at that point. The 15E line was selected to illustrate these responses because it encompassed the edge of Feature | and all of Anomaly 18, which contained several features. Depth to the clay B horizon was recorded by Ed Janak of the Soil Conservation Service, using an auger to collect specimens. 149 The upper graph in Figure 10-7 provides a plot of the depth to clay which shows that the B horizon was encountered between 35 and 40 cm in this portion of the site, except where clay had been removed by the excavation of large pits (i.e., features associated with Anomaly 18 and Feature 1). The plot of the conductivity response closely parallels the plot of the depth to clay in the area over Anomaly 18. A sharp decrease in conductivity occurs at the same point that depth to clay increases. The relationship between depth to clay and soil conductivity is not strictly a one to one relationship, as demonstrated by the gradual decrease in conductivity toward Feature 1, where depth to clay remains more or less constant. However, it is clear that the EM-38 responded to large pits which had completely penetrated the B horizon, since the lowest conductivity responses were recorded within Feature 1 and the features associated with Anomaly 18. The results of the additional conductivity survey indicate that the EM-38 may only be effective for locating large features which have completely penetrated the B horizon. Although several anomalies were observed on maps of Grids 3, 4, and 5, excavation revealed that they were not associated with any of the small features present. Since the vast majority of cultural features on archaeological sites are similar in size to these, the inability to record small features appears to be a major limitation of this instrument. The magnetometer response along the 15E line is more complex than the response of the EM-38. The variations in the magnetic readings shown in Figure 10-7 appear to be only slightly related to the depth of clay, which should be expected since the magnetometer responds to changes in the distribution of iron oxides and magnetically enhanced rock. Even though the plot of the magnetic data fluctuates considerably, it clearly shows the location of Anomaly 18 as a group of low readings ranging between 0 and -10 gammas to the north followed by a dramatic increase to the south of readings between 30 and 45 gammas, This is the characteristic response of a dipole anomaly. Excavation revealed that subsurface features were present beneath nearly all of the magnetic anomalies. Although many features did not exhibit magnetic anomalies, more features were detected by the magnetometer than by the EM-38 relative to the areas surveyed by both instruments. In addition, the magnetometer recorded features as small as 1 m in diameter as well as large features, whereas the EM-38 only recorded large features. Also, the magnetometer picked up anomalies over the same large features which were recorded by the EM-38. For these reasons, the magnetometer appears to be a more effective and efficient instrument for use in locating cultural features, at least within this Project area. The latter possibility seemed most likely because of the presence of fire cracked rock and because roasting is a historically documented means of nut preparation (Swanton 1946:364), as well as of Psoralea preparation (Reid 1978). Earlier during the course of the research at Bird Point Island, the archaeologists (Bruseth and Martin) and the magnetic specialist (Huggins) met informally on several occasions to discuss possible causes of anomalies and excavation strategies. At this point, additional meetings were convened to devise a means of testing the hypothesized function of the features. A series of experiments was designed to examine the two hypotheses related to storage and roasting, and to determine the precise source of magnetism within the features. It was reasoned that magnetic enhancement of the iron-rich Wilcox sandstone probably occurred when it was heated for use in cooking or roasting. This idea could be tested by examining the magnetic response of Wilcox sandstone before and after heating in an experimental hearth. On the other hand, the disturbance of iron oxides in the soil caused by digging a storage pit and backfilling after use may have accounted for the observed increase in magnetism. This could be tested by measuring the magnetic response of a pit dug and refilled as part of the experiment. If a magnetic increase was observed over the heated rock, but little increase was observed over the pit, this would lend support to the roasting hypothesis. If the reverse was observed, then the storage hypothesis would make more sense. The test required an area free from excessive background noise and devoid of cultural anomalies. A nearby terrace was selected which had geological and soils properties identical to Bird Point Island, but which lacked cultural material. Two contiguous areas of 440 m2 each (designated Area 1 and Area 2) were surveyed with readings taken at 50 cm intervals. No anomalies were recorded in Area 1, and only a small anomaly due to an iron object was recorded in Area 2. To examine the effect of excavation and mixing of soils on the magnetic field, a pit 1 m in diameter and .75 m deep was excavated in Area 2. This depth.was selected to insure that A and B horizon soils would be disturbed and mixed to a similar degree as that found in the the prehistoric features at Bird Point Island. The pit was refilled and surveyed with the results showing no detectable anomaly. The conclusion derived from these experiments is that the pits at Bird Point Island are magnetically detectable largely due to the presence of fire cracked rock. The next question addressed concerned the site formation processes responsible for the deposition of fire cracked rock in the pits. Although it was clear that the magnetism in the pits was due to the presence of fire cracked rock, it was not clear whether this rock had entered the pits as the result of a primary, heat related activity or was introduced as discard from activity elsewhere on the site. Since trash disposal in pits has been observed elsewhere in Texas (Bruseth and Perttula 1981), disposal of the fire cracked rock was considered a likely possibility until otherwise ruled out. Once again, magnetic properties were used to provide the answer to this problem. One of the properties of magnetically enhanced rock is that as it cools in situ, the iron oxides become oriented toward magnetic north, giving the rock the same magnetic declination and inclination as the earth’s magnetic field at the time of cooling. This realignment of iron oxides during heating is the same property utilized by the archaeomagnetic dating technique. If the rocks had been placed in the pit while hot and had cooled in situ, they should all exhibit the same, or allowing for the effects of bioturbation, very similar orientations. Magnetic field (in gammas) over the experimental hearth after burning. other hand, if the rocks had been discarded into the pit, then their orientations should vary and no central tendency should be apparent. Five samples of Wilcox sandstone, from three rocks in one of the large pits, were collected by Holly Hathaway of the Colorado State University Archaeomagnetic Laboratory. Horizontal strikes were made on each rock while in situ and the rock's compass orientation was recorded. One inch cylindrical cores were taken from the rocks in the laboratory, then cut to appropriate lengths and sanded to remove impurities from the coring process. Three samples were taken from the largest rock (Sample Numbers 1-3) and one sample each was obtained for the other two rocks (Sample Numbers 4 and 5). The cores were measured for their natural remanent magnetism on a Schonstedt Spinner Magnetometer (Hathaway, personal communication 1983). The results indicate that all of the rocks had magnetic fields oriented towards north. Figure 10-14. Feature 104, a hearth filled with fire cracked rock similar to the experimental hearth.

These results seem to rule out the possibility that fire cracked rocks found in the pits were the result of trash disposal and lend additional support to the roasting pit hypothesis. SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF FIRE CRACKED ROCK Aside from providing information about feature function which could have been obtained by no other means, magnetic data also aided the interpretation of spatial distribution of fire cracked rock. In recent years, increasing emphasis has been placed on the study of spatial patterning of artifacts as a means of delineating discrete activity areas on archaeological sites. The generation of maps from large data sets has been simplified by computer programs such as SYMAP (Jermann and Dunnell 1976). The definition of spatial distribution of features and activity areas was a major research goal at Bird Point Island, so SYMAPs were generated for each artifact category. Use of magnetic survey data, in conjunction with the expertise of the magnetic specialist, helped to explain puzzling patterns observed with respect to the distribution of fire cracked rock across the site. When the SYMAP for large fire cracked rock (2.5 cm or greater) was compared with the SYMAP for small fire cracked rock (1-2.5 cm), major differences were observed. A 20 X 7m cluster of large fire cracked rock was observed curving around the wall of House 1, but the distribution of small fire cracked rock exhibited a low density in the same location (see Chapter 13). This phenomenon was rather confusing, so the map of the magnetic field was examined to search for some interpretive clue. Although two small magnetic highs, which may represent hearths, were observed within the area encompassed by the large cluster, the vast majority of the cluster exhibited an overall decrease in magnetism. Since the magnetometer experiment had demonstrated that Wilcox sandstone is weakly magnetic in an unfired state and becomes strongly magnetic when heated, it was clear that the majority of rock in this cluster had never been fired. Because of the natural reddish to black color of the unmodified sandstone, it was often impossible to visually distinguish bummed from unburned sandstone in the laboratory. As a result, the rock in the cluster had been misidentified as fire cracked and included on the map. Without the aid of the magnetic survey, this fact would not have been recognzied. The presence of a concentration of unburned rock makes sense if Wilcox sandstone was stored on site for use in hearths and roasting pits. The fact that the rock outcrop in the slough is under water during a significant portion of the year strongly implies that collection and storage must have occurred during the dry season. A likely location for storage would be an area in close proximity to hearths and roasting pits. The location of the cluster next to House 1 would have placed rock within easy access for household cooking and for roasting in a nearby pit associated with House 1. The unburned large fragments recovered from excavation 153 probably represent pieces that broke off as rocks were tossed in piles. The broader spatial implications of this information are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 13. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS Magnetic surveys and electromagnetic conductivity surveys were conducted at Bird Point Island over the course of three seasons of field work. A large area was surveyed with a proton precession magnetometer, an instrument proven effective for locating cultural features on other archaeological sites. The results of the magnetic survey were positive, with most anomalies marking the locations of subsurface pits. In addition, the shapes of many of the anomalies closely resembled the shapes of the corresponding archaeological features. A small area was surveyed with an EM-38 to assess its utility for locating features. The initial results were good, with the sensor recording the same large features recorded by the magnetometer, so additional areas were surveyed. However, the EM-38 did not pick up small features and therefore recorded fewer features than the magnetometer. As a result, magnetic survey appears to be the best remote sensing technique for use in locating features at sites such as those in the Richland Creek area. : For a magnetic survey to successfully locate cultural features, a broad area should be covered and the survey of a control area is highly recommended. Only under rare circumstances is it possible to survey an entire site, but it is usually feasible to include some marginal site areas. where little activity is believed to have occurred. This information is useful for delineating site boundaries and isolating areas of concentrated activity. The survey of a control area having geological and pedological properties similar to those of the site also provides useful data for comparison and is an essential part of any overall program. The magnetic field over the control area can allow cultural anomalies to be separated . from any natural anomalies that may be present by providing a picture of the natural level of background noise and the extent of natural anomalies. Once features have been located and excavated, magnetic data can often aid in their interpretation. The experiments conducted with the magnetometer to test hypotheses about feature function provided important information which could not have been obtained in any other manner. Although most excavations are subject to time constraints which preclude the design and execution of such experiments, long term projects can benefit by budgeting for experimentation designed to identify sources of magnetism. Such identification is a major step toward defining feature function. Finally, the necessity of communication between the archaeologist and the magnetic specialist cannot be emphasized strongly enough. The ability of a proton precession magnetometer to detect cultural anomalies depends on the geological and pedological properties of the site as well as the kinds of cultural features present. Data collection requires corrections for diurnal drift and a knowledge of natural factors that can adversely affect survey results. Once data have been collected, interpretation of the results requires a knowledge of the correct ratio of high and low components for cultural features in the latitude of the survey area, as well as a knowledge of filtering techniques necessary to remove extraneous responses. Only someone with training in remote sensing applications can be expected to interpret these data accurately. Archaeologists who believe that a magnetometer can be used with the ease of a metal detector and attempt to conduct surveys without the aid of a specialist will probably be disappointed in their results. Certainly their results will be less useful than they could be if the expertise of a specialist had been enlisted.

ANTHROPIC SOIL DISCOLORATION by James E. Bruseth Prior to commencement of the 1980-1981 testing season at Bird Point Island, information was supplied by Mr. Bill Young, an avoca- tional archaeologist from Corsicana, Texas, that a midden deposit existed at Bird Point Island. According to Young, the midden was detectable after the site had been cleared and plowed during the 1970s. Unfortunately, precise definition of the midden could not be made during the 1980-1981 season. Since one of the objectives of the Season II methodology at the site was an accurate definition of the midden through delineation of its dark soil color, two techniques were used to accomplish this. The first was aerial photography, with panchromatic and infrared black and white film. The other technique was the systematic collection of Munsell soil color values and computerized contouring of these values. Both techniques were used during Season II, and this chapter describes the methodologies employed and the results obtained. AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY METHODS Although the use of aerial photography has become a common tool of many archaeologists (Gumerman and Lyons 1971; Lyons and Avery 1977), the results that can be obtained on a given site are only generally known. Procedures for the interpretation of phe- nomena that are of potential archaeological significance are avail- able, but accurate identification of these phenomena often must be determined through site excavation. Consequently, the aerial pho- tography at Bird Point Island was planned as an experimental tool for delineating the limits of the midden, as well as for detecting potential features to aid subsequent site investigation. To minimize photographic variability caused by vegetation, the site was plowed. Two flights were made over the site. The first was flown at an altitude of 570 ft during sunny weather at midday. A 35 mm camera was used mounted to the bottom of a small aircraft, and Kodak pancromatic black-and-white film was used. The altitude was high enough to cover the site with a single frame. The second flight was flown at a lower altitude to achieve larger scale photographs. A series of 37 photographs was taken using Kodak black-and-white infrared film with the same camera used for the higher altitude photography. The individual frames were triggered by hand and sufficient overlap between frames was allowed to provide stereo pairs. RESULTS The aerial photographs produced from the two flights over Bird Point Island were not as successful as had been hoped. The first, and perhaps most important, cause of the poor results was a lack of ade- quate planning prior to actually taking the photographs. Unfor- tunately, too little attention to detail was paid to the percentage of coverage between adjacent photographs and to the scale. The coverage between frames (i.¢., overlap) and between rows of frames (i.e., sidelap) was poorly controlled, and as a result, adjacent rows of some photographs failed to have overlap and could not be used for distance measures. The lack of an adequate scale was most notable in the distortion of the image. This distortion, which prevented ground distances from being taken by direct measurements, was probably due to three factors: (1) optical dispacement, (2) tilting of the camera lens, and (3) terrain variations. The exact contribution of each of these is not known; but the first, optical displacement, was probably the largest contributor. A metrically corrected camera would have avoided this problem. Photographs then could be used for direct measurements and could be digitized for computer image enhancement and filtration. We had assumed that the pilot flying the airplane would take care of determining photographic scale and percent coverage. These variables, in retrospect, should have been decided by the archae- ologist in consultation with the pilot. Another problem with the aerial 155

On both the infrared and panchro- matic photos, the general outline of the midden noted by Mr. Young was identified. The best definition was on the panchromatic film print, largely because the entire site was shown on a single frame. This allowed the slightly darker soil color of the midden to stand out, whereas on the larger scale infrared photos, the size of the midden cut across several frames and was difficult to observe. The other dark area was a small zone, about 3 to 4 m in diameter, on the northern third of the site. The area was examined in the field and it seemed to contain increased frequencies of charcoal as compared to sur- rounding areas. As a result, this area was thought initially to be simply another location where brush was burned during recent clearing of the site. However, the results of the spatial analysis of systematically collected artifacts from A horizon excavations at the site showed that charcoal was abundant in this area (see Chapter 13 and Figure 13- 9). The distribution of charcoal was found to overlie House 2, with an elongation to the southeast. Moreover, quality of the charcoal was not as ‘fresh’ as specimens from the recent brush-burned areas, and we interpret the charcoal to represent the remains of a structure, associated with the house pattern, that burned. The implications of this interpretation on overall community patterning are discussed in Chapters 13 and 14. SYSTEMATIC COLLECTION OF MUNSELL SOIL COLOR METHODS The differential distribution of Munsell color values for the soils across the site was used to help define midden boundaries. Soil samples, consisting of about 10 g, were collected at 5 m intervals across the site. The samples were taken at a depth of 20 cm, or below the plow zone, and sealed in plastic bags to preserve soil moisture. Samples were collected below the plow zone to minimize the effect that plowing may have had upon soil color. When soil is churned by a plow, certain soil constituents such as organic matter will leach out more quickly and may cause the soil to display a lighter color (Ed Janak, personal communication 1983). Once the samples were collected they were brought back to the Project laboratory for processing. This consisted of opening each sample and identifying its color code on the Munsell Soil Color Chart (1975). Lighting was provided by a fluorescent light, and all observations were made by the same individual. The sample values were then entered into a microcomputer which digitized the Munsell color codes into numeric representations. The correspondence between color codes and digitized results are shown in Table 11-1. The digitized values were used to rank the Munsell color ordinally from lightest to darkest. This ranking reflects an attempt to relate both color value and chroma onto a single scale. These digitized values were then input into a SYMAP computer program to generate spatial maps of color values. The data were simplified from the ten values to four values or contour levels to provide a simpler map. The grouping of values into four levels also insured that noise arising from individual chromas or values being slightly out of order (a possibility, since some of the Munsell codes were difficult to rank exactly) was minimized. The ranges of Munsell values for each contour level are shown in Table 11-2. RESULTS The map produced by the SYMAP program is shown in Figure 11-1. Overall, the techniques worked well in identifying culturally relevant variability in soil color at the site. The midden, the primary area to be delimited, shows clearly and corresponds to the darkest soil color contour. This midden could not be visually defined by walking across the site during Season II. How Young was able to observe the midden after clearing in the early 1970s is unknown. Perhaps, since the site had been recently cleared, soil color was “fresher” and in subsequent years the dark soil color leached to a lighter color. The midden also corresponds to the distribution of surface and subsurface artifacts (see Chapter 13) corroborating the fact that the soil darkness is due to cultural factors and not to modern conditions or natural soil color variations. In addition, several other areas of dark soil color are observed elsewhere across the site. Two of these are locations where trees were piled and burned a decade ago when the site was cleared and also show on the aerial photographs. These areas are labeled ‘““Bumed Brush Areas” on Figure 11-1, and are characterized by substantial quantities of charcoal in the soil.

Bruseth and William A. Martin The objective of this chapter is to discuss the major classes of chronological data from the Bird Point Island site. Following this presentation, the data are integrated into a culture-historical framework that outlines the major periods of site occupation. This framework forms the foundation for the concluding chapter of this volume, which summarizes all the data and presents an overview of cultural activity at the site. Three classes of data are included in this chapter: (1) radiocarbon dates, (2) projectile point styles, and (3) ceramic artifacts. The first class, radiocarbon dates, has been presented to some degree in previous chapters whenever this information was needed, However, this prior presentation has often been brief, awaiting fuller explanation in this chapter; for this reason, the radiocarbon dates from the site are discussed in detail. The other two data classes, projectile point styles and ceramics, have been more fully explained elsewhere and are only summarized here. These data were presented in Chapters 7 and 8, respectively, as part of the overall analysis of artifacts from the site. Only the stylistic quality of the points, namely their typological ascriptions, are used in this chapter since these have primary temporal significance. Although a complete ceramic analysis was presented in Chapter 8, only that part of the analysis which uncovered chronologically meaningful results is used here. RADIOCARBON DATING A total of 26 carbon samples has been dated from Bird Point Island from a variety of contexts, including burials, pits, hearths, and post holes. During the collection process, every attempt was made to be discriminating in the choice of specimens and to be even more so in the final selection of samples to be submitted for dating. The overall goal of the radiometric dating program has been to obtain dates from the most meaningful contexts possible. Despite this intention, the dates listed in Table 12-1 show considerable variation in time, even among features of similar types from adjacent locations. In addition, several modern dates have been obtained from what seemed to be good contexts. The perplexing quality of many of the dates necessitates a detailed discussion of each one, especially in regard to how it relates to site interpretations. In some instances a date can be assumed to be a bad indicator based on its association with temporally sensitive ceramics or points. However, these artifacts are, at best, general chronological indicators and can only corroborate or reject the grossly errant dates, In other cases, spatial proximity of features can imply contemporaneity and thus give some indication of whether a radiocarbon date is acceptable or not. Implicit in this discussion is our intention not to let preconceived notions of site chronology shade our acceptance of data. This type of bias is impossible to eliminate entirely, but the discussion of our reasons for accepting or rejecting each date permits the reader to examine our logic. Basic information on each date is also presented to enable other conclusions to be made on intrasite chronology. The following discussion focuses on groups of dates that either are from similar contexts or have similar problems in regard to acceptability. Detailed comments on specific dates can be found in Table 12-1. The first group of dates is Beta-5590, Beta-5595, Beta-5597, and Beta-9106. All of these specimens were found to be modern. Two of these, Beta-5590 and Beta-5595, are from a shallow depth and from general midden deposits overlying Feature 1, (Figure 12-1). The stratigraphy within the pit was complex and these samples were collected in an attempt to date the upper zone of the Stratigraphy. Unfortunately, the shallow depth (i.e., between 20 and 40 cm) from which the samples were collected suggests that they were contaminated by modem carbon in the plow zone. The other two dates, Beta-5597 and Beta-9106, are more difficult to understand. Beta-5597 is from a depth of 80 cm within Feature 12 which was located within Feature 1. Feature 12 was an irregularly shaped pit located in the southwestern slope of Feature 1; no evidence of modern disturbance to the feature could be seen. There is a pronounced lack of superpositioning of features within the North area in contrast to the Midden area, where numerous examples of overlapping features are seen and where temporally sensitive artifacts suggest at least two substantial periods of occupation. For this reason, we believe that the 30 B.C. date from Feature 35 does not accurately date the feature and represents charcoal from some earlier Archaic occupation that was incorporated at a later date into the pit fill. Perhaps the best sequence of dates from a common context comes from Feature 1, the large pit. The stratigraphic sequence is presented in detail in Chapter 6, and is only briefly reviewed here. Three cultural zones have been defined for the pit. Zone 3 is associated with the Late Archaic period and represents initial construction and use of the pit for ritual activities. Four dates have been obtained from this zone, all from Burial 9/11. In each case, portions of the skeleton were dated because no other suitable dating material was available, and the temporal placement of this zone was critical for understanding site chronology. Since the reliability of radiocarbon dating of bone is somewhat controversial, samples were sent to two different labs. One sample was submitted to Beta Analytic, and the insoluble collagen fraction dated to A.D. 140 + 110 (Beta-5598). Samples were also submitted to the SMU radiocarbon lab, where three separate dates were run on bone apatite (bone mineral), soluble collagen, and insoluble collagen. The bone apatite date was A.D. 521 + 81 (SMU-1162) and was considered the least reliable by the lab director (Herbert Haas, personal communication 1985). The other two SMU dates were A.D. 36 + 203 and 107 + 239 B.C. The standard deviations of these two dates overlap with each other and with the standard deviation of the Beta date. Since different bone fractions were dated, an estimated midpoint of A.D. 1 was chosen.as the date of Burial 9/11 (and hence, Zone 3) instead of the strict numerical average. Zone 2 within Feature 1 consists of a layer of dark sandy loam above Zone 3. Two carbon dates have been obtained from this zone. One is from the cremation (Burials 19 and 20) discussed earlier that dates to A.D. 720 + 140. The other date is from charcoal outside the cremation, but at the same stratigraphic level. This date is A.D. 700 + 100 (Beta-5593), and these two dates together convincingly place this zone at A.D. 700. Above this zone are midden deposits labeled Zone 1 and part of the larger area on the southern half of the site referred to as the Midden (see Figure 1-1). Several radiometric determinations have been obtained on carbon specimens from the Midden. Two of the dates were obtained from within the plow zone, and as noted earlier, were determined by the lab to be modern. Dates from deeper levels in the Zone 1 midden, however, are good approximations of the age of these deposits. The dates are A.D. 1280 + 110 (Beta-5594), A. D. 1350 + 90 (Beta-5592), A.D. 1370 + 50 (Beta 5596), A.D. 1422 +56 (SMU-1130), and A.D.1510 + 60 (Beta-5591). The two latest dates (A.D. 1422 and 1510) are both from a log associated with Burial 8. The difference between the dates may well be due to different parts of the log having been dated; that is, one date may represent the interior portion and the other the exterior part of the log. The log diameter was sizable, and it could well have been a hundred years old or older when cut. If this is indeed the case, then the burial must date to sometime after A.D. 1510. The other three midden dates are all within 80 years of one another and indicate that the midden in this area was produced during the fourteenth century A.D. However, many of the ceramic artifacts from the Midden suggest an earlier temporal span, between A.D. 1000 and 1200. The ceramic decorations are similar to types associated with the early Caddoan period of East Texas (see Chapter 8), and identical ceramics within House 1, dated to A.D. 1030, A few ceramic decorations that are probably associated with the late Caddoan period do occur within the _ midden, but are rare in number. What may actually occur in the Zone 1 midden are two separate cultural layers. The dark soil color may have obscured their separation, and charcoal associated with the upper and more recent layer may have been churned 163 downward into the lower layer. This compares well with data from the Midden over Feature 1 that show substantial deposits from two temporally distinct components, one dating from the occupation of the houses around A.D. 1000-1200 and the other from sometime after A.D. 1300. Three additional dates from the site were collected from several features within the Midden. These are: A.D. 1080 + 70 (Beta-9105), A.D. 1280 + 280 (Beta- 7158), and A.D. 1290 + 60 (Beta-9107). The first date is from a pit (Feature 101) containing lithic debris and several large sherds. The sherds form major parts of two vessels and minor parts of several more. Identifiable sherds were very similar to the Late Caddoan type, Maydelle Incised. The dates associated with this type do not correspond with the carbon date, and presumably, older charcoal was incorporated into the pit fill during use, or alternatively, carbon from midden deposits around the pit was chumed into the fill. However, the date does fit well with ceramic types in the Midden overall, and is further evidence of occupation during the eleventh century A.D. The A.D. 1280 date is from a post hole in the Midden. No pattern with surrounding post holes could be observed, and the dated post hole does not seem to be associated with a structure. Only 0.1 g of carbon from this feature was datable, and as a result it is not known exactly what the charcoal represents. It is certainly not from the post that filled the hole, since there is little evidence of the post ever having been burned. Instead, the charcoal probably represents a specimen that was present in the Midden and was accidently incorporated into the pit. Consequently, the date is only useful as an indicator that occupation took place in the Midden during the specified time. The third date of A.D. 1290 is from a hearth, Feature 104. A large amount of charcoal was associated with this feature, as well as several burned pieces of Wilcox sandstone. Based on the large sample of charcoal, we consider this to be a good date and to accurately reflect the time of hearth use. ; Two additional dates were obtained from probable hearths in the North area of the site. These dates are A.D. 1440 + 230 (Beta- 9103) from Feature 103 and A.D. 1640 +. 60 (Beta-9104) from Feature 85. Both samples were charcoal recovered in pits containing oxidized clay and are assumed to be accurate. Although accurate, Beta-9102 is not very precise since it has a 230-year standard deviation. This is due to the small quantity of carbon available (0.15 g) for dating. Based on the foregoing review of the radiocarbon determinations from Bird Point Island, we can see that many dates appear to be valid and useful temporal indicators. These dates form the building blocks of our interpretations of intrasite structure discussed in Chapter 14, At the same time, several dates contradict other temporal indicators, such as ceramics, projectile points, and spatial associations. It is difficult to understand why more of the dates are not useful. All are probably accurate indicators of the dated charcoal, but whether they date the features from which they were collected is debatable. Although we attempted to follow the advice of Story and Valastro (1977:88) by collecting samples from discriminating contexts, our results suggest we did not receive the full benefits of this advice. Rather than simply selecting charcoal from within a pit or post hole, we should have selected charcoal that was definitely associated with a feature. For instance, the charcoal from Feature 104, a hearth, was clearly part of the fuel used for heating. Thus its radiocarbon date provided an accurate date of feature use. On the other hand, scattered bits of charcoal from a feature are suspect. The charcoal may be dating some unknown episode of cultural activity unrelated to the feature's use. This activity may have been contemporaneous with, or years older than, the pit. PROJECTILE POINT CHRONOLOGY A total of 734 reasonably complete projectile points was analyzed using the typological system outlined by Suhm et al. (1954) and modified by Suhm and Jelks (1962). Other typological refinements for Central and East Texas were also considered for

164 this analysis (Johnson 1962; Duffield 1963, Prewitt 1974b, 1981). The temporal estimates for each type are used only as general time indicators, and radiocarbon dates are used to refine the projectile point chronology for the site. Results of the typological analysis reveal point styles ranging from Early Archaic dart points through Late Prehistoric arrow points (see Chapter 7). The overall assemblage indicates repeated occupation of the site over the course of several millennia. The dart point styles associated with the Early to Middle Archaic period (Angostura, Bulverde, Marshall, Palmillas, Pedernales, and Yarbrough) are relatively scarce, indicating that Archaic occupation was sporadic. The Gary point is the most common dart point within all spatial subdivisions of the site, but it is a poor chronological indicator which appears to have been used from the Archaic period into the Late Prehistoric period. It is impossible to precisely define the extent or intensity of Archaic occupation because it is not possible to separate early Gary points from later points (except for the small variety). Arrow point styles vary considerably among the spatial subdivisions of the site. In the North area, Alba, unidentified contracting stem, and unidentified expanding stem types are most frequent. In the Midden, Alba, Perdiz, and unidentified contracting stem types are common. In the South, Alba is most common, followed by Perdiz (see Chapter 7). Based on the published temporal placement of Perdiz points (Suhm et al. 1954; Prewitt 1981), it appears that one early arrow-producing occupation was concentrated in the North and Midden areas, whereas a later arrow-producing occupation occurred on the southern portion of the site. This interpretation is supported by the fact that arrow points in general increase in frequency from the North area to the South area. ; Originally, the occurrence of dart points within all areas of the site was believed to represent widespread Archaic occupation. However, the consistent co-occurrence of dart and arrow points within features radiocarbon dated to the Late Prehistoric period Jed to the hypothesis that many dart points were contemporaneous with arrow points. To test this hypothesis, projectile points from features within House 1 (ca. A.D. 1030 + 250) and from Feature 38 (ca. A.D. 1120 + 120) were examined. Four of the five points associated with House 1 features were dart points, and all 17 points found in Feature 38 were dart points. This information demonstrates that dart points were in use during the Late Prehistoric period. CERAMIC CHRONOLOGY Although nearly 5,000 ceramic sherds were found during excavations at the site, the chronological value of these items is ‘minimal. There seems to have been minor change in their mode of manufacture and method of decoration throughout the Late Prehistoric occupation of the site. These areas of minor change are the focus of this section. , The primary evidence for temporal change in the ceramic assemblage at the site comes from comparison of sherds in the southern portions of the site (i.e., the South Midden and the South) to other parts of the site and from comparison of Zones | and 2 inside Feature 1, the large pit. Starting with the differences between the southern and the northern halves of the site, four attributes show temporal significance. The first of these is in the range of lip forms present. The most frequent lip forms at the site are rounded and squared. The rolled form, in contrast, occurs rarely, but when it does, it is found only in the South Midden and the South. This lip treatment is common on several Late Caddoan ceramic types (Suhm and Jelks 1962; Bruseth and Perttula 1981). The second attribute which tends to have chronological importance is the rim orientation of the complete vessel. As outlined in Chapter 8, few rims were large enough for this attribute to be observable, but where it could be seen, there is a tendency for inverted rims to occur in the South Midden and in the South, A third variable, again with smal! samples upon which to Volume II, Part One base conclusions, that shows temporal value is tempering. Shell temper, rare overall, shows up only in the Midden. This kind of temper occurs more frequently to the north of the Project area where it is thought to date relatively late (Lorrain 1969:14; Krieger 1946). Mention should be made that shell tempering has been found in the lowest level of Feature 1 at Adams Ranch and is dated to the Late Archaic period. The shell tempered ceramics from the Midden however, do not appear to be from Late Archaic occupations, but from Late Prehistoric use of the site. Fourth, the occurrence of a particular ceramic design element configuration adds another spatial-temporal clue. This element is the engraved and excised triangle. Almost certainly this decoration is part of a larger pattern of vessel decoration similar to that of the type Ripley: Engraved or Patton Engraved, but the small size of the sherds precludes accurate type association. From within the zones of Feature 1 we find additional data on the chronological meaning of the sherds. The context of this pit offers the best time control at the site, since discrete layering is observed within the feature. Although some degree of mixture of levels has occurred from bioturbation and prehistoric digging, radiocarbon dates show that sufficient integrity exists to warrant detailed examination. There is a tendency for more decorated sherds to occur in Zone 1 than in Zone 2, and Zone 1 dates between A.D. 1000 and 1650. Zone 2 dates from A.D. 580 to A.D. 860. The higher incidence of decorated sherds in Zone 1 is solely due to the higher frequency of engraving, which implies that this mode of vessel design was used more frequently during the later occupations at the site. It is worth noting that the engraved and excised triangle element configuration only occurs in Zone 1. In more general terms, these data show a pattern of limited temporal change in ceramics at the site. Overall, ceramics remained similar over time with comparable manufacturing techniques, similar clay sources, and similar decorations and vessel treatments being used. However, more decorated sherds occurred later (ie., after A.D. 1000). Also during this period or later, after A.D. 1300 based on dating of similar developments in East Texas (Bruseth and Perttula 1981), shell tempered, outflaring lips and carinated bowls may have been made occasionally. Design motifs that employed the element configuration of Engraved Triangles were used. The overail trend is similar to that seen in East Texas during the Caddoan archaeological period from the transition of Early to Late Caddo (Suhm et al. 1954; Krieger 1949). Despite the low frequency of ceramic artifacts, this similarity in ceramic change to the East Texas Caddo certainly argues for some type of repeated contact. OCCUPATION SEQUENCE AT BIRD POINT ISLAND Having reviewed the radiocarbon dates, projectile point styles, and ceramic data as to their applicability for intrasite dating, we are now able to view these data as a whole for isolating major periods of prehistoric occupation at Bird Point Island. Although individually each data set has yielded information about some of the major periods of site occupation, together the data serve to form a more complete framework for site chronology. Figure 12-2 graphically displays ali of the relevant radiocarbon dates from the site in chronological order along with their standard deviations. It should be noted that all carbon dates except modern determinations have been included in the graph. Although some of the samples do not date to the time of use of the feature from which they were obtained, they do provide a date of cultural activity at the site. Since we are interested in viewing the overall pattern of occupation at Bird Point Island, these dates provide useful information. If the dates are viewed without regard for their spatial contexts, then a relatively smooth overall trend is seen which lends support to the idea that the site has been occupied intermittently over a long period of time. At a more specific level, though, the graph of the dates shows several points in time that have few or no dates and other times with many averlapping dates.

OCCUPATION I: LATE ARCHAIC The first major use of the site occurred around the time of Christ and is labeled Occupation I on Figure 12-2. With one standard deviation added, the dates from this period range from 410 B.C. to A.D. 250. Three of the dates are from Burial 9/11 from inside Feature 1, and the other two dates are from features in the North area of the site. Given the large sigma values and the deviation among ages of the bone dates from Burial 9/11, it is difficult to accurately estimate the temporal duration of this period. A span of approximately 300 years is indicated on Figure 12-2 based on the overlap of four or more date standard deviations (bone and charcoal dates included). Based on this a time frame of 170 B.C. to A.D, 130 is proposed, although this is at best a rough approximation. During this occupation, Feature 1 was excavated and used for human burial and roasting of plant and animal foods. The skeletal remains of seven individuals were recovered from Zone 3. Since 38% of the pit was excavated, we can estimate the total population of burials inside the pit. However, since excavations were concentrated more in the center than in the periphery of the pit, and because there seems to have been a tendency to bury in the central part of the pit, we estimate 50% of the total number of burials have been recovered. This indicates a total burial population of at least 14, but perhaps as many as 18 when infant underenumeration is taken into account (see Chapter 6). Two of the carbon dates for this period are from pits outside of Feature 1: one is from a roasting pit (Beta-7160) and one is from a cremation burial (Beta-7156). In both cases the charcoal which was collected was not integrally associated with the feature. Although it was collected from within the feature, it seems to represent Late Archaic period charcoal that was accidentally incorporated into the feature at a later time. This interpretation is supported by the physical similarity of these features to others which had later radiocarbon dates and temporally diagnostic artifacts. If this interpretation is correct, then all that can be concluded is that occupation did occur around the large pit, but did not result in features that are clearly identifiable with this period. Although several Late Archaic projectile point styles have been identified at the site, particularly from the North area, it is difficult to discern with any degree of reliability which styles are definitely attributable to this occupation. OCCUPATION I: RICHLAND CREEK PHASE The next major component on the site has been labeled Occupation II. In addition, phase names have been ascribed to this and the following occupations, in convention with the culture- history nomenclature presented in Part Two of Volume III. Although these phases are described in detail in Volume II, a brief discussion is in order here to clarify what is meant by the use of the term phase. We use this term to refer to a cultural episode that occurred within a given time and that possessed a given set of traits sufficiently distinctive to be separated from other cultural episodes. More specifically, a phase in the reservoir area is a period of time during which we have sufficient information on the types and styles of artifacts in use, the range of features present, the economic strategies employed, and the general internal structure of sites to say that this period is distinctive from other periods. Only a few sites are presently understood well enough to be used for the formation of phases. Only two radiocarbon dates are available for the Richland Creek phase at Bird Point Island, and both suggest a midpoint date of between A.D. 700 and 720. With standard deviations added, the dates range from A.D. 580 to 860; but the close correspondence of the midpoints, both of which are from the same stratigraphic level within Feature 1, argue for a relatively short occupation. One of the dates (Beta-8388) is from charcoal associated with Burials 19 and 20, both from the same cremation pit; and the other (Beta- 5593) is from the same stratigraphic position in the pit but outside of the cremation burial. No radiocarbon dates from this period have been identified outside of Feature 1, which indicates that little occupation occurred around the pit. It seems that occupation during this time was solely for the burial of cremated remains in the pit and that this process may have resulted in some debris accumulating over Feature I (i.e., the charcoal for date Beta- 5593) but nowhere else on the site. The main evidence for a phase designation comes from other sites in the area (See Volume IID). It is difficult to identify the projectile point or ceramic styles that were used during this period since we have no features other than a cremation to provide a temporally specific context. A few exceptions have been noted which show that shell tempering, _outflaring lips, carinated bowls, and design motifs using engraved and excised triangles were added to the preexisting ceramic inventory. ## Page 189

SPATIAL ANALYSIS OF ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS by James E. Bruseth and William A. Martin This chapter presents the results of spatial analysis conducted on systematically collected artifacts from the site. Three data sets are used for this analysis. The first consists of artifacts collected during a surface collection of the site. The site was plowed prior to this activity, and all artifacts were gathered from 5 x 5 m squares. The second data set comprises artifacts from the excavation of 50 x 50 cm units systematically placed across much of the site. The units form a data base that is useful in making interpretations about cultural activity over large portions of the site and is valuable for assessing the merits of subsurface sampling relative to systematic surface collections. The third data set consists of artifacts collected from a block excavation over House 1. This house was partially exposed by a bulldozer trench during Season II. Approximately 60% of the pattern remained intact, and during Season IH this area was block excavated to obtain a sample from inside the house (see Chapter 3 for details on this excavation), CONTROLLED SURFACE COLLECTION Until recently, many archaeologists had assumed that disturbances caused by plowing were too great to allow the study of plow zone artifacts, except as crude indicators of subsurface features. Recent experiments conducted by tillage engineers and archaeologists have shown that agriculturally altered deposits follow predictable patterns of artifact displacement and breakage (Roper 1976; Kouwenhoven and Terpstra 1979; Nartov 1979; Lewarch 1979). Once these patterns are understood, plow zone data can be used effectively. Controlled surface collection has been shown to be a useful indicator of artifact populations for sites located on stable landforms in East Texas (Bruseth and Pertulla 1981). Since Bird Point Island is a terrace with a stable surface, it is ideal for this technique. The soil type, equipment used, direction of plowing, and length of plowing time all influence the displacement of artifacts (Lewarch 1979:106). Experiments have shown that longitudinal movement is greater than transverse movement and that objects at greater depth are less subject to movement than those near the surface. Vertical displacement is cumulative, and a point is reached after several equipment passes where further cultivation will not change this distribution. Lateral displacement, on the other hand, can be randomized by the effects of multiple equipment passes. In fact, multiple passes may disturb the original context less than a single pass would (Lewarch 1979:106). Prior to surface collection at Bird Point Island, the site was plowed twice, with tractor passes in opposite directions to randomize lateral artifact displacement and to insure consistent soil exposure. After sufficient rainfall had exposed artifacts, collection began. A unit size of 5 x 5 m was selected. Collection units were demarcated quickly by setting stakes at 5 m intervals in between 20 m grid stakes and stretching string between them. One 20 x 20 m block (16 units) was collected at a time with 10 crew members working one to a unit. All artifacts were collected regardless of size of class, and no time limit was imposed. The northwest comer of each unit was used to designate provenience, and specimen bags were labeled only by supervisors to minimize errors. A total of 31 blocks (496 units) was collected with a minimal amount of labor (30 person-days). - In the laboratory, artifacts were sorted into the following morphological categories: lithic debris, biface, core, uniface, projectile point, ground stone, miscellaneous stone (including fire cracked rock), ceramics, baked clay, bone, and shell. Lithic debris included whole flakes, broken flakes, and shatter. Miscellaneous stone consisted primarily of fire cracked rock but also included unmodified cobbles. Artifact data were entered onto microcomputers in the laboratory and subsequently were transferred by telephone to the main computer in the Bradfield Computer Center at Southern Methodist University. This permitted access to the SYMAP program, a synographic computer mapping program which uses a complex algorithm to construct contours of similar artifact frequencies. This program allows the use to select the number of contours and the interval magnitude for each contour. Five contour intervals were used, based on studies conducted by Bruseth and Perttula (1981) which have shown that this number is optimal for sites in eastern Texas. 169

170 SYMAPs generated for all artifact classes were examined to search for evidence of specialized work areas. However, because stone tool manufacture was conducted in and around other activity areas, such as houses, hearths, and specialized work areas, the quantity of lithic debris was substantially greater than the quantity of other artifacts deposited. As a result, the lithic debris SYMAP provided the clearest view of the principal activity areas at the site. Figure 13-1 shows the major activity areas delineated by surface lithic debris distribution. The Midden south of Feature 1 is clearly visible as a large cluster extending from 30N to -25N and from -20E to 50E. Within this large cluster are smaller, high-density clusters which mark hot spots of activity. A dramatic decline in frequency occurs south of this Midden, until another cluster is encountered adjacent to the slough from -70N to -80N and OE to 20E. Finally, several small clusters are visible on the north half of the site, which lacks the high-density clusters found within the Midden. SYSTEMATIC SUBSURFACE COLLECTION During Season JI at Bird Point Island, a major emphasis of the field work was the excavation of systematically placed 50 x 50 cm units spaced 5 m apart. Details on the excavation procedures and screening methods of this work are presented in Chapter 3. Although this method of excavation had been employed on several historic sites in the Project area, it had not been used on prehistoric sites and useful results could not be guaranteed. Consequently the 5 m spacing was selected to minimize the time spent on this activity. After analysis, the artifact data were input into the SYMAP computer program to produce maps of artifact density. The maps showed that several clusters occurred for most artifact classes and the clusters were highly interpretable when compared with the locations of features. The initial success of the maps prompted the excavation of additional 50 x 50 cm units during Season III field work; these units were placed in between the 5 m units to increase the map resolution in the hope of providing even greater interpretability. This resulted in a final spacing of 1.67 m. However, since the 1.67 m spacing greatly increased excavation time over the 5 m spacing, not all of the areas sampled during Season II could be sampled during Season III (see Figure 3-5). Despite this limitation, more than 6,000 m2 of the site were sampled by this technique, including the highest elevations of the site where the principal cultural activity took place. Spatial imaging of the new data set was undertaken in a more complex manner than for the 5 m data alone. The 1.67 m interval data set encompassed several areas where adjacent 50 x 50 cm units were missing due to bulldozer test trenches that had been cut across the site. Program SYMAP was used to interpolate across these areas in order to provide a spatially complete data set. Next the output from SYMAP was smoothed by a custom program to provide more interpretable maps. Due to the fine grained sampling, the unsmoothed data had a very patchy quality with frequencies in adjacent units varying 50% or more in some instances. Although large scale trends were apparent in the data, these were difficult to define and in places were obscured by the patchy quality. Since the goal of the systematically spaced units was to sample site variability over large areas at the the sacrifice of localized detail, data smoothing was considered a necessary step in the interpretation process. The smoothing program selected 16 units surrounding a central point and computed a weighted average to replace the central value. The values were weighted so that units closer to the center were counted more heavily than units located further from it. This procedure allowed large scale trends in the data to become more clearly visible. Once the data were smoothed, they were input into a spatial contouring program developed by Robert Huggins. As noted in Chapter 12, the Midden appears to be the product of two major periods of occupation at the site: one between A.D. 1000 to A.D. 1200 and one from A.D. 1300 to A.D. 1650 or later. Both of these occupations used ceramics and the sherds from the Midden are believed to be the product of both occupations. The heavier frequency of ceramics in the southern third of the Midden may irdicate that the later occupation, which occurs mostly in the southern half of the site, was more intense in this area. Figure 13-5 shows the distribution of large (greater than 2.5 cm) pieces of fire cracked rock and Figure 13-6 the distribution of small pieces of fire cracked rock (between 1 and 2.5 cm), Fire cracked rock was size graded in the laboratory into these two groups to investigate any differential spatial distributions each size might have, The impetus for this action was an observation made in the field that smaller fire cracked rock seemed to occur in clusters away from larger pieces. Spatial maps were then produced on each of these data sets. The two maps show significantly different distributions. Large fire cracked rock occurs mostly across the southern half of the map and is clustered into several distinct groups. Most small fire cracked rock, on the other hand, is | located in a single northeast to southwest extending cluster that follows the crest of the site. As discussed in Chapter 10, the small pieces of fire cracked rock correlate with magnetic anomalies, | particularly in the North area. Chapter 10 presents the argument that the small pieces represent the residue of earth oven Toasting with Wilcox sandstone, the raw material used for fire cracked rock. This conclusion was reached after detailed experiments were conducted on Wilcox sandstone to observe the action of heat upon this material. Substantial amounts of each stone were exfoliated by the heat, and the residue of this process was numerous pieces of bumed Wilcox sandstone identical in size and appearance to the small category of fire cracked rock identified in the laboratory. 173 Chapter 10 also notes that the Wilcox sandstone is weakly magnetic in a natural state but becomes highly magnetic after firing. Therefore, the correlation of magnetic anomalies with small pieces of fire cracked rock shows that these rocks have been heated and further supports the notion that the small pieces of rock are residue from pit roasting. The distribution of large pieces of fire cracked rock appears to represent the location of Wilcox sandstone that has not been subjected to heat. A possible clue to the purpose of the large, unburned rock comes from the cluster located immediately outside of and to the southwest of House 1. The location of this large fire cracked rock cluster lacks a corresponding cluster on the small fire cracked rock map. In fact, the map of small fire cracked rock distribution shows a frequency “low” in the same location as the large fire cracked rock cluster. Since no large magnetic anomaly was located in this area, we know that this cluster is unburned rock and not really fire cracked. The lack of subsurface pits in this area further supports the argument that the rock was not used for roasting. What then was the purpose of the large rock in this cluster? ‘ A possible clue is the seasonal availability of the outcrop of Wilcox sandstone along the southern margin of the site. During the rainy season in this part of Texas, which occurs from March through June, the outcrop is often inundated by the overflow of Richland Creek. The periods of flooding are not predictable within the rainy season and are related to the occurrence of major storms. In contrast, an important plant food that was roasted in the pits, Psoralea tubers, is a predictable resource that must be gathered and processed within a two to three week period beginning in early May (Wedel 1978). This period occurs in the middle of the rainy season, and it is likely that Wilcox sandstone was collected and stored to provide an adequate supply for later Psoralea processing. As a result, the sandstone cluster on the southwestern side of the house may represent the remains of such a storage location. This is not to imply that the entire cluster, measuring 7 x 20 m, was used at once, but that several episodes of small scale storage likely took place over many years and resulted in what appears today as the large cluster. The rock that makes up this cluster probably represents residual pieces that were not used and were ultimately churned into the A horizon, In the Midden the examples of inverse relationships between the large and small fire cracked rocks are not as clear. The Midden is thought to represent debris from two major periods of site occupations, and the spatial patterns of fire cracked rock are difficult to interpret. Although some areas of large, unburned rock occur where there is a corresponding lack of small pieces, various degrees of overlap occur more frequently. This general lack of clarity in the patterns is believed to be due to overlapping activities. Figure 13-7 is the spatial map for bone. Unlike the previous spatial maps, bone shows a markedly reduced distribution, partly the result of a smaller sample size. A single small cluster of bone is located in the North part of the site. Since no other bone clusters occur in this area, this material may be modern and unrelated to prehistoric activity at the site. The soil conditions on the North result in poor bone preservation (see Chapter 2), which may account for the lack of bone recovered in this area. Bone is better preserved in the Midden and the principal clustering is in the central part. Lithic debris occurs over much of the area where bone is found and the major clusters of ceramics are found around the bone concentrations to the west and the south. In addition, the spatial clustering of bone shows’ prominently over Feature 45, a proposed roasting pit. The distribution of shell is displayed in Figure 13-8. Shell shows a very similar distribution to bone with dominance in the Midden. A cluster of shell shows over Feature 45, as was the case with bone, and these two faunal residues may indicate that the pit was used for trash disposal after it ceased to be used for plant roasting. Perhaps the broader distributions of shell and bone, which show overall correspondence, indicate that trash disposal took place in the central part of the Midden.

HOUSE 1 MAPS House 1 was discovered during the initial phase of A horizon removal at the site. As a result of this discovery, a decision was made to block excavate the remainder of the house so that spatial analysis could be undertaken on the artifacts. CONCLUSION The systematic collection of artifacts from the site has formed an important data source for making cultural interpretations at the intrasite level. Although several suggestions on what these distributions indicate have been made in this section, Chapter 14 uses these data to form an overall synthesis of intrasite cultural behavior. It must be pointed out that not all of the spatial data sets are equally as valuable. The surface collected data basically mirrored the distributions produced by subsurface artifacts. However, the surface matetials showed a general blurring of cluster outlines and an inability to reliably detect smaller clusters. The value of the surface data must be viewed in relation to the relatively short amount of time spent on this activity (see Chapter 3 for details). ## Page 201

PREHISTORIC SETTLEMENT AT BIRD POINT ISLAND by James E. Bruseth and William A. Martin . In the previous chapters of this report, information has been presented from five seasons of field work at Bird Point Island. Each chapter has concentrated on a specific set of data, such as lithic artifacts or subsistence remains, with little concern for the broader interrelationships of the data. The purpose of this chapter is to summarize the major points of the earlier chapters and use this information to formulate an overall intrepretation of prehistoric settlement at the site. The format of this presentation is by the major periods of site occupation outlined in Chapter 12. Although the site has undoubtedly been visited numerous times over the past several millennia, major periods of occupation are evident from only four periods: Late Archaic, Richland Creek phase, Round Prairie phase, and St. Elmo phase. Each period forms a major division later in this chapter. Mention should also be made of the hypotheses, formulated during the survey and testing phase of the project (Raab and Moir 1982), that initially served to guide research at the site. These hypotheses pertained to the age and function of Feature 1 (see Chapter 1), and the results that bear upon each hypothesis are presented within the appropriate time period. INTEGRATIVE PROBLEMS Within each of the temporal periods of site ocupation, five problem areas are addressed as a means of synthesizing the site data and presenting a picture of cultural activity. Hopefully, the investigation of these problem areas serves to elevate the discussion from the simple presentation of trends in the data to an understanding of cultural behavior for the groups present during each period of occupation. The first problem area is the definition of architectural features. Specifically, this refers to pits and above ground structures constructed during each period, such as houses, drying racks, and ramadas, as denoted by features such as post holes, 181 hearths, and storage pits. Discussion of the second problem area employs the spatial data presented in Chapters 11 and 13 to identify the locations of activities on the site and to understand overall community patterning. The distribution of features presented in Chapter 4 is also used. Since the site has multiple components with a certain degree of spatial overlap, features are assigned to periods of occupation according to the criteria used in Chapter 4 (see Table 4-10); however, as previously noted, the temporal assignments in some cases are only estimates. The third problem area focuses on the economic strategy utilized by each group to maintain an adequate food supply. The data from Chapter 9 are used to understand the patterns of economic exploitation for each time period. Even though the preservation of subsistence remains at the site was relatively poor, overall trends in the exploitation of food species can be seen. The fourth problem concerns the size of the occupying group during each period. This problem area is more difficult to address since some occupations represent accumulations of debris from sporadic visits over several decades or centuries, whereas other occupations reflect the accumulation of debris from sedentary habitation. Estimates of population size for mobile groups are less likely to be accurate than those for sedentary groups. Similarly, the final problem is the duration of occupation for each group and is equally difficult to estimate; particularly for the mobile groups who occupied the site. ; It is not possible to address all problems for every time period because the quality and quantity of data attributable to each period varies markedly, and little or no information exists for some problem areas during certain periods. For example, even though Late Archaic projectile points are found across the site, the only clearly dated Late Archaic context is Zone 3 of Feature 1. Other artifacts found outside of Feature 1 are almost certainly related to the Late Archaic occupation, but only the diagnostic projectile points can be separated with certainty from the lithic debris and stone tools of later occupations. As a result, it is very difficult to define the community layout for this period. Therefore, only those problems for which meaningful conclusions can be reached are discussed.
