182 OCCUPATION I: LATE ARCHAIC (170 B.C. TO A.D. 130) Projectile points attributable to all periods of the Archaic have been found at the site, but the only recognizable cultural activity in good context is found within Zone 3 of Feature 1. As stated in the conclusion of Chapter 6, Feature 1 represents four major periods of use, beginning with the Archaic period. Originally, Feature 1 was the focus of ritual activity involving the processing of plant and animal foods, as well as the interment of deceased humans and dogs. The means of several radiocarbon dates from skeletal remains in Zone 3 range between 170 B.C. and A.D. 130 (see Chapter 12). This supports the hypothesis posited prior to mitigation that the pit had a Late Archaic origin (Raab and Moir 1981:203). Few conclusions can be drawn for the Late Archaic group with respect to the five problem areas outlined above because so few data were clearly associated with this occupation. No conclusions about architectural features can be made other than that despite extensive work inside Feature 1, no evidence of a superstructure was found within or around the pit. Likewise, few conclusions can be made regarding intrasite activity since few artifacts can be positively associated with the people who first occupied the site. Nevertheless, the paucity of Late Archaic features and associated artifacts indicates that only short term occupations occurred during this period. The subsistence strategy employed by this early group can be inferred on the basis of faunal remains found in Zone 3 of Feature 1. Bone preservation was better in this context than in any other found on the site, and a varied assemblage was collected. Whitetail deer dominated the assemblage, but fish, turtle, bird, rabbit, bison, and opossum were also consumed. Dog remains were found in Zone 3, but most are attributable to intentional interments rather than to use for food. Although very few floral remains were recovered, the most important appear to have been hickory nuts, acoms, and Psoralea tubers. A diffuse economic strategy in which a wide variety of species were used appears to have been practiced (Cleland 1976). The size of the Late Archaic group and the length of occupation are largely speculative. From the relatively low quantities of artifacts attributable to this period, it would appear that only limited, short-term occupations occurred. However, this is based on the few artifacts that can be definitely associated with this occupation; it is quite probable that many of the lithic artifacts from A horizon contexts around Feature 1 may be associated with Late Archaic occupations. Based on the present data, the best interpretation for Late Archaic period use of the site is that it served as a location for interband feasting and as a cemetery for local hunting and gathering groups (see Chapter 21). Seven burials were found in the central portion of Zone 3 that was excavated (nearly 50% of the central portion), suggesting that 14 individuals may have been present. Accounting for possible infant underenumeration, there may have been as many as 18 individuals interred in Feature 1. Although this estimate is speculative, such a group size is compatible with mortality expectations for a small band. OCCUPATION II: RICHLAND CREEK PHASE (A.D. 580 TO 860) Little is known about this period of occupation at the site. It is marked only by two cremations in the upper portion of Zone 2 in Feature 1 (see Chapter 6). Although artifacts from this occupation probably occur elsewhere on the site, the imprecise chronology for most artifacts prevents the detection of these deposits. In fact, the rationale for classifying this occupation as a "phase" comes from data recovered at other sites in the reservoir (see Chapter 15, Volume III). Consequently, discussions of architecture, intrasite activity areas, subsistence strategy, group size, and duration of Volume II, Part One occupation are presented in Chapter 18 of Volume III. It can be said here that the overall pattern of this phase is similar to that of the Late Archaic and is marked by the diffuse economy but with a less mobile settlement pattern. It is possible that the concentration of features immediately south and east of Feature 1 represents Richland Creek phase activity, although no radiocarbon dates were obtained from any of these features which would permit exact chronological placement. The presence of cremation Burial 27 immediately southwest of Feature 1, and the fact that other features excavated in this area look very similar to cremations found elsewhere on the site, suggest that at least some of the activity in this area is related to the Richland Creek phase. Since Richland Creek phase cremations were placed within Feature 1, the presence of one, and possibly several, cremations in this area may represent an extension of the cemetery outside of the pit during this period. Of course, cremations were also present during the following Round Prairie phase, so it is possible that this area was used as a cemetery by the groups of this later period. Unfortunately, the lack of identifiable human bone in most of these features precludes their firm identification. All of these features are listed as possible cremations and as possible hearths in Table 4-10 because their contents were similar to both of these types of features. However, the presence of a definite cremation (Burial 27) in this area suggests that these other features may also be cremations. OCCUPATION ITI: ROUND PRAIRIE PHASE (A.D. 1000 TO 1200) This phase is marked by the presence of a hamlet consisting of three houses in the North area of the site. Although some features were directly datable by chronometric means or on the basis of diagnostic artifacts, few intrusive features were observed suggesting that most features were created during a single occupation. This contrasts with the Midden where radiocarbon dates indicate two major periods of occupation and considerable superpositioning of features is evident. Most discussion of the Round Prairie phase is limited to the features which are present in this North area. This is largely because the principal living area at this time appears to have been in this portion of the site, and because the Midden is too mixed to permit clear conclusions to be drawn. This phase receives the most detailed treatment of all phases at the site because the data base is largest for this occupation. ARCHITECTURE Three structures were identified on the basis of circular patterns of post holes with four interior post holes arranged in a rectangular pattern (Figure 14-1). The interior posts were larger and set deeper than the wall posts, and apparently provided the primary support for the structure. The roof was probably formed by timbers spanning the area from the wall posts to beams supported by the interior posts, with roof timbers tied together near the center of the structure. The roof was probably pitched and may have had an opening in the center to release smoke froma central hearth. Figure 14-2 is a photograph of a Caddo house taken in the 1860s in Oklahoma that is similar to the houses found at Bird Point Island. In all probability, other above-ground structures were present near the houses. Drying racks, covered work areas (arbors), and isolated posts set in the ground are often pictured in nineteenth century photographs of Indian villages. The locations of possible drying racks and arbors are illustrated in Figure 14-1, These areas have been identified on the basis of clusters of post holes that are not parts of houses. Extensive scraping of the B horizon revealed these clusters, but failed to turn up complete house patterns. For example, in the complex cluster of post holes west of House 3, a Prehistor

For instance, curation behavior (Binford 1973) can result in artifact deposits with certain key elements of tool assemblages missing, since unbroken tools can be used for activities on other parts of the site. Also, differential preservation, particularly for economic reasons, can create a biased view of the activities that were conducted in any given location. For the analysis of activity areas within the hamlet, specific statements can be made with respect to lithic tool manufacture, food preparation, and activities associated with features of known function, The spatial maps of artifact distributions in the following figures are based on data collected from the 50 x 50 cm units spaced at 1.67 m intervals (see Chapter 13). Two levels of lithic debris contours are shown in Figure 14-3. The lower contour represents 20-28 artifacts per 50 x 50 cm unit and encompasses all of the houses and the areas in between the houses. The houses and the majority of the low-density cluster occur on the crest of the terrace, except for two elongations to the east and west. Both elongations are located downslope and probably reflect trash disposal areas. This idea was examined in Chapter 7, but no definite conclusions could be reached. Two high-level clusters are present, consisting of 28-45 artifacts per unit. One is located over part of House 1 and extends to the northeast; the other is situated immediately south of House 2. This suggests that most stone tool manufacture was conducted in and around the houses and especially between Houses 1 and 3. Interestingly, no high-density cluster was found over House 3, so this activity may not have occurred near this structure. No correlations were observed between lithic debris and features other than houses, so stone tool making appears to be unrelated to the use of features. Ceramic distributions, pictured in Figure 14-4, indicate that ceramic related activities, such as cooking, serving, and storage, were conducted in less restricted locations than was stone tool manufacture. Low ceramic density levels represent one artifact per unit and high-density levels represent more than one artifact per unit. The low-level clusters occur over and to one side of each of the houses and show general agreement with the location of lithic debris clusters. On the other hand, the high-level clusters that reflect intensive ceramic use are distributed in a different manner than high-level lithic debris clusters. Assuming that stone tool manufacture was a male activity and that cooking was a female activity, it appears that each sex worked in slightly different areas within the hamlet. The only exception to this is the area northeast of House 1 where larger clusters for many artifact classes were present. The longer period of occupation of House 1, as suggested Volume II, Part One by an extra pair of interior posts from a repair episode, may account for the observed overlap of lithic and ceramic clusters. The distribution of large fire cracked rock in Figure 14-5 is very interesting, since magnetometer studies have shown that several clusters exhibit little magnetism and actually represent unburned rock concentrations which were misidentified as fire cracked rock (see Chapter 10). These unburned clusters occur adjacent to the wall of House 1, immediately northeast of Feature 38 (a roasting pit), immediately south of House 3, and along the western edge of the scraped area. All of them are believed to be storage areas for rock used in hearths and roasting pits. It appears that substantial quantities of Wilcox sandstone were gathered from the slough during the dry season and stored for use near habitations and roasting pits. Figure 14-6 illustrates the distribution of charcoal by weight within the A horizon units. The location of a single, large cluster with two high-level clusters inside it coincides with the location of House 2 and is believed to represent the charred debris that fell upon the surface and was scattered by natural forces after the structure burned. In addition, no magnetic anomaly was recorded over House 2, such as the large anomaly recorded over the hearth in House 1 (Feature 57). It appears that House 2 may have burned before the quantities of fire cracked rock built up to a level sufficient to be detectable by the magnetometer. This hypothesis of a shorter duration of occupation in House 2 is also supported by the smaller artifact clusters found over this structure. The final spatial distribution map illustrates the accumulation of midden over portions of the North area as indicated by darkening of the soil by increases in organic matter content from human occupation (Cook and Heizer 1965:10). The area over and immediately southeast of House 1 is the largest area of midden accumulation in the North (Figure 14-7). This probably reflects the gradual addition of organic matter from plant and animal residues during the occupation of the house rather than intentional disposal of refuse within the structure. The increase in soil color over Feature 38 does not correspond to lithic debris or ceramic clusters and may represent intentional disposal of plant and animal refuse. Smaller clusters of soil discoloration occur over Houses 2 and 3, which suggests that they were utilized to a lesser extent than House 1. An area of dark soil also coincides with the clusters of lithic debris and ceramics to the southeast of the three houses, supporting the idea that this represents a trash disposal area. ; The intra-house activity pattern within House | is illustrated in Figure 14-8. Three zones of activity are apparent, based on the block excavation data from the northern 60% of this house. First, the central hearth and the immediately surrounding area are marked by a concentration of fire cracked rock, ceramics, and projectile points denoting use as a food preparation area. Although projectile points are traditionally assumed to reflect hunting activity, the consistent occurrence of projectile points, especially dart points, within hearths and roasting pits at Bird Point Island suggests that they were also used as knives and scrapers. Second, the zone between the hearth and the interior posts is marked by the highest frequency of lithic debris and aborted bifaces and is the location of most storage pits. Therefore, this area of the house appears to represent a work and storage area in which tool manufacture occurred and foods were preserved in subfloor storage pits. Finally, the zone between the interior posts and the wall posts was marked by the lowest frequency of artifacts and features. This area probably was used for sleeping and above ground storage. An artist's reconstruction of the site during the Round Prairie phase is shown in Figure 14-9. This accurately depicts the locations of houses, roasting pits and activity areas based on site maps. Feature 1 is shown in the foreground to register the scene, and House 3 is shown under construction to illustrate details of architecture. The activities of food preparation, pit roasting, stone tool manufacture, and refuse disposal in the upper zone of Feature 1 are all depicted. House 1 exhibits the largest and clearest magnetic anomaly, the largest artifact clusters, the most soil discoloration, and contains extra interior posts and closely spaced wall posts indicative of rebuilding. Thus, House 1 was probably occupied longer than any of the other structures. House 2 apparently burned before it was occupied for any substantial length of time. Its similarity to House 1 and its degree of completeness suggest that it was used in a similar manner. On the other hand, House 3 is marked by an incomplete post hole pattern, different distributions of artifacts, and less soil discoloration than observed for the other houses. In Chapter 13, it is suggested that House 3 was actually a covered work area. Another explanation is that it served as a summer house. Swanton (1946:386-392) notes the occurrence of two seasonal house types among several tribes of Southeast Indians: a winter house of substantial construction, and a summer house of less substantial construction, often with portions of walls missing. It is possible that House 1 was a winter house, and that House 3, with the southeast portion of the wall missing, represented a summer house. Warm weather would have permitted daily activities to be conducted in a less restricted area, thereby reducing the likelihood of accumulating artifacts within the structure. . SUBSISTENCE STRATEGY: SEDENTARY HUNTERS AND GATHERERS Faunal and floral remains recovered from storage pits, roasting pits, and other features clearly associated with the hamlet occupation provide an important interpretation of prehistoric economic patterns during this phase. Although dozens of features were excavated and subjected to flotation recovery, including storage pits and post holes clearly related to house occupation, no evidence of agriculture was recovered. The absence of maize does Volume H, Part One not prove conclusively that this food was not used, but some corn should have been found if it was used even as a supplement, based on com recovery rates from agricultural groups in East Texas (cf., Bruseth and Perttula 1981). The subsistence strategy hinged on the use of three naturally abundant wild foods. These were (1) deer, forming the principal source of protein; (2) acorns and nuts, providing fats and carbohydrates; and (3) Psoralea tubers, forming an additional source of carbohydrates. The presence of significant quantities of Psoralea remains is a particularly important discovery because this represents the first evidence, to our knowledge, of this resource found within an archaeological context. In fact, Wedel (1978) stated that this resource might never by found in an archaeological context because of its poor potential for preservation. The principal plant foods are complementary from the standpoint of harvesting, with nuts and acorns abundant in the fall and Psoralea available in the spring. All of these species have high storage potential once dried or roasted, so they formed dependable supplies of food. Although nut production is cyclical, different species produce in different cycles so that a bad year for one species is often offset by a good year for another (Hilliard 1980). Psoralea is a relatively drought resistant species, so it also forms a reliable subsistence base (Wedel 1978). Thus, these plant species can be relied upon despite fluctuations in annual rainfall. The location of Bird Point Island within the Post Oak Savannah has important implications for economic exploitation. Large quantities of nuts and acorns would have been available in this zone, which in turn would have attracted populations of deer. The open woodland of the savannah would have also contained many “edge” areas that provide browse for deer. Psoralea would also have been found in this zone because it prefers the sandy soils that are confined to the Post Oak Savannah. Thus, the Post Oak Savannah would have provided alt of the staples, whereas the other neighboring zones would have provided numerous supplements to the diet. It is no coincidence that Bird Point Island is in the center of this zone, and as presented in Chapter 18, Volume III, we argue that the Round Prairie phase occupation represents a specialized adaptation to the Post Oak Savannah. In addition, Bird Point Island provided an important mineral resource, Wilcox sandstone. This material, which was heated for roasting, provided a necessary resource required for processing the plants in roasting pits, thus enabling the abundant food resources of the Post Oak Savanah to be processed and stored. GROUP SIZE In Chapter 4, ethnographic sources were used to obtain estimates of population size for the hamlet occupation. Assuming that all three houses were occupied simultaneously, a maximum population of 20 was derived. However, as noted in the previous section, it is unlikely that all houses were inhabited concurrently. If House 1 and House 3 were occupied at the same time, the estimate is reduced to 13. Finally, if House 1 was a winter house and House 3 was a summer house, then a single household with a population no greater than eight would have formed the group occupying the site. None of the estimates point to the presence of a large population, and all of them could represent a single extended family. ; DEGREE OF SEDENTISM AND DURATION OF OCCUPATION The degree of sedentism reflects the total length of time the group occupied the site during a single year, whereas the duration of occupation is related to the number of years that the hamlet was occupied. The presence of substantial structures argues for a high degree of sedentism during the Round Prairie phase, and this idea is supported by floral and faunal data. Deer remains from Zone 1 of Feature 1, which are related to this occupation and to the final occupation, include antlers fused to frontal bones, and deer mandibles from individuals aged approximately 1.7 years. Since antlers are shed in the winter, and deer are born in the spring, the presence of fused antlers and the age of deer at time of death both indicate a fall/winter period of exploitation (see Chapter 9). The well developed hearth inside House 1 suggests that it was used for household heating as well as cooking, and further supports the hypothesis that the site was occupied during the winter. Thus, the evidence indicates a year-round, or sedentary, occupation of the site, apart from brief periods of abandonment for nut collecting or hunting trips. This sedentism based on a hunting and gathering economy was made possible by high concentration of important food resources in the Post Oak Savannah (see Chapter 18, Volume III). Little data are available with which to make an estimate of total length of the Round Prairie phase occupation. Using post decay rates provided by the Texas Forest Service, Good (1982) estimated that houses at the De Shazo site lasted an average of 20 years, and perhaps as long as 30 years. The houses at Bird Point Island were situated on the highest elevation of the terrace, almost certainly to facilitate drainage. However, the evidence that two interior posts of House 1 were replaced suggests that it was occupied long enough for wood decay to become a problem. Good's estimate of 20 years is probably reasonable for the length of use of House 1. Since this structure appears to have been occupied longer than any of the others, the entire duration of hamlet occupation probably fell within this 20 year period. OCCUPATION IV: ST. ELMO PHASE (A.D. 1300 TO 1650) Several separate occupations actually occurred during this 350- year period (see Chapter 12), but insufficient data are available to draw conclusions about individual occupations, so the overall characteristics of the entire period are discussed. The nature of St. Elmo phase artifacts and features suggests that there was a high degree of cultural similarity among all occupations of this period, and that the nature of occupation was quite different from occupation during the Round Prairie phase. Most evidence for the St. Elmo phase comes from the North Midden, South Midden, and South areas of the site. Unfortunately, features and artifacts dating to the Round Prairie phase are mixed in among these areas along with later St. Elmo phase materials. Vertical mixing of the artifacts in the A horizon and the inability to associate many features with individual components makes it

Consequently, the discussion of cultural behavior during the St. Elmo phase is subject to a greater degree of speculation than for the preceding phase. ARCHITECTURE No complete house patterns were uncovered within the Midden, but a cluster of post holes was recognized in the southwest portion of the South Midden (Figure 14-10). The cluster falls within an area comprised primarily of St. Elmo phase ceramics and projectile points and is interpreted as evidence for one or more above ground structures related to this period. Despite intensive scraping and examination of the area for additional post holes, no complete arc or rectangle of post holes was recognized. The few post holes present suggest that structures built during the St. Elmo phase were more temporary than those constructed during the Round Prairie phase. This interpretation is supported by data from site 41NV173, another St. Elmo phase site, which lacked evidence of house patterns despite extensive scraping (see Chapter 11, Volume III). Instead, isolated clusters of post holes similar to those found at Bird Point Island were present. This suggests that people may have been more mobile, occupying sites for shorter periods, during the St. Elmo phase. Figure 14-11 is an artist's conception of the more temporary structures hypothesized to have existed in the Midden and South areas of the site during this phase. INTRASITE ACTIVITY ANALYSIS It is difficult to make definitive statements about activity areas because of the mixture of components present within the Midden. For instance, the lithic debris distribution shows a single large cluster over the entire Midden and it is impossible to make statements about the specific locations of tool manufacture within this cluster. Ceramics provide the most interpretable clusters within this area because their relative scarcity at the site creates small discrete clusters. Figure 14-12 illustrates the ceramic concentrations in the Midden along with the features assigned to the St. Elmo phase. Most ceramics occur in the South Midden, and most late ceramic types occur in the South Midden and South areas (Chapter 8). The ceramic cluster in this area occurs over the cluster of post holes in the South Midden, showing a similar distribution to the ceramics over Round Prairie phase houses. However, the spatial data are too mixed to draw firm conclusions other than that the most intense occupation during the St. Elmo phase occurred in the South Midden area. SUBSISTENCE STRATEGY: MOBILE HORTICULTURALISTS The overall pattern of economic exploitation remained unchanged between the Round Prairie and the St. Elmo phases, with one very’ important exception. This exception was the introduction of maize as a supplement to the diet of wild foods. Three features associated with this phase contained very small quantities of maize, indicating a minimal use of corn. Trace element data and an increase in dental calculus associated with Burial 8 also suggest that maize was a supplement (see Chapter 5). However, it is significant that maize was added to a diet that previously was sufficient to maintain a sedentary population. This implies that some type of stress may have occurred which stimulated a need for a change in subsistence strategy. Archaeological evidence indicates that the Caddoan people to the east were producing corn contemporaneously with both the Round Prairie and St. Elmo phases (Bruseth and Pertulla 1981; Story 1981). Why then was corn absent from the botanical specimens recovered from the Round Prairie phase features? Sampling is not the answer since a greater number of features and Volume II, Part One a larger volume of fill was floated from the Round Prairie phase than from the St. Elmo phase. The best interpretation is that St. Elmo phase groups were mobile, perhaps only seasonally, occupying Bird Point Island. The ceramic design elements attributable to this phase are very similar to late Caddoan styles in East Texas (Bruseth and Perttula 1981:6). This similarity to ceramic styles of the Caddo combined with the lack of permanent structures, and the use of maize, suggests that St. Elmo phase people were mobile and maintained more direct contact with the Caddoan tribes than did the Round Prairie phase group. Although Caddoan people themselves may have visited the site on bison- hunting trips to Central Texas, such as occurred among the historic Caddo (Swanton 1946), it seems unlikely that they were responsible for the St. Elmo phase occupation. The Caddo were adapted to a pine forest environment which lacked Psoralea, so it is difficult to imagine Caddoan visitors adopting an economic strategy involving the use of these tubers. It is more logical to interpret the St. Elmo phase subsistence pattern as one in which mobile groups of hunters and gatherers utilized small quantities of maize, perhaps obtained from contact with the East Texas Caddo. In Chapter 18 of Volume II, the stress induced impetus for the change in subsistence strategy is related to climatic fluctuation. The results of paleoenvironmental studies based on pollen analysis of cores recovered from bogs outside the reservoir, pollen analysis of floodplain sediments within the reservoir, and geological work within the reservoir are presented in Chapter 5 of Volume I. These data suggest that the climate of the past two millenia has been slowly drying. About 2,000 years ago, rainfall was greater than that observed today and the floodplain of Richland Creek was rapidly alluviating. Sometime around A.D. 700 the annual precipitation level began dropping until around A.D. 1200, when a significant drought is proposed to have occurred and alluviation in the floodplain of Richland Creek ceased. This proposed climatic change parallels the shifts in subsistence strategy from a sedentary occupation based solely on wild foods to a more mobile occupation with an increased reliance on corn. This correlation of climatic change to cultural behavior is explored further in Chapter 18, Volume III. GROUP SIZE AND DURATION OF OCCUPATION It is difficult to make statements about St. Elmo phase group size or duration of occupation owing to the mixed nature of the data base. As mentioned previously, the available data indicate that the occupation was not sedentary. Only three burials were clearly associated with this component, which indicates that group size was small or that the site was infrequently visited during the 350 years of the St. Elmo phase. The duration of each visit to the site is also difficult to estimate, but probably varied according to the season of the year and the nature of the resources being exploited. These issues are considered in more detail in Part Two of Volume III where data from several sites in the reservoir are used to examine this phase. CONCLUSIONS The data base accumulated from Bird Point Island over the course of testing and four seasons of mitigation, as well as the numerous data collection and analytical methodologies used to assess the data, have allowed us to reach conclusions about four major periods of occupation ranging from approximately 170 B.C. to A.D. 1650. The spatial arrangement of features, particularly of post holes, permitted the identification of three structures dating to the A.D. 1000-1200 period. Analysis of post hole spacing and depth allowed us to reconstruct the architecture of these structures, and a spatial analysis of the artifacts using the SYMAP program allowed us to identify the locations of various domestic activites within the structures and also across the site in general. Artist's rendering of a St. Elmo phase occupation in the Midden and South areas. and gathering mode of existence was prevalent throughout all periods of occupation, with resources of the Post Oak Savannah and Bottomland Forest zones contributing significantly to the diet. During the final occupation, maize was introduced as a supplement both at Bird Point Island and at other sites within the Richland Creek area. It is suggested that the introduction of maize reflects a response to a deteriorating climatic regime culminating around A.D. 1200. The sequence of occupation may be summarized as follows. At some point between 170 B.C. to A.D. 130, Feature 1 was excavated by a Late Archaic hunting band. Roasting was conducted, as evidenced by the presence of fire cracked rock and food refuse, perhaps for ritual feasts related to seasonal macro- band aggregation (see Chapter 21). The feature also served as a cemetery into which males, females, infants, and dogs were interred. The mortuary function of this feature continued until the end of the A.D. 580-860 occupation. Artifacts from both of these periods are present outside of Feature 1, but no other features have been definitely dated to either period, so little is known about the nature of these groups. It is suggested that numerous short term seasonal occupations occurred during the Late Archaic and early portion of the Late Prehistoric periods. Then between A.D. 1000 and 1200, a sedentary hamlet consisting of three structures existed along the crest of the terrace. Numerous features, including roasting pits containing charred nut shell and Psoralea tubers, date to this period. In fact, most of the artifacts and features found in the North area are believed to date to this period. Although the presence of substantial structures and recovery of food species representing all seasons of the year demonstrate that the occupation was sedentary, no evidence of agriculture was found. Apparently, nuts, deer, and prairie turnips provided enough food to maintain a settled existence. Finally, between A.D. 1300 and 1650, a shift in settlement and subsistence occurred. No evidence of substantial structures was found which suggests that temporary shelters were used, probably by mobile bands of hunters and gatherers. Small quantities of maize were introduced into the diet, either as a result of increased trade with agricultural Caddoan groups or experimentation with plant husbandry by local groups.

## Page 219

THE ADAMS RANCH SITE by William A. Martin with a contribution by Edward F. Janak, Jr. The Adams Ranch site (41NV177) is a multicomponent site with a large depression that was discovered by avocational archaeologist, Mr. Bill Young. Young noticed the depression along the southern slope of the terrace when the site was cleared of vegetation in 1970 and suggested that it might be a Wylie focus pit. He also made surface collections:that contained both Archaic and Late Prehistoric period artifacts; however, he did not find a large midden deposit like the one present at Bird Point Island. Therefore, he suggested that this site was occupied less intensively than was Bird Point Island.- The pit at Adams Ranch yielded the chronological data used to formulate the two hypotheses about Wylie focus pit utilization generated in 1982. These hypotheses stated that (1) the Wylie focus pit developed from a local Archaic stage cultural base, and (2) the nature of pit utilization changed through time (Raab and Moir 1982:203). Intensive excavations at Bird Point Island during Seasons II and III supported these hypotheses, demonstrating an Archaic period of-origin for initial pit excavation and use. Both economic and mortuary uses were observed in the original fill from this period, followed by increased usage of the depression for roasting and trash disposal during the Late Prehistoric period. The mitigation research at Adams Ranch addressed these hypotheses, but also examined questions related to similarities and differences between the pits at both sites. For instance, were both pits first used as cemeteries as well as for economic activities such as roasting? Were these pits used concurrently or sequentially? The data recovery program at Adams Ranch was designed to provide a better understanding of the function and chronology of these large pit features. The report on the Adams Ranch site, Chapters 15-20, follows the format used.to ‘report the Bird Point Island data. However, because far less data were recovered from Adams Ranch than from Bird Point Island, Part II is much shorter than Part I. Classes of data that were complex enough to warrant treatment in separate chapters in Part I are treated as subsections of Chapters 15-20 in Part IT. In addition, much: of the information about soils and the 199 various methodologies discussed for Bird Point Island also applies to Adams Ranch, so the pertinent discussions in Part I are referenced in Part II to avoid redundancy. As a result, theoretical discussions already presented in Part I are kept to a minimum in this portion of the report. PEDOLOGICAL BACKGROUND (by Edward F. Janak, Jr.) LANDFORM DESCRIPTION The Adams Ranch site is located approximately 1 km north of Richland Creek and about 2 km northwest of Bird Point Island. The site is bounded by a farm road on the north and a slough on the south, Studies conducted by David Pheasant, geomorphologist for the Richland Creek Archaeological Project, and Edward F, Janak, Jr., area soil scientist for the USDA Soil Conservation Service, demonstrate that both sites are situated on Pleistocene terrace sediments which overlie the Wilcox formation of the Tertiary system. During Season I, Pheasant ran chemical and particle size analyses on soil samples recovered from backhoe trench Units 51 and 53 to assess geological discontinuities. He recognized both recent alluvial soils and Pleistocene terrace sediments within these trenches, and described the landform as part of the T-1 eroded terrace system. During Season IV, Janak examined the soils across the entire terrace to provide a soils map with information pertinent to the selection of excavation methodologies. He noted that the type and extent of soil development provide additional support for the designation of the site as an eroded T-1 terrace as defined by Pheasant (1982: 217-228). The geological atlas shows the site to lie on the Wilcox formation (University of Texas, Bureau of Economic Geology 1970), Presumably, Wilcox sediments are present at some depth, but they were not encountered within 2 m of the surface at any of the observation points used for soil mapping.

SOIL DESCRIPTION Backhoe trenches and archaeological excavation units were examined to supplement information obtained from auger-hole observations along north-south and east-west transects. These data were used to construct a soils map of Adams Ranch (Figure 15-1) as well as a cross section of the landform (Figure 15-2). The soils recognized at the subgroup level are the same as some of the soils recognized at Bird Point Island. Chapter 2 presents detailed descriptions of the composition and properties of these soils. Soils from three classifications at the subgroup level were recognized at the site, but only two of these are present in mappable amounts. Udic Haplustalfs are on the highest, best drained portion of the site, and Typic Haplustalfs occupy the intermediate elevations. All of these soils are characterized by sandy loam A horizons 20-30 cm thick which overlie sandy clay loam B horizons. A calcic horizon, which includes visible carbonate nodules, is present in the lower portion of the B horizon and within the C horizon of some pedons. The absence of visible carbonates at Bird Point Island was due to the dominance of highly leached Ultic Haplustalfs, which contain carbonates at depths far greater than those penetrated by the excavation units. At Adams Ranch, the less freely drained lower footslope position of the site resulted in the accumulation of carbonates much closer to the surface. As groundwater moved downslope along the terrace/Wilcox contact, the increased moisture content at the lower elevations restricted leaching and contributed to the accumulation of the carbonates observed in the lower B and C horizons today.

The profile of backhoe trench Unit 500 revealed a layer of black clay of alluvial origin immediately above the Typic Haplustalf profile. This same flood deposit also occurred within the profile of Feature 1 at a depth of 60-75 cm below surface, dating to between A.D, 800 and A.D. 1000 (see Chapter 17). On top of this layer, a dark loam of colluvial origin was present in both profiles, and the uppermost layer was black clay loam alluvium confined to the plow zone. As shown in Figure 15-2, these overlying sediments thin out with increasing elevation. At the lowest elevations they lose their integrity to the recent floodplain alluvium. The post-A.D, 800 time frame for the deposition of the alluvium and colluvium seems accurate from the perspective of soil development. For example, the expression of horizonation is the same for both the Typic Haplustalfs exposed on the surface at the middle elevations, and those further downslope which are buried by the Holocene sediments. This parallel development of the soil profile strongly suggests that all Typic Haplustalfs were subjected to the same soil forming processes until a relatively recent period on the geological time scale. Therefore, these alluvial and colluvial sediments must represent relatively recent deposits. The Holocene sediments appear to represent an alluvial- colluvial-alluvial series, judging from the low elevation of the site, and the textural variability of the three layers. The original flood layer is of a textural and mineralogical content that precludes any source other than alluvium from Richland Creek. The physical properties of these sediments correlate well with sediments deposited on nearby natural levees and point bars at corresponding elevations. In addition, these sediments are much too clayey to be colluvial in origin, considering the sandy nature of the soils upslope. The layer overlying the alluvium is distinctly coarser and appears to represent colluvium. Although a high energy flood deposit could result in the accumulation of similar coarser- textured material, the fact that artifact content was relatively high throughout this layer suggests that it formed gradually, rather than as a single event. Cultural material density generally drops within a flood deposit because normal activities are interrupted by the flood. On the other hand, this density decreases only slightly in a colluvial deposit where normal activities are continuously conducted throughout an extended period of gradual colluvial deposition. The top layer, confined to the plow zone, is comprised of clayey sediments similar to those described for the initial flood layer. This deposit appears to represent alluvium which was subsequently mixed with the underlying colluvial layer by cultivation. ARCHAEOLOGICAL IMPLICATIONS The properties of the A and B horizons have a pronounced effect on the selection of an appropriate excavation methodology because they have very different potentials for the preservation of cultural features, perishable remains, and interpretable cultural stratigraphy. The detailed discussion of the archaeological implications of soils presented in Chapter 2 also applies to the soils at Adams Ranch, so the major points are merely summarized here. Briefly, the sandy loam A horizon is the organically enriched zone characterized by dark chromas that is subjected to maximum disturbance from biological and mechanical agents, The high degree of disturbance obscures the boundaries of cultural features and creates a vertically mixed stratigraphy, removing artifacts from their original point of deposition. The B horizon has a high clay content which resists bioturbation and impedes the vertical movement of artifacts. In addition, the chroma associated with the B horizon is lighter than the dark chromas of the A horizon. Asa result, cultural features which are difficult to detect within the A

Because shovel tests failed to produce many artifacts or any signs of midden accumulation outside of the pit, Feature 1 was recommended as the primary focus of excavation. In the summer of 1982, Season I data recovery began with a magnetic survey of 1100 m2 over and around the Feature 1 depression. Prior to the initiation of field work, the southwest quarter of Feature 1 had been targeted for investigation. However, this plan was modified to include excavation outside of Feature 1 when the results of the magnetic survey revealed the presence of anomalies of possible cultural origin north of the depression. Units 34-40 were 40 x 40 cm units dug at 1 m intervals in the vicinity of the anomaly to search for cultural features. Unit 41 wasa 1 x 1m unit dug near the center of the anomaly, and Unit 43 was an additional shovel test dug to examine the source of the anomaly. Since no evidence of cultural features was observed in these units, mechanical stripping of a 2.5 x 6 m area over the anomaly was conducted to expose a broader area. This scraped area, labeled Unit 50 (Figure 15-4), was found to contain a small oval pit near the center of the anomaly (Feature 5). Most Season I investigation was conducted within Feature 1. The backhoe trenches were reopened and the trench walls were shored for the safety of the crew prior to the excavation of seven contiguous 2 x 2 m units (Units 42 and 44-49). SPATIAL DIVISIONS OF THE SITE Unlike the spatial divisions defined for Bird Point Island, which in many cases represented chronologically distinct areas of occupation with minimal overlap of occupations, those recognized Volume HU, Part Two at Adams Ranch cannot be separated temporally. Four subdivisions (Areas A-D) were selected on the basis of overlapping high density SYMAP clusters (Figure 15-6). These represent discrete areas of intensive activity aside from the activity confined to Feature 1, which is treated as a separate area of the site for the purposes of analysis. The lithic, ceramic, floral, and faunal data were separated into these discrete areas for analysis in an effort to identify functionally distinct areas (activity areas), and temporally distinct areas. Unfortunately, it was not possible to delineate temporally distinct areas because of the substantial overlap of Archaic and Late Prehistoric artifacts. The four subdivisions of the site are separated by areas containing units which have been lumped together under a category called "Other" for the purposes of data presentation. Only those units within the high artifact density SYMAP clusters were included in Areas A-D, in order to maximize information pertinent to the activities conducted in those areas. Units falling outside of these clusters were omitted to minimize background noise that would tend to obscure the principal activities that were conducted in each area. It should be noted that 2 x 2 m Units 42, §9, and 60 adjacent to Feature 1 are included in the "Other" category which is otherwise comprised of 50 x 50 cm and 1 x 1m units. As a result, the assemblage listed under this category is dominated by artifacts from these 2 x 2 m units. Area A lies between 100-120 N, 80 E and 100-120 N, 104 E and encompasses the area over and around a large roasting pit (Feature 51). Area B is between 100-112 N, 104 E and 100-112 N, 128 E which overlaps the south end of Feature 1, and includes the area over two large pits adjacent to Feature 1 (Features 101 and 102). Area C lies between 116-128 N, 116 E and 116-128 N, 140 E and represents an activity area immediately east of Feature 1 that included some small pit features. Finally, Area D extends from . 132-200.N, 80 E to 132-200 N, 140 E and includes the entire north half of the site. This area was marked by a large lithic debris cluster which included overlapping clusters of bifaces and ceramics similar to the clusters found over the houses at Bird Point . Island. CULTURAL FEATURES AND HUMAN BURIALS by William A. Martin with a contribution by Gary Rutenberg All features and burials recorded at Adams Ranch, including those associated with Feature 1, are described in this chapter. However, Feature 1 is complex enough to warrant treatment in a separate chapter, so Chapter 17 discusses the features and burials found within it in greater detail. The purpose of this chapter is to describe the dimensions, color, texture and contents of all features and to classify the features into categories with chronological and functional meaning. In addition, the osteological analysis - conducted by Gary Rutenberg is presented. This chapter is divided into three sections, beginning with the descriptive data for cultural features identified at Adams Ranch and a discussion of the analytical methodology used to classify them. All cultural features mapped at Adams Ranch are shown in Figure 16-1, and those features that were excavated are illustrated in Figures 16-2 through 16-4. Brief discussions of each feature class are presented to summarize their principal attributes. Finally, the osteological analysis of Burials 1 through 7 is presented by Rutenberg. FEATURE DESCRIPTIONS Tables 16-1 through 16-3 follow formats similar to those used for the description of Bird Point Island features (Tables 4-1 through 4-5). Gaps between the feature numbers listed in these tables are the result of the reclassification of some features as post holes or burials according to the numbering system described in Chapter 4. In some cases, natural disturbances were mistakenly assigned feature numbers and were later eliminated from the list. Table 16-1 lists metric attributes of features, as well as the color and texture of the feature fill. These categories are fairly straightforward and are discussed further in Chapter 4. The categories listed in Table 16-2 are identical to those listed in Table 4-2, See Chapter 4 for a discussion of each category contained in these tables. Volume-corrected densities are listed as counts per 100 1 or weight in grams per 100 1, as indicated by the notations in Table 16-3; actual frequencies for each data class are listed in Appendix H. DATA COMPARABILITY The data collected during Season I at Adams Ranch is very comparable to that collected during Season IV, except for the omission of fire cracked rock from the Season I data base. The difference in the rate of recovery and artifact breakage noted between dry screening and water screening at Bird Point Island was not a problem at Adams Ranch because water screening systems were used during both Season I and Season IV. The type of flotation recovery device used during each season was different. During Season I a froth flotation device was used (Appendix E) whereas during Season IV a simpler direct flotation process was employed (Appendix F). The principal difference between the two devices lies in the relative proportion of seeds recovered in the heavy and light fractions. Since both fractions were saved, sorted, and added together for presentation, the data from both seasons are directly comparable. MISSING DATA Some categories in Tables 16-1 and 16-2 have missing data. In Table 16-1, incomplete metric data were available for Burials 1 and 3 from the testing phase and for Burials 4 and 5 from Season I because they were disturbed by a backhoe. Burials 7 and 8 were represented by single elements that were not in primary context, so no measurements could be taken. Several features inside Feature 1 extended beyond the limits of the excavation units, so they were only partially excavated, and complete dimensions could not be obtained. The incomplete dimensions are designated by the symbol meaning greater than, indicating that the feature extends beyond the listed measurement by an undetermined amount. In Table 16-2, it was impossible to estimate the percentage excavated for those features that extended beyond the limits of excavation units. These are designated by question marks in the percent excavated column. In some instances, features were excavated, but the samples were not processed due to time constraints. These features are marked by an X in the processing column of Table 16-2 and are omitted entirely from Table 16-3. 207

ANALYSIS OF FEATURES | The analysis of Adams Ranch features was adapted from the Bird Point Island feature analysis, drawing upon the lessons learned from experiments designed to determine feature function. Characteristics of size, shape, artifact content, and magnetic response were examined in light of relationships observed between these variables and feature function at Bird Point Island. For example, at Bird Point Island roasting pits were consistently large, usually asymmetrical, and contained high densities of fire cracked rock which produced intense magnetic anomalies. At Adamis Ranch, pits which shared these characteristics were also classified as roasting pits. At Bird Point Island, principal components analysis of feature content isolated roasting pits as a single factor, but grouped features with different functions together into other factors. This analysis provided useful information about the relationship of feature content to feature function, demonstrating that feature content alone cannot be used to identify feature function in most cases. Therefore, this kind of analysis of feature content was avoided for the classification.of feature function at Adams Ranch. ; FEATURE CLASSIFICATION Several features could not be assigned to specific functional classes and are listed as unknowns with respect to function in Table 16-4, Feature function cannot always be ascertained on the basis of content alone because secondary deposition of artifacts inside the feature fill can create a false impression of feature use.-Unless a pit contains a very high proportion of a few specific artifact classes, it 209 is often impossible to determine its original function. For example, a small circular pit with high charcoal, baked clay, and fire cracked rock densities can be classified as a hearth, whereas the same pit without significant artifact increases cannot be classified with any degree of certainty. The effects of secondary deposition are especially prevalent for features within Feature 1. Features dug into the various zones of Feature 1 contained artifacts originally deposited in the zones as well as the artifacts associated with feature use. The contents of feature fill and the fill of the surrounding matrix were often so thoroughly mixed that they were indistinguishable. This fact is illustrated in Table 17-6 where macrobotanical remains floated from the fill of Zone 2d are nearly identical to those within features found in Zone 2d (see Chapter 17). As a result, these features are designated with an "f" in Table 16-4 to indicate that their classification represents a best estimate of function rather than a positive identification. Feature size and shape were important criteria for classifying features as roasting pits (large, asymmetrical pits) and post holes (small, symmetrical pits with tapering profiles). However, the results of a Chi-square analysis for size and shape at Bird Point Island (see Chapter 4) indicated that several features, such as hearths and storage pits, ranged in size from small to medium and could be either symmetrical or asymmetrical in shape. Therefore, size and shape alone could not be used as criteria for the classification of many features, just as feature content alone could not be used. This lack of criteria capable of providing positive identification of feature function is responsible for the large number of features assigned to the unknown category or _ designated by an "f in the other categories of Table 16-4. At Bird Point Island, features were assigned temporal designations on the basis of their vertical location within Feature 1 or their horizontal location with respect to dated features or structures such as House 1. At Adams Ranch, however, the only radiocarbon dates obtained came from Feature 1, so only those features inside Feature 1 can be confidently placed in a chronological scheme. Those features located outside of Feature 1 are listed as unknowns with respect to temporal placement, but the abundance of features found in the pit that date between A.D. 800 and A.D. 1000 suggest that most of these features also date to that period. ROASTING PITS Fewer roasting pits were found at Adams Ranch than at Bird Point Island, but those that were found looked nearly identical to the Bird Point Island features in size, shape, and content. Two definite roasting pits, Feature 12 and Feature 51, were recorded along with possible roasting pit Feature 101. Feature 12 was encountered in Units 59 and 60 just north of Feature 1 (Figure 16- 5). It was only partially excavated because it extended beyond the limits of these excavation units, so its complete dimensions are unknown, It must be fairly large, since it measured 252 cm x 72 cm within these units, and the incline of the pit wall indicated that the deepest portion of the pit was west of Units 59 and 60. Its high fire cracked rock content and its irregular, undulating profile are characteristic of roasting pits identified at Bird Point Island. Feature 51 was completely exposed by mechanical scraping after it was observed in 1 x 1 m Units 1108 - 1115 and 1140 - 1144. Its large size (ca. 16m?) and asymmetrical plan view (Figure 16-4) are remarkably similar to Features 34 - 36 and Feature 38 at Bird Point Island. The assemblages of both Feature 38 and Feature 51 were dominated by fire cracked rock; comparing all artifact classes listed as counts, 90.6 % of the Feature 38 assemblage and 89.9% of the Feature 51 assemblage were comprised of fire cracked rock. Feature 51 also contained an abundance of dart points, cores, and scrapers like those associated with Bird Point Island roasting pits. The fire cracked rock content of Feature 101 was high, although not as high as that of Feature 51, and the bone and mussel

A HORIZON ROASTING AREAS The A Horizon roasting areas form a class of features unique to Adams Ranch. Only one such feature (Feature 104) was recorded, but fire cracked rock concentrations corresponding to magnetic anomalies elsewhere on the site suggest that other such features exist (see Chapter 19). These features are concentrations of fire cracked rock confined to the A horizon, with no pit extending into the B horizon. It is clear from magnetic data that the rock concentrations have been burned and do not represent storage areas like those observed outside the structures at Bird Point Island (see Chapter 19). Because of the difficulty involved in observing A Horizon pits, there is no means of determining whether these features represent shallow roasting pits or simply areas where rock was piled, burned on the surface, and later entered into the soil by trampling and bioturbation.

Examination of the artifact summary table (Appendix F) reveals that the frequencies for lithic debris and other artifacts are relatively low, whereas the fire cracked rock content is up to 15 times higher than the content of other 1 x 1 m units excavated at the site. HEARTHS The same criteria used to identify hearths at Bird Point Island were used to classify features as hearths at Adams Ranch. The presence of oxidized soil indicative of in situ burning and the presence of charcoal were the principal criteria. Some hearths contained fire cracked rock, but not all hearths did. Feature 25 was a definite hearth inside Feature 1 which contained lumps of oxidized clay and an ash lens (see Figure 17-7). Similarly, Feature 68 contained lumps of oxidized clay. Features 100 and 103 contained high charcoal and fire cracked rock frequencies. Other features listed as possible hearths contained significant quantities of baked clay, but many were found within Zone 2d of Feature 1, which also contained a high proportion of baked clay (see Chapter 17) throughout the fill. Consequently, it is impossible to determine whether their high baked clay content is the result of in situ burning or simply secondary deposition resulting from their location within the fill of Zone 2d. DOG BURIALS Only one dog burial, Feature 52, was observed at Adams Ranch. This skeleton consisted of long bone fragments. and a mandibular ramus found in Zone 2c of Feature 1 (see Chapter 17). Although only a single dog burial was recognized during the course of excavation, other dog bones were recovered from Feature 1 fill that may represent dog burials which were too poorly preserved to be recognized by the excavators. POST HOLES Size (0.01 - 0.15 m2) and shape (circular in plan view, straight to tapering in profile) were the principal criteria used to classify features as post holes. No structures were recognized by the spatial arrangement of post holes at Adams Ranch, but post holes were found at scattered locations across the site. Post holes were present east of Feature 1 (P8 - P10) and north of Feature 1 (P11 - P13). Two post holes, P8 and P10 extended down 60 cm or so below the top of the B horizon (Figure 16-6). This is deeper than the other post holes, which ranged from 10 - 26 cm deep. Several post holes were found within Feature 1 (P1.- P7) and probably represent posts that formed drying racks or some other utilitarian structures, No house patterns were observed at Adams Ranch. PALEOPATHOLOGY The general disease categories recognized among individuals at Adams Ranch include: (1) arthritis, generalized degenerative boney changes inclusive of articular surfaces and vertebral bodies; (2) periostitis, generalized boney changes of the endosteum, cortical bone, or combinations of the two; and (3) neoplasms, new growths of abnormal tissue (i.e., tumors), The distribution of these pathologies is summarized in Table 16-9. Obviously, the small sample size precludes the formulation of conclusions regarding changes in diet, nutrient deficiencies, or infectious disease patterns over time. Only the A.D. 200 - 700 period burials from the site were complete enough or old enough at death to exhibit pathological lesions. No evidence of trauma was observed among any of the skeletal remains, suggesting that warfare was not a common occurrence at Adams Ranch. ## Page 239

J } L Features and Burials contain roasting pits, hearths, post holes, human burials, and dog burials. Some important differences between the sites also exist. No post hole patterns indicative of substantial structures were found at Adams Ranch. However, the presence of features related to food preparation (i.e., hearths and roasting pits), as well as the refuse discarded from meals (i.e., bone, mussel shell, and charred plant remains in feature fill) demonstrate that substantial occupation ocurred at Adams Ranch. The structures that were used as shelter must have been less substantial than those constructed at Bird Point Island; supporting poles must have been anchored entirely within the A horizon, since no post hole patterns were observed in the B horizon. . Another difference between the sites is the presence of A horizon roasting areas at Adams Ranch, and the apparent lack of these features at Bird Point Island. Although there are no chronological indicators associated with an A horizon roasting area, it is possible that A horizon roasting occurred during occupations when the roasting pits were not in use. An alternative hypothesis is that A horizon roasting areas were used for processing different materials than the roasting pits, and that both were used synchronously. Since few artifacts, other than fire cracked rock, were recovered from these features, it is not possible to test these hypotheses with the current data base. 219 The presence of human burials at Adams Ranch is another indicator of prolonged use of the site. Most burials that can be assigned to dated contexts were recovered from Zone 3 of Feature 1 (A.D. 200 - 700). These are the only burials that exhibited pathological lesions, but no conclusions about the health status of the population over time can be made because later burials were too young to exhibit degenerative changes or too incomplete to provide pathological data. The burial distribution is similar to that at Bird Point Island in that most burials were found within Feature 1. Like Feature 1 at Bird Point Island, burials recovered in Feature 1 at Adams Ranch included males and females as well as children. However, one important difference is that no cremations were positively identified at Adams Ranch. Only three proveniences were listed by Rutenberg as possible cremations. Another difference is a lack of additional cemetery areas such. as the cluster of burials found between Houses 2 and 3 at Bird Point Island. The only burials found outside Feature 1 at Adams Ranch were in nearby Feature 102. Additional features are listed in Table 16-4 as possible cremations because of their similar appearance to positively identified cremations at Bird Point Island. Unfortunately, the smail sample size of the Adams Ranch burials does not allow rigorious testing of bioarchacological hypotheses.

INVESTIGATION OF FEATURE 1 by. William A. Martin Like Feature 1 at Bird Point Island, Feature 1 at Adams Ranch is the largest and most complex feature at the site, and contains the only cultural deposit with interpretable stratigraphy. The size and depth of both features are also remarkably similar, For example, the pit at Bird Point Island measures 17 x 13 m and is 2.2 m deep, while the pit at Adams Ranch measures 18 x 15 m and is also 2.2 m deep. Even though Unit 49 was dug to a depth of 2.6 m, the area excavated below 2.2 m proved to be a rodent den rather than a cultural feature. The similarities between both features suggest thay they had similar uses and that the hypotheses generated as a result of excavations at Bird Point Island can be addressed with Adams Ranch data. The goal of this chapter is to examine all sources of data recovered from Feature 1 at Adams Ranch in light of the hypotheses generated during testing (Raab and Moir 1982:203) and in relation to the findings in Feature 1 at Bird Point Island. Whenever important similarities or differences between these two features warrant discussion, comparisons are made. However, many comparisons are reserved for the discussion of the Wylie focus concept in Part III of this volume (see Chapter 21). An understanding of Feature 1 utilization requires an explicit discussion of sampling strategies and an assessment of all data classes observed within the feature. These data classes include soils, features, burials, artifacts, floral and faunal remains, and radiocarbon dates. Although most of these classes are reported for the site as a whole in other chapters of the report, an effort to avoid redundancy is made here by examining data from a different perspective. For example, in this chapter artifact densities are used to understand different utilization within different layers of pit fill, whereas a discussion of the artifact types associated with these zones is reserved for the discussion of chronology presented in Chapter 18. Due to the complex nature of Feature 1, an accurate picture of pit chronology and use cannot be drawn unless some of the conclusions presented in subsequent chapters are considered. These conclusions are alluded to at appropriate points in the discussion, but repetition is kept to a minimum. SAMPLING AND EXCAVATION STRATEGIES The pit at Adams Ranch was investigated by a series of increasingly focused data recovery strategies, beginning with the testing phase and continuing through two seasons of mitigation. The testing phase excavation strategy was designed to examine the depression rapidly by excavating two intersecting backhoe trenches through its center (Units 4 and 17) to determine if it was of cultural or natural origin (see Figure 15-3). The trench profiles revealed distinctive soil layers which contained varying quantities of artifacts, demonstrating that the depression was the result of cultural deposition within a large man-made pit. Intrusive pits were also visible in the profile, reflecting continued use of the feature over time. Unit 14, a 1 x 1 m unit, was dug north of the intersection of Units 4 and 17 to recover a controlled sample of artifacts. It provided 240 lithic artifacts, many of which were associated with bone and mussel shell near the bottom of the unit between 90 and 110 cm below surface (McGregor et al. 1982: 46). Fourteen soil zones were recognized in the trench profiles on the basis of differences in soil color, texture, relative frequencies of charcoal, bone, and shell, and the presence of carbonate nodules (Figure 17-1) (McGregor et al. 1982:45). However, not all of these zones of soil color and texture differences represented cultural strata resulting from successive layers of deposition. Instead, two zones (Strata 11 and 12) were part of the natural C horizon subsoil, one (Stratum 3) was actually the sandy clay B horizon, another (Stratum 1) denoted the plow zone, and one (Stratum 7) represented the fill of an intrusive pit visible in the east profile (see McGregor et al. 1982:47 for illustrations of Strata 4, 7, 8, and 9 which were only visible in the east profile). The remaining strata represented layers with varying degrees of cultural deposition and temporal separation. Stratum 2 was defined as a homogeneous layer of very dark gray sandy loam 221

West profile of backhoe trench Unit 4 excavated during the 1980-81 testing program (after McGregor et al. 1982:47). containing some charcoal flecks and a small quantity of bone and lithic debris that capped Strata 5, 6, and 10. Stratum 5 consisted of black clayey soil containing a concentration of animal bone and mussel shell. An intrusive burial pit containing Burial 2, and a charcoal sample dating to A.D. 910 + 210 were found in this layer. Stratum 10 was comprised of lighter colored brown and dark brown sandy loam with carbonate nodules present throughout the matrix (McGregor et al. 1982:45). Burial 1 was recovered from this layer near the bottom of the pit in Unit 17 (Figure 17-1). These strata identified during testing were simplified into 3 major zones on the basis of Season IV data analysis. During Season I excavations at the site, the southwest quarter of Feature 1 was the focus of excavation. Season I research goals were: (1) to excavate a portion of the feature all the way to the bottom so that the original excavation and fill sequence could be examined, (2) to obtain radiocarbon dates necessary to address hypotheses related to periods of pit utilization, and (3) to collect artifacts indicative of pit function. These research goals were designed to test the hypotheses posited by Raab and Moir (1982:204). These hypotheses stated that (1) the pit had an Archaic period origin with use continuing through the Late Prehistoric period, and (2) pit utilization changed over time. Seven contiguous 2 x 2 m units were opened up parallel to Unit . 4 south of its intersection with Unit 17. Unit 42 was situated completely outside of the pit, whereas Units 44-49 were located inside Feature 1 (see Figure 15-4). During the last part of Season I, the crew moved to Bird Point Island to assist with the excavation. As a result, the only levels completed during Season I were: levels 1-3 in Unit 42, levels 1-6 in Units 44, 45, and 47, levels 1-5 in Unit 46, and levels 1-9 in Units 44-49. None of the hypotheses could be addressed with the limited set of data obtained from Season I excavations, so further research was postponed until an adequate sample could be excavated during Season IV. By the time Season IV began, all work within Feature 1 at Bird Point Island had been completed and refined hypotheses had been formulated regarding the nature of pit utilization (see Chapter 6). During Season IV at Adams Ranch, work conducted within Feature 1 was designed to test the hypothesized function of these features based on the findings at Bird Point Island (i.e., that the pits originally served as Late Archaic cemeteries and roasting pits, followed by intensive Late Prehistoric economic use for both roasting and trash disposal). The excavation strategy changed from excavation of the southwest quarter of the pit to the excavation of a trench all the way across the feature, as had been done at Bird Point Island. Contiguous 2 x 2 m Units 56-60 were excavated adjacent to Units 44-49 to complete the trench through the center of Feature 1 (see Figure 15-5). More than 47 m3 were excavated within the confines of Feature 1, which is estimated to be about 22% of the entire feature. The profile of this excavation revealed the entire fill sequence inside the pit, while Units 59 and 60 provided a sample of artifacts from the area immediately outside of the pit for comparison with artifacts recovered from the fill of Feature 1. Figure 17-2 shows the location of 1 x 1 m and 2 x 2 m excavation units dug to investigate Feature 1, as well as the location of backhoe trench Units 4 and 17, All units were excavated in arbitrary 10 cm levels, keeping the strata recognized by McGregor et al. (1982) separate within each level to maintain maximum control of provenience. In fact, additional transitional strata (2/10, 5/6, and 6/10) were defined to accommodate soils that had characteristics of two or more of the strata defined in 1982. This fine level of separation permitted analysis both by level and by stratum to determine which of the strata had clear functional or chronological implications important for understanding the aboriginal uses of the pit. Under this system, a single level could have three or more bags of artifacts associated with it, one for each of the strata observed within the level. For example, in Unit 56, levels 9-13 contained Strata 6, 5/6, and 14; these were collected separately and coded separately so that they could be recovered from the computer printout by either stratum or level, depending on the the nature of the analysis desired. Screening procedures were identical during Seasons I and IV, ‘so both data sets are very comparable. Ten liters of soil were coliected from the northwest corner of each level and water screened through 1/16 inch (1.4 mm) mesh; the remaining soil was water screened through 1/4 inch (6 mm) mesh. The only discrepancy between the Season I and Season IV data sets occurs with respect to fire cracked rock. During Season I, the numerous fragments of Wilcox sandstone found all across the site were thought to be natural inclusions in the soil and were not collected. As a result, fire cracked rock frequencies for the upper portion of the pit are missing from Units 44-49 and can only be examined for Units 56-58 which were dug during Season IV. During Season I, the upper 10 cm of soil in some units was comprised entirely of overburden consisting of backdirt from backhoe trench Units 4 and 17. In these units, level 1 actually began 10 cm below the present ground surface after the overburden was removed. In units with insignificant amounts of overburden, level 1 began at the present ground surface. As a result, the depth of level 1 in the first group of units matches the depth for level 2 in the relatively undisturbed units. A line level attached to a vertical datum was used to guide excavation in Units 42 and 44-49, so all levels match up along the same horizontal plane. However, to make accurate comparisons among units, depths of levels should be compared rather than level numbers. Because Units 56-60 were situated on a slope, arbitrary levels were measured down from all four corners of each unit in increments of 10 cm (20 cm for plow zone level 1), rather than from the line level attached to the vertical datum. These units were dug parallel to the existing ground surface, so that all levels match up along the same inclined plane to avoid crosscutting the strata. Finally, in Unit 56, level 18 was accidentally dug as a 20 cm thick level. Since sterile C horizon soil was present in most of the unit at this depth, level 19 was removed by scraping the feature fill away from the subsoil until it lensed out 40 cm below level 18. The bottom 30 cm of Unit 57 represented Feature 54, which was excavated as a feature rather than as a series of 10 cm levels. For example, the outer pit dug into the south rim of Feature 1, and the flood layer marking an old surface are unique to Adams Ranch. CHRONOLOGY OF PIT UTILIZATION Only five radiocarbon dates were obtained at Adams Ranch, and all of these were recovered from features, burials, or general fill within Feature 1. Table 17-2 lists these five dates by zone, along with their maximum range; Figure 17-11 illustrates their approximate locations within the pit profile. Unfortunately, charcoal sufficient for a reliable radiocarbon date was not obtained from Zone 1. The charcoal sample from the highest point in the pit profile came from the interface of Zones 1 and 2d at a: depth of 100 - 110 cm below surface in Unit 49. This date (A.D. 960 + 80) could be associated with either the Zone 2 occupation or one of the earliest Zone 1 occupations. Temporal distinctions between Zones 2 and 3 are indicated by the remaining dates. The early date from Zone 3 (A.D. 200.+ 100) was obtained from wood charcoal scattered throughout levels 19 and 20 in Unit 49 near the bottom of the pit. Collagen from Burial 1 provided the later date of A.D. 640 + 70. Since bone collagen from Bird Point Island burials consistently dated later than charcoal found in the same ' proveniences, it is possible that the date obtained for Burial 1 may also be too recent. The earliest date from Zone 2 (A.D. 910 + 210) extends back only as far as A.D. 700, even when the broad standard deviation is included. Thus, a clear temporal separation is apparent between Zones 2 and 3. In addition to radiocarbon dates, other lines of evidence demonstrate temporal differences among zones, with the clearest distinctions observed between Zones 2 and 3. The vertical distribution of arrow points, which are clear markers of the Late Prehistoric period, shows a marked decline in arrow point frequency in Zone 3 (Figure 17-12). Including all fragments, the ratio of arrow points to dart points for Zone 1 is 38:14 or 2.7:1 which is very similar to the Zone 2 ratio of 35:16 or 2.2:1. In Zone 3, however, the ratio drops to 2:7 or .28:1. The ceramic data are even more striking. Zones 1 and 2 contained grit/grog/bone tempered wares, whereas Zone 3 contained only thin, shell tempered ware (Figure 17-13). Two shell tempered sherds were present in the lower portion of Zone 2, but were located in portions which are clearly intrusive into Zone 3; they were mixed into Zone 2 as a result of the intrusive digging. Although conventional chronologies place shell tempered ware after grit, grog, or bone tempered wares (cf., Suhm and Jelks 1962), shell tempered ceramics have been recovered in Late Archaic contexts at three other sites in the Richland Creek area (see Chapter 15, Volume III). Therefore, the ceramic distribution agrees well with the radiocarbon dates obtained from the pit. The chronology of utilization for Feature 1 can be defined on the basis of radiocarbon dates and the temporal information supplied by the distribution of artifacts. Since shell tempered ceramics were present in Zone 3 at Adams Ranch, but were absent from Zone 3 at Bird Point Island (ca. 170 B.C. - A.D. 130), it is clear that the introduction of shell tempered wares occurred after A.D. 130. Thus, the original excavation of Feature 1 at Adams Ranch probably occurred close to the A.D. 200 radiocarbon estimate, The final utilization of Zone 3 appears to be represented by Burial 1, extending the range as late as A.D. 700. The ceramics in Zone 2 are part of the ceramic tradition of East Texas which began around A.D. 800 (cf., Suhm and Jelks 1962). The maximum range of the radiocarbon dates places the upper limit of Zone 2 occupation at A.D. 1120. However, A.D. 1000 may be a more accurate estimate, since the ceramics deposited in Zone 1 are similar to those associated with the houses at Bird Point Island dating between A.D. 1000 and 1200. Zone 1 must be assigned to the post-A.D. 1000 period, but additional refinement is impossible because no radiocarbon dates are available for this layer.
