## Page 251

Feature 1 The final chronological estimates for the three zones within Feature 1 (and hence, for the major periods of site occupation) are summarized as follows. Zone 1 dates from A.D. 200 - 700 and falls within the Late Archaic period. Zone 2 dates from A.D. 800 - 1000 and represents an early Round Prairie phase occupation. Finally, Zone 1 dates after A.D. 1000 and represents a mixture of Round Prairie and St. Elmo phase occupations. UTILIZATION OF FEATURE 1 In this section, artifact density, features, burials, and the floral and faunal remains associated with each zone in Feature 1 are examined to address the hypotheses related to feature function. Specifically, the results of Bird Point Island excavations led to the hypothesis that these features were originally intended for limited economic use as well as for mortuary purposes. Later, economic uses such as roasting and trash disposal took precedent and the mortuary role diminished during the later occupations. Evidence for both mortuary and economic uses of the pit is examined in the following sections. MORTUARY AND CEREMONIAL USE The presence of human burials within Zones 2 and 3 of Feature 1 clearly demonstrates that the pit served a mortuary function. However, unlike Feature 1 at Bird Point Island, the mortuary role at Adams Ranch was very limited. Only six burials were recovered in Feature 1 at Adams Ranch as opposed to 13 burials at Bird Point Island. At both sites, the burials were confined to the trench of contiguous 2 x 2 m units and backhoe trenches which bisected the feature. Since, this represents a comparable area in both features, the greater number of burials at Bird Point Island cannot be attributed to the excavation of a larger area at that site. The relatively low density of burials in Zone 3 at Adams Ranch suggests that the mortuary function was secondary, and that the pit was originaly excavated for some other purpose. The majority of burials (67%) was found within Zone 3 between 125 and 240 cm below surface, whereas only two burials (33%) were present in Zone 2, Zone 1 was devoid of human remains, which indicates that Feature 1 ceased to be used as a cemetery during the later periods of site occupation. Unlike Bird Point Island, no definite human cremations were identified at Adams Ranch. However, some burned bone fragments were classified as possible human bone (see Chapter 16) and features with very high burned bone densities similar to the cremations at Bird Point Island were present in Zone 2a. Therefore, it is possible that cremations occurred at the site even though no definite conclusions may be drawn. Ceremonial interment of dogs occurred in the lower zones at both sites. Three dog burials were recognized in Feature 1! at Bird Point Island, but only one was recognized at Adams Ranch (Feature 52 in Zone 2c). However, other dog bones were found at various levels within the lower zones of both pits. The poor state of preservation of these remains makes it difficult to determine whether they were ceremonial interments or simply refuse from meals. Even if these dogs were eaten and their bones were discarded in the pit, ceremonial behavior is still indicated. Ethnohistoric accounts across the North American continent repeatedly note that dogs were eaten ordinarily on ceremonial occasions as part of ritual feasts (cf., Quimby 1962; Tooker 1965). Therefore, the presence of dog bones reflects either intentional interment or evidence of ritual feasting, both of which indicate that Feature 1 had a ceremonial function. The mortuary function of Feature 1 was greatest during the A.D. 800-1000 period. Although Zone 1 was devoid of human burials, Burial 2 in Zone 2d may have been intrusive from Zone 1, so limited use of the pit for burial purposes could have continued into the post-A.D. 1000 period before it ceased entirely during the final occupations of the site. 231 NONMORTUARY USES The extremely low density of human skeletal remains attests to the fact that Feature 1 was not intended to be used solely as a cemetery. To understand the primary function of this large pit the floral, faunal, and artifact contents of each zone must be scrutinized. In Table 17-3, artifact densities are presented by zone as artifacts per cubic meter. The assemblage composition of each zone is expressed as percentages in Table 17-4. The Zone 1 data presented in Table 17-4 include only Units 56-53 for which fire cracked rock data are available. Zone 1 contained relatively low densities of all artifact classes, except ceramics, which were the highest. The low density for most classes reflects both infrequent use of the depression after A.D. 1000, and increased colluvial deposition during this period. Colluvium gradually covered the artifacts, resulting in fewer artifacts per cubic meter of soil. After A.D. 1000, trash disposal may have been the primary function of the depression. Features 6 and 22 appear to represent discarded refuse. The high sherd frequencies were concentrated in the upper three levels of Zone 1, reflecting episodes of trash discard during the final occupations of the site, well after A.D. 1000, However, fire cracked rock and charcoal densities, as well as magnetic data (see Chapter 19), suggest that some degree of roasting also occurred. When the assemblage composition is compared, the Season IV data indicate that Zone 1 has proportions of baked clay, charcoal, and fire cracked rock similar to those associated with roasting pits at Bird Point Island (Table 17-4). This activity may have been confined to the north end of Feature 1, since other roasting pits are located just outside of Feature | to the north. Zone 2a had low artifact densities for most classes, but had the highest dart point and uniface densities. The significance of these two classes is difficult to assess, but the low density of fire cracked rocks and baked clay indicates that roasting was not the primary . function of the outer pit. Likewise, Zone 2b had high densities of arrow points and unifaces, but low densities of other classes. Therefore, its function also remains unclear on the basis of artifact density. On the other hand, Zones 2c and 2d contained high densities of fire cracked rock, baked clay, charcoal, bone, and shell. These items are characteristic of roasting and cooking activities. In addition, the presence of hearths further supports the idea that economic activities were concentrated in Zones 2c and 2d. Zone 2d had extremely high densities of bone and shell, the highest of any zone in Feature 1. At least three deer and 193 mussels were present in this layer (see Chapter 18). Since Zone 2d was an intrusive pit into Zone 2c, its contents probably represent a short term deposit, perhaps the refuse from a single season's occupation or even the remains of a large feast. The specific events are not discernible, but it is clear that the primary function of Zones 2c and 2d was cooking and/or roasting. Zone 3 contained the lowest densities for most artifact classes, . but had moderately high bone and shell densities. From the perspective of artifact density alone, this would suggest that refuse from cooking was discarded into the Zone 3 fill, and that other activities did not occur aside from interment. However, when the percentages in Table 17-4 are examined, the Zone 3 assemblage appears to be dominated by fire cracked rock, just as in Zone 2c. These zones also have similar proportions of baked clay, charcoal, bone, and shell. Therefore, roasting must have occurred in the pit during the original period of use in addition to ceremonial activities. The low density of fire cracked rock and other artifacts simply indicates that roasting was limited to a short duration, not that the activity did not take place. A more precise look at the vertical distribution of artifacts is provided by Table 17-5. This table presents artifact densities on a level by level basis for Units 45, 47, 49, and 57. Collectively, these units represent all of the zones observed in Feature 1. The most striking vertical changes in artifact densities occur within the levels comprised of the clay flood deposit and those levels immediately beneath this deposit. For example, in Unit 47, artifact density drops dramatically within the flood deposit (50 - 70 cm)

Units 45 and 57 do not exhibit evidence of occupation along this surface, Zone 2a in Unit 45, (the outer pit) was excavated sometime around A.D. 800 and the flood occurred shortly thereafter, sometime between A.D. 800 + 80 and A.D. 960 + 80. As a result, there was little opportunity for artifacts to accumulate along the surface. In Unit 57, Zone 2c contained several intrusive pits which disturbed any evidence of a surface. These pits also mixed Late Prehistoric period artifacts deeper into the pit fill. For example, arrow points in this unit are concentrated down to 160 cm, and are found as deep as 200 cm below surface. The same general trends discussed for each zone are also apparent on this level by level comparison. For instance, extremely high densities of bone, shell, baked clay, and fire cracked rock occur in levels associated with Zone 2d in Unit 49 (90- 140 cm). Beneath these levels, in Zone 3 (140 - 240 cm), densities of lithic debris, fire cracked rock, and baked clay decline, with a sharp drop below 190 cm. In these same levels, bone and shell densities remain high and actually increase in some levels, illustrating the major role of fauna in the Zone 3 assemblage. At Bird Point Island, the macrobotanical contents of features in each zone illustrated an increased economic utilization of Feature 1 over time. At Adams Ranch, the macrobotanical contents of features were also examined to assess the level of economic activity conducted in each zone. Table 17-6 lists the volume- corrected macrobotanical contents of the features by zone. In addition, a flotation sample of non-feature fill (FS 429) recovered from Zone 2d is included. Notice that this sample contained very high densities of plant remains, equal to or surpassing the contents of the features intrusive into Zone 2d. This situation demonstrates the fact that feature content is directly related to the contents of the fill in each zone of Feature 1. Thus, feature content is a relatively accurate representation of zone content. Conversely, this example demonstrates that feature function usually cannot be accurately determined on the basis of feature content alone. The distribution of macrobotanical remains indicates that most plant foods were processed in Feature 1 during the Zone 2 (A.D. 800 - 1000) occupation. Hickory, pecan, acorn, Psoralea, and seeds are weil represented in the Zone 2 floral assemblage, especially in Zones 2c and 2d. Although floral remains occur in Volume II, Part Two Zones 1 and 3, the primary food appears to have been hickory nuts. Very low densities of other plant foods are indicated for the majority of Zone 1 and 3 features, although Psoralea is present in two of the three Zone 3 features. On the basis of artifact, floral, and faunal densities, it is clear that some degree of economic activity was conducted within all zones of Feature 1. Whereas at Bird Point Island the greatest amount of economic activity occurred within Zone 1, at Adams Ranch, Zone 2 was the focus of economic activity. At both sites, Zone 3 was used for both mortuary and economic activity related to the processing of fauna and the preparation of plant foods. At Bird Point Island, burials and cremations were observed in the center of Feature 1, whereas features with economic functions concentrated near thé edge of the pit. This was not true of the distribution at Adams Ranch, where burials and features were evenly divided between the pit edge and the center (Table 17-7). No clear patterning is discernible with respect to this distribution of features. The horizontal distribution of artifacts is similarly inconclusive. Artifact densities increase immediately outside Feature 1 in Unit 59, similar to the pattern observed immediately outside the pit at Bird Point Island. This increased density is due in part to the fact that erosion has removed much of the A horizon sandy loam and deposited it downslope within the depression of the pit. However, increased activity around a roasting pit (Feature 12) immediately north of Feature 1 is probably responsible for most of the observed increase in artifact density. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS Feature 1 is a complex feature containing a variety of soils that have been grouped together into three major zones. Each zone yielded either radiocarbon dates or specific artifact types that permitted the site chronology to be reconstructed. On the basis of this information, three major periods of site occupation are proposed. First, the pit was originally dug and partially filled to create Zone 3 between A.D. 200 and 700. Finally, after A.D. 1000, the pit gradually filled with colluvium and alluvium. Although occupation continued during this period, the low artifact densities of Zone 1 indicate that it was less intensive than the previous occupation. Both ceremonial mortuary activity and economic activities were conducted within Feature 1. The sequence of Feature 1 utilization may be summarized as follows. The original Feature 1 excavation occurred sometime around A.D. 200 and encompassed the area from the center of Unit 46 on the south, northward to the present pit edge in Unit 58 (see Figure 17-3). Economic and mortuary uses of the pit appear to have occurred simultaneously. Burials 1 and 6 were definitely interred at this point in time, judging from their location in the bottom of the pit and the presence of only C horizon subsoil in the grave fill, Burials 3 and 7 may have been interred at this time, but their fragmentary nature precludes a final determination. The composition of the artifact assemblage is marked by a high proportion of fire cracked rock ‘ indicative of roasting. The high faunal and relatively low floral content of Zone 3 suggests that animal foods may have been processed to a greater extent than plant foods. Low densities of all classes suggest that economic activities were confined to a relatively short duration. Zone 3 appears to represent a rapid fill episode. The fill is a mixture of A, B, and C horizon soils characterized by a mixture of soil colors. The dominant chromas of Zone 3 are light chromas, indicating that there has been little accumulation of organic matter in the fill (Janak, personal communication 1985). If Feature 1 had been left open for an appreciable length of time, organic matter would have entered into the fill and created a darker soil layer

The inclusion of a whole deer antler in Feature 40 may represent ceremonial activity, but the principal focus of activity appears to have been related to cooking,” judging from the number of hearths found in the bottom of this it. P Roasting and cooking activities were conducted in all subdivisions of Zone 2, especially Zones 2c and 2d where densities of fire cracked rock, charcoal, baked clay, and flora and fauna were extremely high. Although Burials 2 and 8 were found in Zone 2d, the mortuary role of Feature 1 appears to have diminished by that point in time. After A.D. 1000, colluvial deposition continued as the sandy loam A horizon from upslope washed in to fill the depression even further, creating Zone 1. The low artifact density of Zone 1 indicates that site occupation was less intensive after A.D. 1000. The depression was used primarily for trash disposal, except at the extreme north end where cooking and roasting activities were concentrated, The final layer of sediment deposited within the Volume II, Part Two depression was a clayey flood deposit which was confined to the modern plow zone. The few post holes observed in Zone 2 are assumed to have originated in Zone 1 and are therefore associated with the post A.D. 1000 occupation. No coherent post hole patterns were observed that would suggest the construction of substantial architecture within the pit. The few post holes that were found probably represent arbor-like structures or drying racks used during one of the later occupations. In conclusion, results of the excavations inside Feature 1 at Adams Ranch show many similarities with trends observed in Feature 1 at Bird Point Island. For instance, Zone 3 at both sites dates from the Late Archaic period and contains human burials, low artifact densities, and moderately high faunal densities. Some differences are also apparent between the two sites. Zone 3 at Bird Point Island contained more burials.than found at Adams Ranch. It also lacked shell tempered pottery like that found at Adams Ranch, which suggests it was in use earlier than Feature 1 at Adams Ranch. However, the presence of fauna and fire cracked rock at both sites indicates that the pits were not designed solely for mortuary use. Apparently, economic activities such as cooking and roasting were conducted within Zone 3 at both sites. During later occupations, economic utilization continued while the mortuary role diminished. Other similar trends are apparent, but they are associated with different zones at each site. For instance, at Bird Point Island there are few artifacts and features clearly associated with the A.D. 580 - 860 occupation of Zone ,whereas Zone 1, dating from A.D. 1000 - 1650, contains greater densities of artifacts and features. At Adams Ranch, on the other hand, the highest artifact densities and greatest number of features are associated with the A.D. 800 - 1000 occupation responsible for the Zone 2 deposit, and artifact densities drop in the post-A.D. 1000 deposit of Zone 1. These data suggest that both pits were originally excavated and used during the Late Archaic period. Then, intensive occupation was concentrated at Adams Ranch until A.D. 1000. After A.D. 1000, intensive occupation shifted to Bird Point Island. Thus, the use of these features at both sites appears to have been sequential rather than concurrent.

CULTURAL MATERIALS AND SUBSISTENCE REMAINS by . William A. Martin with contributions by James E. Bruseth, Gayle J. Fritz, Phillip Murry, and Richard Fullington The lithic tools, ceramics, and floral and faunal remains recovered from all contexts at Adams Ranch are described in this chapter. The results of analysis are presented within a chronological framework to examine changes in projectile point and ceramic manufacture over time, as well as changes in the selection of plant and animal species exploited for food from one period to the next. All lithic tools are described in the first section, and their distributions are presented in the second section. The vertical distribution of projectile points within Feature 1 is used to develop a projectile point chronology for the site, and the horizontal distribution of all tool classes is examined to investigate activity areas, The ceramic sherds are described and analyzed by James E. Bruseth, who places them within the framework of the ceramic traditions recognized elsewhere within the Project area. Next, the floral species are described by Gayle Fritz, who compares the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch flora and discusses similarities and differences in the assemblages. The vertebrate faunal assemblage is described by Phillip Murry, and finally, the molluscan faunal assemblage is discussed by Richard Fullington. LITHIC ARTIFACTS LITHIC ARTIFACT DESCRIPTIONS In this section, the various classes of lithic artifacts identified at Adams Ranch are described and quantified. The definitions of each class are presented in Chapter 7, so they are omitted here. PROJECTILE POINTS Arrow Points Alba (22 specimens, Figure 18-1a). These specimens have rectangular stems with straight to slightly convex bases. They exhibit triangular blades with prominent right-angled shoulders. Large specimens with blades more than 3 cm in length are not uncommon in the Adams Ranch assemblage. Catahoula (1 specimen). This specimen has concave blade edges, full barbs with squared ends, and an expanding stem with convex base. Cliffton (7 specimens). All of these specimens exhibit broad triangular blades with very short contracting stems. All specimens were recovered from Feature 1 between 70 and 100 cm below surface. Cuney (2 specimens). Both specimens are characterized by short expanding stems with concave bases and triangular blades with barbed shoulders. Fresno (1 specimen; Figure 18-1b). This is a small triangular point without a stem. The base is straight to slightly concave. Friley-like (1 specimen). This specimen has an expanding stem and recurved barbs along with a serrated blade. Hayes (1 specimen). This specimen has a triangular blade with concave edges and a bulbous stem with a rounded base. Livermore-like (1 specimen). This specimen has a. long slender blade with prominent shoulders and an expanding stem. Perdiz (6 specimens; Figure 18-1c). These specimens exhibit triangular blades with pronounced shoulders and contracting stems. Blade edges are marked by fine serrations. Scallorn (11 specimens, Figure 18-1d). These specimens are corner notched, with triangular blades and expanding stems. They have prominent right-angled shoulders or downward pointing barbs and straight to concave bases. 237

240 Possible Projectile Point Medial Fragments (27 specimens) Fourteen of these specimens are dart size medial blade sections and thirteen are arrow point size. Possible Projectile Point Indeterminate Fragments (171 specimens). These are broken specimens showing bifacial retouch along one or more edges. UNIFACES Steeply Chipped Unifaces End Scraper (14 specimens). These are thick flakes exhibiting steep unifacial retouch along the distal or proximal end. Some specimens also exhibit retouch along their sides. Side Scraper (22 specimens; Figure 18-3d). These are thick flakes which have steep unifacial retouch along one or more edges. Scraper with Graver Spur (5 specimens). These are side scrapers which have one or more pointed tips along the steeply chipped edge. Seraper on Tabular Pieces of Silicified Wood (15 specimens; Figure 18-3e). These are thin slabs of silicified wood which have been steeply chipped to form a bit. Many specimens exhibit retouch along one end and also along one or more lateral edges. Marginally Modified Unifaces Graver (16 specimens). These are small thin flakes with one or more pointed tips resulting from retouch. Denticulate (12 specimens). These are flakes exhibiting retouch along one lateral edge such that three or more regularly spaced, pointed tips are present. Concave Working Edge or Notch (99 specimens). These specimens have been retouched such that one or more concave notches are present. Straight to Convex Working Edge (941 specimens). These specimens consist of flakes and broken flakes with minimal retouch flake scars along one edge. Regularly patterned flake scars are visible on some specimens, but the majority exhibit random flake scars. Flakes in the latter group look similar to flakes which have sustained edge damage as a result of post-depositional trampling (cf., Gifford-Gonzalez et al. 1985:815). MISCELLANEOUS ARTIFACTS Cores Split or Tested Nodule (30 specimens). These are cobbles with one or very few flakes removed. Freehand Percussion Core Bifacial Platform (7 specimens). Flakes were removed bifacially from the core, but with no attempt to thin the parent nodule. Cortex Platform Single Platform (1 specimen). This specimen has a single cortex platform at one end. Double Platform (3 specimens). These specimens have two cortex platforms located at opposite ends. Multifaceted Nodule (33 specimens). On these specimens flakes have been removed from a number of directions without consistent platform development. Volume II, Part Two Prepared Platform (3 specimens). The platforms were prepared by splitting the cobbles. The resulting flat surfaces were then used as platforms for the removal of flakes. Small Bidirectional Cores (1 specimen). This specimen is similar to a bipolar core formed using the hammer and anvil technique. Core Fragments (48 specimens). These are broken cores which are too fragmentary to allow further classification. Pecked, Ground, and Battered Stone Hammerstone (16 specimens). These specimens are cobbles which exhibit battering on one or more ends. Seven of the eight are quartzite cobbles and one is a chert cobble. Mano (2 specimens). These specimens are oval cobbles of quartzite with flattened smoothed surfaces on one side. Grinding Slab (3 specimens). These specimens are all slabs of limestone with smoothed surfaces forming shallow depressions. All of the specimens were recovered inside Feature 1. Pitted Stone (2 specimens). These are oval to rectangular blocks of sandstone which have one or more small depressions or “pits” pecked into their surfaces. These are sometimes called nutting stones or anvil stones. Grooved Abrader (2 specimens). These sandstone specimens vary in outline, but both have a smooth linear groove which was apparently used for grinding or abrading. Ground Stone Fragments (2 specimens). These specimens have a ground surface, but are too fragmentary to permit further classification. LITHIC ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS CHRONOLOGICAL PLACEMENT OF PROJECTILE POINT TYPES As stated in Chapter 17, Feature 1 contained the only well dated contexts in which projectile points were recovered. The projectile point types recognized within the various zones of Feature | are listed in Table 18-1 (dart points) and Table 18-2 (arrow points). The chronological estimates for each zone are used to estimate the periods of use for each type. The earliest occupation at Adams Ranch, ca. A. D. 200 - 700, was dominated by the use of dart points. Gary points and untyped, contracting stem points are associated with this time period. Although an arrow point fragment was recovered deep within Feature 1, it was probably removed from its original point of deposition higher up in the profile by the action of burrowing rodents. Certainly, more than a single arrow point fragment would have been found if the bow and arrow had been in use during the first period of Feature 1 utilization. During the A. D. 800 - 1000 period, Gary points and untyped contracting stem dart points continued to be used, but untyped, straight stem dart points also came into use. In addition to the Gary, regular variety, the Gary, serrated blade variety began to be used. This type is similar to the Neches River, oletha variety which is associated with the Middle Archaic period by Prewitt (1974b:67). However, it has been found in a post-A.D. 300 context at site 41FT193, and appears to be associated with Late Archaic through Round Prairie phase sites in the Richland Creek vicinity. Arrow points limited to the A.D. 800 - 1000 time frame (i.e., those found only in Zone 2) include Steiner, untyped, straight stem points, and untyped, bifurcated stem points. ASSEMBLAGES OF SITE SPATIAL DIVISIONS The stone tool assemblages found within the different spatial divisions of the site are examined here to assess functional variability. Specific tool classes (Table 18-3) were collapsed into generalized categories (Table 18-4) to obtain ceil frequencies large enough to permit Chi-square analysis. This analysis was conducted to identify statistically significant differences among the assemblages which might reflect different activities associated with each of the site areas. The results of this analysis are presented in Table 18-5 as a matrix of Chi-square values and associated probability values. The .05 level of significance was selected to test the hypothesis of assemblage homogeneity. The assemblage of Area A is significantly different from the assemblages of Areas C and D. Likewise, the Area B assemblage is significantly different from that of Area C. The source of these differences and their relationship to different activities can be observed by examining Table 18-4. This table reveals that Area A contains much higher proportions of projectile points, finished bifaces, and steeply chipped unifaces than do Areas C and D. A high incidence of these classes was observed for roasting pits at 241 Bird Point Island (see Chapter 7), and since Area A encompasses roasting pit Feature 51, the similarity to a roasting pit assemblage is not surprising. Activities directly related to the use of Feature 51 must have been concentrated around the edge of this feature, so any artifact classes present inside the feature would also have been discarded along its periphery. On the basis of lithic tools, Area A appears to have been the focus of roasting and food processing activities associated with Feature 51. Area B differs from Area C in that it has slightly higher proportions of all tool classes, except aborted bifaces and marginally modified unifaces. Only finished bifaces are found in Area B whereas twice as many aborted bifaces are found in Area C than finished bifaces. At Bird Point Island, a higher incidence of aborted bifaces was noted inside House 1, which appears to reflect stone tool manufacture that occurred inside the house (see Chapter 7). Although sampling error resulting from the small sample size of the Area C assemblage might be responsible for the observed pattern, the results indicate that Area C was a locus of stone tool manufacture. Activities involving the use of finished bifacial tools, such as butchering, occurred within Area B. However, when lithic debris concentrations are considered in addition to the tool classes described here, Area B also appears to have been a locus of lithic reduction (see Chapter 19). The assemblage of Area D does not fall into an easily recognizable pattern; this is probably due to the fact that the size of the area is large enough to encompass several smailer activity areas which were used for a variety of purposes. The activities conducted within Area D, as well as the other site areas, can be better understood when the spatial maps for all artifact classes are considered (see Chapter 19). Tables 18-3 and 18-4 also include the lithic tool assemblage recovered from each zone of Feature 1. However, all frequencies were too low to permit statistical analysis of assemblage homo- geneity, so only general observations are noted here. Zone 3 contains a higher proportion of steeply chipped unifaces than any other zone of Feature 1. The high proportion of steeply chipped unifaces, together with the high proportion of fire cracked rock is characteristic of roasting pit assemblages, and supports the idea that Zone 3 was used for roasting. However, the Zone 3 assemblage differs from a typical roasting pit assemblage in its extremely high proportion of marginally modified unifaces. This difference suggests that some other economic activity in addition to roasting was conducted in Zone 3. Interior and core colors tend to be darker (10YR3/1, 10YR3/2, and 10YR4/1). Sherd thicknesses range from 6 to 11 mm and average 8.3 mm. Only one rim sherd was large enough for a diameter measurement to be made; this measurement was 12.6 cm. Vessel shapes were difficult to discern from the small size of most sherds. However, those shapes that could be observed included carinated and simple bowls and straight and flaring rim jars. Lip forms were most often rounded with occasional flat and beveled varieties also occurring. The ceramics belonging to this tradition were decorated with a variety of techniques. Incision was the most common decorative technique, usually forming the design element configurations Crosshatched Incised Lines and Diagonal Incised Lines. Both of these configurations are similar to the ceramic type Canton Incised (Suhm and Jelks 1962). Punctations are next most common and are generally randomly placed. Brushed and slipped sherds were also recovered. The distribution of design element configurations across the site is shown in Table 18-7. Minimal interpretation can be made about the distributions since the sample of identifiable specimens is small. However, the configurations tend to indicate that occupation around Feature 1 occurred primarily during a single period of time approximately corresponding to the Round Prairie phase identified at Bird Point Island. The relatively distinctive element configuration, Fingernail Punctations Separated by Incised Lines (similar to types Weches Fingernail Impressed; Suhm and Jelks 1962), is also found at Bird Point Island. . In addition to the grog tempered sherds from the site, 10 shell tempered sherds were recovered. These sherds all possess a platey texture with shell tempered paste and belong to a shell tempered tradition seen at other sites within the Project area. Not all of the sherds of this group have shell visible in the paste, but those lacking shell show vesicules where this material has leached eut. Evidence for sherds once having had shell comes from other sherds which have both shell and vesicular (or leached) areas. The surfaces of the shell tempered sherds are eroded and pitted. Exterior colors are generally light (7.5YR6/4, 7.5YR7./4, and 10YR8/3) with interior and core colors darker (10YR3/1 and 10YR4/2). The thickness of the sherds is uniformly thin, ranging from 4 to 6 mm and averaging 4.9 mh. All of the sherds are undecorated body specimens. It is quite significant that the majority of these sherds occur within Zone 3 of Feature 1. The ceramic distributions from Feature 1, where radiocarbon dates allow good chronological control, indicate a temporal estimate for the shell tempered ware between A. D. 200 and A. D. 700. This Volume II, Part Two dating is consistent with the temporal occurrence of this ceramic tradition at other sites within the Project area. Finally, a single sandy paste sherd was recovered from Zone 1 of Feature 1. Elsewhere in the Project area, this type of ceramic has been associated with A. D. 700 to 900 dates and has been found in association with grog tempered sherds. The occurrence of this sherd in the upper layer of the large pit is confusing since a later temporal estimate has been assumed. The sherd may not be in primary context. The exterior color is a very dark brown (10YR3/1) and the interior and core colors are yellowish brown (10YR5/4). The sherd thickness is 7 mm. Briefly, the analysis supported the results of visual identification of certain temper types and demonstrated local manufacture of the ceramics from the site. MACROBOTANICAL REMAINS (by Gayle J. Fritz) Fifty-nine flotation samples from Adams Ranch were examined for macrobotanical remains using the methodology explicitly stated in Chapter 9, Table 18-8 lists the weights of macrobotanical remains recovered from these samples. Wood charcoal was present in 58 samples, with sorted particles greater than 2 mm weighing a total of 23.56 g. Hickory nutshell, in 54 features, weighed a total of 26.68 g. Pecan shell from 20 samples weighed 0.86 g and acorn shell from 15 samples weighed 0.14 g. Psoralea tuber fragments weighing 1.52 g were recognized in 23 samples, while charred rhizome segments were found in four samples with a total weight of 0.12 g. Fragments of unknown substances were present in 37 samples, weighing 1.79 g. A total of 202 seeds other than “unidentifiable” fragments was sorted from the Adams Ranch flotation samples. The seeds fall into only six categories (Table 18-9). The collection was clearly dominated by wild-sized sumpweed (Iva annua), which was present in 18 features, totaling 166 specimens. Complete achenes (fruits), pericarp fragments, and free kernels (true seeds) were all represented. The seed counts of individual samples adjust for duplication of specimens if kernels and pericarp fragments are both present; in other words, a sample with two loose kernels and half of a pericarp shell would be counted as two specimens rather than three. Other seeds at Adams Ranch are the vetch type (Vicia and/or Lathyrus) with 11 specimens from six samples, grape family (Vitaceae), with 13 specimens from 13 samples, spurge family (Euphorbiaceae), with two specimens from separate samples, maygrass (Phalaris caroliniana), with one specimen, and nine unidentified seeds. Twelve fragments from six samples are currently considered unidentifiable. The Vitaceae specimens are mostly present in fragments. They are believed to be a type of wild grape (Vitis), but other genera such as Ampelopsis and Parthenocissus can not be ruled out. Thirty-eight of the features from which flotation samples were processed could be assigned temporally. Of these, three features were assigned to the A. D. 200 - 700 time period, 27 features to the A. D. 800 - 1000 time period, and eight features to the post-A. D. 1000 time period. Table 18-10 presents percentages of plant food remains by weight for the three periods. The three A. D. 200 - 700 features combined yielded less than a gram of carbonized plant foods, consisting of an average of 83.7% hickory nutshell, 10.4% tuber, and 5.9% seed (2 Vitaceae and 2 unidentified). The 27 features assigned to A. D. 800 - 1000 accounted for 18.65 g plant food remains, or 78% of plant food weight from the site as a whole. Hickory nutshell contributed 85.1%, followed by 4.9% pecan shell, 3.1% Psoralea tuber, 1.3% acorn, and 0.1% rhizome. Seeds were present in 21 features of this period, with a total of 191 seeds. FAUNAL REMAINS In the following sections, the vertebrate faunal assemblage from the entire site is discussed by Phillip Murry and a sample of the molluscan faunal assemblage is presented by Richard Fullington. The methodology used at Bird Point Island was also used to identify species at Adams Ranch. Detailed discussion of the methodology and of the habitat requirements for each species identified is presented in Chapter 9. Faunal data from Adams Ranch are presented in tabular form paralleling the format used to report Bird Point Island faunal data. The results of the analysis are summarized to address changes in faunal exploitation over time, indicators of seasonality of site occupation, and indicators of climatic change over time. VERTEBRATE FAUNAL ASSEMBLAGE (by Phillip R. Murry) The Adams Ranch faunal assemblage is dominated by whitetail deer (Odocoileus virginianus) and testudinid turtles, just like the faunal assemblages at most of the sites in the Richland Creek drainage. All of the mammalian species described in Chapter 9 were also identified in the Adams Ranch assemblage except the white-footed mouse (Peromyscus sp.). In addition to these species, squirrel (Sciurus sp.), wood rat (Neotoma floridiana), skunk (Mephitis mephitis), coyote (Canis latrans), and armadillo (Dasyphus sp.) were recovered at Adams Ranch. Gar (Lepisosteus sp.) and catfish (/ctaluras sp.) were the only species of fish that could be clearly identified, although other fish bones were noted. The reptilian species include all those identified at Bird Point Island except softshell turtle (Trionyx sp.), pine snake (Pituophis melenoleucus), and com snake (Elaphe sp.). Avian species identified include the wild turkey (Meleagris gallopavo) and the cardinal (Richmondena cardinalis); however, most bird bones recovered at Adams Ranch could not be identified to genus or species. The distribution of identifiable faunal remains within the zones defined for Feature 1 is presented in Table 18-11. Fauna identified from cultural features is presented in Table 18-12, with features 247 arranged by time period. The faunal content of the features mirrors the contents of the zones within Feature 1 in which they are located. For example, Zones 2d and 3 contained the greatest numbers of identifiable elements found within Feature 1 and the features present within these zones also contained a great number of identifiable elements. As a result, Tables 18-11 and 18-12 offer similar information that must be viewed together to understand changes in faunal utilization over time. The earliest occupation at Adams Ranch, A. D. 200 - 700, is denoted by Zone 3. Like the Late Archaic faunal assemblage at Bird Point Island, this assemblage also contains the greatest number of identifiable elements and the greatest faunal diversity associated with any occupation at Adams Ranch. The highest frequencies of reptilian and avian elements are associated with this period, and high frequencies of deer, cottontail rabbit and rodents are also present. Whitetail deer, testudinid turtle, and cottontail rabbit appear to have formed the principal sources of protein in the diet during the Late Archaic period. Prairie species are poorly represented during the Late Archaic period; no jackrabbit bones were identified and only two bison bones were found. This lack of prairie species during the Late Archaic period is identical to the pattern observed at Bird Point Island. The heavy utilization of cottontail rabbit suggests that rabbits were a common food source, but the lack of jackrabbit elements indicates that the Tall Grass Prairie was not within easily exploitable range of the site. The climate must have been moister during the Late Archaic period, promoting the growth of Bottomland Forest while keeping the prairie further to the west. The few bison bones probably represent occasional hunting trips out onto the prairie specifically to acquire large game. Seasonal bison exploitation has been observed among the Caddo Indians during the historic period (Swanton 1942) and was probably a common subsistance practice throughout much of prehistory. The density of features and artifacts within Feature 1 suggests that Late Archaic occupation was limited, and that the most intensive occupation occurred during the A. D. 800 - 1000 early Round Prairie occupation. However, the faunal assemblage is greatest for the Late Archaic occupation. This apparent discrepancy is probably due to the greater potential for bone preservation in the carbonate enriched soil of Zone 3. The carbonates create a neutral to slightly basic pH which promotes bone preservation. In addition, some rodent and reptilian remains may represent natural inclusions of burrowing animals subsequent to the filling of Zone 2. The early Round Prairie phase occupation, A. D. 800 - 1000, is represented by Zone 2. The faunal assemblage contains reptilian, rodent, and avian species, but is dominated by whitetail deer and testudinid turtle. Significantly, jackrabbit elements occur during this period while fewer cottontail rabbit elements are found. This suggests that a shift to a drier climate occurred which reduced the area encompassed by forest and moved the Tall Grass Prairie to within an exploitable range of the site. There is little evidence to draw on from the post-A.D. 1000 faunal assemblage with respect to the principal food species exploited or climatic changes that may have occurred. The refuse in Feature 6 is the primary source of identifiable faunal remains from this late period of occupation. The concentration is dominated by whitetail deer, but some turtle and bison bone is also present. Thus, Bottomland Forest, Post Oak Savannah, and Tall Grass Prairie species were all utilized after A.D. 1000, but the small sample size prevents a determination of the relative importance of each biotic zone from being made. It is assumed that deer and turtle continued to form the principal sources of protein. Faunal indicators of seasonality of occupation are limited to the post-A.D. 1000 period. Deer mandibles were recovered from Feature 6 and general Zone 1 fill which indicated an age at death of approximately 1 year 6 months. This age places the season of exploitation in the late fall or early winter, since deer give birth between May and June in this part of Texas (Schmidly 1983:296). One other indicator of fall exploitation of deer is a large antler attached to a frontal bone. Since deer shed their antlers between December and mid-February, the deer must have been taken prior

MOLLUSCAN ASSEMBLAGE (by Richard Fullington) Seven mussel species and four species of gastropods were identified at Adams Ranch. A sample was selected from the large molluscan assemblage which would encompass all of the occupation periods represented at the site. Units 48 and 49 in the center of the Feature 1 block excavation were selected for the purposes of this analysis, encompassing Zones 1, 2c, 2d, and 3. The results of this analysis are represented in Table 18-4. Like the vertebrate faunal assembage, the highest molluscan frequencies were observed in Zone 3, representing the A.D. 200 - 700 period. However, when volume is taken into account, a greater density of mussels and gastropods is associated with the A.D. 800 - 1000 occupation of Zone 2d which has a much smaller volume than Zone 3. Finally, frequencies for all species decreased dramaticaly during the post-A.D. 1000 period. The species composition remained unchanged over time and is identical to the bivalve fauna found in Richland Creek today. No conclusions may be formulated regarding environmental change because the mussel species are poor indicators of change and the gastropod sample is too small to be of use. Amblema plicata is a species which prefers pooled areas, whereas the other mussel species occupy riffle zones. Apparently, the aboriginal population exploited the shallow water species to a much greater extent than the deep water species. Martin The goal of intrasite spatial analysis is to understand the different kinds of activities that occurred in different parts of the site. Systematically collected data from the magnetic survey and from the excavation of 50 x 50 cm units were used to create computer generated maps of magnetic anomalies and artifact concentrations. These maps were compared with each other and with similar maps from Bird Point Island, where habitation and work areas were clearly identified, in an effort to interpret the spatial patterns observed. These maps were also compared with the map of cultural features recorded after mechanical stripping of the A horizon to assess the relationships among magnetic anomalies, artifact clusters, and cultural features. Activity Areas A through D were defined on the basis of overlapping high density SYMAP clusters for various artifact classes. The patterns used to divide the site into these areas are discussed, the composition of each area is described, and conclusions concerning the activities conducted within each area are made. The area outside of Areas A through D, particularly the area over Feature 1, is also examined. Although three periods of occupation are defined for Adams Ranch, the majority of activity took place between A. D. 800 and 1000. There is undoubtedly some mixture of the three components in Areas A through D, but the distribution of ceramics and arrow points (see Chapter 18) suggest that most activity across the site occurred during the A. D, 800 - 1000 period. The discussion in this chapter is not presented by time period because this distinction is not possible outside of Feature 1. It is assumed that most of the activities indicated by the presence of artifact concentrations and features were conducted during the early Round Prairie phase occupation. Maps of artifacts recovered from the systematically excavated units were examined to identify patterns indicative of specialized activity areas, such as habitation, roasting, stone tool manufacture, etc. The SYMAP patterns used to divide the site into Areas A - D are discussed, and the composition of each area is described. 253 MAGNETIC DATA The magnetic survey procedures used at Bird Point Island were also used at Adams Ranch (see Chapter 10). During Season I, 1000 m2 were examined over and around Feature 1. Most magnetic anomalies were diffuse, suggesting the presence of a widespread activity area over Feature 1 rather than discrete features, However, a large symmetrical anomaly that appeared to represent a discrete feature (Anomaly 1) was identified just south of the 140 N 120 E stake. Excavation in this area uncovered an oval pit (Feature 5) near the center of the anomaly. The initial success of the magnetometer prompted additional magnetic survey prior to Season IV excavation. An additional 2400 m2 were surveyed adjacent to the Season I survey area, forming a total survey area of 3500 m2. Using the criteria discussed in Chapter 10, the remote sensing consultant designated 35 magnetic anomalies as possible cultural features (Figure 19-1). Most magnetic anomalies fall within the range of 50 - 75 gammias, but a few (Anomalies 13, 21, 22, 23, 24, 31, and 34) exhibit intense highs of more than 75 gammas. The largest and most intense anomaly covers nearly 100 m2 and is characterized by N-S polarization with a high greater than 75 gammas to the south and a low of 5 - 10 gammas to the north. This anomaly is caused by recent iron trash accumulation which, unfortunately, obscures any readings resulting from cultural features that may have been located in this area. Most anomalies greater than 75 gammas were located in Area D on the north half of the site. Trenches of contiguous 1x 1m units were excavated across the centers of these anomalies with the expectation that roasting pits similar to those found at Bird Point Island would be found. However, none of these anomalies were caused by features which penetrated the B horizon. This pattern was puzzling because it was quite the opposite of the pattern observed at Bird Point Island. ARTIFACTS FROM SYSTEMATIC EXCAVATIONS SYMAP DESCRIPTIONS Analysis of the Bird Point Island data indicated that the spatial patterns which were identified using 1.67 m spacing between 50 x 50 cm units could also be recognized using larger intervals. At Adams Ranch, units were excavated at 4 m intervals which provided enough information to recognize important artifact patterning at a greatly reduced cost in time and labor. Systematic units were excavated in a single level down to the interface of the A and B horizons (20 - 30 cm), except along the southern edge of the site where the B horizon was buried by alluvium and colluvium. Units in this area were excavated to a depth of 30 cm. The artifact data were transferred to the mainframe computer at SMU and were processed with the SYMAP program to provide maps of the spatial distributions of lithic debris, bifaces, unifaces, projectile points, ceramics, fire cracked rock, baked clay, bone, shell, and charcoal. Although ail of these maps were carefully examined, only those most important for identifying activity areas are illustrated here. At Bird Point Island, the lithic debris SYMAP generated during Season II from units spaced at 5 m intervals exhibited large clusters which covered Houses 1 - 3 and the roasting pits located near those structures. The lithic debris SYMAP from Adams Ranch was examined for similar clusters, but only one cluster of the correct dimensions was observed. This cluster was observed in the northwest portion of the excavation area (Figure 19-3). The lithic debris map was dominated by a large cluster which was concentrated along the northern, eastern, and southern edges of Feature 1 nearly encircling the depression. The densest clusters of lithic debris indicate that stone tool manufacturing occurred in the northwest cluster and around Feature 1, especially within the high density cluster immediately adjacent to the pit on the southwest. The SYMAP of fire cracked rock (Figure 19-4) shows a large moderate to high density cluster surrounding Feature 1 and occurring partially within the feature. Fire cracked rock appears to be absent inside the depression. However, from the , magnetometer data, it is clear that the absence of fire cracked rock 255 in the center of Feature 1 is due to sampling error. The portion of Feature 1 which had been removed during Season | ecavations (Units 44-49) was recorded as a block of missing data during the Season IV systematic excavations. The missing data caused the SYMAP program to produce a map showing the central portion of Feature 1 as an area with a low density of fire cracked rock. The distribution of fire cracked rock within 50 x 50 cm units in the remainder of the depression demonstrates that cooking and roasting activities were concentrated around and within Feature 1. Since the 50 x 50 cm units only encompassed the upper 30 cm of Feature I, roasting activity must have been conducted in the pit during the post-A. D. 1000 period. This fact was not discernible from excavation through the center of Feature 1 because Season I fire cracked rock data were missing. Although the fire cracked rock outside Feature 1 could have been deposited during any of the occupations at Adams Ranch, the high density of fire cracked rock observed in Zones 2b and 2c (see Chapter 17) suggest that much of it was deposited between A. D. 800 and 1000. The SYMAP for charcoal is of little value for interpreting prehistoric activities at Adams Ranch because it shows one large cluster within a recent tree-burn area, but little else. Baked clay is also high in the area, but small clusters on the other parts of the site coincide with fire cracked rock, suggesting that hearths were located in those areas. Although the bone and mussel shell data are not influenced by recent cultural activity, their distributions were not very informative because each map had only a few small clusters. These clusters encompassed only one or two units each, reflecting the virtual absence of bone and shell in the A horizon due to the poor preservational qualtities of the acidic soil. Bifaces, unifaces, projectile points, and ceramics are low density artifact classes, so the SYMAPs obtained for these classes lack the large scale clusters observed for high frequency classes such as lithic debris and fire cracked rock. Maps of low density artifact classes have a patchy quality characterized by small clusters scattered across the site. The only way to understand activity patterning for these classes is to plot the clusters from each SYMAP onto overlays and examine their co-occurrence. Areas A through D were defined using this technique. AREAS A THROUGH D The moderate to high density clusters observed on all SYMAPs were plotted onto overlays so that co-associations could be examined and compared with patterns observed over the houses and roasting pits at Bird Point Island (Figure 19-5). At Bird Point Island, Houses | - 3 were marked by large clusters of lithic debris which encompassed small clusters of ceramics, projectile points, bifaces, and fire cracked rock. The variety of artifacts found together in these areas reflects the broad variety of activities associated with household maintenance (i.e., cooking, tool manufacture, storage, etc.). The areas over Bird Point Island roasting pits were visible as large high density clusters of fire cracked rock which encompassed smaller clusters of baked clay, projectile points, and bifaces. At Adams Ranch, three discrete areas of overlapping artifact concentrations were observed within the south half of the site near Feature 1. These areas were labeled A, B, and C and were intensively investigated to search for possible roasting and habitation areas (Figure 19-5). Area D on the north half of the site was characterized by the co-ocurrence of small clusters of fire cracked rock, baked clay, and ceramics indicative of numerous hearths and A horizon roasting areas. Area D also contained a large lithic debris cluster similar to clusters observed over structures at Bird Point Island. Other artifact classes were also concentrated within this cluster. It was carefully investigated for signs of a structure, but no post hole pattern was observed in the B horizon once the A horizon had been scraped away. Spatial data from SYMAPs, in conjunction with the spatial distribution of features, can be used to understand the activities conducted in Areas A through D. The relationship between magnetic enhancement of site areas and the site's distribution of fire cracked rock is virtually one to one for sites in the Richland Creek drainage. Maps of magnetic anomalies and fire cracked rock distributions at Adams Ranch do not appear to correlate on a one to one level, but this is because of differences in sampling strategies. Since the magnetic data were collected at 1 m intervals, as opposed to the 4 m intervals used to collect artifacts, the magnetometer recorded more hearths and roasting areas than did the SYMAPs plotted from systematic excavation data. Some features that could not be classified on the basis of content alone were classified as hearths because they exhibited magnetic anomalies with the same symmetry and polarity observed for hearths at Bird Point Island. Thus, the magnetometer provided insights into the function of features that otherwise would have remained uninterpretable if traditional approaches toward feature classification had been the only methods used. 259 Activity areas can be defined by examining the co-occurrence of artifact clusters generated by the SYMAP program, and comparing the assemblages from these clusters with those from proveniences where function has been determined. The dis- tribution of features of known function within an area of overlapping clusters can then be compared with the artifact data to formulate conclusions about the utilization of the area. Although it is rarely possible to identify all of the specific activities that occurred across a site, this method serves as a useful starting point for the investigation of community patterning. Using this approach, four subareas of the site were defined (Areas A-D). Area A appears to have been primarily a food roasting area, whereas Area B seems to have been a stone tool manufacturing area at one time, and a burial area at some other point in time. | Areas C and D contained a wide variety of tool clusters and features and probably represent areas where house structures and attendant domestic activities were concentrated.

## Page 283

PREHISTORIC SETTLEMENT AT ADAMS RANCH William A. Martin This chapter provides a synthesis of all the Adams Ranch data presented in earlier chapters. It is modeled after the discussion of the Bird Point Island occupational sequence. Five problem areas were addressed at Bird Point Island: (1) architectural features, (2) intrasite activities, (3) subsistence behavior, (4) group size, and (5) duration of occupation. Some of the problem areas addressed in the Bird Point Island discussion do not apply at Adams Ranch. For instance, even though post holes were found at Adams Ranch which are undoubtedly related to structures, these structures were not substantial and no house patterns were defined, As a result, assessments of architecture and estimates of group size cannot be made. On the other hand, sufficient data were recovered to address problem areas related to the study of intrasite functional variability, subsistence behavior, and duration of occupation. The first section is a brief summary of the chronological data (radiocarbon dates, projectile point types, and ceramic types) presented in detail in Chapters 17 and 18. First, the evidence for three major occupation periods is presented, then each of the problem areas outlined for Bird Point Island in Chapter 14 are addressed when applicable. The primary focus concerns the community patterning associated with the early Round Prairie phase occupation, since most of the data are related to this occupation. The spatial distribution of artifacts and features across the site is used to summarize the Round Prairie phase community. Finally, the subsistence strategies for each period are outlined and paleoenvironmental implications are discussed, CHRONOLOGY Three major periods of site occupation were identified on the basis of radiocarbon dates and the distribution of projectile point and ceramic types within Feature 1. The earliest occupation was a Late Archaic period occupation placed at A. D. 200 - 700 on the basis of two radiocarbon dates from the bottom layer (Zone 3) of Feature 1. This layer was nearly devoid of arrow points, which are by diagnostic artifacts of the Late Prehistoric period, further supporting for the Late Archaic placement for the origin of Feature 1. In addition, a distinctive shell tempered ceramic tradition was limited to this bottom layer and to pits intrusive from into this layer from the subsequent layer (Zone 2). This type of pottery has also been found in Late Archaic contexts at other sites along Richland Creek, and is characteristic of the Transitional/Late Archaic phase (see Chapter 15 Volume III). The next period of occupation, between A. D. 800 and A. D. 1000, represents the most intensive occupation of the site. This early Round Prairie phase occupation was responsible for the deposition of most of the artifacts and creation of most of the features found at Adams Ranch. The temporal frame for this occupation is provided by three radiocarbon dates from the middle layer of Feature 1 (Zone 2). One date is around A. D. 800, whereas two of these dates are close to A. D. 1000. The projectile point types and ceramic types associated with the middle layer of pit fill are identical to those associated with the Round Prairie phase occupation at Bird Point Island. Arrow points include Alba, Scaliorn, Steiner, and several untyped varieties. Gary, regular variety and Gary, serrated blade dart points are associated with this phase. The ceramic tradition is comprised of grog/grit/bone tempered utility wares; this tradition completely replaced the shell tempered tradition of the earlier period.. The final period of occupation began sometime after A. D. 1000 and persisted for an indeterminate length of time. No radiocarbon dates were obtained from the upper layer of Feature 1 (Zone 1). The post-A. D. 1000 estimate is based on the fact that the upper layer of the pit was deposited on top of the layer with terminal dates of A. D. 1000. The projectile points found in Zone 1 link the final period of occupation to the St. Elmo phase. Perdiz points, which are a late type, were found within Zone 1, but are absent from lower zones. Perdiz points were also found in Area D along with a Fresno point, another late type. The scarcity of late point types and ceramics related to the St. Elmo phase indicates that occupation was sporadic during this period, 261

262 OCCUPATION I: THE LATE ARCHAIC PERIOD (A.D. 200 TO 700) Few conclusions can be drawn for the Late Archaic group with respect to the five problem areas outlined in Chapter 14. No evidence of structures was found in association with the Late Archaic layer of Feature 1; all post holes found within this feature were associated with later occupations. Intrasite activities cannot be defined because few of the artifacts or features can be positively associated with the first occupants of the site. The scarcity of Late Archaic point types suggests that other Late Archaic artifacts were also scarce, judging from ratios of lithic debris to projectile points observed in the context of House 1 at Bird Point Island. Therefore, short term occupations probably occurred during the temporal span of A. D, 200 - 700. SUBSISTENCE The Late Archaic subsistence strategy is inferred from the plant and animal remains recovered from the bottom layer of Feature 1. A hunting/gathering subsistence strategy is indicated, with a heavy reliance on deer, turtle, birds, and cottontail rabbit as well as hickory nuts, Psoralea tubers, and seeds. The wide variety of fauna associated with the Late Archaic period is far greater than from subsequent periods. This is due in part to the better potential for bone preservation in Zone 3. However, the number of bird, cottontail rabbit, and snake elements are much higher in Zone 3 than in Zone 2, which contained a relatively well preserved assemblage, so a shift in the selection of animal species is suggested following the Late Archaic period. The Late Archaic population appears to have followed a diffuse economic strategy involving the selection of a broad variety of species (Cleland 1976). DURATION OF OCCUPATION It is impossible to provide estimates of group size for the Late Archaic population because of the low quantities of artifacts and features associated with this period. Obviously, considerable labor was expended to excavate Feature 1, so at some point a number of individuals occupied the site. However, the low incidence of artifacts and burials in the lower layer of Feature 1 indicates that such occupation was short term, perhaps representing the seasonal gathering of bands for ritual and mortuary purposes. The presence of charcoal dating from A. D. 200 + 100 and a burial dating from A. D. 640 + 70 indicates that short term Late Archaic occupations occurred over a long duration of time, approximately 500 years. OCCUPATION II: EARLY ROUND PRAIRIE PHASE (A.D. 800 TO 1000) The densest concentrations of artifacts and features within Feature 1 were found in Zone 2, the layer dating from A. D. 800 to A. D. 1000. Also, the distribution of arrow points and ceramics across the rest of the site suggests that the most intensive occupation occurred during this period. Therefore, the features observed outside of Feature 1 are assumed to be related to this period of occupation. Data from features and the spatial distribution of artifacts provide sufficient information to address several of the problem areas in detail. ARCHITECTURE Post holes were found within Zones 2a and 2d of Feature 1, but they appear to be intrusive from the post-A. D. 1000 occupation. Volume II, Part Two Very few post holes were observed outside of Feature 1 within the scraped areas. Those that were recorded were isolated posts, so no pattern indicative of structure shape or size was observed. These posts occur close to hearths and probably represent supports for less substantial structures than were present at Bird Point Island during the Round Prairie phase. However, no conclusions can be reached regarding the nature of these hypothesized structures due to the lack of visible remains. INTRASITE ACTIVITIES The distribution of features with known functions, the distribution of magnetic anomalies, and the co-associaton of artifact classes across the site permit the recognition of activity areas for the early Round Prairie phase. The evidence indicates that Area A, west of Feature 1, was used primarily for roasting and food processing activities. Area A encompasses roasting pit Feature 51 which contained high densities of fire cracked rock, baked clay, bifaces, steeply chipped unifaces, and dart points. The A horizon over and around this roasting pit also contained these items. The co-association of these artifact classes is characteristic of the roasting pit assemblages recorded at Bird Point Island. Fire cracked rock was observed on the surface of the B horizon throughout the eastern portion of Area A, which surrounded Feature 51 and the smaller hearths or roasting pits in close proximity to this feature. The assignment of Feature 51 to the early Round Prairie phase is supported by the presence of grog/grit/bone tempered ceramics in levels 1 - 6. A single shell tempered sherd was recovered from level 8, which indicates that initial use of the feature may have occurred during the Late Archaic period. However, the bulk of activity within the pit appears to have occurred between A. D. 800 and1000. Area B appears to have been used for several functions. It contained the largest, densest cluster of lithic debris found at the site (see Chapter 19). This indicates that it was a locus of lithic reduction, even though aborted bifaces are missing from the assemblage. The presence of ceramics and two large features (Feature 101 and Feature 102) containing fire cracked rock indicates that other activities related to roasting were also conducted in Area B. Finally, the presence of two human burials within Feature 102 (B4 and B5) demonstrates that mortuary activity also occurred in Area B. Area C is another multiple use area which may have been the location of a habitation, judging from the co-occurrence of artifacts and the presence of a hearth (Feature 72). Small clusters of lithic debris, projectile points, fire cracked rock, and mussel shell occur together in Area C, which suggests that stone tool manufacture, cooking, and other maintenence activities associated with habitation were conducted in this area. However, no post holes were observed, so no firm conclusions about the presence of a structure can be drawn. Area D contained a lithic debris cluster similar in size to clusters observed over Houses 1 - 3 at Bird Point Island. This cluster is situated on the highest, flattest portion of the site, which is an ideal topographic setting for a habitation. Clusters of bifaces, unifaces, and fire cracked rock occur within the lithic debris cluster which was also characteristic of the dwellings found at Bird Point Island. Hearths which were recorded as magnetic anomalies were found when the area was mechanically scraped, but no post holes were found in this vicinity, so the presence of a habitation cannot be demonstrated. It is clear from the number of features and the quantity of debris associated with the early Round Prairie phase that substantial long term occupation occurred. The lack of house patterns indicates that the structures used during this period were fess substantial than those used later on in the Round Prairie phase at Bird Point Island. Area D contained several A horizon roasting areas in addition to the possible habitation. These areas registered as magnetic highs and as high density fire cracked rock clusters on SYMAPs, but they had no manifestation in the B horizon. Although the projectile points and ceramics indicate substantial use of Area D during the early Round Prairie phase, the presence of Perdiz and Fresno points indicates that St. Elmo phase occupation was also concentrated in this area. No radiocarbon dates or clear artifact associations exist, but it is possible that the A horizon roasting areas are related to St. Elmo phase occupation. This idea is speculative, but it follows the pattern observed throughout the Project area that roasting pits get smaller through time. SUBSISTENCE The principal faunal species exploited during the early Round Prairie phase were whitetail deer and testudinid turtle. The major plant foods were hickory nuts, pecans, acorns, Psoralea tubers, and seeds. A diffuse hunting/gathering economy persisted, but the selection of species used to supplement the diet changed. Far fewer cottontail rabbit, bird, and snake elements were recovered from Zone 2 of Feature 1 than from the Late Archaic Zone 3. Instead, a higher density-of mussel and plant species, especially vetch and sumpweed seeds, was utilized. Also, prairie species such as jackrabbit, began to be exploited. Floral and faunal data suggest that the site was occupied during both the spring and the fall. The principal plant foods in the assemblage are complementary from the standpoint of harvesting; spring species, such as vetch and Psoralea sp., and fall species, like nuts and acoms, are present together in the assemblage. Turtle and mussel would have been exploited in the summer or fall, when the creeks were low. Deer could have been taken at any time during the year, since no clear indicators of seasonality were found; however, they were probably taken in the fall when deer congregate in areas with high mast yields. DURATION OF OCCUPATION The food species represented in the early Round Prairie phase assemblage could have supported a year round occupation, as they did at Bird Point Island. However, the lack of substantial structures at Adams Ranch suggests that shorter seasonal occupations occurred. Numerous separate occupations would have been required to result in the creation of so many features and the deposition of so many artifacts. At Bird Point Island, where even more debris was found, the Round Prairie phase occupation was estimated at 20 years. However, the hamlet at Bird Point Island was probably occupied on a year round basis, so its length of occupation is not directly comparable to the intermittent Round Prairie phase occupations at Adams Ranch. It seems likely that the deposit at Adams Ranch was formed over a greater length of time, with numerous short term occupations creating the observed deposit. The range of the radiocarbon dates from the lower to the upper portions of the Zone 2 deposit indicate that occupations occurred over a 200 year time span. OCCUPATION IN: ST. ELMO PHASE (POST-A.D. 1000) As with the Late Archaic occupation, very little can be stated about the nature of the St. Elmo phase occupation. The post holes observed in the outer pit (Zone 2a) of Feature 1 appear to have originated in the upper layer (Zone 1) which is attributed to this later occupation. However, no clear post hole pattern was observed that would indicate the dimensions of a structure, so little can be concluded about the nature of the architecture. These posts 263 probably represent drying racks or structures for other activities conducted within the pit, rather than the remains of dwellings. Presumably, some form of dwellings was used during the final occupation, but it must have been as insubstantial as those of previous occupations. SUBSISTENCE From the limited food remains clearly associated with the St. Elmo phase occupation, it is clear that whitetail deer was the most important source of protein, and that use of bison increased slightly. Hickory nuts, pecans, acorns, and Psoralea tubers continued to provide the bulk of the plant species in the diet, and the use of seeds declined. Unlike most other St. Elmo phase occupations in the Richland Creek area (Bird Point Island and the Little Cedar Creek site) which contained small quantities of maize, no evidence of maize horticulture was observed at Adams Ranch. This may indicate that Adams Ranch was occupied during the early St. Elmo phase, prior to the introduction of maize into the diet. DURATION OF OCCUPATION The low quantity of St. Elmo phase artifacts observed at the site suggests that occupation after A. D. 1000 was very limited and sporadic. There are no clear indicators of a terminal date for this occupation, since no radiocarbon dates and few distinctive projectile point or ceramic types were obtained. CONCLUSIONS The data recovered from Adams Ranch indicate that three major periods of occupation occurred at the site. These occupations fall within periods defined at Bird Point Island, but the two sites appear to have been used sequentially, rather than simultaneously. For instance, the lack of shell tempered ceramics coupled with the early radiocarbon dates for Zone 3 of Feature 1 at Bird Point Island indicate that it was in use sometime prior to the introduction of the shell tempered ceramics which were found in Zone 3 at Adams Ranch. Likewise, the Round Prairie phase occupation at Bird Point Island appears to have begun shortly after the major occupation at Adams Ranch ended. Finally, the greater quantity of St. Elmo phase artifacts and the discovery of maize at Bird Point Island indicate that a longer, more intensive St. Elmo phase occupation occurred there. Data from both sites indicate a shift in climate after A. D. 700, since prairie species such as jackrabbit are missing from Zone 3 and are found in Zone 2 at both sites. This indicates a drier period in which the Bottomland Forest receded and the Tall Grass Prairie advanced to within exploitable distance of Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch. The introduction of maize after A. D. 1300 at Bird Point Island and the Little Cedar Creek site suggests a response to a more dramatic shift in climate, but this was not observed at Adams Ranch. Apparently, occupation of the site was minimal during this late period. The sequence of occupation at Adams Ranch may be summarized as follows. At some point around A. D, 200, Feature 1 was excavated and used for economic and mortuary activities. Roasting and food preparation were conducted within the feature. Since the amount of labor required to excavate the feature would have required a large group of individuals, it is likely that several bands came together to excavate the pit and that ritual feasting ensued. This concept is discussed further in Part Three of this volume. Around A. D. 800, the outer pit (Zone 2a) was excavated, which enlarged the dimensions of Feature 1. Intensive short term occupations. occurred from spring to fall for the next 200 years, as
