## Page 289

THE WYLIE FOCUS: CULTURAL REALITY OR ARCHAEOLOGICAL MYTH? by James E. Bruseth and William A. Martin The Wylie focus of North Central Texas has been a problem- atical concept since its formulation in 1952. It was originally defined to describe a group of Late Prehistoric sites within the Tall Grass Prairie along the East Fork of the Trinity River near Dallas which contained large, man-made depressions (Figure 21-1), These enigmatic depressions lacked easily explainable contents and form. Despite excavations inside the pits at several sites, some of which were extensive (Stephenson 1952a; Lynott 1975), the function of these features has never been completely understood. Several pit functions were proposed, but these hypotheses needed to be tested (Lynott 1975). With the discovery of similar depressions at the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites along Richland Creek, expectations were raised. that the hypothesized uses could be tested and new insights into the function of these features would be provided. Chapters 6 and 17 provide detailed analyses of these pits and provide descriptive data pertaining to feature use. Chapter 21 provides an evaluative discussion of the Wylie focus as a culture- historical construct and examines the function of the large depressions at sites along Richland Creek and the East Fork of the Trinity River. Specifically the first section of the chapter provides a summary of the sites that comprise the Wylie focus along the East Fork. The Richland Creek work is summarized in the next section and is used as a comparative data base for comparison with the East Fork sites. The overall concept of the Wylie focus is evaluated in the next portion of the chapter, and the usefulness of the Wylie focus concept as a culture-historical construct is discussed. Since its original definition more than three decades ago, the term has gained increasing popularity and has become entrenched in the literature, despite valid criticism that it does not have distinctive cultural and temporal meaning (cf., Ross 1966:18; Sorrow 1966:61; Story 1965:253; Lorrain and Hoffrichter 1968:75-77). Consequently, this chapter is a forum for critical evaluation of the Wylie focus as a culture-historical concept. The final section of this chapter addresses the issue of function of the large depressions. Previous hypotheses are examined and a new hypothesis, based in part on the hypothesis advanced by Lynott (1977), is presented and discussed. WYLIE FOCUS: DEVELOPMENT OF THE CONCEPT Although the Wylie focus was defined as a constellation of traits, the single best identifying characteristic is the presence of large, man-made depressions measuring 16 m or more in diameter and between 2 m and 4 m in depth. These features were first identified at several sites along the East Fork by members of the Dallas Archeological Society, who noted that the pits were once substantially deeper and that recent plowing had caused soil to fill the depressions (Wilson 1946). During the 1930s and 1940s, members of the Dallas Archeological Society (DAS) worked on several other sites along the East Fork; many had large depressions, but others without depressions were otherwise similar to the pit sites (Housewright and Wilson 1942; Harris 1942; Hatzenbuehler 1942a; Harris and Hatzenbuehler 1948). Although the Wylie focus was not formally defined until the 1950s, this early work by the DAS was instrumental in providing the background for professional excavations that led to the definition of the focus. After survey of the proposed Lavon Reservoir (Stephenson 1949a), excavations were conducted at three sites: Hogge Bridge, Campbell Hole, and Branch. Only the Hogge Bridge site was ever reported in detail, and this site became the type locality for definition of the Wylie focus (Stephenson 1952b). Building upon the work of the DAS, Stephenson used the Midwestern Taxonomic System (McKern 1939) to propose the Wylie focus as a culture- historical construct incorporating sites situated along an 80 km stretch of the East Fork. Six characteristics were defined that, taken as a whole, distinguished the Wylie focus from other known foci: 267

(6) Artifacts of all types are consistently similar throughout all components, and are reasonably distinctive, in total assemblage, from those of other foci of nearby areas, through some individual types are similar to those found in known foci. (Stephenson 1952a:305). The large depression at the Hogge Bridge site was the target of Stephenson's field work, and after extensive excavations he found the pit to be ". . . 90 feet in diameter, circular in shape, with excavation spoil from the interior thrown up around the edges in a rim 8 to.10 feet high" (Stephenson 1952a:307). Although the function of the pit eluded Stephenson, several proposed uses were suggested, including water storage, defensive breastworks, dance arenas, gaming areas, and open-air council chambers. In the 1960s, combined professional and amateur investigations were conducted along a section of the East Fork that was scheduled to be inundated by Forney Reservoir (now Lake Ray Hubbard; Harris and Suhm 1963). The excavation phase of the field work concentrated on three Wylie focus sites: Glen Hill, Upper Rockwall, and Lower Rockwall. The work at these sites was important in establishing doubts about the validity of the Wylie focus as a culture-historical construct, since both Archaic and Late Prehistoric materials were found together (Ross 1966:18, 43; Lorrain and Hoffrichter 1968:75-77). These workers argued that the focus, as defined by Stephenson, spanned too much time, and moreover, there was no clear evidence that the Wylie focus people had even built the pits. At the Upper Rockwall and Lower Rockwall sites, work was also conducted inside the large depressions, but the function of these features was not determined. The most useful data were reported by Ross (1966), who excavated the pit at the Upper Rockwall site by stratigraphic layers and related artifact frequencies to each layer. This information showed that the lowest layer of the pit was largely devoid of artifacts and that the original use of the pit had failed to produce an appreciable accumulation of artifacts (Ross 1966:18). The next professional archaeological work along the East Fork occurred at Lake Lavon, where an enlargement of the existing reservoir was anticipated. Test excavations were conducted at several Archaic and Wylie focus sites including the McGuire and Dugger sites (Dawson and Sullivan 1973). The most notable work was conducted at the Sister Grove Creek site (Lynott 1975). Extensive excavations were undertaken inside a large depression as well as in midden deposits around this feature. This work _ represents one of the more in-depth investigations conducted at a Wylie focus site, and the results of the excavations determined directions for future work by developing new questions to be addressed (Lynott 1975:117). Specifically, the work in the large depression eliminated several of the hypothesized uses, and indicated that ritual feasting and human burial were the most likely uses of the pit (Lynott 1975:117). Lynott was able to obtain several radiocarbon dates from inside and around the pit which provided the first adequate chronology for the focus; the dates spanned the period from A. D. 950 to A. D. 1590, With the completion of the Lake Lavon enlargment, the remaining components of the Wylie focus known to contain large pits were inundated and lost to archaeological investigation. Reports of additional sites with large depressions exist (D. Granberry, personal communication 1982), but the existence of depressions at these sites has yet to be verified. It is possible, however, that other large pit sites exist along other parts of the East Fork or its tributaries. Certainly the occurrence of two such sites along Richland Creek supports this speculation and suggests Volume II, Part Three that other tributaries of the Trinity River, or the Trinity itself, should be closely examined. EAST FORK SITES It is difficult to determine the exact number of sites along the East Fork of the Trinity River that belong to the Wylie focus. Many of the sites found in the area were located by members of the DAS. Some sites have been reported in issues of the Society's journal, The Record; while others are recorded only by personal collections and are otherwise unstudied. Compounding this problem, the traits devised by Stephenson (1952a) to define the focus are indistinct enough to include virtually any Late Prehistoric site in North Texas. Aside from the presence of a large depression, which Stephenson (1952a:305) admits does not have to be present, few characteristics remain to distinguish a Wylie focus site from sites of other periods. Rather than attempting to inventory and describe all known Wylie focus sites in the upper Trinity River basin, the sites discussed in this chapter include only the East Fork sites which have published data from field excavations. This represents a sample of 11 sites (Figure 21-1), all of which are discussed in alphabetical order. The amount of published data varies considerably from site to site, ranging from the reporting of only a few features at some to complete monographs on others. This variability in reporting creates problems for comparison of the sites. For instance, the absence of an elevated rim around a large depression cannot be inferred simply because no mention of such a characteristic is made in a given report. The rim may have existed, but may not have been reported. Despite these problems, the East Fork sites provide a useful collective data base with which to examine the Wylie focus and to compare with the Richland Creek sites. The Branch site, located on a terrace of the East Fork, was excavated by Stephenson in 1951. Unfortunately, the results of this work have never been written up. In 1959, the DAS conducted test excavations at the site and subsequently published their results in The Record (Dallas Archeological Society 1965). Based on this information, the site can be described as small, occupying an area of slightly more than one ha in area. Wave action from Lake Lavon had caused considerable damage to the site at the time of investigation, and the remaining deposit consisted of a thin layer of black clay soil over a sterile clay subsoil. The remains of Stephenson's excavations were still visible and consisted of two long trenches, one through the large depression and another through nearby midden deposits. The DAS excavations were conducted outside of the large pit and recovered a wide variety of artifacts; these artifacts are listed in Table 21-1. Occupation during both the Archaic and Late Prehistoric time periods can be inferred. A few features were encountered, including a hearth and a small pit, but no evidence of structures was encountered. The Butler Hole site, located south of the Branch site along the East Fork, is an important Wylie focus component in that a house pattern was uncovered. This pattern was elliptical in shape and measured 3 x 4.1 m (Housewright et al. 1947:9). The "floor" of the house was observed 46 cm below the surface, and although not described as such, it may actually have been the contact with the underlying B horizon rather than a floor. Numerous pieces of burned, shell tempered daub were found over and around the structure, suggesting that the house had burned. Although some artifacts were recovered inside the house, many came from midden deposits around the house. Ceramics, stone and bone tools, and ground stone objects are reported from the site. No large depression was located. Limited testing was conducted by Stephenson (1949a) at the Campbell Hole site, located in the floodplain immediately adjacent to the present channel of the East Fork. The site covers less than one ha and has been covered by 30 cm of recent alluvium. It was discovered where the present river channel cut into the site,

The presence of both dart and arrow points suggests a multicomponent site. Although a depression was Volume II, Part Three observable on the surface of the site, this feature was not investigated to determine if it was a man-made pit. The Dugger site, one of the sites excavated prior to the Lake Lavon enlargement, is a controversial component of the Wylie focus largely because of the presence of a pithouse at the site (Dawson and Sullivan 1973:42). The pithouse is reported as semisubterranean and consisting of two compartments with a row of small, charred poles 2.5 to 4 cm in diameter along the southeastern wall. Unfortunately, inadequate reporting of this and other discoveries at the site precludes serious consideration of these features. Moreover, the vertisolic soils dominant at many East Fork sites are noted for extensive subsoil disturbances termed gilgai (Duffield 1970; Newman 1982:12-13). These disturbances form when A horizon soil is worked downward into the B horizon through soil cracks, creating basin-shaped depressions, filled with A horizon soils, which are as much as 2 m deep and 4 m in diameter. Until better documented data are produced on pithouses along the East Fork, these features from Lake Lavon should be treated skeptically and viewed as potential pilgai. The artifacts recovered from the site are summarized in Table 21-1 and characteristics on the large pit are provided in Table 21- 2. Overall, the Dugger site is most useful in demonstrating that a Wylie focus component is present along Pilot Grove Creek. A Wylie focus component was encountered at the Glen Hill site, located on a knoll in the floodplain of the East Fork (Ross 1966:19). The site covers an area of approximately one half ha. A series of backhoe trenches was excavated across the site in the hope of locating a large depression, but this effort failed. Artifacts recovered from the site are listed in Table 21-1 and include specimens indicating both Archaic and Late Prehistoric period occupations, although a case can be made for greater use of the site during the Archaic period based on the higher incidence of dart points relative to arrow points. Seven burials were located at the site during testing, all of which were flexed (Ross 1966:20-22). The Gilkey Hill site is located on a low rise in the floodplain of the East Fork and on a nearby upland area (Harris 1942). The site covers approximately 6 ha in total extent, with the portion on the floodplain rise consisting of a deep midden deposit. Several “cooking pits," measuring 1 to 2 m in diameter and 25 to 35 cm deep, are reported (Harris 1942: 48). However, the contents of the features suggest trash fill instead of artifacts associated with cooking. Overall, a wide variety of artifacts is reported, although counts are not provided and the site therefore has not been included in Table 21-1. Among the identified artifacts, there are expanding and contracting stem dart points, triangular, straight stem, and expanding stem arrow points, and several other lithic tool types such as drills, knives, and scrapers. In addition, ceramics are reported with most sherds containing shell temper (Harris 1942). Several flexed burials have also been recovered from the site, but no large depression is reported. The best known site along the East Fork is Hogge Bridge, initially excavated by members of the DAS and later by a field crew under the direction of Stephenson (1952a). The site, covering an area of 1.6 ha, is situated on a terrace projection extending into the floodplain of the East Fork. The excavations at this site consisted of hand dug trenches and block excavations in and around the large depression present on the site. Approximately 40% of the large pit was excavated, and this work was used to define the size and content of the feature (Table 21-2). The pit was described as circular with an elevated rim that at one time appeared to have encircled the entire pit. The feature measured 27 m in diameter and 3 m in depth (defined as below the normal ground surface). Within the feature, a cemetery consisting of 7 graves with 13 individual burials was located. Other features were encountered within the large depression, including two concentrations of burned limestone rocks and a cluster of snail shells. Unfortunately, the excavated artifacts were not quantified by level, so vertical comparisons cannot be made. However, Marmaduke (1975) examined the artifacts from the site and concluded that meaningful vertical differences do not occur in the

Extensive excavations were conducted at the Sister Grove Creek site by SMU during the summer of 1974 (Lynott 1975), The work was designed to determine the pit's function, to investigate midden deposits around the pit, and to evaluate the nature of occupation at the site. Concerning the latter goal, an historic Wichita settlement-subsistence model was formulated that proposed a semi-sedentary economic strategy involving agriculture, use of wild animal and plant foods during the spring through fall, and a diet of bison during the winter. According to this model, Sister Grove Creek would have been occupied only during the spring through fall. Investigations inside the large depression showed that it had been excavated into the underlying sterile yellow clay and subsequently filled with a dark brown clay (Lynott 1975 22). At the bottom of the pit, a 50 cm thick zone of transition was visible. The overall shape of the pit was oval, measuring 24 m by 14 m and 3.5 to 4 m deep. Since the majority of the pit was excavated with a backhoe, artifact frequencies by vertical levels are not available, | and thus, chronological differences in the fill sequence cannot be examined. Thirteen features, including burials (one human and one dog), hearths, and pits were found in the fill of the depression. In addition, numerous burned soil lenses were encountered, but were not systematically investigated (M. Lynott, personal communication, 1986). Radiocarbon dates from the pit range between A. D. 980 + 200 (TX2034) and A. D. 1590 + 70 (TX2033). The wide range in the dates argues for multiple fill episodes, although these apparently were not visually observable in the field. The floor of the pit was found to be very irregular (Figure 21-2), and Lynott (1975:25) suggested this to be the result of erosion along the wall of the feature. The presence of hearths inside the fill suggested that cooking, possibly associated with ritual feasting, had taken place in the pit. In addition, the occurrence of a single human burial in the pit indicated that a few high status individuals, perhaps females, were buried in the depression (Lynott 1975). Excavations in the midden outside of the pit were successful in obtaining a sample of artifacts related to habitation at the site. Several features, including hearths, pits, and post holes, were uncovered as well as several burials. Because com was not recovered, Lynott (1975:122) argued that agriculture was not practiced by the Wylie focus people. However, no flotation recovery was undertaken on feature fill, so this non-agricultural hypothesis may have been premature. Corn fragments have been found at other Wylie focus sites (Stephenson 1952a:305), and the difficulties of finding fragmented comm remains (cf., Bruseth and Pertulla 1981) suggests that careful searches for this food resource ‘are needed before proper assessment can be made. Radiocarbon dates from the midden deposits suggest that the site was occupied from A. D. 1000 to perhaps as late as A. D. 1600. Lynott (1977:236) argued that occupation during this time span belonged to the Wylie focus, with an early, non-ceramic dart point phase followed by a ceramic and arrow point phase. In 1965 major excavations were conducted at Upper Rockwall, a multicomponent site with a Wylie focus occupation and an associated large depression. The site covers approximately 5 ha along a projection of a terrace into the floodplain. Most work at the site was conducted in the large depression. This work determined that the pit was oval in shape and measured 27 m by 19 m, with the long axis oriented NW-SE. The depth of the pit was 4.2 m below the ground surface. The depression was found to have an uneven floor and to drop sharply towards center, where a secondary basin was identified (Figure 21-3). Five zones were identified in the fill of the pit (Ross 1966:5-6). The lowest zone was a grayish tan clay with caliche, shell, charcoal flecks, and faunal remains; few artifacts were found in this layer. Above this, a mass of snail shells was found in a darker tan-brown zone. The next layer consisted of numerous lenses of oxidized clay, many of which had stick impressions on one side. A radiocarbon date of A. Volume II, Part Three Figure 21-2. Cross section of the large depression excavated at the Sister Grove Creek site (after Lynott 1975). D. 1020 + 90 (TX-315) was obtained from this zone. Artifacts were more frequent in this and later levels. Overlying this zone, a layer of dark clay was observed which was similar to the floodplain soils surrounding the site. And finally, a layer of recent colluvium capped the pit fill, A metal fragment was recovered at the bottom of this zone which dated it to the historic time period. Two flexed burials were recovered inside the depression: One burial was associated with an engraved vessel and several conch shell beads, while the other burial only had conch shell beads included as grave goods. Both graves were presumed to have been excavated from the multi-colored zone, and a radiocarbon date of A. D. 1300 + 120 (TX-320) is reported for the burial associated with the vessel and beads. The artifacts recovered from work in this feature are listed in Table 21-1 and demonstrate occupation of the site by both Archaic and Late Prehistoric groups. The work inside this feature led Ross (1966:18) to conclude: Since as yet there has been no conclusive proof as to the chronological position of association of these depressions with Late’ Archaic or Neo-American materials, and since the definition of the Wylie focus rests largely on the presence of these large depressions, it may be that the Wylie focus is entirely a consiruct of the archaeologist, with no basis in reality. RICHLAND CREEK SITES Four sites from the Richland Creek drainage have been selected for discussion (Figure 21-1). Two of these, Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch, have been extensively described. in the earlier chapters of this volume. Both sites contain large pits with visible surface depressions. The other two sites are the Irvine and Strawn Creek sites which have smaller pits and are located further west along Richland Creek. The Irvine site, reported in Volume III, contains several smaller pits, all lacking visible surface manifestations. The Strawn Creek site is located in Navarro Mills Reservoir and was excavated in 1961 (Duffield 1963). A large pit lacking a visible surface depression was recorded as a midden deposit at this site. These four sites are used for comparison with the Wylie focus sites of the East Fork. The common characteristic shared by the Richland Creek sites is the presence of large pit features, although the size and shape of these features vary considerably. However, this variability in size and shape has useful explanatory potential for interpreting the function of the pits at all sites. In addition, many similarities exist between the pits from the Richland Creek sites and the features from the East Fork sites. And finally, the four Richland Creek sites provide a cross section of the archaeology along the entire drainage, forming a representative data base useful for evaluating whether or not the Wylie focus concept should also be applied to Richland Creek. A clarification in terminology needs to be made concerning the large pits present at sites along Richland Creek and the East Fork. It is useful for later discussions to distinguish those pit features with a surface manifestation from those without this characteristic.

ADAMS RANCH The Adams Ranch site is located along Richland Creek approximately 12 km from the confluence of Richland Creek and the Trinity River. The site is situated on a terrace projection into the floodplain of Richland Creek and covers an area of .7 ha. The most notable feature at the site is a large depression measuring 16 m X 18 m. This feature is oval in shape and oriented NE-SW along its longest dimension. The depth of the feature is 2.4 m, as measured from the normal ground surface above the center of the feature to the bottom of the feature. In cross section, the pit is basin-shaped with gently sloping walls and an irregular floor. Although the site has been occupied over a considerable period of time, primary periods of site use occurred during the Late Archaic and Round Prairie phases. During the Late Archaic period, the large depression (Feature 1) was excavated and partially filled. Four burials recovered from the fill of the feature are associated with this time period. Based on radiocarbon dates from the lower layer of the depression (Zone 3), a temporal span of A. D. 200 to 700 is estimated. Although some Late Archaic materials were recovered from around the large depression, the low quantity of material suggests limited use of the site during this period. , Zone 2 of the large depression, stratigraphically above Zone 3, has been dated to A. D. 800 - 1000. During this time, the pit was used both for trash deposition and food roasting. The deposits ’ around the large depression indicate that the site was intensively used, but the absence of permanent structures, as indicated by the lack of complete post hole patterns, suggests that occupation may have been seasonal rather than year-round. The final layer of the large depression (Zone 1) records a period of alluvial and colluvial filling with intermittent occupation by small groups belonging to the St. Elmo phase (post - A. D. 1200). Few St. Elmo phase artifacts were recovered from around the depression, which suggests that the site was minimally used by groups of this time. The few artifacts that occur within Zone 1 are probably related to activities which took place immediately around the feature and were washed inside the depression by erosion or tossed into the depression as loads of trash. Artifacts recovered from the site are listed in Table 21-3. An attempt has been made to maintain a classification similar to that used by Lynott (1975) for the East Fork sites to facilitate assemblage comparison, so not all recorded items are listed. In addition, several projectile point types have been added to provide more detailed chronological information. Other artifact classes are as comparable as possible, but some bias no doubt exists since the Richland Creek artifact tabulations have been severely condensed to provide comparable groupings. The reader is referred to the individual site descriptions in this volume and Volume III for more detailed artifact information. A final problem hindering comparison between the East Fork and the Richland Creek sites is the nature of the excavation techniques used. The materials from the East Fork sites have been collected by many different organizations and individuals over the past 40 years, and selective collecting has been a major factor in forming the present artifact sample. Nonetheless, the goal of describing and comparing the Richland Creek sites with the East Fork sites is to examine major similarities and differences between the assemblages that transcend these collection biases. Thus, a detailed type by type comparison is not needed for the present discussion. More detailed discussion of artifact type comparisons, not only with the East Fork sites but also with other surrounding sites in North Central Texas, can be found in Chapter 15 of Volume IIL. The range of artifact types from the Adams Ranch site indicates a general level of similarity with the East Fork sites. Arrow and dart points, bifaces, and retouched pieces are all dominant tool categories. Moreover, ceramics are present but in low frequency. Within the point types, Gary dart points are the most common. However, some differences also occur between these areas. For example, Steiner arrow points are common at Adams Ranch, but are absent from the East Fork sites. Conversely, Catahoula arrow points are common along the East Fork, but are rare at Adams

BIRD POINT ISLAND Bird Point Island is located 5 km from the confluence of Richland Creek and the Trinity River, and occupies a 4 ha knoll situated in the floodplain of Richland Creek. A significant feature at the site is a large depression measuring 13 m x 17 m with the axis oriented NE-SW. The depth of the feature as measured from the normal ground surface over the center of the pit to the bottom of the pit is 2.7 m. The floor of the pit was extremely irregular and difficult to. follow in the field. The overall form of the pit in cross section was basin-shaped with gently sloping walls. In plan view, the pit was roughly oval with an irregular outline. The site has been occupied over several millennia, with notable major episodes of occupation during the Late Archaic (170 B. C. - A. D. 130), Richland Creek phase (A. D. 580 - 860}, Round Prairie phase (A. D. 1000 - 1200), and the St. Elmo phase (A. D. 1300 - 1650). During the Late Archaic period, the large depression (Feature 1) was excavated and partially filled and occupation occurred around the feature. Seven burials were recovered from the Late Archaic layer (Zone 3). Next, the Richland Creek phase occupation created a midden that contained human cremations and occupational debris forming Zone 2. This layer has been radiocarbon dated to A. D. 580 - 860, but little evidence of use of the area around the pit was observed for this period. During the subsequent Round Praire phase, a small hamlet existed at the site which consisted of two, and possibly three, circular houses, Extensive debris associated with this occupation is found over the site and inside the large depression. The final occupation of the site was by mobile groups which repeatedly visited the site for brief periods between A. D. 1300 and 1650. Overall, a wide variety of artifacts was recovered from Bird Point Island. In comparison with the East Fork sites, similar basic classes of artifacts are observed. Both share high frequencies of Gary dart points with lesser representations by other types such as Yarbrough and Ellis. Several varieties of arrow points, such as Alba, Perdiz, and Scallorn, are also common. However, no examples of the arrow point type Harrell were found at Bird Point Island. Stone tools show additional overall similarity, indicating that a similar range of activities took place at sites in both areas. Ceramics, on the other hand, demonstrate some important differences. While the grog, grit, and bone tempered categories are similar, shell tempered sherds were rarely observed from Bird Point Island. At a broad level, the Bird Point Island artifacts show basic similarity with the Wylie focus sites, with an important exception. Traits considered diagnostic of the Henrietta Focus (Harrell points and shell tempered pottery) are rare at Bird Point Island. In an effort to factor out the multicomponent mixing of the overall artifact assemblages from Bird Point Island, the frequencies of artifacts from the zones within the large depression are listed separately in Table 21-3. These frequencies underscore the concern that overall assemblage comparisons mix the distinctiveness of individual occupations. For instance, it is apparent that ceramics most frequently occur within the upper two zones of the pit and are rare in the lowest zone. These artifacts are encountered over much of the site outside of the pit. STRAWN CREEK The Strawn Creek site is located at the confluence of Strawn Creek and Richland Creek, some 48 km upstream from the Irvine site (Duffield 1963). The site was excavated in 1961 by a crew from the Texas Archeological Survey Project. The principal area of cultural deposits was found to be an oval-shaped midden measuring 6 x 15 m. Upon excavation the midden was found to fill a depression dug into the subsoil to a depth of about 70 cm deep (Figure 21-5), All excavation was conducted within this feature. The large pit had no surface manifestation and is similar to the features reported for the Irvine site. This similarity is seen in the oval irregular plain view of the pit at Sawn Creek and in the highly irregular bottom. Several pits were recorded within the large pit, including pits with scattered bits of human bones, rodent burrows, and unidentified pits (Duffield 1963:7). Postmortem disturbances and poor preservation potential of the soil caused the fragmentary condition of the human remains. No concentrations of rocks, ash, or charcoal were noted, and no post holes indicating a structure were found. The artifacts from Strawn Creek are listed in Table 21-3. Although some liberty was used in condensing the original artifact classes into those on the list, less collapsing was required than for the previous Richland Creek sites. This is due to the less complex classification scheme used by Duffield (1963). The overall frequencies show similarity to the East Fork sites, but certain absences, specifically gouges, cores, and ground stone, are difficult to explain. Considering that the site was excavated more than 20 years ago, they are probably not the result of cultural behavior; but rather reflect a lack of recognition or collection of these tool types. WYLIE FOCUS: AN APPRAISAL OF THE FACTS As noted previously, the Wylie focus was established in 1952 to describe a cultural manifestation along the East Fork of the Trinity River (Stephenson 1952a). A series of traits was devised to characterize this cultural development following the Midwestern Taxonomic System (MTS). These included the presence of large, man-made depressions (although not mandatory), trade pottery from surrounding areas, flexed burials lacking grave goods, and artifacts representative of a wide variety of types. In 1952, when 277 these characteristics were devised, relatively little was known. about North Central Texas archaeology, other than the preliminary foundation established by members of the DAS (Harris 1936, 1942, 1948; Harris and Hatzenbuehler 1948; Hatzenbuehler 1942a; Housewright et al. 1947). Although Krieger's monumental Culture Complexes of Northern Texas (1946) was available, this primarily provided comparative data on sites to the east and west of the East Fork area. Therefore, it is not surprising that traits that seemed reasonable in the 1950s, when littie comparative data was available, today seem too generalized to provide a meaningful basis for culture-historical classification. The additional information collected from sites in North Central Texas since 1952 requires us to reassess the usefulness of the Wylie focus concept in terms of today's archaeological goals. Specifically, we must address two questions: (1) how well is the Wylie focus serving as a culture-historical construct, and (2) are we actually advancing our understanding of North Central Texas prehistory by assigning sites to this focus? To answer these questions, we must first examine the original definition of a focus as part of the MTS. A focus was defined as a collection ". . . of traits . . . [that] reoccur in characteristic purity and practical completeness . . . at a variety of sites" (McKern 1939:308). When adequately formulated, a focus will equate with a distinct social grouping such as a tribe. Foci were, moreover, to be timeless and spaceless (Caldwell and Henning 1978:115), and to merely connect similar archaeological manifestations for later temporal and spatial consideration. However, Stephenson's (1952a:311) definition of the Wylie focus attempted to move beyond the strict MTS and to propose chronological boundaries. The precision of these boundaries was hampered by a lack of temporally diagnostic artifacts, and since radiocarbon dating was in its infancy, only a rough estimate of A. D. 1300 to 1600 was made based on similar cultural developments in other areas. Stephenson (1952a:312) did note that with future radiocarbon dating, the temporal position of the focus would likely be refined, Lynott (1977), on the basis of 12 radiocarbon dates from sites of the focus, concluded that a wider time span was in order. Based on work at the Sister Grove Creek site, a time frame of A. D. 900 to perhaps as late as A. D. 1590 was suggested. _ Lynott (1977:236) further postulated the existence of a preceramic dart point phase of the Wylie focus that was coeval with the Sanders focus of East Texas, This phase developed into a ceramic and arrow producing phase that contained traits similar to the Henrietta focus to the west. As a result of Lynott’s temporally expanded estimate combined with Stephenson's broad complex of identifying traits, virtually any Late Prehistoric site in the upper Trinity River basin could be identified as belonging to the Wylie focus (cf., Smith 1969). It is clear today that the broad temporal range and vague trait characteristics of the Wylie focus limit the usefulness of the concept. This is particularly true since the inclusion of dart points as a trait within the focus means that it is difficult, if not impossible, to separate Archaic from Wylie focus components at the same site. The most distinctive quality of Archaic occupations, namely the presence of certain dart point forms, is lost. Although it may be correct that dart and arrow points were concurrently in use at the East Fork sites, this has not been demonstrated but simply assumed. The nature of this problem can be seen more clearly by comparing the Richland Creek sites to the East Fork sites. Due to the extensive investigations undertaken at the Richland Creek sites, particularly those of the RCAP, it is possible to understand the periods of occupation and to identify the asemblages associated with each period. Most of the sites represent occupations by both Archaic and Late Prehistoric groups, and the large depression at the sites are associated specifically with Late Archaic occupations. A demonstration that the Richland Creek and the East Fork sites are similar from an overall assemblage perspective (ie., the sum of all components at a site) will make a strong case for the existence of mixed components at the East Fork sites as well. On the other hand, if the East Fork sites are sufficiently different from the Richland Creek sites, and further, show interassemblage

In fact, the Wylie focus concept along the East Fork should be replaced by a culture-historical scheme that attempts to more critically synthesize and classify the archaeological record. LARGE PITS AND NORTH CENTRAL TEXAS ARCHAEOLOGY We have concluded that the Wylie focus is a flawed culture- historical construct for describing the archaeology of the East Fork of the Trinity River. Moreover, we have suggested that the artifact assemblages from most Wylie focus sites are actually composites of multiple occupations during distinctly different periods of prehistory. However, we have not addressed the most enigmatic characteristic of the Wylie focus, namely, the function of the large depressions present at most sites. In this section the function of these feaures is examined by first reviewing existing hypotheses and then proposing a refined hypothesis that more - realistically addresses the data base and places this material into a broader behavioral perspective. PREVIOUS HYPOTHESES The hypotheses that have been proposed by various researchers to account for the large depressions along the East Fork have been discussed earlier in this volume, so only a brief review of these hypotheses is presented here. The first systematic consideration of these features was by Stephenson (1952a:307) at Hogge Bridge. He proposed that the depression at this site, as well as other sites of the focus, was likely used for one of the following purposes: dance arenas, gaming areas, ceremonial centers, open-air council chambers, or defensive breastworks. An additional possibility, that the pits were used for water storage; was discarded since ample water would likely have been available from nearby springs and creeks. Ross (1966:16), based on work at the Upper Rockwall site, reviewed several of these alternatives and added some important insights on the subject. He too agreed that water storage was unlikely, since the depression at the Upper Rockwall site penetrated a gravel substratum that would have permitted water to drain out. In fact, Ross (1966:18) suggested that excavation of the secondary basin in the center may have been designed to contact the subsurface gravels to promote drainage. Conceming the defensive hypothesis, he argued that this was unlikely since these features are consistently located along the slopes of the site landforms. Such a position would have put people inside the depressions at a disadvantage since an invading group would have been on higher ground with a strategic advantage. The most rigorous examination of the function of these features was conducted by Lynott (1975) based on excavations at the Sister Grove Creek site. He evaluated Stephenson's hypotheses and determined that they all were inadequate when viewed against the data from excavations at the Sister Grove Creek site. As an altemative, Lynott proposed a new hypothesis to more realistically address the functional problem. The new hypothesis proposed that the depressions had served as focal points for ritual feasting. The ritual aspect of this hypothesis came form the idea that the pits represented a form of community symbol and that the activities conducted in them would have had significance to the entire group who occupied the site (Lynott, personal comunication, 1985). The evidence in support of Lynott’s (1975:39) interpretation of ritual feasting was based on the numerous hearths, fire cracked rock, mussel shell, and other faunal remains from the feature at Sister Grove Creek. In addition, he proposed that high status female burials were placed into the pits. However, since only one burial was excavated at Sister Grove Creek, where approximately 90% of the pit was excavated, interment was not a primary purpose of the features. Based on a series of radiocarbon dates from the site, construction of the pit was proposed to have commenced prior to A. D. 1000. Influence from the Gibson aspect of the Caddoan 279 mound sites in East Texas was viewed as the probable source of innovation for this activity along the East Fork. Lynott's hypothesis is important because it offers an interpretation that systematically addresses the contents of the depressions. Despite this, two unsettling questions persist about this hypothesis. First, detailed stratigraphic information from pits at other sites show evidence of a bottom layer which lacks burned lenses and has little associated food debris (e.g., Upper Rockwall, Bird Point Island, and Adams Ranch). What is the relationship of this layer to the ritual feasting hypothesis? Such a layer was not recognized at the Sister Grove Creek site, but it must be noted that there the large depression was excavated mostly by a backhoe. A similar layer may have been overlooked, particularly if if was not visually distinctive and was detectable only by a change in artifact styles or frequencies. A second unsettling question is why would ceremonial feasting take place in a large depression, particularly one that is actively being filled by eroded soil, as Lynott (1975:25) indicates was the case at Sister Grove Creek? FEATURE CHARACTERISTICS By examining previous hypotheses in light of the work from Richland Creek, we now are in a position to provide a refined understanding of the function of these features. To accomplish this, we first need to examine the characteristics of the large depressions from all sites within a comparative framework to isolate characteristics that are common to all large depressions and identify those that tend to be unique to one or only a few. Characteristics shared by all features are assumed to be more indicative of their function then those common to one or a few. Including only those sites with large depressions (i.¢., only those with a surface manifestation), we find that the features have three sets of characteristics. The first set consists of traits that are the result of cultural activity and occur consistently at all depressions. They include the following: (1) An elongated outline and irregular walls, (when this information has been carefully collected), Although the Hogge Bridge site is described as nearly circular (Stephenson 1952a:307), this was determined from perpendicular trenches and limited block excava- tions; extensive horizontal scraping, the best method for outline definition, was not undertaken. (2) Surface manifestations varying from slightly less than I m to over I m in depth (as measured from the elevation of the normal ground surface). (3) Location on the slopes of site landforms. (4) One or more burials (when sufficient portions of the depressions have been sampled.) The location of the human remains is not consistent within the depressions, (5) Association of considerable quantities of both Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric artifacts. In addition to these universal traits, several characteristics were found to differ from feature to feature. These are: (1) Size and depth of the features. They vary from a minimum length of 17 m to a maximum length of 27 m, and from a minimum depth of 2.4 m to a maximum depth of 4.2 m. (2) Presence of an elevated rim. This trait was only clearly observable at the Hogge Bridge site. (3) Presence of definable stratigraphy. Unfortunately, not all workers consistently recorded this information. And finally, a non-cultural characteristic of the large depressions must be considered. This has to do with the types of soils found inside and around the features. The depressions have

280 been constructed on several different types of landforms, including floodplain knolls and terrace remnants. Consequently, the soils that make up the features also vary from clays to sandy loams. This variability in soil types has permitted various natural soil disturbance agents such as soil cracking (Newman 1982; Duffield 1970) and rodent disturbance (Eriandson 1984) to differentially affect the deposits. For example, the pocket gopher (Geomys sp.), a common agent of site disturbance in North Central Texas, prefers sandy soil habitats and causes considerable soil mixing in these locations (Schmidly 1983:143). Consequently, sites with sandy deposits will show more disturbance from this animal than sites in clay soils. What do these sets of characteristics tell us about the function of the large depressions present at many sites along the East Fork and Richland Creek? The consistently occurring cultural characteristics indicate that similar behavioral processes were responsible for the initial formation of the features. Whether this initial formation was intended for ritual feasting or some other purpose cannot yet be determined, but the evidence argues for a common original function. The fact that the features are always located on the slopes of site landforms indicates that they were located away from prime areas for habitation (i.e., the tops of knolls). This suggests that the pits functioned in an ancillary fashion to activities conducted on the prime topographic setting (e.g., human habitation). The consistent occurrence of burials within the features demonstrates that human burial was a part of the purpose for the features, but not the primary purpose. If the pits had been used solely as cemeteries, then we might expect a greater number of burials placed in the central portions of the depressions. The consistent occurrence of Late Archaic through Late Prehistoric artifacts at sites with the large depressions adds important information on the chronological placement of these features. The origins of the depressions at Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch are clearly dated to the Late Archaic period. A similar temporal placement might be posited for the pits along the East Fork. The existing radiocarbon dates from depressions on the East Fork sites post-date the initial construction of the pits. Although Lynott (1977:236) argues for a construction and initial use between A. D. 900 and 1000, there is no firm evidence for this. The earliest date from the large depression at Sister Grove Creek was A. D. 900 200 (Lynott 1977:29). However, this sample was recovered from the slope of the depression and not from the bottom. Conversely, access would have been provided for movement of Gulf marine shell northward. Those cultural traits that vary from depression to depression offer important additional information pertaining to pit function. The size of features varies both in terms of horizontal dimensions and depth, suggesting that the processes responsible for their construction varied in intensity. That is, the smaller pits found at Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island along Richland Creek reflect a tower level of the activities responsible for the creation of these features than occurred at sites along the East Fork, where the pits are consistently large. A Jack of a consistent elevated rim indicates that this feature either has been eroded away or that a rim was incidental to the purpose of the feature. And finally, the inconsistent occurrence of stratigraphy demonstrates that the fill episodes of the features varied after construction and initial use. We interpret this to suggest that the function of some of the features changed over time. The chronological information from Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch indicates that later groups used the depressions, but for different purposes. The lack of stratigraphy at other sites suggests that some features were abandoned after their initial period of use. And finally, the variability in soil characteristics of the features suggests that whatever cultural activities took place inside them has been differentially disturbed by natural processes. Some sites may be relatively undisturbed by natural agents while others have been heavily disturbed, Consequently, our interpretations must account for potential mixing and overall blurring of the distinctiveness of the deposits, in addition to the systemic context of deposition (cf., Schiffer 1975). FEATURE FUNCTION: A NEW HYPOTHESIS Given that the large depressions along Richland Creek and the East Fork show similarities in shape, content, and chronology, we are now in a position to examine the question of function by providing a new hypothesis. Although recent work along Richland Creek has provided pertinent data on pit formation processes, generalizations outside of this area should be considered tentative. The large depressions from the Richland Creek and East Fork sites are similar; however, the East Fork sites have been less intensively investigated and several feature characteristics are poorly (1966:18) concluded that the temporal association of the large“ understood. features was uncertain and that a Late Archaic affiliation was a distinct possibility. It is our contention that the chronological position of the large depressions has not been firmly determined and that a Late Archaic time frame for initial excavation and use of the pits along the East Fork is consistent with existing data. The occurrence of large quantities of Late Archaic artifacts on all of the East Fork sites lends support to this argument. In fact, the East Fork sites contain more exotic or elaborate Late Archaic artifacts such as boatstones, gorgets, and worked marine shell (Table 21-4) than all known sites from surrounding areas. Hall (1981:291-309) has proposed a Late Archaic, or Woodland, period import-export sphere linking southcentral and coastal Texas with other parts of the southeastern U. S. Three main items formed this exchange system: comer tanged knives, boatstones, and marine shell. Two of these three items (boatstones and marine shell artifacts) occur within the East Fork drainage and suggest that the Late Archaic inhabitants of this area were somehow participating in this import-export sphere. It is interesting to note that other drainages of the Trinity River do not show this same elaboration of Archaic culture. It is difficult to imagine what the East Fork Late Archaic could have been contributing to the import-export system to the exclusion of surrounding areas. Perhaps the location of the East Fork was important as a direct route connecting the Trinity River with the Red River. The East Fork is the only major tributary of the Trinity River oriented directly north-south; it would have permitted direct access to the "QUICK TIME" EXPECTATIONS VERSUS A SYSTEMIC CONTEXT OF EXPLANATION Before discussing this new hypothesis, the assumptions underlying an understanding of pit function must be considered. Are we looking for the evidence, frozen in time, of a once-living culture which disappeared while utilizing a large depression? This "Pompeii premise,” as it has been labeled (Ascher 1961), proposes that cultures leave a perfectly fossilized picture of their behavior in the archaeological record when they cease to exist. Seldom does this situation occur, and as Schiffer (1976:11-12) has noted: Between the time artifacts were manufactured and used in the past and the time these objects are unearthed by the archaeologist they have been subjected to a series of cultural and noncultural processes which have transformed them spatially, quantitatively, and formally and relationally .. . If we desire to reconstruct the past from archaeological remains, these processes must be taken into account, and a more generally applicable methodological principle substituted for the one that asserts that there is an equivalence between past cultural systems and its archaeological record.

Past researchers have approached the problem as if the large depressions ceased_to function immediately after use and that the artifact record reflects this sudden event. For instance, Lynott (1975:39-40) proposed that his hypothesis of ceremonial feasting will be evident through the identification of hearths, representing temporary cooking, and large mammal remains, representative of a large group. This implies that the food was cooked within the pits, consumed, and that all evidence, such as the hearths and associated food debris, was left behind and covered in place. Although the effects of ceremonial cleaning are discussed, the more probable effects of animal scavengers and natural disturbances, such as leaching of the hearths by rainfall and displacement of the artifacts by erosion, are not discussed. As an alternative, Binford (1981:197) argues that we should attempt to understand features not simply as isolated pieces of a descriptive history, but as part of the cultural systems that produced them. The archaeological record represents a massive palimpsest of many separate episodes of human behavior, and the identification of specific events is often impossible. More importantly, the identification of these unique events in prehistory is not an integral part of modern anthropological archaeology. Rather, we should attempt to understand human behavior from the diachronic perspective that only archaeology can provide (Binford 1964). This approach is useful for furthering our understanding of the function of the large depressions for two reasons. First, it offers a chance to move beyond the quick-time expectations of earlier hypotheses and to more realistically address the complex and often accretional nature of the archaeological record. Second, and more importantly, this viewpoint focuses attention on how these features 281 functioned within the societies that constructed them. That is, the relationship of the depressions to other parts of the prehistoric cultural system becomes the target of explanation. If ritual feasting is the hypothesized use, then we must explain why ritual feasting was undertaken in the first place. What advantage does feasting in a pit offer? Certainly eating can be done anywhere on the site, and to undertake this activity inside a 3 m deep depression in the ground does not, by itself, seem logical. It is only within the context of the total cultural system that the rationale for pit construction and use can be understood. COMPARISONS WITH ROASTING PITS Since the large depressions contain artifacts and floral and faunal remains indicative of economic use, an indication of their purpose can be gained by comparing them with smaller pit features that have been identified as roasting pits. At Bird Point Island, extensive experimental work demonstrated that these pits functioned as roasting ovens for a variety of foods, including hickory nuts, acorns, Psoralea tubers, and probably meat. The purpose of the roasting activity was to cook and/or preserve food resources. Hilliard (1980:16), in describing processing of hickory huts, notes that roasting stops the process of germination by removing the moisture content, makes the shells easier to remove, and kills larvae that might have infested the nuts. Beneficial effects of roasting can also be assumed for some of the other plant foods found within these features. For instance, roasting would also have been a means of drying Psoralea tubers and meat, and the use of this technique has been documented historically (Mandlebaum 1940:202). At first glance, the low incidence of artifacts suggestive of Toasting activity (fire cracked rock, hearths, concentrations of food remains) from the bottom layers of the depressions at Bird Point Island, Adams Ranch, and Upper Rockwall do not seem to correspond to what would be expected for a roasting pit. However, as noted earlier, we cannot expect these features today to contain the same proportions of artifacts that they had when in use. These features were reused many times and only the non-reusable items (charred fragments of food, fragmented small pieces of fire cracked rock, etc.) can be expected to remain. Moreover, any oxidization of the soil from heat would have been disturbed by subsequent digging. In fact, depending upon the clay content of the soil, oxidized lenses might not even form. Blurring this entire picture are the natural post-depositional processes outlined earlier in this chapter. To understand what artifacts would be expected in these features if they were used for roasting, comparison can be made to Feature 38 from Bird Point Island and Feature 51 from Adams Ranch which have been convincingly identified as roasting pits (Table 21-5). The functional assessment of these features was based on a high incidence of fire cracked rock, baked clay, a lower incidence of many other artifact classes, and the presence of many types of charred floral remains. The fire cracked rock did not appear to be abundant during excavation, and became noticeable only after the matrix had been water screened and the small pieces were observed. Similarly, the baked clay was not easily observable: and its presence seems to have been influenced by the quantity of clay in the soil available for oxidation. The raw material heated for roasting was Wilcox sandstone, and large rocks were evidently reused until they exfoliated into smaller pieces. Thus, a lack of large fire cracked rocks does not indicate that roasting did not take place. In fact, from a diachronic perspective, we would expect to find mostly the small non-reusable pieces left behind in the pit fill. The lowest layers of the depressions at both Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch contained quantities of fire cracked rock, albeit in lower frequencies than the smaller roasting pits. The mere presence of this material suggests that some degree of roasting took place. Viewing the proportional frequencies of artifacts instead of the absolute frequencies (Table 21-6), a different picture emerges concerning the occurrence of fire cracked rock. THE SYSTEMIC CONTEXT OF LATE ARCHAIC ROASTING PITS Earlier in this chapter, the argument was made that all the large depressions may have been constructed by Late Archaic populations. It has also been argued that the large depressions functioned as roasting pits, in much the same manner that the smaller pits clearly associated with earth oven cooking. Assuming these two arguments are correct, the question now becomes, why did Late Archaic groups need such large roasting pits? The great size of these features suggests that substantial amounts of resources were being processed. This could either indicate a large resident population or, more likely, the coalescence of several regional bands at sites with depressions. Such aggregations of neighboring bands during certain times of the year is observed among modern hunting and gathering societies (Service 1962:58-59), and can be expected to have occurred prehistorically. Evidence supporting this situation is the relatively low frequency of Late Archaic materials around the large depression at Adams Ranch. The depression at this site has been dated to the Late Archaic period, and diagnostic artifacts have been recovered from the lowest layer of the feature. The paucity of Late Archaic artifacts around the pit argues for brief encampments at the site rather than a large resident population. Although it could be argued that the coalescence of a large band might produce substantial quantities of artifacts, this would not occur if each occupation was brief and the occupations were separated by several seasons. Although other sites with depressions show evidence of more intensive Late Archaic occupation, we propose that these large depressions, such as Bird Point Island and many of the East Fork sites, also reflect roasting activities associated with aggregations of local groups. Not all sites were apparently used for this activity to the same extent, and this seems to have-created the observed differential quantities of Late Archaic artifacts. Compounding this problem is the almost certain use of many of the sites as seasonal camps before or after use of the depressions. The nature of roasting activities conducted at sites with large depressions probably included: (1) large scale processing of certain plant and animal foods, and (2) cooking for ritual feasts associated with macroband aggregation. Plants such as Psoralea sp. and nuts occur in high abundance for very brief periods of the year, so their collection and processing must be conducted rapidly. Macroband aggregation for the purpose of collecting and preserving staple foods would have provided a means of increasing the harvest beyond the capabilities of individual bands. Since roasting is a well-documented means of preserving both nuts (Hilliard 1980) and Psoralea (Wedel 1978), significant roasting activity would have occurred during harvest periods. Ritual feasting, derived from Lynott's (1975) hypothesis, is viewed here as an important social activity which occurred during the gathering of bands for the purpose of food collection and processing. The variety of food species recovered from the large depressions at Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island is reminiscent of the types of foods found in association with burned rock middens of Central Texas, which are also believed to have been used for roasting (Peter 1982). In fact, the problems involved with understanding the origins and function of burned rock middens are strikingly similar to those affecting the interpretation of the large pits found in North Central Texas. Both seem to have grown from gradual accretion, and at first glance, seem too large to have been created by small bands. The large depressions may be the equivalent of the burned rock middens in stone poor areas, and the reason that burned rock middens are not found in North Central Texas is due to the lack of abundant stone resources. Under these conditions, a different strategy for roasting developed, namely earth-oven roasting. To understand why the large pits originated during the Late Archaic period, data related to population size, territorial extent, energy requirements, and risk management strategies must be considered within the perspective of the broader cultural system. On a rudimentary level, the depressions served as roasting pits, but they appear to have provided a far more important function on sociological and ideological levels. The following presentation examines the role of these features in light of the development-of hunter-gatherer cultural complexity during the Late Archaic period discussed in Chapter 18 of Volume III. During the Late Archaic period, human population increased in North Central Texas, as evidenced by a greater number of sites with artifacts diagnostic of this period than sites with artifacts diagnostic of the Early or Middle Archaic periods (see Chapter 18, Volume III). As population increased, territorial size decreased. This is documented by the distribution of chert types, which shows an increased use of local resources and decrease in imported cherts over time (see Chapter 16, Volume III). As a result of increased population and decreased territory, new approaches toward the management of resource stress developed. A prominent feature of the prairies of Texas is the abundance of certain key food resources (e.g., Psoralea, acorns, hickory nuts), yet these same resources are noted by marked seasonality and spatial inequity. As argued in Chapter 18 of Volume III, hunter-gatherers deal with this temporal and spatial incongruity in resources through various types of risk management strategies (Earle 1980). Given a stable environment and constant but low level population, hunter-gatherers prefer to accomplish this through mobility (Cohen 1977, 1985; Binford 1980). Binford calls this form of organization, whereby consumers move to goods, residential mobility. We argue that this economic strategy was employed by the Early and Middle Archaic populations in the Richland Creek area. Evidence in support of this argument is the high proportion of cherts in the local assemblages which are assumed to have been procured from distant sources. The higher population densities recorded for the Late Archaic period resulted in reduced exploitation territories which limited 283 mobility and made this form of risk management precarious. The reduced group territories meant that each society was more vulnerable to local fluctuation in plant and animal availability (cf., Ford 1979:236). If for instance, nut production in one area significantly decreased, which is commonly observed among many nut bearing trees (Hilliard1980), economic hardship was brought upon the group inhabiting the area. The interactive effects of a shortage of one resource upon other food sources, such as a lowering of deer populations due to the low mast yields, would have compounded this problem. A common means by which contemporary hunter-gatherers cope with this problem is through risk sharing (Wiessner 1982: 65; Gould 1982). Generalized reciprocity (Service 1979:17) is maintained with neighboring groups, and social obligations are stored through feasting, exchange, and gift-giving. Band coalescence at the sites with large depression could have served much the same purpose. During periods when local resources were scarce, band aggregation would serve to redistribute foods to those groups in need. Under conditions of better resource harvests, feasting and general socialization could serve to store social obligations for future resource shortfalls. In either case, the depressions would be the by-products of short term cooking and processing of food associated with this seasonal congregation. Assuming such a hypothesis is correct, how do we explain the spatial segregation of the sites with depressions? To date, only two clusters of sites are known: those along the East Fork and those along Richland Creek. Moreover, several sites with depressions are recorded for the East Fork, whereas only two are observed along Richland Creek. Perhaps the groups of depressions are located along “tension zones" between neighboring groups, where due to natural geography, vegetational patterns, or some other factor, local bands tended to come into contact. Not all of the depressions would have been used at the same time, but each would have served its purpose for a relatively short period. By comparing the radiocarbon dates between Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch, a strong case can be made for sequential use of the features, first at Bird Point Island and later at Adams Ranch. With refined chronological control, a similar situation might have been found at the East Fork sites. Assuming this is correct, the greater number of sites with depressions along the East Fork suggests that the social institution represented by the depressions occurred over a longer period of time. It is interesting to note the high incidence of exotic or labor intensive artifacts mentioned earlier in this chapter at sites of this drainage. The artifacts are missing at the Richland Creek sites. The presence of those artifacts was interpreted to indicate participation in a Late Archaic import- export sphere in Texas and surrounding states. This evidence combined with the overall greater number of depression sites argues for the emergence of hunter-gatherer complexity along the East Fork reminiscent of developments further north in the Midwest (Brown 1985). The ideological importance of the depressions is demonstrated by their consistent inclusion of human burials, although the mortuary role of these features appears to have been secondary to their economic role. Almost all of the depressions recorded along the East Fork and both depressions along Richland Creek contained human burials in their lowest layers. The limited excavations along the East Fork provided data that suggested the depressions were restricted to the burial of high status females, although this interpretation was based on a small sample (Lynctt 1975:118). The larger sample of burials from the Richland Creek depressions included males, females, and infants without associated grave offerings indicative of status differentation. The important point is that these features functioned in an ideological capacity in both areas. The ideological importance of established cemeteries may be directly related to the pressures of increased population and decreased territory during the Late Archaic period. Charles and Buikstra (1983) have interpreted the appearance of Archaic period cemeteries in the Central Mississippi Valley as an indicator of the emergence of corporate lineal inheritance of crucial and restricted resources. They state that "the remains of one's ancestors on the

Thus, a major function of cemeteries, aside from providing a resting place for the dead, was to serve as territorial markers. The presence of a cemetery legitimized a group's claim to the area and hence to its crucial resources. This concept of cemeteries as territorial markers fits well with the data from North Central Texas, where increased population, concomitant restriction of territoral areas, and the use of the depressions are all first observed during the Late Archaic period. Along Richland Creek, the depressions were used for processing the abundant resources which were restricted to the Post Oak Savannah and Bottomland Forest zones, and it seems quite reasonable that the inclusion of burials served as a means of laying claim to these critical plant collecting areas and favored hunting grounds. The absence of cemeteries during the Early and Middle Archaic periods in North Central Texas lends additional support to this interpretation, since these periods were characterized by low populations with increased residential mobility, and presumably, little conflict over available resources. SUMMARY Conclusions have been presented throughout this chapter concerning the usefulness of the Wylie focus concept for under- standing the prehistory of North Central Texas, and the origin and functions of the large pit features associated with the focus. In addition, a new hypothesis regarding use of these features has been proposed which considers their role within the entire cultural system of Late Archaic hunter-gatherers. The major points of these discussions are summarized here. First of all, the concept of the Wylie focus is obsolete and should no longer be used for the classification of sites in North Central Texas. The complex of identifying traits associated with the Wylie focus, as defined by Stephenson (1952a), is very broad and mixes artifact types that are now known to represent both Archaic and Late Prehistoric occupations. The Wylie focus sites were originally assigned to a temporal frame of A. D. 1300 to 1600 (Stephenson 1952a), and later were pushed back as early as A. D. 900 (Lynott 1977:236). Lynott also proposed a preceramic , phase of the Wylie focus based on work at the Sister Grove Creek” site. This expanded time frame, in combination with the broad complex of identifying traits, permits nearly any site found in North Central Texas to be included in the Wylie focus. As a result, its usefulness as a classificatory tool is dubious. In 1952, the Wylie focus concept was a welcome attempt to organize the accumulating data from two decades of investigations along the East Fork, but it has outlived its usefulness and now detracts from our under- standing of prehistory. Future research should avoid the use of this concept, The origins and purpose of the large man-made depressions observed at the sites along the East Fork have been the target of research since they were first reported. Several researchers have proposed a broad range of hypotheses regarding the nature of pit use including use as defensive structures, water storage structures, dance arenas, gaming areas, ceremonial centers, open-air council chambers, and ritual feasting areas. The gaming area hypothesis was merely a speculation based on the similarity in size and shape of these depressions to the ballcourts of the southwest and Meso- America,whereas the defensive structure hypothesis was derived from descriptions of historic period Wichita defensive structures (Wilbarger 1889). Other hypotheses, such as the ritual feasting hypothesis, were formulated on the basis of excavation data which revealed the presence of hearths and faunal remains. None of the hypotheses, however, adequately explained all of the phenomena associated with the large depressions, such as the presence of human burials along with food remains. Since little funding was Volume II, Part Three available for research at the East Fork sites, many questions were left unanswered. ‘The discovery of two similar large depressions along Richland Creek presented a new opportunity to study the origins and uses of these features. The Richland Creek excavations revealed that the artifacts, features, and stratigraphy observed in the depressions at Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch were similar to those found in the East Fork depressions. Thus, the Richland Creek sites appeared to be part of a cultural manifestation that extended up the East Fork and could therefore shed light upon the nature of the large depressions first noted along that drainage. The initial construction of these features was believed to have occurred around A. D. 900, based largely on a radiocarbon date from the Sister Grove Creek site (Lynott 1975). However, radiocarbon dates from the lowest layers in both of the Richland Creek depressions indicate that these features were first used during the Late Archaic period, perhaps as early as 170 B.C. at Bird Point Island, and by 200 A. D, at Adams Ranch. Since the radiocarbon date for the depression at the Sister Grove Creek site came from the south slope of the feature, rather than from the bottom, we believe that all of the large depressions may be much older than previously believed. Re-examining the numerous hypotheses concerning the utiliza- tion of these features was more problematical than assessing the proposed dates of their initial excavation and the chronology of fill episodes. Soils studies, artifact analysis, feature comparison, and osteological investigations were employed to examine the factors contributing to the original excavation and use of the large depressions along Richland Creek. The presence of fire cracked rock, baked clay, charred plant remains, and faunal remains in all layers of the features suggests that they had been used for the roasting of food. The presence of human burials documents the role of these features as cemeteries in addition to their economic role. At both of the Richland Creek sites with depressions, the number of interred individuals was greatest in the lowest layer of fill and decreased in the upper layers, reflecting 2 change in the importance of the mortuary function over time. The reasons for the development of the large depressions during the Late Archaic period are postulated to be tied to economic pressures associated with a population increase and a concomitant decrease in the territorial size of local bands. According to this new hypothesis, the features functioned as areas in which acoms, nuts, and Psoralea tubers were preserved by roasting during periods of seasonal macroband aggregation. Macroband aggregation would have occurred during the fall, when acorns and nuts were abundant, and again during the spring, when Psoralea tubers are harvested. In addition to cooperating in economic pusuits (e.g., food collection and processing), the people shared in religious and social rituals during these seasonal coalescences. Ritual feasting and exchange of goods served to reinforce social ties to neighboring bands; these social bonds served to reduce the potential risk associated with future resource failure. That is, bands experiencing temporary food shortages could rely on allied bands living in more productive territories to provide assitance. The inclusion of human burials within the depressions served to legitimize the band’s claim to the land, and to the important food resources produced on that land. We do not claim to have solved the enigma of the large depressions as a result of the Richland Creek work. Obviously, final solutions are rarely achieved in archaeology since many important cultural variables affecting human behavior leave few or no material traces in the archaeological record. Rather, this study has examined the facts and presented a new hypothesis which, we believe, more completely encompasses the data and attempts to explain the features within a behavioral framework. Hopefully, this hypothesis will stimulate the development of even more refined hypotheses.
