UNIT NUMBERING SYSTEM FOR BIRD POINT ISLAND William A. Martin —_— This appendix presents the reader with an explanation of the numbering system for units at the Bird Point Island site. For a variety of reasons, the numbering system does not follow consecutively from 1 through 5771, as one might expect. Instead, gaps are present between biocks of unit numbers. Although this system may appear confusing to the reader, it was devised to avoid duplication in numbering and to provide a logical framework of numerical designation, The gap between the last unit excavated during testing (Unit 30) and the first unit dug during Season I (Unit 88) is the result of a change in excavation strategy during Season I. As previously mentioned, a larger block was planned prior to the initiation of field work than was actually excavated. Units 31 through 87 were laid out on paper, surrounding Feature 1, but the complexity of the excava- tion within the pit did not allow time for their excavation. Instead, only units directly inside the pit were chosen for excavation. Gaps were intentionally left in the sequence of unit numbers during Seasons IT, III, and IV to serve as mnemonic devices assisting the recall of a given unit’s size and the season in which it was dug. For example, 1X1 m units excavated during Season II began with Unit 150 and continued consecutively through Unit 315. These units were easily distinguished from units excavated during previous seasons which had only two digit designations. By the same measure, 50X50 cm units were distinguished from 1><1 m units by using four digit designations beginning with 1001 and ending with 1395. This was a useful distinction when examining computer printouts of artifact data because the specific types of units involved could be determined without referring to maps or field notes. During Season II, 1X1 m units in the block excavation over House | began with Unit 320 rather than 316. Because excavation in by House 1 and Feature 1 were conducted simultaneously, the units in Feature 1 were labeled 401-404 to avoid accidental mixing of pro- veniences from the two areas at the waterscreen or in the laboratory. Although few problems were experienced with the mixing of proveniences, it was considered wise to minimize the chances of accidental mixing of wheelbarrow loads by using 300 series and 400 series numbers. Of course, the use of these distinctive designations also aided the recognition of artifacts from each area when scanning computer printouts. Season [II 50X50 cm units began with Unit 4001 and ended with Unit 5771 which easily distinguished them from Season IT 50X50 cm units. The strict separation of unit designation according to unit size was not adhered to for Units 405-451 because the majority of these designations were assigned to the halves of features removed for processing regardless of the volume excavated. The exceptions to this procedure were Units 411-418 which were 1X1 m units dug in | Feature 45 and Units 423-434 which were 1X.5 m units dug in Feature 38. Although the numbering system is somewhat unorthodox, it actually promoted efficiency during the later stages of the Project when questions about specific units arose. On the basis of the unit number alone, the kind of unit in question and the season in which it was dug were known, which immediately narrowed the selection of notes and records to be searched for answers. Since nearly 600 pages of field notes, hundreds of pages of level forms, and dozens of maps and computer printouts were compiled over the course of four field seasons, the ability to move directly to the pertinent records servedto reduce the work load and increase efficiency. 287

MUN YQaYQQOaquy om a) A wwe ww oo wna nA n Qo Wow FROTH FLOTATION Michael Pendleton Flotation is a basic technique which facilitates the recovery of small and fragile materials from soil samples obtained from archaeo- logical sites. In order to separate such items as plant remains, small bones, fish scales, and insect parts from their soil matrix using the flotation technique, a sample must be immersed within a fluid. Compared to dry screening through quarter-inch size mesh, flotation is fifty times as effective for the recovery of plant remains in quantity (Munson, Parmalee, and Yarnell 1971:421). FROTH FLOTATION DEVICE OPERATION A froth flotation device (patent pending), similar in general opera- tion to a recovery unit described by Jarman, Legge, and Charles (1972:39), is utilized for the recovery of delicate botanical remains from soil samples taken at the Richland Project (Figure D-1). Letter designations in the following discussion refer to Figure D-1. The froth flotation method relies on the lifting action of air bubbled through a submerged soil sample within a fluid medium to facilitate the separa- tion of small plant parts from their soil matrix. Bubbles of air are formed within the fluid by the passage of compressed air through sintered bronze flange cones. The cones are fixed to a rigid network of plastic tubing (f) which directs compressed air through the cones and into the flotation fluid held within a polypropylene plastic tank (a). During flotation, this rigid tubing, or bubbler, is lowered to the bottom of the fluid filled tank and compressed air, supplied by a portable compressor, is forced through the bubbler’s flange cones. If desired, 9 mm of Aerofroth 65 (registered by the American Cyanamid Corporation) frother chemical and 2 mm of kerosene are placed into the flotation tank fluid prior to the addition of sample soil to the bubbling liquid. Additional water is constantly added to the tank fluid through the connection provided at the tank drain cap. The by upward force of water from the base of the flotation tank churns settled material back up toward the bubbling liquid. A screen, which is attached to the bubbler, covers the tank drain hole (b) during flota- tion processing and prevents material from falling below the zone of effective frothing activity within the tank. The additional fluid and materials separated from the soil sample within the tank overflow along the tank’s upper edge and are channeled into a trough. Both fluid and materials are guided by a trough (c) into a series of screens (d) to facilitate later analysis by size differentiation. A propellor agi- tator (e) is placed beneath the screen series to break up any build-up of silt which impedes the flow of water through these screens. Water directed through small holes in the agitator causes a rotation of the propellor which interrupts the water stream and effectively breaks up the silt layer on the screen series. After the flotation process is com- pleted (usually after 20 minutes per 9.5 1 of sample soil), the bubbler is raised along with the screen at the base of the tank in order to facili- tate efficient tank draining. Following the removal of the tank’s drain pipe cap, fluid flowing out of this pipe may be screened to recover materials which have settied to the bottom of the tank during flota- tion processing. Materials collected on screens are placed on news- papers to dry for analysis. Certain problems in froth flotation processing were encountered at the Richland/Chambers Project. For example, the hard water used in the flotation tank caused a deposit of minerals to form on the sintered bronze cones attached to the bubbler. As suggested by Jarman, Legge, and Charles (1972:44), a periodic immersion of the bubbler in weak acetic acid cleaned the bronze cones and allowed the unit to operate effectively. Since a gauge was attached to the pressur- ized air line from the compressor to the bubbler, an abnormally high pressure reading of this gauge indicates the need for acetic acid treat- ment of the bubbler before any mineral deposit hinders efficient frothing activity. 291

COMPARISONS OF FROTH FLOTATION TO TUB FLOTATION Prior to the processing of soil samples by froth flotation at the Richland Project, the recovery efficiencies of tub and froth flotation were compared by experiments performed at California State University, Chico. These experiments utilized over 1500 carbon- ized seeds divided into matched samples (Pendleton 1979; 1980; 1983). Ten types of seeds commonly available in any garden supply store were chosen for these experiments. Such seeds, if carbonized, Volume II, Appendix D placed into a soil matrix and processed by a flotation device, provide a standard of recovery efficiency for the device for more than one kind of seed. For the tub flotation processing in these experiments, a large washtub was utilized which has its bottom replaced by a fine screen described by Struever (1968:353). The tub, into which the soil sample is placed, is partially submerged in a river, stream, or other large body of water until its screened bottom is one inch below the water’s surface. Both silt and dirt are washed away from the sample by agitating and rotating the partially submerged tub, at which time a second operator, using a small tea strainer or screen mesh scoop, skims off material on the surface or in suspension in the fluid within the tub. The agitation and skimming processes are continued until the fluid within the tub appears clear. The recovered materials from the strainers or scoops (the light fraction) and the residue on the screen within the tub (the heavy fraction) are then placed on news- paper to dry for analysis. The results (shown in Table D-1) of experimental tests of the efficiency of recovery for tub and froth flotation (Pendleton 1979; 1980; 1983) imply that, for the light fraction (which includes only those materials which are caught in the tub flotation scoops or are channelled into the screen series during froth flotation), froth recovers a more representative non-floating seed species assemblage than does tub flotation. The two non-buoyant carbonized seed species tested are recovered in significantly greater percentages (significance levels of .01) by the froth flotation method for light fraction materials. For the eight species of buoyant carbonized seed species tested, four species are recovered in greater percentages by the tub method while the other four species are recovered in greater percentages by the froth flotation method. For the buoyant car- bonized seed species tested, the range of recovery for the tub method is 24 to 100 percent, while the recovery range is 62 to 96 percent for the froth method. The greater minimum recovery percentages noted for froth flotation imply that a more representative assemblage of carbonized seed species (especially non-buoyant types) is obtained in the light fraction by utilizing froth flotation rather than tub flotation methods. This advantage suggests that froth flotation is an appropriate method of recovery for botanical materials from soil samples taken at the Richland/Chambers Project. ar @ IERIE BEES Eee wee ee FLOTATION METHODOLOGY FLOTATION DEVICE The flotation device substituted for the froth flotation device was a 50 gallon barrel which had been modified by adding a flotation chamber, an overflow valve and an overflow chute. The flotation chamber was a 5 gallon bucket which was attached to the top of the barrel. A 6.4 mm screen rested on the bottom of the chamber. The overflow chute was designed to carry the float material from the flotation chamber into a series of screens (Nos. 6, 10, and 12). The overflow valve is connected to the barrel and was used to control the water level within the flotation chamber. FLOTATION PROCESS The flotation samples were pre-soaked to aid the breakdown of the soil matrix. No chemicals were used for deflocculation. While in operation, the barrel was filled with water until overflowing. The flotation sample was slowly added to the running watér above the heavy fraction screen within the flotation chamber. A garden hose provided the pressure needed to churn the sample within the flotation chamber. Once the soil had been broken down by the churning water and manual stirring, the overflow valve was closed. This resulted in the gradual rise of the water level in the flotation chamber until it reached the overflow chute which directed the water and floated remains through a set of three by Duane E. Peter screens (light fraction). This process continued for 20 minutes. At the end of that time, the overflow valve was opened, the water drained off, and the heavy and light fraction screens were dumped onto newspaper for drying. FLOTATION SORTING Once the fractions dried, they were sorted by means of screening and hand picking of the materials retained by each screen size. Initially, the heavy fraction was sifted through a 6.4 mm screen and all materials remaining on the screen were sorted and bagged. The material that passed through the screen was sifted through a smaller mesh screen (2 mm), and all macrobotanical, charcoal, stone, shell, and bone remains were bagged separately. All material, except stone, less than 2 mm in diameter was bagged and sent to the macrobotanical specialist. The light fraction material was contained within three samples: 1) 3.35 mm, 2) 1.7 mm, and 3) .85 mm. The largest of the light fraction samples was initially sifted through a 6.4 mm screen to remove grass stems and roots. The material that passed through this screen was then sifted through a 2 mm screen and sorted. Everything less than 2 mm in diameter from this sample and the smaller screen samples (1.7 and .85 mm) was sent to the macrobotanical analyst for examination without any preliminary sorting.

BIRD POINT ISLAND CHARCOAL ANALYSIS Richard G. Holloway During Season I, 26 samples of charcoal were recovered from Units 89-92 in Feature 1 at Bird Point Island and sent to Texas A&M University for analysis. A few of the samples were sub- samples of those used for radiocarbon dating, but the majority were derived from either archaeological features or from the soil matrix of Feature 1 fill. In the absence of other paleo- environmental indicators only tentative correlations may be proposed. METHODS AND MATERIALS Charcoal, when immediately removed from its depositional environment, is extremely difficult to identify. The vessels and tracheids are often clogged with soil, debris which obscures identification. Thus, it is imperative to obtain clean, clear sections for identification. Thin-sectioning is often thought to be of particular value but this is usually not the case. Embedding the specimen is time- consuming and, often, the results are less than desired due to the nature of the substance (carbon). Additionally, during sectioning, the likelihood of crushing the vessel and tracheid walls is increased, thereby rendering identification more difficult, if not impossible. To avoid the problem, I have used a modification of Leney and Casteel's (1975) method in which a clean exposed transverse surface is produced with minimal damage to cellular structure. The major drawback to the utilization of this method is that the break is often not exactly even, which presents difficulties in photomicrography, especially at higher magnifications. The ease and rapidity of specimen preparation, however, offers compensation for the difficulties. Identification of charcoal or wood is based on comparisons of morphological similarities of structural elements within the by xylem. In most cases, a transverse (cross-sectional) view is all that is necessary for identification. In specific cases, however, a radial or tangential section may be required to separate genera of the same family (e.g., Salix and Populus) (Panshin and de Zeeuw 1980). While it is often possible to identify the genus level, species identifications are tenuous, if not impossible, especially using light microscopy. Some groups interbreed and hybridize so readily that it is only with extreme caution that identifications below the genus level should be attempted. The variation between species is usually so slight that these differences can more readily be explained by edaphic and climatic factors than by actual species differences. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Results of the charcoal identifications are presented in Table F- 1. For ease of comparison these samples have been arranged by their stratigraphic position within soil zones and secondarily by units. Salix remains were recovered only once, from a sample located in the plow zone. Given the proximity of Bird Point Island to a watercourse (Richland Creek), the presence of this taxon is quite understandable. Salix was probably located within the riparian vegetational community close to the water source. The distribution of Ulmus charcoal is extremely interesting. Ulmus charcoal was identified only from samples recovered in Zones 1. Zone 1 material was radiocarbon dated between A.D. 1280 + 110 and A.D. 1510+ 60 with a mean date of A.D. 1380. On the basis of the limited charcoal samples which have been analyzed and the distribution of Ulmus remains, I suspect that somewhat more mesic conditions were present, at least locally, Starting some time within the last 600 years. Ulmus presently grows within the area (Fowells 1965) and in the more southerly 295

Its presence so near to a watercourse is not Volume II, Appendix F surprising, but rather expected. However, its absence from the lower zones may indicate its local absence earlier than A.D. 1380 Thus, its absence from these earlier zones may suggest somewhat more arid conditions prior to A.D. 1380. This interpretation is very tentative for the moment. Comparisons with regional and local pollen sequences and additional charcoal analyses are required to solidify this interpretation. Comparisons with palynological records is sometimes tenuous because of the differences between data bases. However, particular attention should be paid to the upper segments of pollen columns which might indicate mesic conditions to test this initial interpretation. The types of charcoal recovered from Zones 2 and 3 are all types which can be found locally at the present. For the most part these are Quercus (oak) and Carya (hickory), and in lesser amounts Juniperus (juniper). As explained elsewhere, identification of Quercus charcoal as well as that of the other taxa beyond the generic level is extremely tenuous. The size of the sample and the fragmentary nature of many of these specimens preclude the possibility of finer division. CONCLUSIONS Analysis of 26 charcoal specimens from Bird Point Island revealed charcoal of taxa currently found growing in the immediate area. There are some preliminary indications of a shift _ to more mesic conditions occurring sometime after A.D. 1380 These preliminary indications are only tentative and must await subsequent additional data for their substantiation.
